HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
Don't Go South, Young Man

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

 BODY:
IN THE TV SERIES "MURDER, SHE Wrote," the character played by Angela Lansbury was accosted by a police lieutenant about a suspect she was helping: "When I sent some guys over to your place to pick him up," the cop complained, "he'd gone south."
In the opposite direction, Adam Sandler wrote in Variety that the recent video release of "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" had sold more than 17 million copies and "generated north of $300 million in retail sales." 
 Now both ways: when The Washington Post's media shoofly, Howard Kurtz, hoped that ratings of the O. J. Simpson trial would "go south," Dan Rather on "48 Hours" on CBS responded, "The ratings were going north, not south."
Rather knows how to handle a compass: North is up, South is down. (I capitalize the directions, though not southern or southward.) Obviously, up is good news, down is bad. But this metaphor, now omnidirectional on television, has deeper roots than it seems. According to Fred Cassidy, editor of the Dictionary of American Regional English (DARE): "Evidently a part of American Indian (Sioux) belief included go south = to die. The sense of deterioration is not far off."
The inspiring Professor Cassidy, now 87 and still only on the letter "O" -- he and his University of Wisconsin team are working as fast as they can -- directed me to Mitford M. Mathews's Dictionary of Americanisms. In that 1951 lexicon, a 1746 citation, from David Brainerd's journal, about an aged Delaware Indian's opinion that the soul departing the body "would go southward" was elucidated in a Harper's Magazine article in 1894: "The Dakota tribes believe that the soul, driven out of the body, journeys off to the south, and 'to go south' is, among the Sioux, the favorite euphemism for death."
A sexual sense was added by whites who followed the American aboriginals. In the 1955 Broadway musical "Silk Stockings," based on the movie "Ninotchka," Cole Porter wrote, "I'd love to make a tour of you"; stops on this lyrical tour included "The eyes, the arms, the mouth of you/ The East, West, North and the South of you." On the surface, an innocent lyric, and never banned from the airwaves; still, when Don Ameche sang the word South, the sexual innuendo about the nether parts of the body was unmistakable.
Financial reporters took up the compass metaphor to enliven their language about the direction of the stock market. "The markets headed south today" is an all-too-frequent usage in finance. Lou Dobbs of the CNN program "Moneyline" tells me, "While I've heard many analysts and market gurus talk about stocks going south, I've never heard anyone say a market is going north."
At least the directional metaphor of North (up, good news) and South (down, bad news) is clear. For example, when there is good statistical news on the jobless or inflation fronts, and those figures drop, you do not hear "Unemployment figures and inflation rates are headed south." Thus, the metaphoric meaning of "headed South" is not so much "downward" as "bad news."
That clarity cannot be claimed by uphill and downhill. "Your column and the crossword puzzle get my week off to a civilized start," Patricia Patricelli of Boston writes. "Usually it's all downhill from there. (Or is it uphill? I've never really understood that expression. Going downhill is easier, but it sounds negative to me, i.e., sinking, down in the depths.)"
It's all downhill from here. Does that mean "From now on, it's easy -- no more struggling uphill" or does it mean "This is as good as it gets, and now we're headed for the pits"?
"I always thought that if someone were going downhill, that signified deterioration," Steve Conn of New York writes, "whereas uphill meant getting better. Tell me: should we prefer to go uphill or downhill?"
Allan Metcalf of the American Dialect Society notes that "Downhill has been going figuratively downhill since the O.E.D.'s first record of its use, in 1591: 'Th' Icie down-Hils of this slippery Life.' Whether we weep or rejoice in any particular instance depends on whither the icy downhills lead -- to a decline, or to an Olympic skiing record."
John Algeo, the neologist of American Speech, points to the two-way working of the metaphor: "If one thinks that the top of the hill is the place to be, then going downhill is declining. But if one thinks about effort, then an uphill struggle is bad, and coasting downhill is good. The difference is between metaphorical place ('up' good, 'down' bad) and metaphorical effort to move on an inclined plane ('uphill' hard, 'downhill' easy)."
Though the first use of downhill, about the slippery life, was pejorative, a more famous use -- by Daniel Defoe in his 1719 "Robinson Crusoe" -- was upbeat: "a very short cut, and all down-hill," which was quicker and easier for the castaway and his man Friday than the long way uphill. "Perhaps a human tendency to look on the dark side favors the pejorative sense," Professor Algeo says. "Metaphorically, both work."
But they work at semantic cross-purposes. The hills are alive with the sound of confusion. My advice: forget the hill metaphor and try something nautical: smooth sailing and rough sailing, or if you go for the icy slopes, easy sledding or hard sledding. Ban the hills; if you want bad news, go South.
 
I Wrote It Myself
President Clinton has taken to running down his speech writers in public, boasting about rejecting prepared remarks and doing the writing himself; this is to show that what he says comes from the Real Him. I suspect that these lines are written by speech writers falling on their pens, mightier than their swords.
In Mr. Clinton's pre-Christmas "Middle Class Bill of Rights" speech (bottomed on Nixon's "Economic Bill of Rights" statement, which we stole from F.D.R.), I was pleased to hear his pickup of the "government that is leaner, not meaner" phrase; was ambivalent about his "raise their children" (purists differentiate between raising cattle and rearing children, and in formal speech that distinction should be made, but Mr. Clinton, even when wearing a dark suit in the Oval Office, prefers the folksy), but was stunned, stunned (one cut above "shocked, shocked") by "Some people do take advantage of the rest of us by . . . flaunting our immigration laws."
To flaunt means "to show off, to parade ostentatiously"; the verb the President meant was flout, "to disregard contemptuously, to mock or scoff at." Even kids raised with the laid-back Merriam-Webster's Dictionary of English Usage are told that mistaking flout for flaunt is "a genuine error" and, by confusing these verbs, "you do run the risk of giving some of your listeners the mistaken impression that they are smarter than you are."

HEADLINE: DANCE;
Dancing Precariously On the Bottom Line

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON DEPOT, Conn.

 BODY:
THE OFFICE IS A CLUTTER OF battered furniture, overflowing file cabinets and obsolete business machines. Highly skilled employees, paid as little as $ 485 a week, and only for the weeks they work, labor under the constant threat of layoffs. Management, lacking a dependable flow of cash or assets to back regular bank loans, must rely on credit-card debt to cover month-to-month obligations.
From the description, this could be any of thousands of small businesses that lack the capital necessary to survive for the long term. In fact, it is Pilobolus Dance Theater, one of America's most popular modern-dance troupes, and its struggles are hardly atypical. The American Ballet Theater came back from a near-death experience in 1993 after gaining concessions from creditors and unions. The Nikolais and Murray Louis Dance Company has downsized drastically just to stay afloat. The Joffrey Ballet, battered by financial problems, announced last month that it would cancel part of its 1995 season. 
 Indeed, as the arts head into the new year in New York and other cities where cultural life is a staple, help, apparently, is not on the way. Republicans are proposing deep tax and budget cuts on both the state and Federal levels; if enacted, the cuts will threaten the viability of all performing-arts groups that depend on government subsidies. While Congressional Republicans haven't yet formally put it on their agenda, financing for the National Endowment for the Arts will almost certainly be challenged.
Adding to established dance companies' woes, what little public and philanthropic money there is supports artistic innovation and audience outreach rather than day-to-day overhead. The Lila Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund, America's largest private donor to the performing arts, did come through for Pilobolus with $ 100,000 a year for three years beginning in 1993, but with restrictions. Rory MacPherson, the coordinator of dance projects for the fund, confirms that the money is intended to bring dance to "unique and underserved audiences."
Everyone, it seems, wants to subsidize what is different, exciting and socially uplifting, but "nobody wants to pay the light bills," says Barbara Hauptman, the executive director of the Alvin Ailey company, yet another celebrated troupe feeling the financial pinch. Eventually, hard times are bound to take their toll on creativity, slowing the introduction of new work and inhibiting experimentation with sets, music and lighting.
Like every dance company, Pilobolus has been buffeted by cycles of feast and famine. A look at its history -- and financial accounts -- offers perspective on the predicament of the performing arts in general and dance in particular. It also serves as a reminder that culture that depends on the kindness of strangers lives at the mercy of economic and political fashions that are hard to predict, let alone influence.
Pilobolus, which is named for a light-seeking mushroom, was born on a lark in 1971, the product of an enthusiastic handful of athletes who took the same dance class in college. "We were just jocks from Dartmouth," recalls Michael Tracy, who joined shortly after the company was founded and is now one of its four artistic directors.
The communal spirit endured long after the troupe became a familiar presence on the dance scene. The dancers choreographed their own witty, free-spirited, breathtakingly gymnastic programs -- "Day Two," "Land's Edge," "Untitled," "Monkshood's Farewell" among them -- and managed their own tours. With two of its artistic directors already living in the area, Pilobolus settled in the tiny northwestern Connecticut town of Washington Depot.
Those with the company from the beginning remember the 1970's as a golden age, when it simply wasn't necessary to pay attention to the humdrum of finances. "We'd sit here, the phone would ring, and we'd be hired," recalls Jonathan Wolken, another artistic director.
In hindsight, it is clear why. Pilobolus neither solicited nor received much direct assistance from private foundations or government. But the troupe depended indirectly on nonprofit organizations -- notably universities and dance festivals -- financed by government and private gifts to sponsor their performances around the country. In fact, most professional dance companies must travel widely to reach an audience large enough to sustain a full-year schedule. And during the 1970's, money to subsidize "presenters" was growing rapidly: grants for dance from the National Endowment for the Arts rose from about $ 5 million in 1975 to nearly $ 9 million in 1980, underwriting a nationwide boom that allowed even marginal companies to flourish.
The good times continued well into the 1980's. Kimber Craine, a spokesman for the National Assembly of State Arts Agencies, a group that coordinates public financing for the arts, points out that while National Endowment money earmarked for dance changed little, state governments took up the slack. Total state government support for dance increased from roughly $ 2 million in 1983 to a whopping $ 18 million in 1990. Corporations and foundations also wrote bigger checks, raising private donations for dance from about $ 9 million in 1983 to $ 19 million in 1989.
But these figures masked a trend that soon undermined the financial viability of individual dance companies. Increased Federal, state and philanthropic financing encouraged regional troupes like the Cleveland Ballet and the Ballet Hispanico to make the leap from local seasons to national touring with elaborate productions that absorbed enormous amounts of cash. This institutionalized support, said Mr. Craine, "created an entire cultural infrastructure," one that needed large sums to sustain and that had smaller troupes competing for subsidies with older, established national companies like the New York City Ballet.
The recession and resultant economic distress of the 90's have hit dance with a vengeance. National Endowment grants are down by roughly $ 2 million a year since the mid-80's. And in 1993, the last year for which data is available, state grants to dance were cut to $ 12 million from the 1990 peak of $ 18 million.
Pilobolus felt the consequences of decreasing financial support later than most companies, at least in part because its playful, acrobatic style is accessible to untutored audiences; hence, when sponsors were forced to cut back their dance bookings, they were apt to retain a company that would sell out in larger auditoriums. In part, too, notes Susan Mandler, Pilobolus's business manager, the troupe could still count on a long and lucrative season in Europe.
But this is no longer the case. European tours, typically cash cows for high-profile American companies, have ceased to be a reliable source of income: Europe, too, has been hit by recession and tight government budgets. Last year, for the first time since the 1970's, Pilobolus was unable to put together a European tour. "We didn't know what hit us," said Robby Barnett, a Pilobolus artistic director.
The company's response to their financial problems was to slash salaries and ask the artistic directors to contribute outside earnings to the communal kitty. Pilobolus now markets dance-education workshops through the Pilobolus Institute, trying to make profitable use of its name and skills when the company is not performing or rehearsing.
UT TEACHING AND miscellaneous earned income (largely from T-shirt sales) accounted for just $ 55,000 last year, 6 percent of the troupe's budget. And like other dance companies, Pilobolus is now caught between the rock of high costs and the hard place of increasing competition for donations, government money and income from touring.
The business distinction between overhead and operating costs, best explained in context, offers a concise way to analyze the financial trap in which most established dance companies find themselves in the increasingly competitive world of touring.
In November, for example, Pilobolus's six dancers, along with two technicians, made a five-day trip from Connecticut to present four shows at the Mountain View Center for the Performing Arts near San Francisco. Trip expenses, including salaries, ran to $ 16,000. Pilobolus was assured a payment of $ 21,000. But since overhead -- rent, secretarial services, medical insurance and artistic directors' salaries -- runs to roughly $ 9,000 a week, the company ended the week $ 4,000 in the red.
Still, the troupe is in a better position than many other companies, since it will inevitably make money on one annual enterprise that is risky even for some of the most established companies: a season in New York City.
New York remains an imperative for every company with aspirations to world-class or even national status. And Pilobolus's annual summer stop is sponsored each year by the nonprofit Joyce Theater, for many years a showcase for modern dance. But larger companies, like the Alvin Ailey, don't fit on the Joyce's relatively modest stage. Nor, for that matter, could they come close to covering costs in the Joyce's 500-seat auditorium.
Hence a larger dance company is effectively obliged to perform at City Center, a space that is staffed by New York's generously compensated craft unions and that requires dance troupes to bear the entire financial risk of an engagement. "If I can cover my costs, it's remarkable," laments the Alvin Ailey company's executive director, Ms. Hauptman.
 If donors and presenters can't or won't pay the full cost of dance, is it possible for already strapped dance companies to reduce costs? It seems unlikely.
Professional dancers are hardly in a position to tighten their belts. As a practical matter, the best that most can hope for is enough work to be eligible for unemployment benefits. The union contracts that cover the dancers with companies like the New York City Ballet, the Merce Cunningham Dance Company and the San Francisco Ballet provide only marginally better pay and benefits.
"I live very frugally," said Peter Francyk, who is dancing his first season with Pilobolus and couldn't possibly moonlight after days of demanding practice. "It's a labor of love," he allows. "Or craziness."
INANCIALLY, choreographers may be a little better off as a group, but they hardly constitute a fat target for bean counters. The National Endowment's most recent survey, in 1989, of 405 choreographers showed a median annual income of $ 18,500 -- most of it from moonlighting in unrelated fields. Pilobolus pays each of its now-middle-aged artistic directors $ 40,000 a year. But along with choreographing new productions they are also obliged to direct rehearsals, teach classes and beat the bushes for donors.
With financial public or private salvation so remote a prospect in this era of reduced spending, it seems almost inevitable that many companies will be forced to scale back, or even go out of business. The fear has been voiced before, of course, but this time professional dance may really bean endangered art form.
Ambitious and marvelously skilled dancers still pour out of schools despite Money magazine's ranking of their job prospects just above butchers, sanitation workers and taxi drivers. When Pilobolus held auditions for two positions last year, hundreds applied. "Almost everyone who showed up could have done the job," reported Alison Chase, another of Pilobolus's artistic directors.
But the supply of dancers may not remain endless when word finally gets out that they can no longer expect to lead even minimally secure lives working at their craft. "You can't starve as fashionably in New York as you once could," said Sali Ann Kriegsman, director of dance for the National Endowment.
Although much of the public and private subsidy for dance companies is for new work, dance simply isn't possible unless the rent and insurance bills are paid. Further, the Pilobolus artistic director Mr. Wolken worries that the anemic sums remaining for costumes, sets and rehearsal time will undermine the quality of the company's new work. Live musical accompaniment to dance has already become as rare as sympathy from Jesse Helms: Ms. Hauptman notes that the Ailey employs an orchestra for just one performance in their New York season.
Bonnie Brooks, the director of Dance/ USA, a Washington association that represents most dance troupes, expresses a deeper worry. Hard times will beget harder times, she frets, as dance loses status in a society inclined to equate value with material results. "Dance is like a suspension bridge," Ms. Brooks suggests, one now "held together with spider webs."

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Despite Safety Concerns, Tourism to Peru Surges

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: CUZCO, Peru

 BODY:
UNFAZED by reports of terrorism, cholera and street crime, tourists from Atlanta to Australia are pouring into Peru at an unprecedented rate, drawn mainly by the lost Inca city of Machu Picchu, and officials expect the final figures to show that 1994 was a record year for tourism in Peru.
Based on preliminary figures, Peru's National Tourism Board estimates that the number of foreign tourists passing through Peru in 1994 exceeded 400,000, compared with 275,000 in 1993. 
 If the 1994 estimate holds true, the number of foreign travelers visiting Peru will surpass its height of 360,000 in 1988, just before an escalation of Shining Path terrorism, hyperinflation and an outbreak of cholera sent tourism into a steep decline.
The sharp rise is attributed to a dramatic turnaround in Peru's economic and political situation under President Alberto J. Fujimori: Cholera is no longer a problem, except in some remote areas; the economy has stabilized, and terrorism is waning with the capture of Shining Path's top leaders.
But the United States State Department continues to warn Americans of the dangers of travel in Peru. A July advisory said that "with the exception of certain tourist areas, terrorist violence, which has diminished over the past year, continues to occur in many parts of the country."
While the State Department's warning said that foreign visitors have not been specifically targeted and tourist areas have generally been free of terrorist activity, United States Embassy officials in Lima said recent acts of violence by the Shining Path guerrillas in Lima and the Andes prompted the agency to warn Americans of the potential danger.
Still, the warning did not keep Chris Hedley, a Los Angeles radiologist, and Felicia Ferrari, a businesswoman, from seeing Machu Picchu, along with thousands of others who arrived early on a December morning to view the ruins, which are considered one of the most important and mysterious archeological monuments in South America.
"It's a place that we've always wanted to come and see, but we had some hesitation because of the reports of terrorism," Mr. Hedley said. "Now that we are here, I'm sorry we didn't come sooner."
Cuzco, which was the center of the Inca Empire, is Peru's top tourist destination, with 32 percent of Peru's visitors taking the one hour flight from Lima to here, en route to Machu Picchu, which is four hours away by train. The ruins suggest the remote stone city of 700 years ago, and visitors can still see the terraced plots where the Incas grew as many as 500 different crops a year.
Frank O'Connell, a 61-year-old retired banker from Perth, Australia, was visiting a friend in Rio when he decided to take the 22-hour trip by plane, train and bus to Machu Picchu. "When I arrived I wondered if I had done the right thing in coming because of the terrorism and all," Mr. O'Connell said. "But after seeing those spectacular ruins, I'm convinced this was the highlight of my trip to South America."
The Peruvian tourism agency said that most visitors to Peru were from North America, Europe, Australia, New Zealand and other South American countries and that the average age of tourists was 65.
Many tourists tour Peru alone and most with little trouble, but street crime is very common in Lima, Cuzco, Ayacucho, Arequipa, Trujillo and other destinations. Tour guides here advise travelers not to carry watches, passports, credit cards or other items of value, as pickpocketing is rampant.
With the number of tourists expected to rise to 500,000 in 1995, Peru is quickly running out of hotel space to accommodate them. Although several deluxe hotels are under construction in Lima and a Government-owned lodging chain is being privatized, tourism officials recommend that visitors book far in advance.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
Of Renaissance Visions And American Dreams

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
"ITALIAN RENAISSANCE Architecture," at the National Gallery in Washington, is a pale shadow of the sumptuous exhibition mounted last summer at the Palazzo Grassi in Venice. Still, even this severely truncated version is worth a visit, especially when seen in conjunction with "World War II and the American Dream," the National Building Museum's outstanding survey of military construction.
Though the shows explore vastly different periods, styles and building types, they tell similar stories. Both are studies in architectural subterfuge. They show how buildings have helped to disguise as well as drive major shifts in cultural history. 
 Beware architects bearing models: that's the unstated moral of the Renaissance show (through March 19). On the cover of the catalogue, a painting depicts Michelangelo presenting a scale model of St. Peter's to Pope Paul IV. The presentation is a tribute to God, and to the supreme power of the church. But it is also an act through which the architect enlarges his own cultural power.
While scarcely social equals, the artist and the Pope are in the same picture. Here, in the words of Arnold Hauser, a sociologist of art, we see "the ascent of the artist from the level of the petit bourgeois artisan to that of the free intellectual worker." In time, that worker will exercise ever greater cultural influence. If this period is called the Renaissance, that is partly because history has defined it as a time of intellectual flowering, and partly because that flowering affected the study of history itself.
As in Venice, the stars of the show are the wooden models that enabled architects and their patrons to study designs in three dimensions, though in Washington these have been pared down to 14 models of three buildings: the cathedrals of Florence and Pavia and the basilica of St. Peter's in Rome.
Many of the models are the size of armoires, but two, of St. Peter's and the Cathedral of Pavia, are virtually buildings in their own right. The largest of these, representing an unexecuted design for St. Peter's by Antonio da Sengallo the Younger, is 15 feet tall, weighs six tons, took seven years to build and is perhaps best understood as a Renaissance version of the Trojan horse. From it will emerge -- metaphorically, at least -- the arts, the humanities and the freedom of thought that will ultimately displace ecclesiastical authority in cultural affairs.
At the Palazzo Grassi, they unpacked the whole horse. That exhibition displayed the entire arsenal of tools with which Italian architects attained cultural prominence. There were rooms devoted to architectural theory, the study of antiquity, the development of such techniques as drawing, model making and construction, the figure of the architect, and the ideal city. The models were firmly planted in the history of ideas.
In Washington, where the show was organized by Henry A. Millon, of the National Gallery, this context is reduced to a skeleton crew of about 50 drawings. Handsomely installed in and around the National Gallery's West Garden Court, the selection provides enough detail to convey the reverence with which architects and architecture came to be held in the 15th and 16th centuries.
Brunelleschi's design for the dome in Florence, for instance, aroused as much popular passion as a modern space program, which, in a sense, it was. But one must consult the catalogue (edited by Mr. Millon and Vittorio Magnano Lampugnani, who was co-curator in Venice) to realize that something more than architecture was at stake. Even as Renaissance architects looked back to the ancient world for inspiration, what they were actually modeling was modernity itself.
Modernity of a more familiar stripe is on view at the National Building Museum show, which runs through this year. Here are kitchen appliances, molded plywood Eames chairs, mobile homes, Levittown and, toward the end of the show, a panorama of postwar affluence that unfolds like the vista of a lost Golden Age. But those who recall the 1950's as a time of national innocence may find this show unnerving.
The world of Ozzie and Harriet was prosperous but hardly innocent. The house, the garden, the car and all those labor-saving appliances were wrapped like camouflage around an architecture of war. President Dwight D. Eisenhower warned his contemporaries about the military-industrial complex. This show uncovers the workings of a military-"Joy of Cooking" complex. It's about how, in becoming a military power, the United States lifted itself out of the Depression and propelled itself down the road toward postwar plenty.
Organized by Donald Albrecht, an architect and independent curator, and presented in a superb installation designed by the architect and critic Michael Sorkin and J. Abbott Miller, a graphic designer, the show pulls into coherent shape a wide range of artifacts: photo murals of bomb factories, prototypes for new consumer products, clips from wartime propaganda films, Hollywood pinups, a full-scale Quonset hut and other materials that illustrate the rise of a superpower.
In 1938, the United States ranked only 20th among the world's military powers. By 1944, it was the world's leading producer of armaments. In 1940, United States Army training camps housed 300,000 soldiers. Two years later, the camps could accommodate more than four million.
Fueling this explosion was a $23 billion construction program. That quantitive explosion produced a qualitative shift. While the techniques of mass production were not new to industry, they were now applied for the first time to the built environment. New materials, new methods of construction, were deployed in mass-producing military architecture: training camps, factory buildings, blimp hangars, civilian housing and shopping centers. Entire secret cities were created for developing atomic weapons, while full-scale "camouflage" cities were built on the roofs of arms factories.
After the war, augmented by new techniques of mass marketing, this production machine was retooled to manufacture the American Dream. Instead of molding acrylics into airplane nose cones, manufacturers turned out transparent shower enclosures. Instead of leg splints, plywood side chairs. Instead of barracks, Levittowns. Suburbia, the show reveals, was a continuation of war by precisely the same means: mass production, territorial expansion and, above all, relentless propaganda, as the advertising industry geared up to inflame consumer desires. "After total war, total living," as one ad proclaimed.
Mr. Albrecht does not cast this story in a sinister light. If anything, the show is celebratory. It's about what a society can accomplish when its individual members are roused to collective action. Yet, as the show hints, the accomplishments of wartime production resulted in costs as well as benefits, and both continued long past D-Day. Regimentation of the work force was great for the war effort, but in peacetime it led to the gray-flannel-suit conformity for which the 50's were famous.
More to the point, did peace ever come? Though World War II ended, the Korean War and the cold war insured that the United States was never, in fact, demilitarized. And the consequences of this indefinite postponement continue to this day. Not only in the country's continued economic dependence on arms production, but in the jarring, split-level reality -- missiles below, barbecues above -- that superpowerdom brought in its wake.
IN A SENSE, BOTH SHOWS RAISE the same question: what happens when the authority of an institution is eroded by the culture it helps to create? The Renaissance show, with its focus on the emergence of the independent mind, looks forward to the Reformation and beyond that, to the Baroque period when the church campaigns to entice straying faithful back into the fold. The World War II show looks forward to the disaffection with the military that took hold of those who grew up amidst postwar plenty.
As Americans discovered in the convulsive 1960's, that generation balked at paying the cost of maintaining the way of life that wartime production had made possible. As we are learning from reactionary quarters today, the 1950's retain their appeal for those who mistake wartime regimentation for the traditional order of things.

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

SOUNDS OF THE PAST
Flute, oboe and horn concertos by Mozart, and Haydn's Symphony No. 49 will be heard as they were in the 1700's, when the Orchestra of the Old Fairfield Academy performs on Saturday at the Westport Arts Center. Diana Erdmann, soprano, will be the soloist in an aria from Haydn's opera "Il Ritornodi Tobais." 
 The orchestra, founded by Thomas Crawford in 1986 as the historical affiliate of the Fairfield Orchestra, is made up of expert period musicians playing authentic instruments. It has appeared at Lincoln Center, and it recorded Mozart's piano concertos on the Musicmasters label.
This concert is a preview of a future recording. Tickets are $25 and may be reserved by calling 831-6020. The arts center is at 17 Morningside Drive South.
 
GRASS-ROOTS PLANNING
 The Regional Plan Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will hold a forum on Friday in Hamden to gather opinions in preparation for publishing its Third Regional Plan in 1995.
The association, which invites business and civic leaders, planners and residents to share in formulating policies on the economy, transportation, land use and the environment, celebrated its 65th year in 1994.
The forum is open to the public free of charge from 9 A.M. to 1 P.M. in the Buckman Theater of Quinnipiac College. Those interested in attending should register by calling (212) 980-8530, ext. 208.
Crucial to Connecticut in the new plan will be recommendations for providing businesses and workers with more efficient transportation, a better regulatory climate and a regional economy that will eliminate border warfare among the three states.
On the environmental agenda is the need for providing patterns of growth that protect the character of the Litchfield Hills, Long Island Sound and the northeastern corner of the state.
Other subjects for review are better education for the work force, improved community planning and the preservation of open space through better zoning, and the reclamation of abandoned industrial buildings for development.
 
COMMENTARY IN DANCE
Stuart Pimsler started out to be a lawyer. He graduated from Catholic University Law School in Washington, D.C., passed his bar exam and worked as an investigator of charges of sex and race discrimination.
While pondering the snail's pace of social change, he wandered into a dance class and decided that he could make a greater and quicker impact as a choreographer than as a lawyer. After completing a master's degree in dance at Connecticut College, he formed the Stuart Pimsler Dance and Theater Company in 1978. The ensemble, which defies all traditional and modern dance mores by speaking lines of dialogue and employing theatrical props, will perform on Saturday at 8 P.M. in the theater of the Norwalk Community- Technical College, 188 Richards Avenue.
Over the years, Pimsler and his troupe have been invited to perform his innovative and often comical commentaries on everyday life at, among other places, the Kennedy Center in Washington, the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C., and the Walker Arts Center in Minneapolis. Tickets, at $14, may be charged to major credit cards by calling the box office, 857-7271.
 
DRAMA IN THE DEPTHS
Imax, short for image maximum, is the 8-story-wide and 6-story-high movie screen at the Norwalk Maritime Center theater, where documentaries on outer space, animals, and the sunken Titanic have been presented.
A new film, "Flight of the Aquanaut," opens on Friday and runs through June 15. While it is based on an event that occurred 15 years ago, the film departs from the documentary form to tell a fictionalized version of the original story.
Paul Mockler, a diver and cinematographer, provided the scenario by recalling his experience off the coast of Newfoundland, when a strong current sucked his small submarine into the wreckage of a cargo ship deep underwater. He and a colleague barely got out alive.
In the film, which has almost no dialogue, a diver on an underwater environmental mission admires the beauty and wonder of marine life until he encounters a sunken ship, just as Mr. Mockler did. But this time, the diver enters the hull on his own volition, attempting to discover the origin of toxic substances seeping out of a number of rusting drums lying near the wreck.
Working almost entirely under water at Grand Bahama Island, the crew operated at depths of up to 120 feet, and the aquanaut, wearing a new device called a Newtsuit, was able to dive to nearly 1,000 feet. At that depth, four crews had to be deployed in sequence to set up gear, film and recover equipment to complete a single shot.
Screenings are at noon on weekdays and at noon and 2 P.M. on weekends. Tickets are $6 for adults, $4.50 for children 2 to 12 and adults 62 and older. More information is available by calling 852-0700.
 
GUILD NEWCOMERS
Thirteen new members were elected to the Silvermine Guild of Artists in New Canaan in 1994, based on works submitted to a jury of guild artists. An exhibition of their work may be seen through Feb. 5 in the center's galleries, 1037 Silvermine Road, and a reception is scheduled for 2 to 4 this afternoon.
The new members are Hillary Burnett of New Canaan; Fred George and Adam Tinkoff of Stamford; Ann Louria, Heidi Roos and Joan Wheeler of Norwalk; Patra Holter of Wilton; Jackie Nach of Weston; Janet Slom of Westport; Alistair Dunn and Maureen Mullarkey of Chappaqua, N.Y.; Gedas Paskauskas of Dorchester, Mass., and Lise Poirier of Patterson, N.Y.
Categories in which they work include painting, drawing, sculpture, printmaking, photography, jewelry and book design. The number for more information is 966-5618.
 
PRISCILLA'S PROGRESS
"Priscilla, Queen of the Desert," starring Terence Stamp as one of three drag performers touring the Australian outback in a bus, will be shown at the SoNo Cinema, 15 Washington Street in Norwalk, this evening at 7:30. Admission is $10, with a $2 discount for those attending the Triangle Community Center Open House today from 2 to 6 P.M. at 25 Van Zandt Street.
The two events mark the fourth anniversary of the center, a service organization for Fairfield County's gay and lesbian community and their families. Admission to the open house, with light refreshments, is free. Information is available by calling 853-0600.
 
THIS OLD HOUSE
Wheeler House, the 1795 home of the Westport Historical Society, is celebrating its 200th anniversary with an exhibition documenting the house's own history.
It opens today from 2:30 to 4 P.M., and remains through March 25 at 25 Avery Place. Visiting hours after today are Tuesday through Saturday from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M., and admission is free.
The house has been remodeled in a mid-19th-century Victorian Italianate style, containing a museum shop in addition to the furnished rooms. Behind it is the Bradley-Wheeler Barn, the only octagonal cobblestone barn in the state.
In conjunction with the anniversary a number of special events are scheduled, beginning with a talk on Westport's commercial history next Sunday at 2 P.M. by Harry Audley, vice president of Antique Tools and Trades in Connecticut. The information number is 222-1424. ELEANOR CHARLES

ANOTHER 'FANTASTICKS'
In May 1960 Jerry Orbach opened in "The Fantasticks" in a little theater far off Broadway on Sullivan Street in Greenwich Village. Since then Mr. Orbach has gone on to fame and fortune on Broadway, in movies and television, and the musical by Tom Jones and Harvey Schmidt has been true to its name, generating 472 productions in 67 countries and just about every one of the 50 United States. 
 It will be performed by the four-year-old Herbert Mark Newman Theater of Pleasantville on Fridays and Saturdays through Jan. 21 at 8 P.M. and next Sunday at 4 P.M., not in Pleasantville, but at the Schoolhouse in Croton Falls. Tickets at $12, $14 and $15 may be reserved by calling 277-8477.
Maria Mills, the Newman Theater's director, reported: "We have four women and four men, instead of the seven men and one woman in the original. There is more choreography, the costumes and sets are our own designs, but the music and the basic show remain the same." A percussionist, violinist, pianist and harpist accompany the cast.
 
ALL MAQUETTES
An exhibition of maquettes by 22 sculptors has just opened at Nardin Galleries in Somers and will remain through Feb. 5. Serving as working models for larger, finished pieces, maquettes are sometimes shown with the final work, but in this show they are the final work. Ranging in height from 12 to 30 inches, they are priced from $300 to $22,000 (for a steel construction by Alexander Rutsch).
Drawings for the maquettes and individual drawings are also in the exhibit. In addition to Mr. Rutsch, some of the other artists represented are Robert Blood, Jacques Lipschitz, Dorothy Dehner, Adolph Gottlieb and Ernest Trova.
The gallery, on Route 202, is open Tuesdays through Sundays from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. and by appointment. Call 276-8485 for more information.
 
PAPERBACK SALE
Thousands of used paperback books will go on sale in the lobby of the New Rochelle Public Library on Friday and Saturday from 9 A.M. to 3 P.M. Popular fiction, records and scholarly works will be available at 10 cents to 25 cents.
A smaller collection of used books in other categories will be sold in the Friends' Book Room on Saturday from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Proceeds will help underwrite the library's concerts, storytelling programs, films, lectures and children's workshops.
Book discussion groups for adults and children will begin this month, with adults meeting on Thursdays from 7 to 9 P.M., starting this week. The group will select its own books. Call 576-1138 or 834-8739 for more information on the discussion groups.
Children's sessions are for grades 4 through 6. A preliminary meeting will be held on Wednesday from 4 to 5 P.M. to plan meeting times and select books. The number for more information is 632-7878.
 
PICTURE EXHIBITION
Fine photography by members of the Ground Glass Inc., celebrating its 20th anniversary, may be seen through Jan. 21 at the Rye Arts Center, 51 Milton Road.
Juried by Cornelia Butler, curator of contemporary art at the Neuberger Museum of Purchase College, the exhibit contains works by 24 art photographers, photojournalists, academics and amateurs. One of the exhibiting photographers is Renata Rainer, who founded the Ground Glass in 1975 as a forum for ideas and a way to share technical information through lectures, workshops and exhibitions.
Hours are Mondays through Fridays from 9:30 A.M. to 12:30 and 1:30 to 5 P.M. and Saturdays from 1 to 5 P.M. Call 967-0700 for more information.
 
FOOD FOR THE ARTS
The Westchester Arts Council has scheduled a benefit for the many cultural programs it provides throughout the county at the Tappan Hill mansion, 81 Highland Avenue in Tarrytown, on Friday at 7 P.M. For $125 a person, patrons will dine on Abigail Kirsch's food and taste wines of France, Italy, Oregon, California and Australia.
Pinot Gris from France and Oregon will accompany hors d'oeuvres of mussels, foie gras, tomato bruschetta and rice cakes. An appetizer of smoked salmon pizza will be washed down with a rose from France and a California white wine, followed by a choice of two salads.
Lamb osso bucco with rice will be served as the main course with California and Australian wines, and the wines of Italy will top off the desserts of apple dumplings and cookies. Call 428-4220 for reservations or more information.
 
REAL ESTATE LUNCH
Real estate trends in the region will be discussed at a public lunch on Thursday at 11:30 A.M. at the Rye Town Hilton, sponsored by the Building Owners and Managers Association of Westchester and the Fairfield-Westchester chapter of the International Association of Corporate Real Estate Executives. Reservations are $40 and may be obtained by calling 328-9703.
Two speakers will address the question "You've Stayed Alive Till '95 -- Now What?" They are Thomas J. Spitznas, president of the economic consulting firm T. J. Spitznas and Associates, specializing in forecasting regional trends in industry and the economy, and Greg David, editor of Crain's New York Business for 10 years.
Mr. Spitznas is a director of the Westchester Private Industry Council and a member of the Westchester County Association. Mr. David, the winner of the John Hancock Award for excellence in financial journalism, appears each week on Public Radio International's "Marketplace Monitor."
 
MAKING LOVE LAST
"Couples and Successful Relationships -- How Are They Built and Sustained?" will be the subject of a program at the Loft in White Plains on Thursday at 7:30 P.M.
Gay and lesbian couples will discuss the personal problems and social issues they face in forming lasting relationships, and they will field questions from the audience. The Loft, a service center for the gay community, is at 255 Grove Street. A donation of $5 is requested. Call 948-4922 for more information. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: BETTER WORK THAN WELFARE. BUT WHAT IF THERE'S NEITHER?

 BODY:
It seems to me that Moore didn't worry too much about quitting jobs she didn't like. Only the middle class does that.
Expensive work-training programs aren't the answer. People go to work and hold on to jobs when they have to. They learn to get along with others and to show up on time because they have to. They practice birth control because they have to. They wait to have children until they are married because they have to. Some of us are old enough to remember when every American lived that way. The incentive is economic survival. Welfare has taken that away. 
 We simply need to phase out welfare and phase in the old economic survival instinct. I suggest that we "grandfather" in all current recipients and refuse to put anyone else, even new babies, on the dole. It's called tough love.
 
ELLEN SCHNEIDER
Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

HEADLINE: WORD & IMAGE;
PBS's Wheel of Fortune

BYLINE: By MAX FRANKEL 

 BODY:
NEWT GINGRICH WANTS TO "ZERO out" the taxpayers' contribution to public broadcasting, and sometimes so do I. The impulse to strangle last struck me during the bonus round of a new quiz show, "Think Twice" -- yes, a PBS quiz show. Two contestants, already bathed in gifts from the Microsoft Corporation, failed to win the jackpot, a generously advertised $2,500 investment in a Keystone mutual fund. No Vanna White appeared, but along with the commercials came an ebullient M.C. and players childishly applauding their own right answers, just like "Wheel of Fortune." It's not only Big Bird and "Masterpiece Theater" for whom the Gingrich tolls.
But then it's not the quality of public broadcasting that bugs the Speaker. If it were, he'd offer more, not less, than the $300 million the Treasury contributes to public television's $1.5 billion annual expenses. Gingrich objects in the name of principle: he contends that PBS is superfluous because cable and satellite can now serve every taste for which there is a "market." They could but they don't. 
 One trouble with his theory is that 40 percent of America's homes don't get or can't afford multichannel service. A bigger trouble is that the commercial market seems unable or unwilling to devote prime time and money to the kind of news analysis, music, dance, history, biography and science available in public television's best weeks. Beyond that, the market offers nothing as wholesome as PBS's educational programs for children and virtually no instructional programs for adults, very little theater beyond the soaps, very little music older than an adolescent. And the Speaker knows it.
What really grates on him, and other aggressive partisans, are the liberal values that shine through many of public broadcasting's cultural and academic programs. Often, the conservative critics honestly misunderstand; they perceive skeptical curiosity or social tolerance as dissent or deviance. Then again, sometimes they are right. Right or wrong, they piously contend that taxpayers should not underwrite views they oppose.
But why not? Why do the champions of imperfect economic markets show no tolerance for flaws in the ideological market? Why is the much more pronounced rightward tilt of opinion in radio talk shows less objectionable than the occasional liberal tilt of "All Things Considered"? Do these experts on public finance fail to recognize the public's financial support for all broadcasting and for the think tanks that supply ammunition to the broadcasters? Rush Limbaugh owes the taxpayers a lot more for the free and profitable use of the public airwaves than Bill Moyers.
A Government that has wisely stopped trying to legislate fairness and equity in broadcasts to mass audiences should not fuss so hard about small lapses in speech addressed to assorted minorities. Elementary fairness in public broadcasting could be better assured by depoliticizing its board of directors, now appointed by the White House and hounded by Congressional committees.
There are days when, with Gingrich & Company, I too rage at "All Things Considered." I am annoyed not only by its occasional longwindedness or lapses into liberalism but also by its excellence, the breadth and depth of its coverage. Why, I wonder, should taxpayers subsidize a news operation that so effectively competes with The New York Times, which must spend hard-earned millions to gather the same news?
But invariably, reality dawns. Even the "all news" radio stations in New York reduce human activity to a few headlines surrounded by weather and traffic reports and commercials. Even The Times's own radio stations, serving sophisticated audiences with classical or golden oldie music, offer no newscasts worthy of the paper or as good as public radio's.
It's a tough concession for any American, but our market culture is an inadequate culture. Without Government subsidy and tax-supported philanthropy, there would be no great universities, no great libraries, no great museums, no grand opera or basic science. Despite all its shortcomings, public broadcasting represents the civilized conviction that not everything of value can be popular.
By not grasping that paradox -- that public broadcasting is not the same as popular broadcasting -- Americans have driven the loose PBS network of 351 stations toward its biggest failings. PBS is in trouble because its layers of insulation from politics have worn too thin. Instead of a reliable stream of multiyear subsidies for innovative programming, it has been held to an insecure Federal dole and required to share it with often redundant and poorly managed local stations. That sustains a helpful lobby in almost every Congressional district, but it drains money from programs that could reach the same large audience through many fewer stations and also by tape and disc and eventually through cyberspace.
Given its predicament, noncommercial television has come to depend on compromising commercials and tedious fund appeals and has been forced to pursue large audiences, meaning "contributing members," with inexpensive but presumably popular programs like the quiz show.
A HIGHLY INTELLIGENT ANALYSIS OF how public television came to be and what it could still become was published last year by a diverse group of distinguished citizens assembled by the Twentieth Century Fund. Called "Quality Time," the group's report urged "fundamental structural change," but it has been largely ignored by critics and defenders alike.
The group wanted Federal subsidies increased but destined entirely for creative and better-protected programming. By ending the subsidies to station operators, it said, Congress would require the states and local communities to decide which of many overlapping stations they can still afford. The group also wanted educational and instructional programs to be improved. And it wanted public broadcasting to be more securely financed with fees collected from commercial broadcasters for their use of the public spectrum -- much as cable operators tax themselves to support the excellent noncommercial C-Span channels.
There you have an agenda worthy of a radical Republican Speaker: No more mandated pass throughs from the Corporation for Public Broadcasting to local station bureaucracies that endear themselves to House members. No more free grazing on the taxpayers' airwaves by commercial broadcasters. And a portion of their royalties sent directly to public broadcasters. With such a program, Gingrich could save tax dollars on public television, earn some money for the taxpayers from commercial television and avoid becoming a censor who appears to want only to zero out the free market of ideas.

HEADLINE: Technology;
Will Video Game Machines Turn Into PC Killers?

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev.

 BODY:
AT this year's Consumer Electronics Show, which ends this evening, it became clear that the personal computer is finally a bona fide consumer-electronics item.
Entertainment software for home personal computers has been the talk of the show and William H. Gates -- the king of Microsoft, who seems to be everywhere these days -- gave a keynote address yesterday where he described his company's new "Bob" software, which is designed to simplify the family PC. 
 It appears to be a timely product introduction, because personal computer sales nearly equaled sales of television sets in 1994, according to data released Friday by the show's sponsor, the Electronic Industries Association.
But the PC's reign in consumer electronics could be short lived. For in the computer industry, things are never stable for long, and the outlines of a new computing world order are already taking shape.
This year will see the arrival of a generation of computers with many times the power of the personal computer, yet costing far less. "The pressure to build super-high-performance machines for zero cost is unbelievable," said Dennis Allison, a Silicon Valley computer designer who has helped design microprocessors for the next generation of video games.
Look for at least three key developments this year:
* New video game machines from Nintendo, Sega, Sony, 3DO and Atari are scheduled to be available for Christmas 1995. These "computers" will have far more processing power than the current top personal computers using Intel's powerful Pentium chip. Rather than costing $2,000 to $3,000, as Pentium PC's do, they will start at less than $500 and fall to $250.
* Television set-top computers, based on a new generation of "media processor" chips, will be introduced. These set-top boxes will be designed to translate streams of digital information sent over cable or telephone networks to let viewers select movies at the time of their own choosing, and will also offer computer animation capabilities rivaling the quality of video game machines.
* The first prototypes of Japanese digital video disk systems, based on competing standards backed separately by Sony and Pioneer, will be demonstrated this year. Designed to replace today's videocassette recorders and scheduled for sale in 1996, the new systems will use powerful and inexpensive microprocessors to play back movies from compact disks the same size as today's audio CD's and the silvery computer disks known as CD-ROM's.
The computing industry is less stable than other businesses because, as a technological rule of thumb, every 18 months it is possible to put twice as many transistors on a single silicon chip.
That means not only the price of computer processing tends to plunge even as speed and performance soar, but also each generation in computing makes the last one obsolete.
Each new generation of computers has not simply replaced those of the previous era. And in the breeds of computers arriving this year, each has been developed for game-playing or other entertainment applications. They will not immediately supplant computers designed for serious business uses.
Yet, these small supercomputers will ultimately be deployed in a wide range of applications that were previously unattainable or too costly for the consumer market -- including voice-recognition devices that respond to a broad range of spoken commands, and smart, portable digital valets capable of handling virtually all their owners' computing and telecommunications needs.
The rise of computing's new order will be anything but painless. Since the mid-1950's the computing world has been overthrown twice: Mini-computers broke the monopoly of mainframes in the late 1960's and early 70's, and in the mid-70's personal computers began edging mini-computers out of the spotlight. Each time, the older machine survived, but it no longer ruled.
In each case, the changes -- whether in terms of letting smaller companies adopt computing or giving more workers access to information -- had an impact throughout the economy.
"The trend is for the fastest to also be the smallest and cheapest," said John Moussouris, co-founder of Microunity Inc., a Silicon Valley chip maker that is developing a television set-top box with backing from companies like Tele-Communications Inc. and the Microsoft Corporation.
"This will continue to disrupt the computer industry to a greater degree than the auto disrupted the horse and buggy or the calculator disrupted the slide rule," he said.
FOR the computer industry itself, consumer electronics companies are already becoming the largest investors in financing research and development in advanced information technology. That is a departure from the past, when computer makers with a scientific and engineering focus, like Cray Research, with financing from several large corporate backers and the Defense Department, were the first to introduce the fastest computers.
Now Pentagon financing for computing is flat or declining, while consumer electronics companies are investing billions of dollars to advance the state of the art. Why? Because consumer electronics companies are best able to spread such investments over millions of customers. Much more than the military or corporate markets, though, the consumer market demands low-cost products.
As with generations of technologists who have come before them, today's executives in the personal computer industry are skeptical that their role as technology innovators is threatened. In fact, their industry is still widely believed to be among the nation's most innovative.
But computer experts who have watched the technological revolutions in recent decades say there is no reason that the PC makers should consider themselves immune from the forces that in 1995 will point to a new world order in computing.
"For about five years I've been telling my friends in the work station business they're not immune to the inexpensive personal computer," said Carver Mead, a computer engineer at the California Institute of Technology and a father of modern chip design.
"Now," he added, "the same pattern is going to be repeated with video games."

HEADLINE: Looking Outward to Keep U.S. Economy Chugging

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

 BODY:
With the nation's economic expansion still strong but aging, this year is likely to provide a crucial test of whether increased trade can visibly deliver on its promised benefits to Americans. For now that the advance in domestic demand is expected to slow at least somewhat, trade specialists say, foreign growth is the best hope to animate the United States economy.
"If the U.S. slows down in the next couple of years," said Jeffrey E. Garten, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, "a lot of slack can be taken up by the resurgence in Europe, Japan and the emerging markets." 
 Trade, in fact, is becoming the new standard currency of American diplomacy, and not just because the cold war has ended. The nation's annual exports have more than doubled in the last decade, accounting for a sharply rising share of the nation's output.
Although economists see no recession soon, increasing interest rates could retard economic growth at home. But many of America's major trading partners are just getting their own recoveries under way, while much of Asia and Latin America is growing much faster than the United States.
Mexico caught up with Japan last year to become the nation's second-largest export market, behind Canada. Although the recent plunge of the peso and an austerity plan is likely to curb Mexican imports this year, most economists expect Mexican demand for American products to continue rising over the longer run.
For almost a decade now, exports have been one of America's secret economic weapons. United States corporations did so well in foreign markets last year -- merchandise exports were up 9.5 percent through September -- that they favored the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade with near-unanimity. From 1985 to 1994, exports rose from 7.2 percent to 10.2 percent of the nation's gross domestic product as American firms vastly improved their competitiveness. With the new global trade agreement and a worldwide economic expansion, business leaders say, things should only get better.
"America has a huge potential for increased export opportunities," said Eckhard Pfeiffer, chief executive of the Compaq Computer Corporation, which gets half its sales from abroad. In an interview, he spoke of having penetrated the Japanese market in 1992, and now expanding in Europe as more companies learn to take advantage of technology. Among the recent visitors at Compaq's headquarters in Houston have been oil executives from the former Soviet republic of Kazakhstan and bankers from Poland.
Labor leaders point out, however, that the trade deficit also swelled last year, despite a weak dollar, which would normally favor exports over imports by making American goods less expensive in foreign markets. And they say the export of jobs, promoted by the year-old North American Free Trade Agreement, is only beginning. While the Administration says that each billion dollars in exports creates 20,000 jobs, the unions respond that each billion dollars in imports destroys 20,000 jobs. And the merchandise trade deficit for 1994 is expected to reach about $160 billion, which would nearly match the 1987 record.
"The trade deficit, the huge deficit, represents a net loss of employment to this nation," said Mark A. Anderson, director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Task Force on Trade. "We are losing the broad middle class that provided stability in this country."
Economists ascribe the imbalance to the economy's gathering strength. Import demand is stronger in the United States than abroad because growth is more robust here. They also say that trade promotes the most efficient allocation of resources, which helps lift living standards across the board for nations that participate in the global economy.
That is little solace to many union officials. While champion exporting companies tend to pay higher wages, labor leaders contend that the surge in international trade has led to little more than stagnating incomes for many workers.
They point to Caterpillar Inc., a leading supporter of GATT, which has gotten the United Automobile Workers union to allow some new workers to receive $8 an hour instead of the usual $17 minimum. Caterpillar, a top maker of construction equipment, has profited from the nation's strong 13 percent rise to $151 billion through three quarters in the export of capital goods, which are used to equip factories, build roads and run offices.
For consumers, the benefits of freer trade are obvious: not only cheaper imports, but also pressure on domestic producers to keep prices down. But some workers inevitably suffer. After the North American pact took effect a year ago, the Administration offered retraining for those who could prove that the flow of goods and investments had cost them their jobs. Labor unions complain that only a quarter of the 48,000 workers who have applied has been certified for retraining.
THE Clinton Administration has promoted exports as single-mindedly, it seems, as anyone since Japan's MITI bureaucrats at their zenith, if not Louis XIV's mercantilist minister Jean-Baptiste Colbert.
"We need a superaggressive national export strategy," the Commerce Department's Mr. Garten said in an interview. "We have to turn up the heat in ways not yet contemplated."
He can already point to billions in foreign contracts signed after executives piled aboard for Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown's many trade missions abroad. Some wonder, however, whether political supporters have an edge in winning seats on the plane.
When Brazil wanted to build a $1.5 billion satellite and radar system in the spring to monitor the Amazon environment, Mr. Garten said, the chiefs of the United States space, environmental and interior agencies lobbied their Brazilian counterparts. Secretary Brown visited the country and the United States promised to match any financing that its chief rivals, the French, could offer. The United States won the contest.
As the Administration and many corporations are discovering, the most rapidly growing export markets are sure to be among such rapidly developing nations. For the first three quarters after the new trade pact took effect, exports to Mexico were up 21.7 percent, imports up 22.8 percent.
That's why when other goals conflict with the pursuit of foreign trade these days, those other goals usually give way. The Chinese Government hardly bothered to make even cosmetic improvements in its human rights record in 1993, but the Clinton Administration decided it had little choice but to grant China the most favorable trade status.

HEADLINE: The Basinger Bankruptcy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
We are writing this letter on behalf of our client, Kim Basinger, to correct false implications which we believe exist in the article about her that appeared last week, "The Basinger Bankruptcy Bomb." 
 The article blames the poor economy in Braselton, Ga., and the failure of the proposed renovation of the town, on Ms. Basinger's bankruptcy case and her dispute with Main Line Pictures. If there are problems in Braselton, those problems were caused by the recession, local and national declines in property values and a change in the investment strategy of the Ameritech Corporation's pension fund, the controlling party in the renovation project. The problems were not caused by Ms. Basinger, her bankruptcy case or her dispute with Main Line Pictures.
The facts of the matter include the following:
In 1989-90, the Ameritech pension fund invested in Braselton based on a strategy mapped out by its managers and third-party real estate promoters. Ms. Basinger agreed to associate her name with the project in the belief that Braselton would be developed into a charming historical/commercial center. Although she borrowed large sums of money to help finance the project, Ms. Basinger, as a limited partner, was legally precluded from controlling the financial workings, day-to-day operations or other business aspects of the project.
As a result of her bankruptcy case, Ms. Basinger was able to complete her appeal in the Main Line matter and obtain a reversal of a judgment that was held by the California appellate court to violate her constitutional right of due process. Although Ms. Basinger won on appeal, the bankruptcy trustee attempted to make a settlement that would have paid Main Line about $2 million and allowed her other creditors only approximately 17 cents on the dollar. Fortunately, the bankruptcy court rejected the trustee's proposal as failing to give appropriate credence to the merit of Ms. Basinger's legal positions. Ms. Basinger's legitimate creditors now have the possibility of recovering 100 cents on the dollar, a chance that would never have been available to them had Ms. Basinger not filed for bankruptcy protection.
While Harvard Law School Prof. Charles Normandin, who was quoted in the article, may be an esteemed bankruptcy scholar, he has had no involvement in the Basinger bankruptcy case. The article's use of Professor Normandin's general views about bankruptcy law cannot substitute for an accurate legal and factual analysis of the Basinger bankruptcy case. The statement in the article that "Americans have long been more understanding than their European ancestors toward deadbeats," which apparently relies on Professor Normandin's opinion, bears no relevance to the Basinger case and incorrectly implies that Ms. Basinger is a "deadbeat." Indeed, the fact that Ms. Basinger won her appeal makes it clear that her decision to go through a bankruptcy case was the right one.
Even before she won her appeal of the Main Line judgment, Ms. Basinger could never have been considered a "deadbeat." To the contrary, Ms. Basinger offered to post all her nonexempt assets as well as three years of prospective earnings as collateral for the right to pursue the appeal. However, Main Line rejected her offer, insisting it would only consider a proposal that would guarantee it 100 percent payment, give a third party chosen by Main Line the right to control Ms. Basinger's career and include a promise that Ms. Basinger (then 40, and a newlywed) would not start a family until Main Line was paid in full. Ms. Basinger's conversion from Chapter 11 to Chapter 7, and the relinquishment of her assets to a bankruptcy trustee, was her only alternative to allowing a third party the right to tell her what professional roles she must accept and when she could have a baby.
The article falsely insinuates that Alec Baldwin's assets should be made available to the bankruptcy case or the Braselton residents. Since Ms. Basinger and Mr. Baldwin were married after the bankruptcy case was filed, by law Mr. Baldwin's assets, life style and ability to provide a life style to his family are excluded from his wife's bankruptcy case.
We take issue as well with another statement in the article: "While the wheels of justice creak and moan, Ms. Basinger's small creditors -- those who arranged her travel plans or repaired her home -- go unpaid. And the folks of Braselton, population 450, learn that getting too involved with an actress can be dangerous." There is no truth to the suggestion that getting involved with Ms. Basinger is "dangerous" and indeed it is false to suggest that Ms. Basinger caused these individuals' problems.
 
LESLIE A. COHEN and JULIE M. PHILIPS
Los Angeles, Jan. 5
 
Ms. Cohen is with the law firm of Levene & Eisenberg, P.C. Ms. Philips is with Bloom, Dekom, Hergott & Cook.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Mexico Will Prosper, but Not Very Soon

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
IN 1863, the American Civil War wasn't the only battle going on in this hemisphere. A French expeditionary force reached Mexico City, having invaded in anger over Mexico's failure to pay its bills.
The history of foreign investment in Latin America is a history of great expectations, fleeting profits, dashed hopes and defaults. There is potential aplenty, but it seems that every generation has its own disaster. As far back as 1825, the ramifications of a Latin American investment boom gone bust almost brought down the Bank of England. 
 To be fair to the Latin Americans, such problems are common in developing countries, at least in ones that are able to attract capital. "The British were had over and over again," recalled Gert von der Linde, the retired chief economist of Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette, in discussing American history. Whether it was toll roads, canals or railroads, America's growth was financed largely by foreigners, who often left feeling fleeced.
We checked in with Mr. von der Linde because he saw the debacle coming, warning last spring that Mexico was living beyond its means and had a history of peso devaluations during presidential election years, like 1994.
Until a few days before Christmas, almost everyone on Wall Street loved Mexico. It had pegged its currency to the dollar, with gradual devaluations that seemingly removed any currency risk, and it was viewed as one of the safest of developing markets, thanks in part to the export market guaranteed by Nafta. Its balance of payment problems were viewed as manageable. Then the peso collapsed, and with it the profits of many American investors.
Mexico's new financial plan was sold brilliantly last week by its new finance minister, Guillermo Ortiz, who wowed almost everyone he met in New York. Listening to him, we found ourselves believing that it all would work, that the workers would take a cut in their standard of living, that the government would slash its spending, that foreign investors would be persuaded not to take money out of the country, and that new investment would pour in to take advantage of lower real wages. More than a few money managers who heard him bought Mexican securities on Thursday, but by the next day the peso was weak again. It has now lost 40 percent of its value against the dollar. Mexico borrowed billions through an unusual short-term bond called a tesobono, denominated in dollars but payable in pesos. So the lenders can take out their money as tesobonos mature in coming months, presumably without losses because the Mexicans will have to pay more pesos to offset the devaluation.
It was a sign of weakness that Mexico was not able to get enough foreign investment without that gimmick. Now, finding a way to persuade investors not to take their money and run, without Mexico having to pay ridiculously high interest rates, is the first challenge confronting Mr. Ortiz, and perhaps the hardest. Mexico has the money, thanks to loans from this country and others, to pay off those loans. But if it has to do so, and thereby depletes its reserves, it could set off a destructive cycle of devaluation and inflation that would wreck whatever chance the Mexican plan has of success.
"We developed," said Mr. von der Linde of the United States. "And so will Mexico, eventually. People are right to say they are good longer term prospects." But not, he added, worth the risk right now.
