SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1450 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: January 1-6

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring 

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
The Economy's Dead. Long Live the Economy.
Two of last week's big stories seemed strikingly at odds. Republicans stormed Capitol Hill with the glee of schoolchildren entering a long-padlocked playground, carried to glory on the shoulders of a failed economy. But hard on the heels of that triumphant return came news that that same economy finished the year on a mighty note: the unemployment rate fell to 5.4 percent, and more than a quarter million jobs were added in December. On top of that, there was a huge upward revision that made November's rise in payrolls the biggest in seven years. All this brought 1994's payroll expansion to 3.5 million, over a million more than in 1993 and the strongest in a decade. Now it might be logical to expect that such news, a clear inflation threat, would spook the markets. But in the bond market, rates actually fell a bit, and stock prices rose strongly. 

Why Are These Men Smiling?
It's here. The Age of Gingrich. Sparks are flying. But the way Bill Clinton and Newt Gingrich smiled when they met, you'd think they were good ol' boys hunting the same duck. Which is what, defying every law of nature, they said they'd try to do. The first deal: the President won't lobby hard against a balanced-budget amendment, Republicans won't bust the budget with too-steep cuts in capital gains taxes. It's the Republicans' day, though: when Senate Democrats tried to scrap one bit of business-as-usual and bar members of Congress from taking lobbyists' gifts, the idea was summarily killed off.
 
What the Dividends Foretell
Each week, a different crystal ball peers into the economy's soul. Yes, we'll soon be hearing about the Super Bowl indicator. The latest tea leaf? Corporate dividends. An S.&P. study out last week showed that while few companies are cutting dividends, they're not quite as quick to raise them. True, payout increases were up in '94 from '93, but the rise wasn't as steep as a powerful economy might suggest. Since directors hate to cut dividends, and thus avoid raising them unless they're sure they can be sustained, this could be a sign of wavering confidence.
 
Orange County Digs Out
Raise taxes? In Orange County? Don't be ridiculous. It's "not going to happen," said an adviser to the county. "I will not support any new taxes," said a county supervisor. Californians feel strongly about such things. Never mind that in the wake of the derivatives debacle, the county -- the very symbol of suburban affluence -- can't pay its bills. It did come up with $40 million in budget cuts recently to try to dig itself out, but it said last week that its shortfall was an awful lot more -- $172 million for the next six months. So without taxes, or a miracle, a lot of services are probably going to disappear.
 
What About New York?
Somehow the New York area fell off the bus a few months ago as the nation's economy sped gleefully onward. The region is one of the weakest in the nation, with job growth vanishing since July. (It did better in December, perhaps because of holiday sales jobs.) So those Federal Reserve rate increases -- meant to cool things off nationwide -- could plunge the city into an icy bath. And it could get worse: Charles Schumer of Brooklyn -- that new rarity, a House Democrat -- just released a study showing that the "Contract With America" would cost the city $1.9 billion in Federal aid next year. New York would be hit hard because, Mr. Schumer said, Newt Gingrich "uses 'New York' as a pejorative adjective."
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Paying Hitler's Bills
The time, the 1920's. The world had been made safe for capitalism, America was roaring, Germany was shattered, and Americans bought $210 million in German bonds. Not a wise move. When Hitler came along, he treated these bonds with his typical respect, and Germany quickly defaulted -- with Roosevelt reportedly saying, with a laugh, "Serves the Wall Street bankers right." Those bonds weren't forgotten, though -- part of the tab was paid years ago -- and now Germany's squaring its debts. It's offering new, presumably more solid bonds to investors, or, more likely, their descendants. Are you among them? Call Deutsche Bank. Now, where were those bonds?
 
Mexico Tries Soothing Words
Mexico, with firmly crossed fingers, is trying to push past this economic crisis. On Tuesday President Ernesto Zedillo announced a detailed recovery plan, and on Thursday the freshly minted Finance Minister, Guillermo Ortiz, came to the money capital, New York, bearing calming words. This is "completely different" from 1982, he said, referring to Mexico's bond default. "We have a fundamentally solid economy." The peso, he assured, should steady itself at about 4.50 to the dollar -- it's now well above 5 -- and do so without Mexico's central bank propping it up. At first, the markets seemed to think he had a point, but on Friday the peso plunged again, to a new low.
 
On the Road Again
They're at it again. The United States and Japan keep trying to hammer out a solution to the lopsided trade in autos and auto parts, and last week they said the stalled talks would resume this month. The American deficit in the auto sector rose to $36.1 billion last year, more than half the trade gap with Japan. True, we're selling more there, but the flow this way more than wipes that out. It's a bit vague what any new talks will focus on, though, for Washington will now deal directly with Japanese companies on buying parts -- that was a big issue. The main thing seemed to be setting a tone of harmony when Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama calls on President Clinton this week.
 
COMPANIES
 
Thinking? Don't Get Caught
If you're toiling away past quitting time, visions of extra pay dancing the pain away, you'd better watch out: If you catch yourself feeling creative, put a lid on it, quick. Only the drones, it seems, need apply for overtime. A former Washington Post reporter, Thomas Sherwood, had insisted that under the Federal Fair Labor Standards Act, he should have gotten time and a half for all the extra hours he put in over the years. But a Federal judge has just ruled that the act does not apply. The act exempts professional and "artistic" workers, it seems, and the judge said many journalists fall into the latter category -- those whose work requires "invention, imagination and talent." So once again, this time by judicial decree, art is its own reward.
 
Go Digital, Young Man
"The Graduate," ca. 1995. Wise older person (not necessarily male) offers Dustin Hoffman type a single word of advice: "Digital." Forget traditional televisions, VCR's and the like. "Digital" is the word from last week's Consumer Electronics Show (a digital broadcast standard is coming), and the race is on. In 1994, sales of home computers, at $8.1 billion, came perilously close to the $8.4 billion spent on TV sets. Soon, in fact -- to hear the electronics gurus tell it -- we won't even be able to tell the difference. After all, a screen, as Humphrey Bogart didn't say, is just a screen. TV's will pay bills, under-$500 personal computers will have remote controls, and consumers will have headaches trying to keep up with it all.
 
Fabio! Believe It!
The folks who make I Can't Believe It's Not Butter! feel strongly about that exclamation point. So it's only natural that before they introduced a spray version last week, they scoured the globe for a human exclamation point to help sell it -- a search that led, of course, to Fabio. Fabio, who's such a superhunk supermodel that he doesn't need a last name, has adorned countless romance novels, but only now -- tomorrow, to be exact -- is he breaking into network commercials. I Can't Believe It's Not Butter! Spray has no fat, no calories, no cholesterol, its makers say; it's cooking in a "whole new way!" (There's that exclamation point again.) And the ads for it end with Fabio -- muscles rippling, blond hair flowing -- closing in to embrace the heroine of the moment. The voice-over: "Who says fantasies don't come true?" Sigh.
 
Just One Minus Sign . . .
Now we know what was behind that vanishing payment at Fidelity Magellan. It was the tiniest thing, Fidelity just told shareholders in a letter -- just a missing minus sign. An accountant, transcribing financial records onto a spreadsheet, accidentally turned a $1.3 billion loss into a $1.3 billion gain. But that $2.6 billion error was no small thing for investors who'd been told in November that they'd get $4.32 a share, then probably spending it before they got it, and ended up with nothing. A fitting end for a bleak year in mutual-fund land.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CEDAR GROVE/FLUSING;
Armory's Status Is Quo As a Dispute Drags On

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
The Flushing Armory was converted into a homeless shelter in 1981, just when downtown Flushing shook itself out of economic doldrums. Over the years, various groups from the Flushing Chinese Business Association to the Borough President's Office have complained bitterly that the shelter brought loitering, prostitution and drugs into the heart of a busy retail area and an Asian center rivaling Manhattan's Chinatown.
And recent turns and twists in the armory's debated life have only irritated them further. 
 Last summer, the city closed the armory, at 137-58 Northern Boulevard, which was serving as one of its largest shelters for homeless women. But two months later, the city redesignated the armory as an emergency shelter for homeless men. (So far, because of the mild winter, it has not been called into service..)
Then, late last month, Assemblyman Brian McLaughlin, a Democrat, reported that a son of Queens would finally end the battle. He said he met privately with Mario M. Cuomo during his last days as Governor, and that a sympathetic Mr. Cuomo said he would have the State Divison of Military and Naval Affairs, which owns and leases the armory to the city, revoke the city's permit for the site.
Mr. Cuomo could not be reached for comment. But last week, Walter C. Wheeler, a spokesman for Military and Naval Affairs, said there has been no change in the armory's status.
"The Governor told me it was among his highest priorities," Mr. McLaughlin said. "Obviously, we are keenly disappointed."
So the fight goes on. The Assemblyman said he would urge Governor Pataki to revoke the permit.They want the armory to be transformed into a community center.
"We are ready to move in," said Regina Colletta, district manager of Community Board 7, which has no permanent office. N.O.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
3 Advisers Set Model Courses for '95

BYLINE: By Carole Gould 

 BODY:
MOST mutual fund investors had a bad 1994, as stock funds lost just over 2.5 percent, on average, and bond funds fell nearly twice that.
But 1995 looks more promising. Ballooning equity valuations have finally burst. And last year's growing economy, which prompted the Fed to raise interest rates six times, may at last be starting to slow down. 
 Given last year's tough markets, it is not surprising that the theme in 1995 fixes on rebounds. That's the common thread running through investments picked by the three advisers who were once again asked to craft model portfolios for the year ahead.
There's the anticipated revival in growth stocks. They offer good value relative to the overall market, and their earnings growth should become more attractive in this year's sluggish economy, the advisers say.
All three also assert that smaller-capitalization stocks are good values; that bonds, particularly hard hit in 1994, should begin to bounce back, and two say thatreal estate prices should be rebounding.
Columbia Growth is a core stock fund (20 percent) in John Rekenthaler's model portfolio for 1995. Mr. Rekenthaler, who edits Morningstar Mutual Funds in Chicago, says the fund's "multiples are reasonable relative to value stocks, and people will start to think more about a slowing economy this year, which is good for growth stocks."
He would also put 20 percent in IAI Regional, a midcap growth fund that survived a tough 1994. That's also a bet on smaller stocks bouncing back, as is Smallcap World (20 percent). It has half its portfolio invested domestically and the rest abroad, including smaller stocks in Europe, which Mr. Rekenthaler called good values now.
His core global position is Ivy International. Mr. Rekenthaler is willing to pay a steep 5.75 percent sales load for Ivy, which is managed by Haken Castegren, who also runs Harbor International. Mr. Rekenthaler calls Harbor "the most consistently successful international fund," but it is closed to new investors. Last fall, Mr. Castegren had Ivy invested in few Japanese and German stocks and split 16 percent equally among South African and Swedish issues.
Mr. Rekenthaler's remaining 20 percent is invested in Fidelity Puritan, a conservative pick with holdings in bonds and high-yielding stocks (up 1.8 percent in 1994).
Growth stocks, big and small, account for more than a third of the model portfolio built by Ken Gregory, who edits the No-Load Fund Analyst in San Francisco. He invests 20 percent in Harbor Capital Appreciation to tap into big-cap growth stocks, which he calls very cheap relative to the overall market and which should profit as the economy slows. Strong Growth (15 percent) buys issues that are still reasonably valued and have good earnings growth, he says.
Real estate investment trusts are coming off a bottom in real estate values and should benefit from a big inflow of capital from institutional investors, Mr. Gregory says. His pick: Cohen & Steers Realty Shares (15 percent), which has worked solely with REIT's for more than 10 years.
Mr. Gregory sees plenty of opportunities internationally. While currency risk remains a worry, long-term exposure overseas is a must, he says. He likes Warburg Pincus International Equity (20 percent).
Emerging markets' bonds were hit hard at the start of 1994 but rebounded nicely as the year went on. Then the devaluation of the peso by Mexico at year-end hit the group hard again, even though most emerging markets debt is dollar-denominated. Mr. Gregory bets on another rebound in 1995 with a 10 percent stake in Fidelity New Markets Income Fund.
As for domestic bonds, they should be far more stable in 1995, returning between 7 and 10 percent, Mr. Gregory says. He likes Pimco Total Return (20 percent), whose high minimum investment can be avoided by buying shares through a discount broker. Harbor Bond, a higher-expense alternative managed by the same firm, can be bought directly with a $2,000 minimum.
Domestic bonds also look like bargains to Anthony Ogorek, an investment adviser in Buffalo. He taps into the market using the Vanguard Total Bond Market Index, a proxy for the United States bond market and 20 percent of his portfolio.
Overseas investments are imperative, he says, with so much of the world's capitalization outside the United States. He would allocate 15 percent to the T. Rowe Price International Stock Fund, which has ranked in the top 6 percent of all foreign stock funds the last decade, he adds.
Among domestic stocks, Mr. Ogorek sees several potential revivals among beaten-down groups. Electric utilities were off almost 20 percent last year, and he would look for a rebound using the Stratton Monthly Dividend Fund (20 percent). He also looks for a rebound in REIT's in 1995, using Cohen & Steers Realty Shares (15 percent).
To tap into smaller capitalization stocks, Mr. Ogorek recommends Strong Growth (15 percent) and Parnassus (15 percent). Parnassus, a "socially responsible" fund, is currently moving into undervalued market sectors like health care, he says.

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Dateline: Chinatown

BYLINE: By JANE H. LII 

 BODY:
ONE recent day, John Yu, a porter in a hotel and an immigrant from Hong Kong, stopped at the newsstand on Canal Street near Mott and perused the four major Chinese-language daily newspapers: World Journal, Sing Tao Daily, The China Press and The United Journal.
"My English isn't that good," Mr. Yu said. "This is the only way I can find out what's going on in the world." 
 He selected the World Journal. But just for this day. Mr. Yu said he alternated his selection on different days.
"It's hard to get the complete news from any one single Chinese-language newspaper here," he said. "Most of the newspapers have a political bent. It's hard to find out what's really going on in the world."
For Chinese immigrants who read little English, the Chinese-language newspapers are a lifeline to the outside world, a way of keeping abreast of the news that is beyond their reach in the American news media and of keeping up with the social and political activities in the Chinese community. But they often read the news with a skeptical eye, believing that the coverage is tainted by the decades of hatred between the Communist Government of the mainland and the exiled Government of Taiwan. Television does not help much. The five hours of Chinese-language programming each week on cable are mostly entertainment.
In recent years, with economic opportunities opening up on the mainland and reunification efforts taking place, the papers have shifted away somewhat from political extremes, and the papers' management proclaims neutrality, with the exception of The United Journal, which is vocally anti-Communist. Still, the Chinese consumers of news perceive differences, even if sometimes those differences are subtle, requiring as much a sense of what is not said as what is.
The different approaches between World Journal and The China Press, for example, were vividly apparent last fall in the coverage of the Chinatown parade celebrating the founding of the Republic of China, commonly known as Taiwan. World Journal, which stresses coverage of Taiwan, ran a front-page story and reported that 60,000 people turned out. The China Press, which focuses on the mainland, placed the news on page 16 and gave a much lower crowd estimate.
Two weeks earlier, after a parade celebrating the founding of the People's Republic of China, or the mainland, The China Press had run a front-page story but made no mention of the handful of pro-democracy demonstrators. World Journal reported the parade on the front page but ran an article next to it on the demonstration.
The local coverage varies in comprehensiveness and is generally uncritical to local Chinese leaders and to organized-crime leaders who are believed to wield enormous power in Chinese neighborhoods.
When Benny Ong, an underworld figure commonly known as "the Godfather of Chinatown," died last August, his obituaries were reverential and there was no mention of his criminal past. Coverage of several recent arrests of organized-crime leaders kept to the basic translation of the indictments. Sometimes, even such perfunctory coverage can be risky. Once, when a reporter mistranslated a court document, the accused demanded a whole roast pig as an apology. He got the pig.
Some Chinese journalists say their objectivity is compromised by having to sell advertising space. Reporters from Sing Tao Daily and The United Journal sell space.
"I don't like what he is doing to the community, but he's my biggest account, what can I do?" a reporter said recently about a businessman.
 
How They Cover New York, the Nation, the World
 
WORLD JOURNAL
 
OWNER United Daily News Group, a media conglomerate based in Taiwan.
 
CIRCULATION 120,000 in New York City area.
 
CORE READERSHIP General Chinese, especially Mandarin-speaking, well-educated, middle to upper-class Chinese.
 
POLITICAL BENT Perceived as Pro-Taiwan government, though management says it is neutral.
 
WHAT'S INSIDE Considered having the most in-depth and comprehensive news coverage. Has major news wire services. Covers international, national and local news and news from Hong Kong, Taiwan and the mainland. Includes international entertainment pages and medical advice columns.
 
LOCAL COVERAGE 24 local reporters, covering City Hall, police and education and other beats in citywide terms. Police coverage focuses on crimes in the Chinese communities, with special attention given Queens and Manhattan.
 
LEAD STORY, JAN. 3 Washington Post Wire Service article on Republicans in Congress at odds on proposals to reduce immigration quotas. Also on front page: New York Times Wire Service article saying 52 percent of the illegal immigrants in the United States came in on legal visas and stand-alone photograph of Pennsylvanian residents holding prayers services for the release of the illegal immigrants detained in a Pennsylania facility after the Golden Venture ran aground in 1993.
 
SING TAO DAILY
 
OWNER Sing Tao New York Limited, a subsidiary of Sing Tao Ltd. of Hong Kong.
Circulation: 80,000 in New York area.
 
CORE READERSHIP General Chinese, especially Cantonese-speaking business people and people with investments in Hong Kong.
 
POLITICAL BENT Perceived to be generally neutral but has become slightly pro-mainland in the last five years.
 
WHAT'S INSIDE Tabloid-style, short, straight news reporting, with little analysis. Has major news wire services, Covers international, national and local coverage and news from Hong Kong, Taiwan and mainland. International entertainment pages, medical advice columns, living sections.
 
LOCAL COVERAGE Six to eight reporters cover city. Very aggressive Chinatown and Brooklyn Chinese-related crime coverage.
 
STAFF Has 80 employees, about six to eight reporters covering the city, most reporters also sell advertising space

CHINA PRESS
 
OWNER a group of Chinese businessmen in New York.
 
CIRCULATION 40,000
 
CORE READERSHIP Older immigrants who are not anti-Mainland; newer immigrants from the Mainland; businessman who invest in China,
 
POLITICAL BENT Perceived to be pro-mainland government but management says it is neutral.
 
WHAT'S INSIDE Depth somewhere between Sing Tao and World Journal. Has major wire services. international, local and national news, with entertainment news mostly from Hong Kong and the Mainland.
 
LOCAL NEWS Emphasizes news in Chinese commmunities. Mix of crime and general news. Four reporters in Chinatown, one in Queens.
 
LEAD STORY, JAN 3: Staff article on the United States threatening trade sanctions against the mainland for trademark violations. Also: Xin Hua wire service article on Chinese Government condemning the United States foor the threat; staff article on Chinese Government blaming the United States for not recognizing the progress the Chinese Government has made so far on the trademarks. Picture of letter from Gov. George E. Pataki congratulating the paper on its fifth anniversary. Staff article on the Chinese G.N.P. surpassing 4 trillion yuan ($360 billion) in 1994.
 
UNITED JOURNAL
 
OWNER Chin Fu Woo, a Chinatown businessman.
 
CIRCULATION 14,000 in New York area.
 
CORE READERSHIP Middle and upper middle- income Cantonese-speaking Chinese.
 
EDITORIAL BENT Anti-Mainland government, Anti-communist and is critical of Taiwainese government for not standingup to the Mainland.
 
COVERAGE Concentrate on local and national news coverage, has some Hong Kong, Taiwan and China news coverage.
 
STAFF Has 35 employees, including 5 reporters. Reporters also sell advertising space.
 
LEAD STORY, JAN. 2 Staff article on the Hong Kong stock market falling sharply because the United States threatened trade sanctions. Also on from page: article saying that corruption is keeping the next generation of leaders on the mainland from emerging as the economy reforms; sarcastic editorial on a Hong King group that visited Beijing; article saying the Australians consume more alcohol than Americans, and article saying that work hours of Americans unlike those of Germans and Japanese, have increased. This is because of material greed, it contends.

SECTION: Section 13; Page 3; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK;
When City Walls Speak

BYLINE: By JENNIFER KINGSON BLOOM 

 BODY:
THE police expected a shootout. After all, they had seen the writing on the wall: a threat scrawled in spray paint on a housing project doorway. Someone named Dock vowed that when he ran into his enemy, Rine, he was going to TOS him -- terminate him on sight.
The cops knew Dock and Rine (rhymes with "sign"). Both had been behind bars for vandalism. But now they were back on the street. The police found Dock, who runs with a crew called the Deadly Ones, and explained that bumping off Rine, a member of the rival Manhattan Known Bombers, would mean jail, for years. 
 "It was a beef over spray paint," recalled Officer Robert Cekada of the housing authority police anti-graffiti unit. "One guy tagged over another guy's tag. What we were able to do was to mediate the whole situation and calm them both down."
Officer Cekada, 23, and his partners, Anthony Gonzalez, 25, and Alberto Ruiz, 29, have spent the last year and a half studying graffiti in East Harlem. In the universe of police work, this may not seem like the most macho assignment or a likely candidate for an episode of "NYPD Blue." But recently, as the housing police have learned, it is often deadly serious work. Understanding the nuances of this Internet of urban youth has helped head off trouble and has brought to light new facts about gang culture.
"Graffiti is being used to sell drugs, to sell prostitution," said Allen Monczyk, a spokesman for the New York City Public Housing Authority. "It was once seen as a social nuisance, a social problem, and because it was allowed to exist and nobody really fought it strenuously, criminals are using it for their benefits."
An example is the case of Jose Lopez, 16, whom the officers caught writing the name of a well-known gang -- Netas -- in bold, four-foot- high letters on asphalt in a courtyard at Clinton Houses. "He said he wanted a police helicopter to know that this was his turf," Officer Cekada said. Jose, who goes by the street name Aco, was arrested for vandalism. But he was wanted on a murder warrant, and the address led the police to a major prostitution ring that they said Jose and other gang members were involved in. The police say the ring was shut down.
Busts like this one have helped the three anti-graffiti officers gain the respect of their peers. Once dubbed the "crayon cops" by colleagues who viewed fighting graffiti as a cushy quality-of-life assignment, the unit has made 200 arrests (most for vandalism), has solved dozens of robberies and drug cases and passed along countless leads.
Their success has surprised the officers' former commander, James Tuller, who set up the unit last year. Mr. Tuller said he knew the housing authority spent $13 million a year to clean graffiti from walls, halls, walkways and windows, but he never recognized its connections to crime.
"As we're picking it up and we're learning the language, " Mr. Tuller said, "I like to say that those walls talk to us."
Residents of the 11 buildings patrolled by the officers call their beepers at the first sign of a fresh tag, and youths who recognize their unmarked Chevy Lumina tease them with gang hand signals.
Graffiti scrawlers sometimes play cat and mouse, incorporating the officers' names into their writings. One vandal whose tag is Spon wrote a slur against Officer Cekada on a wall of Park East High School at 106th Street and Park Avenue. On Halloween, Spon desecrated a nearby handball court with a taunt: "Trick or treat: we write while you sleep."
After that, "we locked Spon up," Officer Gonzalez said with a gleeful smile. Standing in the playground of Park East High -- where an unsanctioned graffiti "Hall of Fame" covers the walls -- Officers Gonzalez and Cekada divide its artists into those they have arrested and those they haven't.
"At 9 A.M. on a Saturday we locked up six guys here with about 200 cans of spray paint," Officer Cekada said. "They were from Rhode Island."
The officers spent their own money to travel to Los Angeles and to Boston to study graffiti. All three hard-boiled New Yorkers were rattled by the drive-by shootings and menacing graffiti they found in Los Angeles. "We thought, 'Oh, we work in Harlem, nothing can scare us,' " Officer Cekada said. "But it's a totally different world out there. They have a much worse problem than we have here."
The trip also taught them more about Los Angeles gang slang, which has migrated East through "gangsta rap" music. So have many members of Los Angeles's most notorious gangs, the Bloods and the Crips.
This month, Officers Cekada, Gonzalez and Ruiz will train 12 more anti-graffiti cops to decipher spray-can hieroglyphics. All 15 will fan out in the five boroughs. Plans call for doubling the size of the unit in 1996.
A $1.8 million grant from the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development will pay for a computer system to record photographs of graffiti from throughout the city on disks, enabling officers to compile a multiborough gang database. The East Harlem officers hope to learn how many of the 50 gangs they know about operate elsewhere in the city. They say they can tell what a gang is up to by what its members write. And they think the gangs are often foolish to cue in the authorities so blatantly.
"A lot of times they even write down the block that they live on," Officer Cekada said. "They're so stupid."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
$300 Million Is Coming. Who Will Spend It?

BYLINE: By JENNIFER KINGSON BLOOM 

 BODY:
If money is power, five political appointees are destined for the fast track. The five, still to be chosen, will decide how $300 million in public money will be spent in Harlem, Washington Heights and parts of the South Bronx, one of six urban empowerment zones picked by President Clinton late last year.
For two years, community advocates in the three areas have compiled wish-lists of projects they would pay for if New York was tapped for the direct government aid and tax breaks zone status confers. At the top: a "one-stop capital shop" for small businesses, two centers to recruit and train unemployed residents for jobs, more day-care and clean-up of vacant lots. 
 With the checks nearly in the mail, local officials are feeling pressure to set up the zone's governing structure and secure money quickly for projects with immediate, measurable impact. They fairly swoon thinking of an influx of new businesses, and a leap in local employment rates by the end of 1997.
"The Federal Government will be keeping a very close eye, a very close tab on progress, so the communities must show progress in the first two years," said Sam Mattingly-Wilford, a spokeswoman for the Harlem Urban Development Corporation.
Another goal is to rebut critics who view the zones as futile attempts to revive costly Great Society programs of the '60s. "This is the show," said Dennis Reeder, the director of the Washington Heights and Inwood Development Corporation. Failure to produce would mean "there's going to be nothing else."
A pledge of $300 million in government money may seem like a windfall when screws are tightening at every turn in the fiscal process. But residents hope it's just seed money to leverage private investment.
Officials hope to have the zone's three governing groups in place by the end of this month. But the chances are remote. A likely bottleneck is the office of Representative Charles B. Rangel, the Harlem Democrat, who fended off a challenge from Borough President Fernando Ferrer to add two Bronx neighborhoods, Melrose and Mott Haven, to the zone.
Despite hints about whom he might appoint to the governing panels, Mr. Rangel has offered only one name, former Mayor David N. Dinkins. And even that came with caveats in an emerging game with Washington. Before formally naming Mr. Dinkins, Mr. Rangel wants to see how senior an official is chosen by the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
"Mayor Dinkins has agreed to serve for Manhattan," he said, "but I would not want him to do it if it were just a lower-level appointee from HUD. Everyone is looking at each other because we want it to be on the same level." JENNIFER KINGSON BLOOM

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Recovery? Not in Your Paycheck.

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
SOMETHING is wrong with America's economic boom. After nearly four years of ever-stronger growth, people's wages should be going up faster than their expenses. For most people they're not, and this is the first time in decades that a recovery has gone so long without putting more money in more pockets. And now, if the recovery runs out of steam in 1995 -- as so many economists predict -- that money might never show up.
Raising wages has become the No. 1 economic issue in the nation today. Robust economic growth and rapid job creation are no longer enough to raise spirits. Both occurred in plenty of time for the November election, and still the Democrats lost Congress.
In his last speech to the nation, in mid-December, President Clinton made raising incomes, particularly wages, the new top priority. But neither the Democrats nor the Republicans are proposing ways to do this, except by lowering taxes. 
 "Think of the income tax-cut proposals," said Richard B. Freeman, an economist at Harvard, "as saying to American workers, 'Gee, we won't let you get wage increases through the job market, so we will give you some tax cuts, which are really wage increases, and we politicians, Democrats or Republicans, can claim credit for it.' "
For months, the Clinton Administration had counted on a strong recovery to create jobs and then to force up wages by more than the inflation rate. The hiring happened; the work force grew by 3.5 million people last year alone, including 256,000 in December. The script written by economists said that as the unemployment rate fell -- it dipped to 5.4 percent last month -- labor shortages would develop and employers would raise wages to get workers.
Some labor shortages have indeed developed, but Corporate America is not bidding up wages.
The average weekly wage of jobholders below management level is $389 today. After adjustments for inflation, that amount turns out to have the same purchasing power as the $342 average wage in March 1990, when the recovery began, the Labor Department reports. Other measures of average or median wages offer similar evidence of stagnation.
Still, there are stories of hefty raises for ordinary workers.
The Gillette Company, for example, regularly upgrades the manufacturing technology at its razor factory in South Boston, where 2,000 people are employed. As more complicated machinery replaces older, simpler equipment, the company requires a higher proportion of very skilled workers.
"If someone is a Grade 11 operator making $8 an hour, then we train him in the new skills he'll need and we promote him to a Grade 10 or Grade 9 operator, making $10 an hour," said Edward DeGraan, a senior vice president of manufacturing at Gillette. "His old job is then eliminated."
That is a 15 percent raise, far above the annual inflation rate of nearly 3 percent.
 
The Making of Machinists
 Similarly, metalworking shops in Rochester, their order books filled in a strong economy, need more machinists, or at least people who can perform some of the functions of a machinist. So they hire away retail clerks making $7 an hour, train them for several months and put them to work as machinists at $9 or $10 an hour, a substantial jump.
The stores, in turn, hire even lower-paid employees away from restaurants and other establishments. Then their owners, being at the bottom of the wage chain, put help-wanted signs in the window, hoping to attract the unemployed to their minimum-wage jobs.
But these examples represent a jump in pay levels for the workers involved, not a change in pay levels themselves. "Each company is reluctant to increase the pay assigned to a particular job," said David Wyss, senior economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill. "What they are doing is reaching down in the spectrum for people in lower-paying work."
And so far this job-shifting and reaching down has not involved enough workers to affect average wages nationally.
 
Between Recessions
 In the pattern set after World War II, wage scales rose frequently between recessions. Each rising economy soon lifted all boats. Living standards would rise for tens of millions of people, whether they were job-hopping or staying put. In the 1980's, however, the recovery from the 1982 recession was nearly six years old before wages recovered. And so far in the 1990's, most boats have not risen at all.
Many explanations have been offered for the delay. The numerous layoffs and plant closings play a role. So do the weakening of labor unions, the alternative of cheaper workers abroad, inefficiency, and falling prices for computers, which hold down wages in that big industry.
Whatever the truth, the nation still possesses a huge pool of standby people eager to shift to higher wage jobs, or any jobs at all. This pool might disappear if the economy continues to grow strongly this year and probably next year as well, many economists say. But they also say the strong growth won't last; although many indicators remain strong, they suggest that the economy has passed its peak for this recovery.
That raises another issue. Suppose the market system fails to end the wage stagnation in the traditional way, by forcing employers to bid for scarce workers to keep their operations running at full capacity. Should the Clinton Administration or Congress or both take steps -- other than their proposals for tax cuts and more training for more workers -- to try to raise people's incomes before the 1996 election?
Neither the Republicans nor the Democrats are debating such things right now. But Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said on Friday that the Administration was discussing an increase in the minimum wage. He also engages in some jawboning.
"American business has gotten everything it wished from this Administration: Nafta, GATT, deficit reduction and vigorous promotion of U.S. exports," Mr. Reich said. "If American industry wants to maintain the loyalty of employees and a political consensus that is pro-business, it has got to get serious about training workers and increasing their pay."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Shoppers! Deciding? Just Ask Your Child.

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AS the members of the beleaguered middle class contemplate the economic forces that are devouring their discretionary funds, they might also look at the self-inflicted one: indulging their children.
Such an idea may not be all that surprising to parents who have made it through another holiday shopping spree and are now realizing how much of a body blow was dealt the family budget by purchases of Power Rangers, the American Girl Doll with accessories or the portable Game Gear with Mortal Kombat. Even as the American public insists that the Government tighten its belt and curb spending, the willingness of parents to shower their children with material goods continues to accelerate. 
 Last year, Americans spent $17.5 billion on toys, nearly 50 percent more than in 1980, after adjusting for inflation, according to the Toy Manufacturers of America, a trade group in New York. Spending on toys, clothing and other items for children was a major reason for the 6.5 percent growth in holiday sales, the third year in a row that Christmas buying produced an increase over the previous year.
 
A Weakened Family
 Some companies and marketing experts believe that dollar figures for toys, games and clothing purchased for children do not reflect the children's true impact on family budgets. James U. McNeal, a marketing professor at Texas A & M University says that during the last decade, children exert an ever-increasing influence in decisions to buy a host of products from food, clothing, vacations, furniture, computers, autos and a range of other products or services that once were the province of adult decision-makers.
"The decision-maker increasingly is becoming the kid," said Mr. McNeal, who has studied family spending habits for more than 30 years, surveying parents, children, manufacturers and advertising and marketing companies.
Mr. McNeal estimates that children played a direct role in the purchase of $157 billion in goods and services in 1993, more than triple the $50 billion in purchases he attributes to them in 1984. And he predicts that the amount of what he calls "kid-influenced spending" will double by 2001. Mr. McNeal and other marketers say that based on their surveys of the industry and families the growth in such spending is pushing up expenditures for families, adding to the financial pressures on the middle-income families.
"How do you think a family making $22,000 feels when their kid says, 'I've just got to have a computer?' " Mr. McNeal asked.
According to Mr. McNeal and others who have studied the American family, the increasing weight of the children in deciding how parents spend their income is an outgrowth of the gradual weakening of family structures. Factors include high rates of divorce, single parenthood and the rising number of families where both parents work, a group that now totals 70 percent of all families with children.
In the past, for example, children might express the wish to wear a particular article of clothing and the nonworking spouse, usually the mother, would browse the stores, looking for something that might fit the bill at the best price. Today, after working a 40-hour week, many mothers are too tired, or don't know where to find specific styles at a discount. As a result, some marketers or others who study family spending behavior say, they are likely to indulge the child's desires, even if they include $100 brand-name sneakers, oversized jeans or a $25 baseball cap to be worn backward.
And some researchers say with the weakening of families, children are more and more disposed to get their values from peer groups and television -- two sources that tend to stress consumerism. "Children can acquire an identity from their home, or they can purchase it in the marketplace," said David Blankenhorn, president of the Institute for American Values, nonpartisan research organization that focuses on family issues. "And we are becoming more and more a society where children want to buy it."
With the diminution of parental authority in buying decisions, a wider variety of corporations than before have begun targeting youngsters in advertising and promotion campaigns. In recent years Holiday Inn and Delta Airlines have established marketing programs aimed at children. Marketers say electronics and computer companies, vacation resorts and clothing manufacturers have joined fast food restaurants in appealing directly to children and hoping that what they call the "nag factor" will help move the merchandise.
No parent who has brought a child along on a grocery-buying expedition has emerged unscathed from certain aisles. Sugared cereals, cookies and salted snacks somehow find their way into the shopping cart along with the meat and potatoes. Companies like General Foods have found that they can charge more for food items if they create them in shapes and colors appealing to children. Parents, who spend less time with their children during the week, find that quality time on the weekend often involves shopping excursions.
"The stuff we come up with, some of it targets directly to the kids and looks at the kids as the primary spender," said Pamela Hege, executive director of Kids Link, an Atlanta-based marketing company. "We have other campaigns where we use the child as a conduit to get to the parents."
 
Material Babies
 The marketers' job has become much easier, researchers say, because children are much more conscious of brands at an earlier age. But before blaming this latest trend on the advertising on Saturday-morning cartoon shows, Mr. McNeal insists that children's penchant for more expensive brand-name items is a direct reflection of their parents' desires for the very same kinds of things.
"You find parents who buy a pair of Nikes or an Izod shirt for their baby because they think it's cute," he said. "Well, baby figures that 'If Mommy or Daddy likes these things, I ought to like them, too.' Children want things more often than not because their parents taught them to want them."

HEADLINE: Word for Word/National Empowerment Television;
You Want Your Newt TV? Whether You Do or You Don't, It's Here.

BYLINE: By TOM KUNTZ 

 BODY:
NEWT GINGRICH, the new Speaker of the House, says he wants to "zero out" funding for public broadcasting because he doesn't think taxpayers should have to "subsidize something that told them how to think."
National Empowerment Television is more his speed. Founded just over a year ago by Paul Weyrich, the 24-hour, Washington-based network is home to two of Mr. Gingrich's programs, including a history course. He says that with its emphasis on live, viewer call-in programming, the conservative network provides a better alternative to the "distortions" of the "media elite." 
 NET's national penetration is patchy now -- it says it reaches roughly 11 million households, via satellite dish or by local cable or broadcast arrangement -- but it expects viewership to grow what with the cable giant Tele-Communications Inc. planning to carry it on more of its systems and interest in the new Republican-dominated Congress high.
The question becomes, what's in store for many American channel-surfers?
The network sums itself up thusly: "NET is must-watch television for public policy wonks and junkies, the C-SPAN crowd looking for more spice and pace, and the PBS and public policy crowd looking for more real-time coverage.
"In short, NET is C-SPAN with an attitude."
Below is a sampling from NET's weekly program schedule, with descriptions excerpted from its promotional literature. For comparison's sake, last week's corresponding programs from the other NET -- the Public Broadcasting System's flagship WNET in Newark -- and from one of the major commercial networks are also listed. All times are Eastern.

HEADLINE: Blacks Say Life In Los Angeles Is Losing Allure

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7

 BODY:
For perhaps half a century, Los Angeles has lured blacks, along with hundreds of thousands of other immigrants from the South and Midwest, with its promise of jobs and the luxury of space. But in the last decade, fed up with high housing costs, drugs and crime, blacks have been fleeing Los Angeles, not only to outlying areas, but also to other states, particularly in the South.
In fact, demographers and geographers say, middle-class and working-class blacks, born in California, are on the verge of disappearing altogether from some neighborhoods. 
 According to population surveys conducted by the Census Bureau, from 1985 to 1990, 61,773 blacks moved out of Los Angeles County. That represents 6.9 percent of the 901,200 blacks over the age of 5 counted in the 1990 Census.
"We are seeing a total restructuring of Southern California's black community," said James H. Johnson, a geographer at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill who studies black migration. "In a community where you have other ethnic groups growing rapidly, these changes have enormous political and electoral significance."
Demographers say most blacks are moving to neighboring counties like Riverside, San Bernardino and Ventura. But a surprising number are moving to other states to seek economic opportunity, especially in the South, even if they do not have roots in that area.
Although South-Central Los Angeles is still predominantly black, in little more than a decade it has also become one of the nation's fastest-growing Hispanic neighborhoods. And by the turn of the century, experts say, Hispanic people will outnumber blacks in both that neighborhood and the county. Asians are also rapidly moving into Los Angeles County in numbers expected to double by the end of the century to at least 12 percent of the total population.
In South-Central Los Angeles, movie theaters, dance clubs, barber shops and pool halls that once catered to a black population are vanishing. Central Avenue, once the center of black life in Los Angeles, now is home to Hispanic-run appliance and furniture stores. And as the neighborhood has changed, there have been clashes between the two groups.
Blacks who are leaving point to the still struggling Southern California economy, whose hard-hit defense industries employed tens of thousands of blacks in relatively high-paying jobs. But almost as important as a chief motivation for the exodus is the area's long eroding quality of life.
Kaama Moseley's parents fled the poverty and bigotry of segregated Arkansas 50 years ago for the jobs, hope and vigor of the West Coast. Now, disillusioned with Los Angeles's stagnant economy, drugs, crowded schools and gangs, Ms. Moseley, her husband and three children have recently resettled in Lithonia, Ga., a semirural suburb of Atlanta.
"It's kind of ironic," said Ms. Moseley, 37, a hairstylist who grew up in East Los Angeles and who until now has lived her entire life in California. "I left California for the same reason my parents abandoned the South. They couldn't make a decent living there, with Jim Crow and all of that, and I couldn't make it anymore in California. I was fed up and tired of that vicious economic cycle."
In an interview in her new home, Ms. Moseley said she left the state partly because her livelihood as a professional hair-braider depended almost entirely on blacks, and over time the market was diminishing.
"I have a product that's designed for black people, so I needed to go where they were," she said. "There are a lot of black businesses here, and a lot of black people who are doing very, very well."
Now, she says, she is the pioneer in her family. "I have a brother coming here in late January or February, and then my younger brother is coming as well," she said. "And a lot of my cousins have been asking me about moving."
Marilyn Thompson, 45, a telephone company manager who lived in Los Angeles for nearly 20 years before moving to Atlanta last year, also said the doors of opportunity seemed open for Hispanic and Asian residents but shut for blacks in California.
"It seems like you can come into California and have nothing and end up with everything," she said of other immigrants to the state. But, she said, blacks "can't seem to get ahead."
Ms. Thompson, who had lived in Baldwin Hills, an affluent black neighborhood on a hill that overlooks South-Central Los Angeles, added that the constant threat of crime and violence had made the city increasingly uninhabitable.
"I lived in a pretty good area, Baldwin Hills, but it didn't matter where you live, you had that element coming in," she said. "That gang scene was getting out of hand. I was tired of those drive-bys."
Some well-educated and relatively affluent blacks see an equally grim picture. Lisa Collins, a 38-year-old lawyer, and her husband, Arthur, a 39-year-old doctor, said they were planning to leave Los Angeles as soon as they could establish their careers elsewhere. Originally from Indianapolis, they cited high living costs and the deteriorating public school system as reasons to move.
"If I was living in Indianapolis, I'd have 50 acres, probably 10 horses and a mansion with a maid," Mrs. Collins said.
The Collinses said they had delayed having children because they lacked confidence in the Los Angeles public schools. Mrs. Collins said: "It seems like most of my friends have enrolled their kids in private schools here. Or they have moved to areas where at least the schools are decent."
Recent studies suggest that while white flight from urban areas has often begun among the middle and upper classes, black flight here is encompassing the entire economic spectrum.
The Census Bureau analysis, conducted for the University of Michigan Center for Population Studies, provided details about the millions of people who moved to, from or within metropolitan Los Angeles in the second half of the 1980's.
"What's important and new about this," said William Frey, a demographer for the Michigan center, "is that the black outmigrants are not only middle class, but also on the lower end of the economic scale."
Dr. Johnson, the North Carolina geographer, said: "The typical picture of poor blacks is that they are the ones who remain in economically depressed communities who become welfare dependents. What these data suggest is that a substantial cadre of poor and disadvantaged blacks are moving in search not of welfare but better economic opportunities."
The blacks who are leaving Los Angeles for other areas in California are generally leapfrogging the familiar suburban destinations of whites, like Orange County, and heading farther east toward Riverside and San Bernardino Counties or up the coast north to Ventura County. From 1980 to 1990, the black population in the Riverside-San Bernardino area increased 113 percent, making it the fastest growing black community in the country.
The blacks who are leaving California altogether are heading to Southern states -- including Florida, Georgia and Texas -- as well as to Illinois, New York and Washington state. Dr. Johnson said some blacks from Los Angeles are also moving to Las Vegas, Nev., where they are seeking service jobs in the casino industry. Other blacks are moving to Alabama, Louisiana and Mississippi, apparently because they have roots in those states.
South-Central Los Angeles's last major ethnic transition occurred in the early 1940's during World War II. Before then, the neighborhood was a mosaic of Italian and Hispanic immigrants and blacks, who had fled the stifling racism of the South. But as more and more blacks moved in, the whites moved out, eventually creating one of the country's most racially segregated areas.
After riots in the Watts section in August 1965, many factories pulled up stakes, taking with them well-paying manufacturing jobs. The area further deteriorated in the 70's and 80's as the few remaining major companies closed their factories.
But the area's economic demise did not dim the hopes of a wave of immigrants from Mexico, Central America and Asia who began to push blacks out of Watts and other areas. Between the 1980 and 1990 censuses, the black population of Los Angeles County dropped to 11 percent from 13 percent of the population, while the Hispanic and Asian populations swelled.
At the same time, many black residents have become increasingly resentful of the new immigrants, who many say are taking most of the region's low-wage jobs.
Ms. Moseley said that Asians who own many of the small businesses in Los Angeles tend to hire other Asians as workers, not blacks.
"I'm not taking anything from them, because I'm trying to emulate them and to watch them and to do as they do, because what they've done is what you're supposed to do," she added. "You come and find an opportunity and seize it, so you can't blame them for that. It just puts us in a very awkward situation as natives.
"I told myself, this is something that's bigger than you," she continued. "You can't change the political structure. Sometimes it's better to leave, which a lot of people have done."

HEADLINE: BUDGET WOES EASE FOR CITIES IN U.S., ANALYSTS REPORT

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
Flush with growing tax receipts from an improved economy and reaping the benefits of years of belt-tightening, the country's major cities are in their best financial shape in years, city officials and analysts say.
This trend is evident despite the fact that it does not include the nation's two largest cities, New York and Los Angeles, where weak local economies have contributed to continuing budget woes. 
 The roster of cities that have made stunning comebacks from the hard times of the recession include municipalities as diverse as Chicago, Miami, Denver, Detroit, San Francisco and Cleveland. Even Bridgeport, Conn., which was forced into bankruptcy in 1991, has returned to fiscal stability.
Many cities are even running surpluses for the first time in years, say students of municipal finances and chief financial officers of large cities.
Analysts of municipal finances say that in recent years more and more cities based budgets on conservative estimates of revenue and then used those estimates as a rationale to trim costs. As a result, as the economy bounced back, revenue exceeded expectations, leaving many cities with balanced budgets or even large surpluses.
"We've found that even the cities that were sort of just hanging in there and not doing terrifically well, even they are reporting that the underlying economic base was better in '94 than it was in the prior two or three years," said Michael A. Pagano, a political science professor at Miami University in Oxford, Ohio, who tracks municipal finances for the National League of Cities.
Beyond increased tax revenue, many cities have, in recent years, reduced expenses. They have instituted hiring freezes, kept wages down and in some cases, introduced new work rules to increase productivity. As a result, Mr. Pagano said, spending by large cities grew by one-half of 1 percent in 1993, a sharp decline from the 3 percent spending growth of the late 1980's and the 2 percent to 2.5 percent of the early years of this decade.
Analysts caution that the heady return to fiscal health of cities could unravel this year. For one thing, urban problems like poverty, crime and AIDS have not gone away as cities made sharp cuts in their social spending to cope with the recession. And unions, after accepting years of wage freezes, may start agitating for pay increases.
In addition, the revenue received by cities could face threats both from a slowdown in the economy, which many experts predict, and from proposals from would-be tax cutters in Congress and many state legislatures to reduce aid to cities.
"It's too early to declare victory," said Hy Grossman, managing director of Standard & Poor's Public Finance Department.
Still, in an annual survey of city fiscal administrators last July, the National League of Cities reported that 54.5 percent of more than 550 chief financial officers felt their cities "were better able to meet their fiscal needs in 1994, compared to 1993." That was a substantial increase in the level of optimism compared with the 33.7 percent who felt that way a year before.
And a report last year by Moody's Investor Service indicated that in 1993 -- the latest year for which complete data are available -- it upgraded the ratings for the general obligation bonds for 83 cities and downgraded the ratings for 39 others. That was a marked improvement in the fiscal health of cities from only a year before, when Moody's upgraded the ratings for 61 cities and downgraded those for 59.
"It's really great," Elizabeth Orr, Denver's finance director, said of her city, which went into the economic doldrums in the late 1980's with the collapse of oil prices. "Since 1989, we've been in very good financial shape. Some of that is just what's going on in the overall economy; some of it is a result of investments the city helped make to encourage economic activity."
Russell Carlson, first deputy budget analyst for Chicago, said that in addition to a healthier economy in the Midwest, his city has benefited from the fall in interest rates, which saved it $90 million in debt service last year. Mr. Carlson said the city ended the last fiscal year with a $76 million surplus and expects a similar result this year.
Three years ago, San Francisco ended its fiscal year with a surplus of $100,000, "which is, like, nothing," said Teresa Serata, the city's director of finance. Two years ago, Ms. Serata said the surplus grew to $600,000. Last year it was $11 million.
Even officials in Detroit, long considered one of the basket cases of American cities, will end its fiscal year next June with a balanced budget, a far cry from the $54 million deficit with which it started the fiscal year, according to Eric Tucker, its finance director.
"Some of it will be done through borrowing," Mr. Tucker said. "Some of it is managing expenses better. A lot of it is an improved economy. This is still the Motor City and the auto industry is doing fairly well."
Most cities are required by law to balance their budgets. But often, especially during hard times, officials employ accounting gimmicks to mask deficits.
Some experts who keep track of municipal finances say that while city budgets are in better shape that does not mean urban areas have cured their endemic problems of poverty, shoddy housing, poor schools and a loss of jobs to suburban areas. Indeed, some experts say cities are balancing budgets by cutting back on programs for low-income residents.
"Cities have pulled back, in most cases, from thinking that they can solve the problems of poverty and social ills and tend to be focusing on day-to-day delivery of core services," said Philip Dearborn, director of government finance research for the Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations, a body created by Congress to study the relationship between Federal, state and local governments.
Still, even as cities enjoy a healthier bottom line, many municipalities continue to struggle. And because three of them -- New York, Washington and Los Angeles -- are the country's prime media centers, there continues to be an impression of overall urban budget problems. At the same time, all three cities face financial problems different from others cities in the country.
In New York, the Giuliani Administration is facing a potential $2 billion deficit next year, despite having negotiated work rule changes that increased productivity of municipal workers. The prime cause of New York's financial woes is the slowdown in the regional economy, especially the banking and securities sectors.
In addition, New York City's counties -- each borough of the city is a separate county -- have to pay 50 percent of the non-Federal share of Medicaid, a burden that is usually picked up entirely by state government.
Los Angeles, which had a $54.1 million deficit for the fiscal year that ended last June 30, has had to deal with cutbacks in defense spending in recent years, which have devastated its aerospace industry. In addition, the city is still digging out from the financial impact of last year's earthquake and the riots of 1992. Also, Los Angeles, like all cities in California, is limited in its ability to raise property taxes, by Proposition 13, the 1978 tax-cutting amendment to the state Constitution.
The District of Columbia sits in the heart of an area that is fifth among the 25 largest cities in household income, third in the percentage of people completing college and first in employment of high-wage professional, managerial and technical jobs. But it nonetheless is facing a budget deficit of $530 million, which some analysts say could rise to nearly $1 billion by the turn of the century.
Part of the current problem is a failure to move quickly to cut costs as revenue fell during the recession. But the District's special constitutional status, as a kind of city-state without full independence, has created other problems. The District has to fully finance certain services, like the non-Federal portion of Medicaid or the incarceration of felons, that are generally picked up in whole or in part by state governments.
Moreover, even though the District of Columbia continues to be the chief location of jobs for people living in the area, it cannot impose a commuter tax without getting permission from Congress -- an increasingly remote prospect with Republicans in control of that body.

HEADLINE: We Still Need C.I.A., but It Needs to Change

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"For C.I.A., History Is the Big Traitor" (The Week in Review, Jan. 1) nails the soft spots in national intelligence: the secondary role of intelligence in international crime; the competition of open-source information; the marginal potentials of intelligence to contribute to ecology, environment and even economic threats, and the lack of a vision of future strategic intelligence needs. 
 You also tell us that a relevant direction for the Central Intelligence Agency is an imperative for national security.
Robert M. Gates, when leaving the National Security Council to become Director of Central Intelligence, got President Bush to sign a directive to all executive departments to conduct a review of intelligence needs for the post-cold-war era. Largely based on these results came the cry, first from Mr. Gates and then from President's Clinton's C.I.A. Director, R. James Woolsey Jr., that the post-cold-war world was a more dangerous place and that intelligence had to do more with less.
They missed the point that the "more" is the marginal and inappropriate work that you rightly dismiss as a basis for continuing the C.I.A.
Post-cold-war geopolitical developments that will eventually force a more aggressive United States foreign policy have not matured to the point of sparking a response strategy. The national, ethnic and boundary-conflict crises that fill the news do not constitute a more dangerous world to United States citizens.
But this early period of the post-cold war is transitional. It is a recess from the offensive foreign policy that we had to endure for four decades. Strategic intelligence needs by policy makers and defense planners are consequently ill defined.
But this doesn't mean no intelligence work. Intelligence must still monitor and interpret the major, glacierlike, regional geopolitical power shifts in all continents, and it will be of immense importance to our future well-being.
Future strategic threats include the Asian economic explosion; the declining rationale for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization; Japan's growing political power; the increased economic strength of a confederated Europe, and Russia's future position in Eurasia.
While the consequences of these geopolitical evolutions look ominous, the results are not predestined. Good foreign and defense policies will be able to minimize the negatives and even create new security opportunities. This will take good intelligence.
The country still needs a healthy Central Intelligence Agency, and there will be no doubt about it by the end of the century, provided that your article is taken as a wakeup call.
 
GORDON NEGUS
Falls Church, Va., Jan. 3, 1995
 
The writer was executive director, Defense Intelligence Agency, 1986-90.

HEADLINE: A Contract for Our Royalist Congress

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Republicans in Congress have put forward a "Contract With America." I propose a three-item "contract" that all members of Congress, both houses, should adopt. 
 (1) Every March the Internal Revenue Service prepares the tax returns of representatives and senators. We taxpayers pay for this privilege, which should be abolished. Congress needs to be subjected to what we taxpayers are put through. Then it might simplify the process.
(2) Congress does not participate in Social Security like the rest of us. It has a Federal pension plan, 100 percent inflation-adjusted annually. It should be abolished, with all members placed on Social Security. Only when they and we share a common plan will they become reasonable about changes to the plan.
(3) Congress has its own health insurance plan. Members pay $25 each month for family health insurance. They also have access to government hospitals, for free surgery and other care. We taxpayers pay for this privilege for them too. In this case again, their interests are not those of the rest of the body politic.
The American people have created a royalist class: Congress! Members have exempted themselves from laws that affect our lives, and we have accepted this terrible mistreatment. We deserve something better, and it's time we demanded it.
 
HAROLD F. ROSENBAUM
Stamford, Conn., Jan. 4, 1995

HEADLINE: General Services Nominee Is Criticized

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 7

 BODY:
The man picked by Gov. George E. Pataki to manage New York State's office space and its $2 billion purchasing operation has been doing the same job for five years in Westchester County, where he has been criticized for awarding lucrative leases to Republican contributors.
As general services administrator here, the nominee, Peter W. Delaney, has been accused by both Democratic and Republican county legislators of steering leases for office space that was not always needed to landlords and developers who were political supporters of the Republican County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke. 
 Mr. Delaney, 43, was nominated to be the state's general services commissioner, a $96,000-a-year position, on Dec. 30. He became Westchester's general services administrator in February 1990, making $102,000 a year. He took a leave from the Westchester job in 1993 to run Mr. O'Rourke's re-election campaign.
During his tenure, the county has moved its surrogate's court, appellate courts and public administrator's offices into two floors of a White Plains office building owned by Louis Cappelli, a builder who contributed $10,250 to Mr. O'Rourke's 1993 campaign.
The county also leases a three-story glass-and-steel building known as the Pep'e-Fareri building from a real estate partnership whose principals include John Fareri, who contributed at least $3,000 to Mr. O'Rourke in 1993. A third of that building space has remained unused by the county since it signed the lease in 1991.
As a result of such leases, say critics like Katherine S. Carsky, a Republican county legislator, the county's office space has doubled while its work force has stayed about the same. In 1985, the county owned or leased 437,222 square feet of office space for 4,809 workers. This year it is expected to have 978,043 square feet, while its work force has grown only slightly, to 5,067.
In choosing Mr. Delaney, Mr. Pataki has picked someone he has known since the mid-1980's and has done business with. In 1989, Mr. Delaney used Mr. Pataki to broker a real estate deal that earned Mr. Pataki the bulk of a $40,000 broker's fee.
Zenia Mucha, director of communications for Governor Pataki, said Mr. Delaney had saved Westchester "millions of dollars through automation" and would fulfill Mr. Pataki's goal of shrinking government.
Asked the administration's position on the awarding of leases to contributors, Ms. Mucha said: "Our understanding is they were given to people who offered the best price for the best product. Just because someone is involved in civic affairs and supports candidates should not automatically exclude them from conducting a business."
Mr. Delaney's appointment must be confirmed by the Republican-dominated State Senate.
He has been the head of a Westchester agency that operates almost 1 million square feet of office space and procures $55 million of equipment and supplies a year for the county. He has served as campaign manager for Mr. O'Rourke twice, in 1989 and 1993.
In an interview, Mr. Delaney denied favoring Republican contributors. "Most of your big landlords and developers give to both sides," he said, adding that the county had just as often rejected buildings owned by other large contributors. He also noted that Mr. Fareri gave his contribution two years after the county began leasing the Pep'e-Fareri building.
He acknowledged that the county's leased space had mushroomed, but said that was because the work force grew during the 1980's. "There were four people in a cubicle meant for one, on top of each other, talking over each other on the phone," he said. "In the past few years, the county has been cutting its work force and so it has had to consolidate some of its office space as well."
Stephen P. Tenore, the chairman of the County Legislature and a Republican, has frequently tangled with Mr. O'Rourke and Mr. Delaney on their leasing practices. He has criticized them for leasing space like the Pep'e-Fareri building in suburban areas like Hawthorne, saying those leases did little to enhance the downtowns of struggling small cities like New Rochelle and Yonkers. "There clearly seems to be a pattern formed," Mr. Tenore said. "When we look to revitalizing the downtown of our inner cities with office space, it's obvious that the Pep'e-Fareri building doesn't fit."
No other building has been as controversial as the Pep'e-Fareri building, which the county leased in 1991 from Mr. Fareri and his partners as a new home for offices and data-processing equipment. About 700 workers from the parks, health and general services departments have been moved there. Yet the data center floor remains vacant, and part of a second floor is vacant as well. Ms. Carsky, the Republican legislator representing parts of Greenburgh, Yonkers and Scarsdale, contends the county wasted $1 million last year alone on the vacant space.
When the lease was negotiated, a bipartisan coalition in the 17-member County Legislature questioned whether the move was necessary and suggested it was a bailout of a faltering office building owned by an influential landlord. But the legislators did not get to vote on the lease. Mr. Delaney structured the rental contract as a 5-year lease with three options to renew for a total of 15 additional years. The legislature has the right to to vote only on leases longer than five years.
The lease was approved by the three-member Board of Acquisitions and Contracts, on which Mr. O'Rourke controls two of the three votes.
Mr. Tenore, the legislature's chairman, Ms. Carsky and others accused Mr. Delaney of circumventing the legislature, saying he had effectively created a 20-year lease. The legislators then refused to approve bonds to refurbish the building, and so the computers remain in the aging county office building in White Plains. Thus, Mr. Delaney said, the Legislature is responsible for the building's vacancies.
Mr. Delaney argued the Pep'e-Fareri building was needed. It has the power capacity to support the county's computers, which now occasionally shut down or slow down, he said. And, he added, it is in the line of sight of the county's radio tower, allowing for microwave communications among the county's scattered computers rather than expensive telephone lines.
He acknowledged that he had tried to avoid a vote by the Legislature on the lease.
"Quite frankly, we were trying to get things done," he said. "We knew we needed 12 votes to pass the leases. Quite frankly, we weren't sure we would have it."
"They put us between a rock and a hard place," he added.
He also accused Mr. Tenore of profiting from the opposition to leasing the building. Mr. Tenore, he said, pressured the county to move employees in the county's environmental facilities department to Mr. Tenore's home turf, New Rochelle, rather than to Hawthorne. Indeed, he said, the New Rochelle building chosen was one whose sale was brokered by a real estate agency for which Mr. Tenore is an agent.
Mr. Tenore said the sale had been made years before the county considered leasing space in the building and that no brokerage fee had been paid.
"He's a wheeler-dealer, who would do good for a private company," Mr. Tenore said of Mr. Delaney. "Some of his actions are not appropriate to government. "
Mr. Delaney says that in his tenure as head of general services the county has developed a new system of electronic purchasing that saves more than $200,000 a year and has bought new equipment that has saved $1.4 million in maintenance costs. He says he has cut the county's automobile fleet for commissioners and other top employees from 176 to 93 and has shopped around for a far cheaper long-distance telephone company.
Mr. Delaney, a broad-shouldered, 6-foot-3 figure with a goatee, is known for shrewd political instincts that were honed as the son of the longtime county sheriff. He was born in the Bronx and spent his teen-age years in Westchester, where his father, Thomas J. Delaney, was first Mount Vernon's police commissioner and then, from 1973 to 1983, the county's elected sheriff. Mr. Delaney worked in his father's campaigns.
He attended Iona College, where he obtained a degree in finance, and later invested in three Baskin-Robbins franchises. He got his start in Westchester County government as an economic development specialist. In 1988, Mr. O'Rourke recruited him to run the County Center. The next year, Mr. O'Rourke asked him to run his re-election campaign and, with his profits from the ice cream franchises, he decided to invest in real estate.
That year, Mr. Delaney and a group of partners paid $1 million to buy 47 vacant acres in Peekskill that once belonged to an Episcopal girl's school. Mr. Pataki, who ran a Peekskill law firm at the time and was that city's former mayor, brokered the deal, receiving the bulk of a $40,000 fee. Mr. Delaney says it was also Mr. Pataki who persuaded him to move to Peekskill and buy a new town house condominium there.
The two have known each other since the mid-1980's. In early December, after attending the tree-lighting ceremony at Rockefeller Center together, they ate dinner nearby at the DeGrezia Restaurant and Mr. Pataki offered him the job as state commissioner.
Mr. Delaney believes his numerous business ventures have prepared him for his new job.
"When you own four or five different businesses, you learn how to manage something, how to get a bottom-line deal," he said. "You learn how to negotiate, how to deal with people. You get a sixth sense for doing this."
