HEADLINE: Texas Senator Gets Nod in Louisiana Republican Straw Poll

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 7

 BODY:
Senator Phil Gramm of Texas overwhelmingly won a Presidential popularity poll today among Louisiana Republicans that may be more a testament to his letter-writing abilities than a reflection of his prospects for the White House in 1996.
Mr. Gramm received 902 votes to 150 for his nearest rival, Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator. None of the others had more than 100 votes. 
 In the larger political scheme, the extremely early Presidential preferences of Republicans in Louisiana -- a state long been dominated by Democratic politics -- is virtually meaningless. More than anything else, it was a way for the state party to attract national attention and raise money at a state convention that would otherwise go unnoticed.
Still, these straw polls have become a rite of passage and can give a candidate aura of momentum. So this, the first of about a half-dozen such events in coming months, set off early jockeying among Republican contenders, most of whom are preparing their official announcements or are in the final throes of deciding whether to run.
One who unquestionably took today's contest seriously was Mr. Gramm, who was so determined to win the support of delegates at the Louisiana Republican Party convention here, in his home region, that he inundated the 1,700 delegates with as many as a half-dozen cards and letters and phone calls from his supporters.
He also prevailed on state party officials to schedule him as the keynote speaker immediately before the voting began and persuaded them to let Senator John McCain of Arizona give a speech that included a plug for the Texas Senator.
Though Jim Norris, a banker from Monroe, backed Mr. Gramm today, he rolled his eyes at the notion of the poll and said he might well vote for someone else in the primary here more than a year from now.
"It's like figuring out who I'm going to vote for in 2040," he said. "It has nothing to do with anything."
John Zmirak, a business writer and a delegate, also expressed mock disbelief at his fellow Republicans for staging the poll. "Come on," he said. "Louisiana Republicans? To use this as the compass to point the country? It's a media gimmick."
Mr. Gramm saw more at stake here than that. "Am I starting to measure the drapes at the White House?" he asked after the votes were tallied. No, but he added, "There's one thing that can't be disputed. We won the first battle in this long war."
Knowing that Mr. Gramm had the edge, former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, another Presidential hopeful, made a point of saying that he was not even trying to compete.
Mr. Alexander, who came in third, with 58 votes, flew to Baton Rouge to speak at a state party dinner on Friday night but did not stay to woo supporters today. "In that contest, I'm not competing," he said of the straw poll. "I have other things to do."
Even so, Mr. Alexander did not want to lose too badly. So he, too, sent a letter out to delegates, though not on Mr. Gramm's grand scale.
Mr. Buchanan was also there and began attacking the Republican field with the same brand of sharp-tongued comments that bruised President George Bush during the 1992 primaries.
Making it plain that he sees himself as the most qualified prospective candidate, Mr. Buchanan said of Mr. Gramm: "I was going to summits with Richard Nixon when some of those guys were still teaching economics at Texas A&M." Mr. Buchanan said he was far from deciding about running, but his supporters were passing out freshly minted "Buchanan '96" buttons.
Some better known contenders, most notably Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate majority leader, sat out the event, although at least one Dole operative was spotted making the rounds here. The Senator drew 28 votes.
Jack F. Kemp, the former Housing Secretary, and Alan Keyes, a former State Department official, each drew 36 votes. Former Vice President Dan Quayle received 17 votes, and six others in the contest drew fewer than 10 each.
This convention attracted Republicans of all stripes, including David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klansman who won national attention for his unsuccessful bids for statewide office. Mr. Duke was milling about at a reception for Mr. Buchanan.
"I'm going to vote for him," Mr. Duke said. "He's the most conservative of the lot."

HEADLINE: A.& S. Layoffs Prompt Worry in Brooklyn

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
One by one, the great Brooklyn institutions seem to evaporate -- the Dodgers, the breweries, Lundy's Restaurant -- but many said the latest loss seemed particularly cruel.
A.& S., the department store chain, will no longer be based in Brooklyn, although it will keep its flagship store there, the chain's new owners said on Friday. Neighboring businesses in downtown Brooklyn said they would be hurt by the loss of 900 jobs, most of them white collar. 
 Shoppers in the A.& S. store in the chain's headquarters building on Fulton Street worried a favorite haunt would somehow change. Other Brooklyn A.& S. employees fretted that they would be next.
"A lot of people are upset, very upset," said Louis Robles, a security officer, who says he began worrying about the store's future when it skipped putting up a Christmas tree and hiring a Santa Claus this Christmas season.
Others say it is inconceivable that the owner of the chain, Federated Department Stores Inc., would close a store often called one of A.& S.'s biggest sellers.
On Friday, Federated announced that it was laying off 650 employees in the executive offices of A.& S. Those laid off, who range from advertising executives to secretaries, are housed in the same downtown Brooklyn building as the company's flagship department store.
Another 250 employees will be transferred to Macy's corporate offices at Herald Square in Manhattan. Federated, which is based in Cincinnati and has owned A.& S. since the 1930's, acquired R.H. Macy & Company last month, rescuing it from bankruptcy.
The move on Friday was not a surprise, but had been mentioned in bankruptcy papers filed in conjunction with Federated's acquisition. "Short-term cutbacks are a necessary part of facilitating a successful merger," said Hal Kahn, chairman of Macy's East, the division that oversees A.& S.
An immediate impact will be on local businesses whose customers include the departing employees. Though many had not heard the news until told by a reporter, employees of record stores, electronic outlets and drug stores all expected their businesses to suffer. Restaurant owners and managers seemed to feel particularly vulnerable.
"This makes it a more difficult business environment," said Peter Aschkenasy, owner of the landmark Gage & Tollner restaurant. He said four of his tables were regularly filled at lunchtime with A.& S. executives, from lawyers to fashion buyers. "I have the sense that Brooklyn didn't work hard enough to keep it."
At the Express Stop, a fast-food restaurant next to A.& S., the owner, Jimmy Salis, said: "This is bad news. Business will come down."
And two and half blocks away at 320 Atlantic Avenue, Lucille Gutierrez, the manager of Antic Restaurant, said she expected lunch crowds to dry up at the eatery, which specializes in lower-priced California and Mediterranean cuisine.
"We get the whole advertising department and a lot of buyers," she said. "These people come to our restaurant four days a week."
An A.& S. store supervisor who asked not to be identified characterized the store -- which moved to its current location in 1883, the year the Brooklyn Bridge opened -- as the economic engine driving the Fulton Mall and neighboring areas.
"This is the money store," he said. "If this thing closes down, everything closes. Forget the mall, forget the little stores, forget Brooklyn."
He also heatedly claimed to resent the possibility of the store's name being changed to Macy's, which has been the subject of much speculation in local newspapers.
"It's not right," he said. "Macy's went broke. A.& S. wasn't broke."
At the store yesterday, customers expressed their devotion. "It's the largest store we have left in Brooklyn -- all the rest are little boutiques," said a teacher who lives in the Flatlands section who would not give his full name. He listed the department stores he has seen close on Fulton Street: May's, Nam's, Korvette's, Martin's.
"I love A.& S.," said Sarah Famiglietta, who said she had come once a week all her life, except for the several years her family lived in Massachusetts. Then, she would make special trips to the Brooklyn A.& S.
"I'd feel terrible if A.& S. were gone," she said, carrying a bag with pajamas for her pregnant daughter to take to the hospital. "I couldn't shop in any other store."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I'd feel terrible if A.& S. were gone," said Sarah Famiglietta, with her husband, Richard, after learning yesterday that the chain would no longer be based in Brooklyn. "I couldn't shop in any other store." (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Congressional Memo;
73 Mr. Smiths, of the G.O.P., Go to Washington

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
The seven House Republicans chosen by their party to summarize the accomplishments of the opening week of the 104th Congress for the press on Friday had a grand combined total of about 14 days in office. They had succeeded lawmakers with a combined total of 110 years in office. Some reporters had to struggle for the freshmen's names, and the freshmen themselves seemed a little unsure about news conference protocol.
But they had their message down, and they had their huge blowup of the "Contract With America," the Republican campaign manifesto. And they were able to check off some items, changes in House rules accomplished and delivered "on behalf of average people," in the words of Representative Gil Gutknecht, a freshman from Minnesota. They were, in short, on their way to "a new day in American politics," as Representative Sue Myrick of North Carolina declared. 
 And then they bustled off to their committee meetings, to change America some more.
There were many moments like that one this week, as the outsiders came inside: the large, feisty Republican freshman class of 1994, sworn into an institution they had campaigned so hard against -- and enjoying it, just a little, albeit cautiously, like a teetotaler at a wine tasting.
"Our class is here to ask why," said Representative Steve Largent of Oklahoma, a former professional football player, one of many Republican freshmen with unconventional backgrounds. "Why do we have to do that? Why do we have to pay that much? Why can't we cut that, why can't we reduce that?"
Virtually every new member comes to the House of Representatives vowing to change things and make a difference; in this, the class of 73 Republican freshmen is not unusual. But freshmen usually run up against the muffling power of seniority, 435 competing agendas and the gradual assimilation of a seductive institution.
This class, however, has the potential to leave its mark on the House and the Government at large as few other classes have, in the view of many analysts, who compare it to the big post-Watergate class of Democrats that shook up Congress in the 1970's.
It is not simply the presence of giant-killers like Representative George Nethercutt, who toppled Speaker Thomas S. Foley on Election Day, and the absence of the giants they disposed of. It is a combination of their youth, their conservatism, their zeal to restructure a Congress that so many ran against as fat, flawed and out of touch.
Representative Dick Chrysler, freshman Republican from Michigan, entered the House chamber this week alongside Representative Zach Wamp, freshman Republican from Tennessee. Mr. Wamp's campaign slogan had been "Wamp Congress," and Mr. Chrysler told him as they entered the House on that historic day, "You're absolutely the appropriate guy to walk into Congress with."
Most significant of all, these freshmen have been given extraordinary power and visibility by the Republican leadership, which clearly sees them as a new and appealing face for the party. The House Rules Committee has its first Republican freshman since 1915, the Ways and Means Committee its first Republican newcomers since George Bush in 1967.
"We view them not as an obstacle, as freshmen are sometimes viewed, but as resources," said Representative Bill Paxon of New York, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee. "They are the face of the Congress we want the people to see: fresh, energetic, diverse."
They are different. Half of them have never held elective office before, in striking contrast to the House as a whole, two-thirds of whose members held elective office before coming to Congress. Many of them are proudly un-political, which suits party strategists just fine in an era when "career politician" is an epithet.
"They don't look like politicians, and they don't sound like politicians," said Frank Luntz, a pollster and adviser to the House Republican leadership, who argues that these freshmen can be a particularly powerful link to independent-minded Perot voters. "Every day I get on my knees and thank God they were not traditional politicians."
Even many of those with past political careers, like Representative Linda Smith, a former State Senator from Washington, rode the wave of grass-roots politics; she won her primary on a write-in.
Not surprisingly, these freshmen seemed achingly sensitive to the dangers of "going Washington" even as they wandered somewhat dazzled through the halls of the Capitol this week. They say they are just passing through on the people's business, or, as Representative J. D. Hayworth, a former sportscaster from Arizona, put it, "I don't want to make the House a home." Representative Roger Wicker of Mississippi, who holds the seat held for 53 years by Jamie L. Whitten, said he hoped to be "somewhere" in 53 years, but not in Congress.
Many of them make a point of keeping their families (i.e., spiritual roots) back in the district. "I want to be in Kansas as much as possible so I can be more like that environment than this," said Representative Sam Brownback, a freshman from Topeka.
These freshmen stand out in another way: They have a clear policy agenda in the "Contract With America," a platform on issues from tax cuts to welfare restructuring to a constitutional amendment that would require a balanced budget. Many Democrats see the contract as nothing more than a poll-driven campaign tool, but to many of the Republican freshmen it is a political bible. Representative Jon Christensen, a 31-year-old insurance agent from Omaha, whipped a laminated copy of it from his suit jacket as he talked about his mission here in Congress.
"I'm a conservative's conservative," Mr. Christensen said. "I don't believe government has the answer to people's problems. I believe government has gotten too big, too expensive, and we need to cut it down."
Their mistrust of government is fundamental and, in many ways, their animating force. Some analysts see them as Reagan's children, noting that a big chunk of them came of age during the glory years of Ronald Reagan's Presidency. Kate O'Beirne, vice president of the conservative Heritage Foundation, said, "There are far more Reagan Republicans in Washington now than there were during the Reagan years."
Mrs. O'Beirne, whose organization helped conduct an orientation for the Republican freshmen, added: "They question all of Washington's assumptions. We had a briefing on reform of the Congressional pension system, and the first question was, 'Why are there Congressional pensions?' "
In fact, some analysts think that there will be times when the Republican freshmen are out in front of their Republican colleagues, that their ideological fervor will make them more eager to cut, more intent on curbing Congressional perquisites and more adamant about term limits. "When and if the leadership blinks," Mrs. O'Beirne said, "whether it's on cutting personal staff or potentially on term limits, the freshman class will go on point."
So far the leadership -- notably Speaker Newt Gingrich and Dick Armey, the majority leader -- have taken pains to cultivate the freshmen, aides say. "There's a strong synthesis between the freshmen and the sophomores and the House Republican leadership," said Ed Gillespie, spokesman for Mr. Armey. "Newt and Armey have very strong ties to the freshmen. They campaigned in more than 100 districts."
For now, all is undiluted promise for the class of '94, so undiluted, in fact, that some of their seniors worry a little. "The only concern I have is I think they're so euphoric about the opportunity to make the changes Republicans have always wanted to make that they haven't quite realized, or maybe don't quite believe, that there's going to be a reaction in the country," said former Representative Vin Weber, now a co-director of the conservative group Empower America.
Mr. Weber came to Congress with the Reagan Republican class of 1980. He recalls the post-budget-cut, mid-recession elections of 1982, when the party lost 26 seats.
This freshman class may change in other ways. The House from the inside can look very different from the abstract institution viewed from the campaign trail. Mr. Hayworth, for example, said he was struck by the intimacy of the place. "The cameras don't do it justice," the Arizona freshman said, "in letting people know how intimate a chamber it is. And in spite of the columnists' comments about the lack of comity and civility, I have found the opposite to be true."
Mr. Nethercutt, the victor over Speaker Foley at the polls, had lunch with him not long ago in a gracious coda to the signature campaign of an anti-Congress year. Mr. Foley told the freshman Republican that he envied him his first term in Congress, when simply walking onto the floor would be a thrill.
Mr. Nethercutt said he remembered that conversation when he entered the House this week. He looked up at his wife and daughter in the gallery, tried to absorb a scene that seemed so improbable just six months ago and decided that Mr. Foley had been right.
The class of '94, in other words, might even learn to love Congress a little.

HEADLINE: Right Double-Cross?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
John Ward's response to "A Fond Farewell to Big Government" (Letters, Dec. 11; At Work, Nov. 13) is beyond even the incredible standards of the ridiculous established by economists and M.B.A.'s. Now that protectionism is associated with unions' trying to save jobs, history is revised to blame -- of all things -- the Smoot Hawley Tariff for the Great Depression! Greed, speculation on margin and general stupidity apparently had nothing to do with it. 
 Mr. Ward goes on about how growth since the Depression was made possible by "wealth creators" whose efforts the Government redistributed. Anyone can create goods and services. What is difficult is creating customers to make those "wealth creators" rich. This was done via programs defined as National Defense.
The big benefit of most military spending is the creation of purchasing power without creating anything to compete for customers. With the passing of the "Evil Empire," we are experiencing readjustments.
The ignorance and arrogance that turns people off is not that of government but of businesses that take customers for granted until the Japanese show them how badly they are being ripped off. The only thing those who voted for Rush Limbaugh proved is that they don't understand the parable of Lucy and the Football.
 
LEE GOELLER
Haddonfield, N.J., Dec. 13

HEADLINE: The World According to Channel One

BYLINE: By ANDY MEISLER 

 BODY:
It is the highest-profile -- one might even say most glamorous -- controversy in American education. For the past five years, teachers, business executives, politicians and editorial writers have been fiercely debating the merits of Channel One, the commercial-studded classroom news show founded by entrepreneur Christopher Whittle.
Is it immoral to beam advertising to captive middle-school and high-school students? Or are two minutes of television ads a small price to pay for 10 minutes of news and public affairs programming? Is Channel One's format -- its MTV-esque graphics and fast pace -- anti-teacher, anti-literacy and ultimately anti-education? Or is it the best way to capture the attention of media-saturated teenagers? 
 And what about Mr. Whittle, who was recently forced to sell most of his communications empire, including Channel One, for a fire-sale price? Can we entrust even part of our kids' education to a man who has apparently frittered away most of his working capital on private jets, white-elephant office buildings and custom-built sock drawers lined with hand-tooled leather?
These are fine questions with which to engage adult minds. The view from educational Ground Zero, however, is quite a bit different.
Or so it seems after a week spent watching Channel One inside a "typical" classroom. Pliny Haskell Junior High, in the blue-collar Los Angeles suburb of Cerritos, Calif., is home to more than 600 seventh and eighth graders and two dozen teachers.
At Haskell -- a collection of one-story structures clustered near a freeway, in a neighborhood of strip malls and aged stucco-and-wood houses -- anything seen even vaguely as a resource is automatically thrown into the endless task of stimulating classroom discussion. And that includes Channel One.
The deal offered to Haskell is the standard one: In exchange for incorporating Channel One into its curriculum, the school received a satellite dish, a videocassette recorder and a closed-circuit television system featuring 19-in. Magnavox sets in each classroom.
The school has been hooked up to Channel One since tk, tk. Below, a week on the receiving end of this controversial connection.
 
Monday, Nov. 14
Let Your Smile Be Your Umbrella, reads the message of the day on the school signpost, as, shortly after 7:00 A. M., a line of mostly older-model cars begins dropping off students near the front gate.
Fifteen minutes later, Paulette Fuller, Haskell's principal, is in her small office, discussing her school and her students.
"A lot of the problems of society find their way here," says Ms. Fuller, who has worked in the school district for 26 years. "Gangs, drugs in the kids' homes. Physical and emotional abuse. Parents working two or three jobs."
The ethnic makeup of Haskell is roughly 35 percent white, 27 percent Hispanic, 25 percent Asian and 13 percent black. Many of the students are first-generation Americans. Recent budget cuts have meant an end to sports teams and all other afterschool programs. Parents are now being asked to purchase paper and other supplies.
Ms. Fuller says few of her students read a daily newspaper or watch nontabloid news shows on TV. "We like Channel One," she says, firmly. "The benefits greatly outweigh the disadvantages."
"Get the lights, somebody," says John Viculin to his eighth-grade English class. It is 7:45 A. M., the start of the first period of the school day. The task for the week is to have students analyze a short story for plot, theme and point of view. But like most of the other first-period teachers at Haskell, Mr. Viculin -- who has been teaching since 1966 -- must first facilitate the daily Channel One session.
His 23 students burrow into their sweatshirts and parkas in the still-chilly classroom.
The TV set is mounted atop the front chalkboard. Seated at desks facing the center of the classroom, most of the eighth graders peer sideways and upwards in the semi-darkness. Several lay their heads down and nap; a few doodle or finish their homework. (At Haskell, watching Channel One is optional. Students are not tested on it. And two minutes, the amount of commercial time in each program, has been added to the school day.)
Tape-delayed from its overnight satellite transmission, Channel One is broadcast schoolwide at the same time each day. It begins today, as it does every day, with a hand-drawn Channel One logo chosen from student submissions. Next, a few moments of rock music and music video-style graphics. Then a quotation flashes on the screen.
" 'Very big, China' -- Noel Coward," hangs above our heads momentarily.
Dissolve to Lisa Ling and Rawley Valverde, two casually dressed Twentyish anchors, in the game room-like Channel One news set.
Mr. Valverde, talking forcefully and seriously -- the Channel One anchor style -- reports briefly on President Clinton's trip to an Asian Pacific economic summit in Manila. Cut to: commercials for M&M candies and Nintendo video games. A few snickers from the classroom -- both commercials' a-bit-too-slick hipness is obvious. Then back to Ms. Ling, who introduces a mini-documentary she produced and taped in China last summer.
The report explains how the Chinese government tries to control the flow of information about its country and the real state of its economy. And Ms. Ling describes how her government escort steers her into filming only at tourist sites and atypical "typical" homes and factories. Excitedly, she holds up the small video camera she used as she escaped from scrutiny and interviewed "real" Chinese citizens.
There follow a few hesitant criticisms of government repression by unmonitored Chinese citizens, then some furtive shots of primitive-looking housing areas, farms and factories. The China report is to continue throughout the week.
"Okay!" says the grayhaired, energetic John Viculin, springing out of his seat as the picture fades and the lights go up. He pulls down a roll-up map of the world.
"Where did Channel One take us today?" he asks.
While his classmates stretch and rub their eyes, a volunteer, Billy, walks to the front and points successfully to China.
"Right! Thank you! Now, why should all of us here in California care about what goes on in China?"
"Because they can blow us up with nuclear weapons?" says Ben, from his seat near the exit.
"Trade?" arises weakly from a confused babble at the other side of the classroom.
" 'Cause they don't have the rights we do?" offers one of the girls, Gaby. "Because they can't say nothing bad about the government?"
"Yes, but why should we care?" counters their teacher.
A lively but somewhat scattered discussion ensues, touching on repression in Haiti, the virtue of obeying questionable government regulations and the true national origin of Toyotas.
After a few more minutes, Mr. Viculin glances at the clock and takes a valiant stab at wrapping things up.
"All right. Let's think about one of the reasons people traveled across the Atlantic to start this country."
Silence.
"Why do we study history?"
Nothing.
"If people are afraid to speak out, what will eventually happen?"
One of the girls sitting near the front, Carolina, cocks an eyebrow skeptically. "Like, is there a specific answer to that question?" she says.
 
Tuesday, Nov. 15
The classroom is cold again; the whispered conversations as the lights go down are in both English and Spanish.
The quote of the day is drawn from Will and Ariel Durant: "Only a fool would try to compress a hundred centuries in a hundred pages of hazardous conclusions. We proceed."
"Huh?" says a voice in the darkness, answered by giggles.
The commercials: pitches for Pepsi and pimple cream. Rawley Valverde is gone, replaced by an equally earnest young anchorman, Kris Osborne.
The main feature of today's broadcast is another installment of Lisa Ling's China project. Wearing a Mao jacket and cap, Ms. Ling scrolls briskly through the modern history of China -- emphasizing its heritage of political repression, the legacy of the 1989 Tianamen Square rebellion, the absence of many of the freedoms Americans enjoy. Many of the points she makes echo the previous day's; a few more heads than before droop to the desktops.
Mr. Viculin, who has been taking notes, kickstarts the discussion.
"What would you say is Lisa's view of China?"
"Negative," says Ben.
"Why?"
"Because they've got nuclear weapons, and they can blow us up."
After the shouts and laughter die down, Mr. Viculin proposes that perhaps, just perhaps, in the point--of-view department, Lisa Ling's Chinese-American heritage makes her extra-sensitive to the differences between her own country and her ancestral one. It is a provocative concept, and for a few seconds the silence crackles.
 
Wednesday, Nov. 16
The quote is from Thomas Jefferson, the commercials for chewing gum, AT&T and a Space Invaders video game. The program includes segments on political repression in Indonesia, the progress of Hurricane Gordon, and the conservative push to legalize school prayer.
Is it the observer's imagination, or are the students falling into a cathode-ray trance state more quickly as the week goes on? Today, there is no change of expression when the program shifts from news to commercials and back again.
"Okay. Form groups of three and brainstorm," says Mr. Viculin. "List the three stories on today's program and put a star next to the one you think is most important."
After huddled discussions and some quickly-suppressed cross-classroom name-calling, the teams report in, voting almost unanimously for Gordon.
Mr. Viculin smiles. "Well, I had the hurricane last, with school prayer first," he muses. "Maybe I was up in the clouds."
 
Thursday, Nov. 17
Even though John Viculin spreads his attentions equally, it's obvious that some of his students are less attuned to his efforts than others. Throughout the week, heads hit the desk even when the lights are up. Given on-the-spot writing assignments, some of his students in first period screw up their faces scornfully and produce barely a line, while their classmates scribble eagerly. During lulls, snatches of gang slang and attitude float by.
"Schoolboy," mutters a girl, with chilling disdain, when one of her male counterparts volunteers to answer a question.
The TV quote today is by Pearl S. Buck: "Nothing and no one can destroy the Chinese people. They are relentless survivors. They are the oldest civilized people on earth." Magnavox: "We make technology people want."
On her segment this morning, Lisa Ling prompts a laugh from the class by showing the patrons of a new Chinese disco dancing to fossilized rock music. Later. she smuggles a fellow exchange student into her Beijing hotel room for an unmonitored interview. As they start taping, the phone rings: It is Mr Young, her government minder, asking if he can come up for a visit her.
Could her hotel room be bugged, she wonders? Hooked on drama, for just a second, we wonder also.
 
Friday, Nov. 18
After a quote that flies by too fast and a brief report on the school prayer controversy, Lisa Ling wraps things up with a skeptical visit to a suspiciously prosperous Chinese farm. Then, a stealthy meeting with some construction workers so poor that they have to sleep at the job site.
The picture fades.
'I'm going to try something,' says Mr. Viculin. "Put your heads down on the table. Close your eyes. Think about a blessing you can count on. Something in your life you value. Okay, head up. What did you think about?"
"This is about the prayer thing, right?" says Ben.
'Hey! You can't say prayers in school!" says Carolina.
"It's okay if they don't announce it over the loudspeakers," says Ben, drawing his own legal conclusions.
A lively discussion breaks out. Mr. Viculin beams.
"How do we know what's right or wrong?' says a boy, Jason, as both sides weigh in. "That's why people go to court."
Carving out a few minutes of class time, Mr. Viculin turns the class over to the visiting reporter for his questions.
What do the kids think of Channel One?
"It's great."
"It's b-o-o-o-oring."
(Simultaneous shout): "The best time to do homework!"
Do the commercials get you to want things you wouldn't otherwise?
"Yes!"
"No!"
"Maybe!"
How many think that Haskell Junior High should keep using Channel One?
The great majority thrust their hands upward. Only two students vote no. A few kids glance around at their classmates, surprised at the near unanimity, and giggle nervously. Their teacher calls for attention, and the class moves on.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 709 words

HEADLINE: Anybody Home?

 BODY:
The Democrats are in the throes of an advice crisis. For once, there is a shortage of people eager to tell the President exactly what he needs to do. Meanwhile, the dangerous White House public-relations team continues to display its gift for feckless hairsplitting (the Hilton Head flyover) and humiliating imagery (the President posing with two terminally lame ducks).
Well, things do look bad for the Razorback Renaissance. Pretty soon, a bulb will have to blink on over Bill Clinton's head or they can turn the lights out at the re-elect office. But with time and discipline, Mr. Clinton could again become a factor in shaping the national policy agenda that was his alone to write only two years ago. 
 He has a couple of things working for him. One, the old Democratic crustaceans are gone. Better a Dick Gephardt trying to bushwhack you than a Tom Foley saying "Don't worry, Boss." Second, House Speaker Newt Gingrich remains slightly out of control. His tarmac sermonette on the need for journalistic cheerleading is only the latest example of a Gantryesque conviction that he has been sworn in as maximum-leader-in-charge-of-all-known-thought. The betting here is still that the voluble Georgian will not self-destruct, but he is creating an opening for Mr. Clinton to look large, calm and -- yes, say it out loud all you senior White House aides -- even Presidential.
Presidents, of course, have programs, convictions and an overarching vision. Any Clinton comeback must start with a strategy for confronting this President's unique double-barreled credibility problem. The American people do not believe what Mr. Clinton says. In addition, they do not believe he knows what he believes. Homely vows about fighting until the last dog, or duck, dies will not fix this malady. What is needed is an attainable set of proposals, quickly embodied in streamlined legislation, that flow from the values upon which Mr. Clinton campaigned. Here's a starter kit:
1. Propose simplified health-care reform that sets universal coverage as a national goal, ends cherry-picking by insurers but -- bowing to political realities -- immediately subsidizes coverage only for low-income children and pregnant women.
2. Offer tough, but humane, welfare reform that recognizes the fact that a majority of Americans oppose Mr. Gingrich's punitive two-years-andout rule.
3. Really push, this time, for a campaign reform bill that curbs PAC's and outlaws the lobbyist gifts that have just been endorsed by the new Republican majority.
4. Outsmart the Republicans on the politics of a bad idea by sticking to plans to target tax cuts on families making less than $75,000 a year. That rewards the workers who elected Mr. Clinton, rather than the affluent beneficiaries of the Gingrich plan.
5. Oppose the balanced-budget amendment as a sham and, as an alternative, support abolition of the industrial and agricultural subsidies now costing taxpayers $225 billion to $250 billion a year. The Democratic Leadership Council believes that Mr. Clinton should challenge the Republicans to whack these subsidies by $50 billion in the new budget.
Such steps would enable Mr. Clinton to make the embracing speeches he now lacks the political authority to deliver. He is, after all, still a better orator than Newt Gingrich, and once, not long ago, he had a better message. But right now the public sees the Democrats as a husk, a party ready for a long redefinitional agony like the one that consumed the British Labor Party for over a decade.
The Bill Clinton of 1992 could explain why America needs a Democratic Party. He described it as a party that invests in people, not corporations. He described a modernized party that responds to economic change by re-educating workers and battling special interests instead of warring on the poor.
In 1995, a weaker Bill Clinton faces a harder task. He must define a valid role for government to a people angry at government and tired of him. In other words, he is up against what George Bush inelegantly called the vision thing. Lack of a cohesive vision defeated Mr. Bush in 1992, and it can do the same for Mr. Clinton in 1996 unless he gets moving. An opportunity to do so still exists, but the moment is fleeting.

HEADLINE: We Still Need C.I.A., but It Needs to Change;
Some Kind of Analysis

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Dec. 29 front-page news analysis on the Central Intelligence Agency's failings omits one that had tremendous repercussions on the United States and on the world. 
 You state that "throughout the cold war, the mission of the C.I.A. was clear," adding, "the Soviet Union was the 'target.' " You describe a concentrated effort to measure the Soviet military buildup. We have since learned that the size of this so-called buildup was grossly overestimated by the agency, resulting in an ever-escalating arms race, especially in nuclear weapons, at a cost of billions of dollars.
As has since been disclosed, it was the United States that led the development of newer and deadlier nuclear weapons, forcing the Soviet Union to respond to these threats from without and leading to proliferation in many other countries.
The result is still being felt in countless ways.
We have yet to come up with any practical means of disposing of dangerous nuclear wastes. Storage is deteriorating, adding to the danger.
There is great danger of nuclear materials that remain in the former Soviet Union will get into the hands of renegade countries or terrorists.
The economic cost has been felt in the tremendous national debt that has had a profound effect on our economy and quality of life. To deal with the budget deficit, programs to help the unemployed, rescue the homeless, improve the cities, provide a decent transportation system, clean up our environment and keep it clean are being slashed from inadequate financing.
With the C.I.A.'s kind of analysis, it makes one wonder why we need that agency at all. We taxpayers deserve better.
 
PAULINE SILVERMAN
Beachwood, Ohio, Jan. 2, 1995

SECTION: Section 1; Page 25; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk; Second Front

HEADLINE: A Small Start At Beachfront On Rockaway

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
Ever since Mayor John V. Lindsay's urban-renewal bulldozers pushed over its crumbling summer cottages in the late 1960's, a vast tract of land in the Arverne section of the Rockaway peninsula has remained desolate, its weeds blowing in the ocean breeze along two miles of some of the best urban beachfront on the East Coast.
For a quarter century, every mayor since Mr. Lindsay has tried to redevelop Arverne, the largest tract of city-owned vacant land in New York. But none has been able to overcome a combination of economic and social problems that have made the 307 acres of Arverne in Queens one of the greatest planning and development challenges in New York City. 
 Now the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is taking its turn at returning the area to life, and typically, its approach is very different from the broad plans of its predecessors.
Rather than prepare a detailed master plan for each of the tract's more than 75 square blocks, the administration wants to start small, proposing 180 two-family town houses on three blocks at the western edge of the tract in the hope of spurring development on the rest. The city would pay for about $ 9 million in street and sewer costs, while private developers would build the market-rate houses with their own financing, possibly beginning next year. The project's modest scale, along with its reliance on private developers for the unsubsidized housing, is an indication of how the administration will try to manage the expensive task of redevelopment at a time when both budgets and political philosophy mandate a sharp decrease in the role of government. While Deborah C. Wright, the city's Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development, says it is not necessarily typical of all of her department's plans, she said Arverne demonstrated how her agency was evolving into a "catalyst" to bring the private sector in contact with public opportunities.
"We're under a lot of pressure here at the city to try to help the private sector create the units, as opposed to us being the engine driving development in the city," said Ms. Wright, who was a member of the New York City Housing Authority in David N. Dinkins's administration. "Every area of operation is shifting to less government in the sense that private actors out there are perfectly capable of doing a lot of what we have historically viewed as our role."
But relying on private developers means that there has to be a profit incentive and a market, and that has proven to be a huge obstacle, due to the size and nature of Arverne.
Over the years, a series of developers has jousted with the tract and walked away in defeat, unable to overcome the city's declining economy and the surrounding neighborhood's blighted reputation. In addition, because the area was formerly dotted with ramshackle bungalows, there are few usable water or sewer mains, adding to a developer's costs.
There have been plans to build casinos, hotels, theme parks and stacks of high-rise public housing on the site. Most recently, in 1991, Oceanview Associates of Manhattan, a partnership led by Forest City Ratner Companies, gave up on a plan to develop all 307 acres with a $ 1.5 billion project of 7,500 apartments, as well as shopping malls, recreation centers and parks. The company said the downturn in the city's real estate market damaged the prospects for the project.
As a result, the city has decided to make just a few blocks available for developers, hoping that the reduced risk will make it easier to entice builders and lenders. The blocks are near the intersection of Beach 74th Street and Rockaway Beach Boulevard. The request for bids is to be made in the spring.
"The strategy is not to just say, sorry, the market is not there for the entire project and not do anything," said Ms. Wright. "Instead, it's an approach of saying, let's get something started. In this portion, we can kick-start some progress."
One of the debates that long held up any progress on the development -- whether to include any subsidized units for low- or moderate-income residents -- has been settled. After residents and politicians said the peninsula already had more than its fair share of public housing units, the city agreed that only full-price housing would attract the kind of residents needed to improve the depressed economy of the Rockaways.
Each of the 180 town houses to be built would cost about $ 210,000, according to Vollmer Associates, the planning consultants hired by the city, and each would also contain a rental unit that would rent for about $ 750. Considering the income that the owner would get from the renter, each buyer would have to earn about $ 60,000 a year to afford a town house, the consultants said in a report given to the city a few weeks ago.
According to figures compiled by the city, there are about 4,000 units of public housing on the peninsula, which is about a quarter of the borough's public housing stock. There are also 6,000 beds in adult homes and nursing homes. Jonathan L. Gaska, district manager of Community Board 14, said the neighborhood convinced the city that was enough.
"We want to bring in working-class, middle-class people," Mr. Gaska said. "Right now, roughly 30 percent of the youth here are under the poverty level, and we want to skew that. Rockaway needs people who will add to the tax base and will spend dollars here."
But will middle-class buyers want to move to an area known for its high-rise public housing projects and vacant land, much of which is likely to remain vacant for some time after the first phase is completed? Some neighborhood residents, such as Lew Simon, are not convinced. Mr. Simon, who runs a local Democratic political club and is a lifelong resident, said the area was too depressed to attract buyers with money and suggested the city build a hotel or resort on the site instead.
The consultant's report, however, predicted that the houses would sell, and proponents of the plan agree, noting that the tract is between two desirable boundaries, the A subway line and the Atlantic Ocean beach, complete with a well-maintained boardwalk.
"That's the kind of housing that sells in this borough as soon as it's built," said Claire Shulman, the Queens Borough President. "They will buy these houses. You have a resort area, an hour from Manhattan, where you don't have to take off early on Friday to get to your beach house. The water is a magnet to draw people there."
Peter Travis, a local developer who was formerly chief operating officer of Forest City Ratner, predicted a strong interest by developers in the project. The housing market is better than it was when Forest City dropped out, he said, and the smaller scale will allow a larger variety of developers to build.
"I think a lot of people in the city would like to live at the beach," said Mr. Travis, managing partner of Washington Square Partners, a firm he said might consider bidding on the project. "And it's a great beach. I've always thought it was one of the great secrets of New York City, that you could take the subway to a beach that's the equivalent of one of the great beaches of the world."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 12, 1995, Thursday

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 16; Column 1; Education Life Supplement

LENGTH: 5400 words

HEADLINE: A Textbook of Virtues

BYLINE: By STEPHEN BATES

 BODY:
Sitting in a circle on the floor, the first graders talked about courage. "It's being nice," a boy said. Jody Colby, the shoft-spoken teacher, reminded him that he had once endured being lost in Toys 'R Us. "That took courage," she said. He nodded eagerly.
 Sarah, a wide-eyed girl with her blond hair in a ponytail, said, "Courage is trying again." 
 "Suppose you fell off your bike," Ms. Colby said.
 "Like I did!" Sarah exclaimed.
 "Would that take courage to get back on?"
 The children chorused "yes."
 Ms. Colby read "Abiyoyo," Pete Seeger's retelling of a South Arican folk tale about outsmarting a monster. At the appropriate points, the children danced and sang while a girl missing a front tooth played the tambourine. Then the teacher asked the children if they had ever been scared of monsters.
 "When it's dark and stuff," Sarah said.
 "I thought there was a big monster," said Mike, "but it was just a doghouse."
 "This car," Kristi said, "it squeaked, and I thought it was a monster coming up the stairs."
 Ben told how he had once spotted a monster at the far end of his bed. He leaned down and seized it, only to discover that "it was my foot!" As he finished the story, he rolled on the floor with laughter.
 Straddling one of the child-sized chairs in the Foster Elementary School classroom, Henry Huffman smiled. Slender, bearded and courtly, he has been, as assistant superintendent of schools in Mount Lebanon, Pa., the moving force behind the district's efforts to teach children about courage and other moral values.
 Dr. Huffman, 50, began crusading for character education in the school system six years ago. There was no precipitating crisis - no drive-by shootings or heroin overdoses roiling this affluent Pittsburgh suburb. Character education was simply something that this former high school English teacher had come to consider important - indeed, inescapable.
 "You cannot avoid dealing with values," he said, just before a visit to Ms. Colby's class. "I can't teach 'Pride and Prejudice' without probing values. Teachers constantly have to deal with values - classroom expectations, school rules. So the question is not will we engage in character education, but how will we?"
 How indeed? School officials across the country are wrestling with this question. About one in five public school districts now offers formal programs in moral education, ranging from modest curriculum add-ons, like an occasional class in ethics, to blueprints for refurbishing the entire schoolhouse culture, like "just communities" in which students help make and enforce school rules. But teaching values begins with defining values, and in many districts, officials are wary. Issues affecting children provoke intense feelings, after all, as do questions of morality. By combining the two, values education - like the simmering struggles over school prayer - has the potential to spark an especially acrimonious and polarizing dispute.
 Here in Mt. Lebanon, the story is still unfolding. Advocates might call Mt. Lebanon's history a textbook example of how to undertake character education (literally: Dr. Huffman has written a book about it).
 But even in a placid, prosperous and fairly homogeneous suburb, a place that seems tailor-made for painless changes in curriculum, dissent and discord have flashed across the politicial landscape. Character education has attracted the attention of critics - experienced, persistent and potentially litigious ones. And it has raised profound questions: Is it the state's role to sculpt character? To teach children to be tolerant? (Tolerant of what, some parents demand to know.) And where are the boundaries of our moral consensus?
 On the bulletin board behind Dr. Huffman's desk is a quotation from Theodore Roosevelt: "To educate a person in mind and not in morals is to education a menace to society." Down the hall in the outer office hangs a cautionary counterpoint to this, and to Dr. Huffman's unswayable optimism: a print of Picasso's Don Quixote.
 To introduce character education to the Mount Lebanon schools, Dr. Huffman didn't closet himself with the works of Plato and Piaget, or plumb the depths of deontology and metaethics. Instead, he concentrated on pragmatic, often bureaucratic, matters. How, he wondered, can teachers, administrators and parents be induced to support a program that focuses on values?
 The answers he came up with - organization and motivation - underlie the how-to book that he wrote for school officials. Published last fall, "Developing a Character Education Program" reads more like a management textbook than an inquiry into morality. It is full of references to strategic planning teams, "transformational leadership" and "executive champion." It quotes not only Aristotle and Spinoza, but also "In Search of Excellence: Lessons from America's Best-Run Companies."
 "One person can't just sit down and write a plan," said Ms. Colby, who served on two of the committees. "With this kind of thing, you have to build consensus the whole time you're doing it."
 In 1991, Dr. Huffman headed a 28-member committee that sought to produce a list of widely shared values - short enough for a student to memorize. The committee, of parents, high-school students, teachers and administrators, came up with more than 40 values, then pruned the list to six "core values," which the district adopted.
 "We believe," the statement says, "that the morally mature person habitually: respects human dignity, demonstrates active responsibility for the welfare for the welfare of others, integrates individual interests and social responsibilities, demonstrates integrity, applies moral principles when making choices and judgments, and seeks peaceful resolution of conflict."
 Committee members discarded several values with potential for controversy. "Respect for life" might have led to disputes over abortion and euthanasia, "and there was pretty quick agreement that we didn't need to head in that direction," Dr. Huffman recalled.
 "Respect for the environment" was dropped, too, because ecology activists and industrialists could disagree about its meaning. And "there was an understanding that we had to stay away from the 'R' word and things closely related to it," Dr. Huffman said, referring to religion.
 Next, they had to inject the values into the district's curriculum. For the elementary grades, Mount Lebanon chose a series of books produced by the Heartwood Institute in the nearby suburb of Wexfrord. Heartwood is a nonprofit organization founded by Eleanore Childs, a criminal defense attorney who felt that many fo her clients didn't seem to grasp basic moral concepts. Starting in 1987, Ms. Childs, who describes herself as "a remnant of the Sixties," worked with three longtime elementary educators to develop a curriculum that uses already published illustrated books, such as "Abiyoyo," as the bases for classroom discussions and activities. The books center around honesty and love. By featuring stories from different parts of the world, Heartwood's books also aim to promote multicultural understanding.
 An advantage of using the Heartwood books is that they do not demand any leap into the pedagogical unknown. "Teachers are comfortable with it because it's literature based," Dr. Huffman said. "Elementary teachers have been teaching reading for years." Heartwood's approach also reassured teachers who worried that character education would require them to talk about their own beliefs and experiences.
 Teachers have developed activities to accompany the books. Carol McCloskey had her Lincoln Elementary School fourth graders think about how they would experience loyalty through their five senses. One child wrote that loyalty "tastes like Fourth of July cupcakes." At Washington Elementary, Eileen Kennon's second-graders staged a play about their respect for a massive oak tree on the school grounds.
 Explicit classroom discussions and activities were just the beginning of school experience is also shaped by what scholars call the "hidden curriculum," the moral framework that encourages punctuality, respect for authority, politeness, obedience and other behaviors considered to be conducive to learning.
 "You can't just have a curriculum," Dr. Huffman said, "You've got to try to affect the entire ethos of a school" - by requiring community service for students or introducing an ethics code for employees and a sportsmanship code for coaches.
 When cafeteria workers complained about students' offhand gibes about school lunches, Dr. Huffman suggested a plan be developed for "talking with kids about empathy, sensitivity, respect - as it relates to the cafeteria workers who take pride in their work." He also suggested name tags for the food employees, so that students could address them properly.
 To sensitize nonteaching staff to the district's ethos, he thought of asking hypothetical quesions during job interviews. "We might ask, 'What happens if you come across a child crying in the hall?" he said. "Or, a child has been disciplined by the teacher and sent to the principal, and the principal's not there - you're the person receiving that child. How do you handle an irate parent?' Even if the answers are wrong, you're signaling through your questions that you have expectations."
 Mount Lebanon's program also aims to reach beyond the classroom. Teachers send home letters about each Heartwood unit, suggesting lines of discussion for parent and child. A fourth-grade letter on loyalty, for example, recommends that the parents "point out the ways that family members sacrifice for each other." the district has also arranged a series of lectures on childrearing.
 As a key administrator, Dr. Huffman tried to bolster the effort. He visited classrooms, taught Heartwood lessons, edited a staff newsletter about ways to promote the core values and otherwise tried to show that his office was committed to the enterprise. "Any innovation requires considerable nurturing," he said. "So many have been victimized by inadequate long-term support."
 Has all the effort produced results?
 "I can't honestly say there's been a big change," said Ms. McCloskey, of her fourth graders at Lincoln Elementary. "The kids were pretty good to start with."
 Other teachers detect subtle changes. Heartwood provides a vocabulary of virtues, in the view of Ms. Colby. "When someone's behavior comes into question, you can say 'Do you think you're showing respect?' You have a point of reference."
 "Evaluation of character education is tough," Dr. Huffman acknowledged. "You can give paper-and-pencil tests, but the kids are smart enough, and the values of the community strong enough, that they're going to work out the right answers."
Attitudes and behaviors - the main targets of character education - are much harder to gauge. "Character is what you do when nobody is looking," in Dr. Huffman's view. The effects of value education on children, he said, may only appear "down the road - after they leave us."
 Still, he finds some early indicators that he says are encouraging. Some parents have told him they try to reinforce the Heartwood concepts at home, including one parent who used the Heartwood teachings about respect to try to dissuade her son form bullying others.
 "Last year," Dr. Huffman said, "a child returned from an absence with a note saying she'd been sick on Friday. The mother came back with the child after lunch, holding the letter on honesty that the school had just sent home. She said to the teacher, 'I can't really expect you folks to nurture honesty if I'm modeling dishonesty at home. I need to set something straight in my child's presence, and that is that she wasn't sick on Friday' we took her out of school to take a three-day trip.' While it's not our intent to focus on parent behavior, it is a way to say to parents that all of us have a resopnsibility to model these core values."
 Not so long ago, character education was an integral part of the curriculum, indeed, a pervasive one. "Every facet of the schools included some kind of moral education," said B. Edward McClellan, a professor of education at Indiana University and the author of "Schools and the Shaping of Character," published in 1992.
 A didactic approach dominated the first half of the 20th century. The idea was that the teacher, who knew more than the students, imparted wisdom to them. "Moral instruction," a 1914 New York Times article said, describing the views of a contemporary educator "should be as systematic and as definite as a course in mathematics."
 Another method coexisted with the didactic approach - as a "critical counterpoint," Professor McClellan said. The so-called progressive approach, favored by John Dewey and others, involved students in the process of moral decision-making. "Learning 'always be honest' wasn't enough in a complicated world," said Professor McClellan.
 In the 1960's, character education began to wane. After the Supreme Court held that school prayer and devotional Bible reading violated the Constitution, many teachers wrongly believed that the Court had prohibited moral education, said Professor McClellan. Added to this, he said, was the "cultural relativism" that came to be popular in the 1960's.
 "Values clarification," the method introduced in the late 1960's, reflected that relativism. The handiwork of a Univesity of Massachusetts professor, Sidney Simon, and his colleagues, it established the teacher as moderator rather than moralizer. The teacher, explains a 1972 handbook wrotten by Dr. Simon, Leland W. Howe and Howard Kirschenbaum, was to be presented as just another "person with values (and often with values confusion) of his own."
 The approach was hugely popular. The handbook sold more than 600,000 copies. At a teachers' conference in the 1970's, more than 100 people crowded into the presentation on values clarification, Robert Hampel writes in "The Last Little Citadel," a history of American high schools. Down the hall, a session on how to teach "The Federalist Papers" attracted an audience of three.
 Not everyone embraced values clarification, though. The relativism troubled conservative Christian parents, among others. So did the questions recommended for classroom discussion. Some, it seemed to them, were stacked against religion. ("Does religion have some meaning in my life, or is it nothing more than a series of outmoded traditions and customs?") Others appeared politically biased. (One question asked students if they would rather join a consciousness-raising group, an environmental group or a food co-operative.)
 The protests against values clarification came mostly from the poltitical right. Some turned ugly. In 1977, the school board in Warsaw, Ind., voted to remove "Values Clarification" from all classrooms "with the understanding that the textbook . . . will be destroyed when legally permissible." A few months later, a group of townspeople torched a pile of the books.
 Perhaps more important, researchers discovered that values clarification wasn't having the intended effect. It wasn't making students more moral, as proponents hoped or less moral, as opponents feared. "All the research evidence suggests that it didn't achieve anything," said Ivor Pritchard, an analyst in the U.S. Education Department.
 So values clarification has quickly faded. "Some administrators today would rather be accused of having asbestos in their ceilings than of using valued clarification in their classrooms," Dr. Kirschenbaum wrote in a 1992 article.
 The latest enthusiasm for character education began in the mid-1980's. Fueled by concerns over increasing violence, promiscuity and drug abuse among students, it continues today - with support, it seems, across the political spectrum. Both Jesse Jackson and Barbara Bush serve on the advisory board of Character Education Partnership, a nonprofit group in Alexandria, Va., that promotes values education nationwide. At the Character Counts Coalition, a youth-focused project of the nonprofit Josephson Institute of Ethics, William J. Bennett works with Barbara Jordan.
 Public attitudes toward character education are a bit more complicated. Large majorities favor the classroom inculcation of particular values. In a 1994 survey conducted by Public Agenda Foundation, a nonprofit group that studies public opinion, 95 percent of respondents said they want schools to teach "honesty and the importance of telling the truth" and "respect for others regardless of their racial or ethnic background."
 But a markedly smaller group - 49 percent - supports the broad concept of character education, according to a 1994 Gallup survey. And 39 percent of the survey's respondents said that "this should be left to the students' parents and/or the churches."
 The disparity - near-unanimous support for teaching particular values, weaker support for teaching values in general - "makes it tough to find a solution," said Terry Peterson, advisor to U.S. Secretary of Education Richard W. Riley. "People are really split."
 Opposition comes from several directions. Some liberals worry that values education will be a Trojan horse for reintroducing Christianity to the classroom. And some civil libertarians say it is impossible to teach "values" in the public schools of a pluralist constitutional democracy. After all, whose values would be taught?
 More potent and vocal are the same critics who massed against values clarification - conservative Christians. Echoing their opposition to that earlier method, they now contend that character education programs tear children away from their faith and traditions, invade the family's privacy, promote moral relativism and "indifferentism" (the notion that all religions lead to salvation), endorse homosexuality and nontraditional family sturctures and further a left-wing political agenda.
 Addressing a predominantly hostile audience at the conference of Americans United for Separation of Church and State in November, Janet Parshall of Concerned Women for American, a conservative group, urged public schools to concentrate on "reinforcing" home-grown values, no "redefining" them. As for supposedly neutral values, she said, "I venture to say that there are some people in this room who would define 'fairness' other than I would."
 The idea of promoting tolerance in the classroom also alarms some conservatives familiar with New York City's Children of the Rainbow curriculum, which aimed in part to dispel prejudice against gay men and lesbians. "Twenty years ago, we would never have thought to define tolerance to equal the inclusion of homosexuality," Mrs. Parshall said after addressing her liberal audience. "My Bible teaches that I am to be intolerant of certain types of behavior."
 By now, fearing controversy, especially from the political right, many school officials are leery of values education. An article appearing a few years ago in one education trade journal termed it "political suicide for administrators."
 If there is a school district where character education could be implemented without discord, Mount Lebanon would seem to be it. A suburb of Pittsburgh, this town of 33,000 is homogeneous (98 percent white) and prosperous (the average family income is nearly $77,000). Its political disputes, says Dr. Huffman, embody "a level of civility in public discourse that you don't often see."
 Curriculum, a contentious issue in many school districts, has rarely come under attack here. When Pennsylvania's conservatives mobilized against the state's planned Outcome-Based Education program, contending that some of the proposed goals for students were less academic than political, the fracas only lightly brushed Mount Lebanon.
 "We hosted a meeting, and I think most of the opposition question came from outside the district," Dr. Huffman said. "Our P.T.A. and parents had confidence in our ability to take whatever outcomes the state generated and work with them in a way that's respectful fo community norms."
 Dr. Huffman himself shares many views of the conservatives who criticize public schools. A churchgoing Methodist, he speaks of "a spiritual dimension" in his life and approvingly cites publications of the conservative organization Focus on the Family. He has criticized as "less than neutral" a classroom video about AIDS that listed reasons why people remain sexually abstinent but failed to mention religious beliefs. He frames his opposition to organized classroom prayer in spiritual terms: "If the prayer is broad enough to satisfy a majority of people, it will be so innocuous as to be offensive to those who take the nuances of their faith seriously."
 But even in Mount Lebanon, even with Dr. Huffman's temperate views and his efforts to forge consensus, dissent and the threat of discord have arisen.
 The school board, for example, vetoed mandatory community service in the high school. "I think it was viewed as part of a liberal political agenda," Dr. Huffman said, adding that "it didn't help" that it was Senator Edward Kennedy who sponsored a 1993 bill calling for student community service in exchange for help with college tuition bills. "So we're paying for the sins of the Massachusetts Senator," he said.
 And there were other objections. "One parent said, 'Are you going to be teaching about homosexuals?' "recalled Ms. Colby, the first-grade teacher. "They're so afraid that in teaching respect and tolerance for others, we might respect and be tolerant of homosexuals."
 Dr. Huffman invited critics of the Heartwood books to meet with him. In one such meeting, Lawrence Dunegan, a Mount Lebanon pediatrician, objected to an assertion in the teacher's manual that "our concept of families is changing," as well as to two stories: one depicting children as wiser than their parents, the other a South African tale that he considered "very Marxist in its appeal."
 "Character formation is not really a proper function for government," Dr. Dunegan said later, after his meeting with Dr. Huffman. In fact, he added, "I don't think government has a right to educate at all."
 At another meeting, Dr. Huffman heard from Dawn Morrison, a parent. After reading some Heartwood materials and a research study about them, Mrs. Morrison concluded that the curriculum was using "psychological methods" to alter children's values. She was disturbed to learn that Heartwood's impact had not been extensively tested. "Is this an experiment?" she asked in an interview. "An experiment with our children's system of moral development, their values, their character?"
 Her opposition to the Heartwood material, Mrs. Morrison says, has nothing to do with her religious faith and little to do with the stories themselves. Although she considers particular stories inappropriate for young children, she limits her criticism to the program's methodology. "I don't want to get labeled a book burner," she said.
Mrs. Morrison says she hasn't asked to have her two children excused from reading the Heartwood books, partly because they "weren't real comfortable with the idea of being removed from the classroom and made to seem different."
Accompanying Mrs. Morrison to the meeting was a seasoned critic of public schools who had also been studying the Heartwood curriculum. From her home in nearby West Alexander, Pa., Anita Hoge, a self-described parents' advocate, had earlier rallied opinion against Outcome-Based Education in the state. Called the "Rosa Parks of the parents' rights movement" by one supporter, Mrs. Hoge has spent years challenging what she considers "invasive testing" about values in the public schools.
Like Mrs. Morrison, Mrs. Hoge says she opposes Heartwood's methodology. She faults the Heartwood program -- along with William Bennett's "Book of Virtues" -- for slighting moral absolutes. In her view, students should be told that stealing is wrong, "according to an authority -- either God or the parents, it doesn't matter." Heartwood's method, in her opinion, simply engenders "situation ethics," and parents have a right to know that.
Eleanore Childs, the president of the Heartwood Institute, disagrees with Mrs. Hoge and the other critics. She views the curriculum she helped develop as nonpartisan. "It's not political, and I think it's a shame to make it political," she said, adding that Heartwood's seven attributes "would fit very nicely into the Christian agenda."
The dispute reminds her of her days in the antiwar movement: "In the '60s, we criticized without offering solutions." From her perspective, that's what Mrs. Hoge and her allies are doing. Ms. Childs finds herself in an unfamiliar role, defending the established order and urging protesters to "collaborate, not criticize."
The Heartwood critics may not be collaborating, but unlike many critics of the school curriculum, they are communicating with the other side. "It was a great discussion Henry and I had," Mrs. Hoge said of her two-and-a-half hour meeting with Dr. Huffman.
In schoolbook battles across the nation, one often hears the same hand-wringing refrain: If only the disputants would sit down together and talk, they would discover vast common ground. In Mt. Lebanon, though, the Heartwood critics and the school officials are sitting down and talking. And it is not enough.
THE ISSUES and tactics arising in Mount Lebanon are also appearing elsewhere. Schoolbook critics across the country have been advancing secular arguments for teaching moral absolutes, in place of the religious arguments they once advanced for teaching Christianity.
"The right wing has learned that if they blatantly raise their religious perspective, it discredits them," said Michael Hudson, Western regional vice president of People for the American Way.
Today's schoolbook protesters are also less confrontational than those of the 1980's, Mr. Hudson says. "They've clearly toned down the rhetoric," he said. "From Pat Robertson all the way down to the grass roots, they're trying not to look so kooky." That rhetorical shift, he added, creates "one of the biggest problems for our side. The movement is so much more sophisticated now. It's not nearly as easy to expose them as it was in the '80s."
As in Mount Lebanon, protesters are commonly focusing on methodology rather than book content, says Eve Hoffman, a former chair of the Gwinnett County, Ga., school board, who has studied the conflicts between conservative Christians and public schools in Georgia. "There are a lot of accusations that schools are practicing psychology without a license," she said.
Among the speakers who have addressed conservative groups in Georgia recently, she added, is Mrs. Hoge. "She's so far to the right, she flashes back to 'None Dare Call It Treason,' " Ms. Hoffman said, referring to John Stormer's anti-Communist tract of 1964. "Hoge is definitely a national player."
Whatever else enters the dispute about values and education, it centers around turf and trust. Dr. Huffman says his message to Heartwood critics is: "We're on the cutting edge here, folks. Trust our professional judgment." Mrs. Hoge's view is that "parents have been going along in this little marshmallow world, trusting the professionals." Her message, she says, is: "Parents -- you are the professionals."
MESSAGES like Mrs. Hoge's may resonate with the public's current mistrust of politics and political institutions. And the electorate's rightward shift may mean that values education will become even tougher to implement. Conservative critics are not easily satisfied these days: Mel Gabler of Longview, Tex., whose textbook reviews influence many book protests, says he doesn't know of any character education program that Christian parents can embrace.
In Mount Lebanon, Mrs. Hoge is contemplating a lawsuit to quash the Heartwood program. She maintains that state regulations require the district to test students on core values, but a Federal law, the Hatch Amendment, prohibits such testing without parental consent. "We have our ducks in a row," she said. "If the parents are pressured, they will do what is necessary to insure that their rights are respected." After a pause, she added: "I will never be stepped on again."
Mrs. Hoge may not have a winning legal argument -- experts dispute her interpretation of both the state and the Federal laws -- but she could still prevail. Defending a lawsuit can be costly and time consuming. And even without a lawsuit, curriculum disputes impose emotional costs. Three longtime school superintendents interviewed by Ms. Hoffman for her Georgia study said that the atmosphere created by conservative Christian protests felt "worse" than the acrimony accompanying desegregation.
Six of Mount Lebanon's nine school board members have taken office since approval of the initial plan for character education. Some of them are cool to the Heartwood program. Might the board abandon character education rather than endure a lawsuit or a political fight? "That's a concern," Dr. Huffman acknowledged.
If so, it won't be the first time that a handful of objectors has succeeded in rejiggering the curriculum. "It's absolutely common that a small minority of highly energized folks can dominate the process," Mr. Hudson of People for the American Way said. Ms. Hoffman agreed. "These folks are driven by an adrenaline rush that most of us don't have," she said. "If they decide to come after you, it does not matter if you have engaged 95 percent of the community -- they're going to get you."
WHATEVER happens to the fledgling program in Mount Lebanon, Dr. Huffman may not be there to deal with it. He has applied for a position as director of a planned Pennsylvania-based research center on character education. Whether or not he gets the job, he intends to leave the Mount Lebanon school district where he has worked for 27 years, and devote himself to advancing moral education across the country.
He hopes to help other districts, especially those without the resources of Mount Lebanon, implement values programs of their own.
What of the program he midwifed? "My leaving may be a good thing for our initiative," he said in a written statement, "to the degree that my presence may have inhibited some staff from playing a more prominent role." No longer will the program be viewed as "Henry Huffman's project."
Ms. Colby isn't so sure Dr. Huffman's departure is a good thing. Sitting in the teachers' lounge after reading "Abiyoyo" to her first-graders, she said, "If somebody wants to take exception to what your're doing, where are you going to go? With Henry not being on site, people are afraid they're not going to be able to stand up to criticism."
Though she had just finished teaching a lesson on courage, Ms. Colby looked apprehensive.
 
Which Values?
When it comes to character education, the first few values on any school's list are fairly predictable: "compassion," "honesty," "tolerance."
Some schools go beyond moral values to address friendliness, or neatness. Some list self-esteem.
And a fewschool districts have developed lengthy lists, like the 36 items (one for each week of the school year) in Dayton, Ohio, or the 24 in Baltimore County, Md. (where the roster includes "courtesy" and "objectivity").
In 1992, the nonprofit Josephson Institute of Ethics endorsed six "core ethical values": respect, responsibility, trustworthiness, caring, justice and fairness, and civic virtue and citizenship. In the view of the participants, representing education organizations, universities and youth groups: "These core ethical values transcend cultural, religious and socio-economic differences."
Amitai Etzioni, a sociologist at George Washington University and author of the 1993 book, "The Spirit of Community," would concentrate on just two values.. "Every human being I know except Mother Theresa commits one sin a day," he said. "There are impulses which are not expungeable." A noble person, then, is one who is "relatively well equipped" to resist the impulses toward misbehavior. "The person has two attributes," Professor Etzioni continued. "First, self-control. And second, empathy -- because if you have only self-control, you will be a very effective murderer." S.B.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Henry Huffman, assistant superintendent of schools in Mount Lebanon, Pa., has been the moving force behind the effort to teach about courage and other moral values. (pg. 16); Teacher Eileen Kennon uses the yellow cut-out to illustrate to her second graders at Washington Elementary School how moral values are understood, felt and acted upon. (pg. 17); After reading a story about loyalty in China, students in Carol McCloskey's fourth-grade class at Lincoln Elementary wrote 'Loyalty' in English and Chinese characters.
