SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1413 words

HEADLINE: Consumers Spending Freely, Confident About Their Jobs

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
Billy Belford, a nurse's aide in Portland, Ore., has big plans for 1995. Feeling "pretty secure" about his job, Mr. Belford, 22, is ready to spend some money.
"Jan. 20 is payday," he said. "That day I have an appointment to go look at a car." 
 The holiday season might have disappointed many retailers, especially in apparel, who were forced by intense competition and too much inventory to cut prices and profits. But in fact, with incomes, jobs and confidence way up, the American consumer is still going strong.
Cars have been rolling off dealers' lots at the fastest rate since the late 1980's. Chain-store sales during the holiday shopping season were up a solid 5 percent or so from December 1993, even with all the price cutting going on. And total consumer spending rose about 4 percent after inflation last year, faster than in all but two years of the shopaholic 1980's.
"What gives spending some underlying momentum and makes it look solid is that consumers are generally looking toward their communities, jobs and shopping centers and seeing strength," said Richard Curtin, who runs the University of Michigan's monthly survey of consumers. Indeed, consumer confidence, which slipped in the middle of the year, wound up as high at the end of 1994 as it was at the beginning, when the University of Michigan index reached a five-year high.
Whether consumers will be able to sustain their current pace for the whole year is a matter of some debate. For one thing, the Federal Reserve raised interest rates six times last year, and seems ready to do so again at the end of the month. The many shoppers with adjustable-rate mortgages and adjustable-rate credit cards will soon see their interest payments rise as past increases catch up.
The recent pace of spending, faster than the growth of Americans' income, is itself a reason for wondering when consumers will run out of gas. But for now, many Americans seem to have the means and the confidence to keep spending. And is there any reason to think that the brake of higher rates will work more quickly than the accelerator of sharply lower rates did in 1990? Remember, too, that higher interest rates also increase interest income.
Ricardo Gonzalez, 37, a shop steward at a General Motors plant in Detroit, is enjoying a new sense of security with the auto industry's boom. Mr. Gonzalez, who is married and has two children, has worked plenty of overtime. He is now driving a 1995 Cutlass Supreme, is moving into a four-bedroom house that costs four times what his old one is worth and is going to college part time.
Eileen Petriccione, a newly married customer-service agent at DHL Worldwide Express, the courier service, is not the mall regular she once was. She and her new husband, Mike, who live in Mamaroneck, N.Y., went to a pot-luck dinner at a friend's house on New Year's Eve, instead of spending a few hundred dollars at clubs, and she paid for most of her Christmas purchases in cash. Nonetheless, with a secure job and a sparsely furnished apartment, Ms. Petriccione is planning to buy some living-room furniture. Last fall, she and her husband spent $3,500 on a bedroom set.
Barbara Swanson is an artist and mother of two in Manhattan. At Christmas her family acquired electronics, clothes and toys. But even though Ms. Swanson is no impulse buyer -- she had her 20-year-old refrigerator repaired instead of replacing it -- she spent the first week of the new year hunting for a new computer that could play compact disks and provide color graphics.
Consumers are feeling better than they have in years mostly because of an abundance of jobs and greater job security. Job growth was solid all last year, and the unemployment rate is now as low as it has been at any time since the early 1970's. The economy created 3.5 million jobs and the pace, around 275,000 a month, has not really slowed yet. The figures for December, released on Friday, reported a gain of 256,000, after a November increase of nearly 500,000 jobs. And business hiring plans are upbeat.
"The big thing here is that there seems to be a feeling that there's going to be a job tomorrow," said Frank R. Anderson Jr., of Sir Walter Chevrolet in Raleigh, N.C., where the unemployment rate is 3.3 percent. "Even with the higher cost of money, it's an up economy."
All those jobs, plus record factory overtime and modestly rising pay, have pushed up income faster than inflation. After-tax income, after inflation, grew 4 percent in the 12 months ended in November, twice as fast as in 1993. Forecasters expect after-tax income to keep growing this year, even if the tax cuts that politicians have promised do not add many dollars or do not materialize until 1996.
The University of Michigan survey found that while consumers expect interest rates to slow the economy later this year, they do not think this will be enough to raise the unemployment rate. And they are upbeat about the economy five years from now, in contrast to the way they felt looking into the future a few years ago.
Another explanation for the continued strong consumer spending is that awareness of rising interest rates can become a reason to buy -- sending Americans shopping before things become more expensive. That happened in the 1970's, when there were expectations of higher inflation. And it is one reason now, economists say, that the housing market has not yet gone into a swoon.
In the University of Michigan's survey, for example, 26 percent of consumers polled said last month that it was a good time to borrow because rates would go higher; in December 1993, only 6 percent said it was a good time to borrow. In the latest survey, only 20 percent thought rates were too high for a major purchase.
And for all those consumers who want to spend more, getting loans is a breeze right now.
"Banks are throwing money at them," said Donald C. Ratajczak, an economist at Georgia State University. "At this point, the consumers are willing to spend because there are no financial constraints on them."
All kinds of lenders -- from Citibank to GE Credit to Sears, Roebuck -- are making loans eagerly, and bank analysts see no signs of an impending change of heart. Consumer loans by banks rose 14.4 percent in the 12 months that ended on Sept. 30. Credit card billings have jumped 25 percent in the last 12 months.
Mail Monitor, a newsletter that tracks promotional mailings, says the number of letters offering home equity loans and credit cards topped two billion in 1994, more than twice the 1992 volume.
As households' finances improve and delinquency rates on mortgages and installment credit have fallen to their lowest levels in decades, lots of lenders have raised credit limits for many customers. Many, like Citibank, have also reduced the minimum monthly payments on credit card balances to one-48th of the outstanding balance from one-36th.
The rapid increase in debt in recent months is potentially worrisome. But data gathered by the Federal Reserve on monthly payments suggest that debt payments are not taking as big a bite out of income as in the late 1980's, largely because of the record refinancings at lower interest rates in recent years and the efforts by many Americans to repay debts.
The ratio of payments to income now stands around 15.9 percent, roughly what it was in the mid-1980's, and considerably below the 17.9 percent of 1989.
There are signs that shoppers will not slow down in the coming months.
Take cars. The increases in interest rates have so far added $75 a month to payments on $20,000 trucks, enough to dent buying, one might think. But Ray Green, president of a Chevrolet chain dealership in Jacksonville, Ill., said he expected his 1995 sales to match last year's. The reason: Buyers couldn't get nearly as many trucks as they wanted because G.M.'s production fell far short.
"There's enough pent-up demand out there," he said. "Popular models will be more available and there are lots of new models that people have been waiting for."
If Mr. Green is right, the consumer boom may take a little longer to wind down than many economists have been predicting.
"If we have another great car year, if credit card use keeps rising and if people buy houses with adjustable-rate mortgages with teaser rates, consumers will be not in such a great position in a couple of years," said Edward McKelvey, an economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "But we're not there yet."

HEADLINE: Peso Crisis Weakens Salinas Bid for International Trade Job

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 8

 BODY:
As President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon scrambles to overcome Mexico's peso crisis, former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari is working hard to salvage his own reputation and his shaky campaign to head the new World Trade Organization.
Mexico's economic problems, caused by an abrupt devaluation of the peso by more than 35 percent just three weeks after Mr. Salinas left office, have cast a shadow over his reputation as an economic magician who transformed the country. They also have raised doubts about whether the economic reforms during the six years of his administration were really as successful as they had been portrayed. 
 Legislators from Mexico's second-largest opposition party say that they will introduce a motion on Monday to bring charges against Mr. Salinas and members of his Cabinet for crimes against the nation. They say he withheld the truth about Mexico's economy to safeguard his chances of being selected to lead the new international organization. However, it is unlikely that a legislature dominated by Mr. Salinas's Institutional Revolutionary Party would ever allow the charges to be filed.
Mr. Salinas has not responded to the accusations, but the leaders of his party have said it is wrong to search for scapegoats now.
Since leaving office on Dec. 1, Mr. Salinas has been campaigning almost nonstop to become the first secretary general of the World Trade Organization, which replaced the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade on Jan. 1. Last week he was in Israel, where a Mexico City newspaper tracked him down and tried to get him to talk about the economic problems in Mexico. His only response was, "No comment."
Mr. Salinas was once considered a strong candidate for the trade job, but even before the peso crisis it was widely reported that he had lost considerable ground to Renato Ruggiero, a former Italian Commerce Secretary, who had the support of the European Union and many former European colonies.
The dark-horse candidate, Kim Chul Su, a former Trade Minister of South Korea, was backed by the Asian block, but also had been losing ground. The selection is made by consensus, and the deadlock that developed forced the trade organization to extend the selection process to March 15.
"The possibility of electing any of the three candidates had disappeared even before the events in Mexico," said Isaac Cohen, director of the Washington office of the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean. "The devaluation was just another nail in the coffin."
Mr. Salinas had the strong backing of Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen for the international trade job before he said in early December that he would leave office. However, since the peso crisis developed in mid-December, the United States has not publicly said anything in support of Mr. Salinas.
A Treasury Department official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that while the United States had not withdrawn its endorsement, it was not aggressively supporting Mr. Salinas, especially since Mr. Bentsen's replacement, Robert Rubin, has not yet been confirmed.
As angry Mexicans look for someone to blame for the current crisis, Mr. Salinas is being vilified. An attack from the political opposition could have been expected, but increasing numbers of Mexicans are willing to believe that Mr. Salinas manipulated the economy for personal gain. The cover of last week's Proceso news magazine carried a picture of Mr. Salinas with the headline, "The Guilty One."
Some people believe that even President Zedillo, a close friend and ally, tried to blame Mr. Salinas for the economic mess. "Before any concern for the presidential image or the renown of public officials, my commitment is to act responsibly, without evading or trying to conceal reality," Mr. Zedillo said in his speech to the nation on Tuesday.
In Mexican politics, the President always is at center stage. But as soon as he is replaced, his popularity plummets. Mr. Salinas appeared to be an exception.
But since Dec. 21, the day Mr. Zedillo's Government was forced to let the peso float freely against the dollar, Mr. Salinas and his six years in office have been rejudged.
The Mexican Government got into its current economic dead end by allowing imports to far exceed exports and by paying for that imbalance with foreign funds. When these funds dried up, Mexico was no longer able to defend the peso.
"It is very possible that Salinas de Gortari had not wanted to assume the cost of a devaluation in order to, firstly, maintain an impeccable image," wrote Jose Antonio Crespo, a political scientist. "For Salinas, it's always been a lot of work to admit he's made mistakes."
Previous Mexican Presidents have accepted the likelihood that public opinion would turn on them. They have been willing to make politically unpopular moves to protect their successors, who always have come from the same party. President Jose Lopez Portillo, who once vowed to defend the peso "like a dog," ordered a devaluation before leaving office. Mexicans sometimes still mock him by howling when they see him in public.
The selection of the new director of the World Trade Organization, based in Geneva, was supposed to have been completed by Jan. 1. When it was not, the former director of the GATT, Peter Sutherland, was asked to stay on until March 15.
Mr. Zedillo called in Mexico's ambassadors Thursday and instructed them to go all-out to build support for Mr. Salinas. The Mexican strategy is based on the belief that Mr. Kim will drop out of the race, with Mr. Salinas picking up the support of the Asian nations that had lined up behind Mr. Kim. Asian diplomats see that scenario as unlikely, however.
If the World Trade Organization is unable to pick among the current candidates, it could turn to someone not now in the running.
In the meantime, Mr. Salinas continues his campaign. And at least one columnist in Mexico City supports it.
"The support is not so much to get him into the international organization," wrote Fray Bartolome, a pseudonym for the editorial staff of the daily Reforma, "but to keep him out of Mexico."

HEADLINE: Russia, Criticized by West, Defers Exercise With NATO

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BONN, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Russia has postponed peacekeeping maneuvers it was to hold with NATO next summer near St. Petersburg, German officials said today.
Although Defense Minister Volker Ruhe strongly criticized the "unprecedented brutality" of the Russian attacks against the breakaway southern region of Chechnya, he said the peacekeeping maneuvers and other plans for military cooperation should eventually go ahead. 
 "I am not in favor of breaking off relations with Russia," Mr. Ruhe told the weekly magazine Der Spiegel, "but I am in favor of clearly and openly stating which accords Russia has breached."
He accused Moscow of violating international agreements obliging it to notify neighbors of its deployment of 40,000 troops to Chechnya.
Agreements signed by all the NATO countries and members of the former Warsaw Pact in 1990 and 1992 require them to announce maneuvers of more than 9,000 troops within 72 hours and to invite observers if more than 13,000 are deployed. German officials said the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, with headquarters in Vienna, had not received the required notification.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl telephoned President Boris N. Yeltsin on Wednesday to express dismay at the civilian casualties in Grozny, the Chechen capital, but has resisted calls to withdraw support for the Russian, whom most European Governments have considered the best hope for democracy in Moscow.
"We see people suffering, civilians, women and children," Mr. Kohl told a Berlin radio station on Saturday. "We see victims among the soldiers and regard it all as complete madness."
But despite calls by the French Defense Minister, Francois Leotard, and others for economic sanctions against Russia, the German leader said he was against such sanctions. Mr. Kohl, who has repeatedly insisted that Chechnya is an internal Russian affair, said the West should not create the impression that it wanted Russia's disintegration.
The European Union's executive commission in Brussels said on Thursday that it would delay an interim agreement intended to encourage more European trade and investment in Russia because of human rights violations in Chechnya. The 15 member countries of the European Union have called for action on the issue by the 53-nation Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, which has no power to impose sanctions. The United States has backed the move.
The Hungarian Foreign Minister, Laszlo Kovacs, chairman of the security organization, condemned the conflict last week as "a serious threat not only to the security of the Russian Federation but of the whole region and the continent as well."
He called for an immediate stop to the offensive and said he was sending a representative to Moscow on Monday to propose ways the organization could help resolve the crisis.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
DOLE AND GORE DIFFER
 WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- President Yeltsin's failure to immediately stop his troops from bombing Chechen civilians raised debate today over who commands Russia's military.
While the White House said Mr. Yeltsin was in control, Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, disagreed. "I think in Chechnya it's pretty obvious either somebody's lying or somebody's not in charge," he said.
Hours earlier, on the CBS News program "Face the Nation," Vice President Al Gore expressed concern over the fighting, but said of Mr. Yeltsin, "We believe that he is in control."
In Grozny, mortar and rocket fire continued today, but it was not clear whether the fighter jets in the air over the area actually dropped any bombs. On Friday, Mr. Yeltsin demanded to know why the city was being bombing despite his orders to halt.
"There is a difference between what he said would happen and what he later found out happened," Mr. Gore said.
He called Mr. Yeltsin's televised rebuke of his Defense Minister, Gen. Pavel S. Grachev, over the bombings an "unusual episode," but said the Russian President retains a firm grip on the military command.
"I would predict that, in the aftermath of that public confrontation, that he will find a way to remove any doubts about the fact that he is in control," Mr. Gore said.
In an interview with CNN, Mr. Dole said United States support for Yeltsin is eroding "almost on a daily basis" because of the assault on Grozny. "When you're killing innocent civilians, it's not going to sell in this country," he said.

HEADLINE: The Yeltsin Problem

 BODY:
When the Russian Foreign Minister defends Moscow's military assault against the breakaway republic of Chechnya by comparing Boris Yeltsin to Abraham Lincoln, it is clear Moscow is anxious about the small but savage confrontation in the Caucasus. Andrei Kozyrev's desire to make the war more comprehensible to Americans is understandable. Mr. Yeltsin's mishandling of the Chechen rebellion is sure to strengthen those who want to end American assistance and return to a strategy of containing rather than befriending Russia. That would be a mistake, but some recalibration of long-term American policy is warranted.
Recognizing that the brutality of the attack has undermined Mr. Yeltsin, President Clinton has urged him to end the killing of civilians and accept an offer from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe to help mediate a political settlement. Moscow should not refuse. Belatedly, Mr. Yeltsin says he is trying to put the military on a tighter leash and end the indiscriminate bombing of Grozny, the Chechen capital. Unfortunately, the army's sledgehammer approach has already dishonored the important principle that Moscow has a right to maintain the cohesion of the Russian federation, and in extreme cases like Chechnya, may use limited military force. 
 But the White House must look beyond the Chechen crisis, for it has altered the political picture in Moscow and Washington. Like Mikhail Gorbachev, who lost political traction at home before he lost his job, and who remained the pivot of American policy toward the Soviet Union long after his leadership had become illusory, Mr. Yeltsin is in trouble before his country or the world is prepared to deal with the consequences. Secretary of State Warren Christopher cannot wish away the problem with expressions of faith in Mr. Yeltsin.
Mr. Yeltsin has lost the support of moderate political leaders, narrowed his circle of advisers and shed much of the moral authority he gained in his fight for reform. It is unclear how much control he retains over an army embarrassed by its performance in Chechnya and embittered by a loss of resources and stature. Mr. Yeltsin will find it hard now to rise above the fractious political forces in Moscow. His prospects for re-election in 1996 are declining.
All this makes it essential that Washington have a Russia policy, not a Yeltsin policy. While not writing off Mr. Yeltsin, President Clinton must avoid the sort of bear hug that left President George Bush locked in Mr. Gorbachev's embrace. American policy should be anchored in support of economic, political and military reform in Russia and the institutions and people making it happen. That means reaching out to other democratic leaders like Yegor Gaidar, the former Prime Minister, cementing ties already formed between American and Russian Government agencies, and expanding exchanges between senior military officials.
Cutting off assistance is not in Russian or American interests. Subsidizing the dismantling of nuclear weapons in the former Soviet Union, one example, is an indispensable investment in post-cold-war security. Congress has appropriated $1.27 billion for that purpose since 1992.
After long delay, the International Monetary Fund is negotiating intensively with Russia about providing $13 billion desperately needed to help stabilize the economy and slow the inflation rate. Delaying or conditioning the aid because of the Chechen conflict may have short-term political appeal; the one sure way to prevent the assistance from indirectly financing the war is to put it on hold. But further delay in helping to shore up the Russian economy would punish the Russian people for Mr. Yeltsin's error. If Mr. Yeltsin is truly committed to making Russia democratic, he must move quickly to end the war in Chechnya.

HEADLINE: President Clinton's Welfare Waffle

 BODY:
Everyone agrees that welfare needs reform; too many programs do far too little to boost recipients toward self-sufficiency. But House Republicans do not just want to reform the system's operation. They seek to demolish the core principle that any American who becomes truly needy is entitled to support.
It is dismaying, but unsurprising, that Speaker Newt Gingrich and his compulsive band of budget cutters would tear up the country's social safety net. The shocker came last week when a timid White House seemed ready to acquiesce. 
 Robert Pear of The Times asked Avis LaVelle, an Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services, whether she would defend the entitlement status of welfare and Medicaid (health insurance for the poor). She answered -- reflecting White House thinking, officials there say -- "No, I can't. . . . It's just not smart for us to take an advocacy position one way or another. The ground is shifting under our feet."
The ground may be shifting. But when important principles are at stake, Presidents are supposed to lead, even if leadership requires digging heels into shifting terrain. The weak-kneed response contrasts sharply with the President's record: he worked to push the laudable 1988 welfare reform bill through Congress and focused his Presidential campaign around a promise of tough but compassionate reform. It would provide up to two years of training, education and child care, but then require able-bodied recipients to find work or take a government job.
What House Republicans propose is an annual national cap on welfare assistance and food stamps: the total amount of welfare money from the Federal Government would be fixed no matter how many applicants would qualify for assistance. Under Republican rules, mothers and children would wait in welfare lines and hope that the money would not run out before their names were called.
Putting annual caps on welfare programs is misguided. For starters, welfare is not draining the Treasury. Cash assistance, food stamps and Medicaid cost less than $150 billion a year; by comparison, two other entitlements -- Social Security and Medicare -- cost nearly $500 billion.
If welfare is lumped in with other discretionary programs, it will shrivel disastrously over time. Even without a balanced budget amendment, total discretionary spending will be held frozen over the next few years; the G.O.P. intends to drive it sharply lower. Congress would almost certainly chop welfare, which has no politically powerful constituency.
Besides cruelty, the proposal would make the economy increasingly vulnerable to recession. Now, as the economy slows and unemployed workers qualify for assistance, government automatically spends more money on welfare. This not only helps the needy but keeps spending levels high. States could pick up where Congress leaves off. But not many states will raise taxes during economic hard times to take care of the poor.
The G.O.P. is right to insist that Congress rethink who should and who should not qualify for welfare. Congress might want to change rules that currently allow upper-income families to play accounting games to trick Medicaid into paying for nursing home care. Congress might want to require able-bodied recipients to work. Washington might want to give states more flexibility to design lower-cost ways to deliver welfare assistance.
Mr. Clinton knows all this. Indeed, he has said as much -- in the past. But now he wants to duck the issue. When Secretary Donna Shalala of Health and Human Services goes to the House this week to testify, she should not be allowed to do the same. Capitol Hill is a perfect place for the Administration to find its political guts.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Yeltsin's Tiananmen

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Which great power is more unsta ble today China or Russia?
The quick answer, of course, is Russia. The elected leader, Boris Yeltsin, is besieged in Moscow after his bloody siege of Grozny, capital of the Connecticut-sized breakaway republic of Chechnya. 
 Russian television showed vivid pictures of the bombing of that city even as it showed Yeltsin saying it wasn't so; then the cameras showed Yeltsin upbraiding his Defense Minister for making him look like a liar.
As Helmut Kohl telephoned to tell him that world opinion frowns on the savage method his Russia Federation is using to preserve its borders, Bill Clinton wrote a "Dear Boris" letter reaffirming support of Federation unity but stressing how "distressed" he is at civilian deaths and suggesting mediation by an organization of 53 nations.
What's Yeltsin to do? The Chechens are dead serious about secession. If Russia lets Chechnya go, other Caucasian dominoes will fall and Moscow will be denied the Caspian oil it needs to rule a hundred nationalities across 11 time zones.
He tried negotiation, which was met by a declaration of independence; he tried an internal coup, which flopped; now he's trying force, which is bringing world obloquy on his head because the Chechens are fiercely fighting for their homeland and the Russian Army has no heart for a lengthy guerrilla battle, especially after its loss in Afghanistan.
All that -- added to Yeltsin's personal punchiness and isolation -- is why Russia appears unstable. We tend to equate the future of democracy with the future of Yeltsin, who is on his last legs.
But consider the political miracle taking place in Moscow today. An unpopular and unjust war is being denounced in the Parliament, with reformer Grigory Yavlinsky openly calling for Yeltsin's resignation. The military is publicly divided between conscience-stricken warriors and hard-line incompetents. Free speech is spilling out all over.
The newspapers, after centuries of czarist and Communist docility, are crusading: a picture of Defense Minister Pavel Grachev is captioned "the most talentless commander in Russia." And the television crews are bringing home the horror of the war just as American cameramen did in Vietnam, with similar impact on Russian public opinion.
This is wonderful. The world should be proud of the Russian people, who should be prouder of themselves for exercising their new-found freedom to debate a great issue.
Contrast that democratic turmoil to the facade of "stability" in China. With the death of Deng Xiaoping imminent, the leadership is cracking down on dissidents.
By jailing its leading independent thinkers, the regime in Beijing reveals its inherent weakness. The new imprisonment of the courageous Wei Jingsheng, China's Sakharov, was the tip-off that the leadership fears a popular uprising, this time led by angry workers rather than idealistic students. As Deng sinks, the number of panicky arrests rises.
This demonstrates again that succession in a Communist state is a ruthless wrestle for power within an impenetrable clique. It mocks the assurances of China's Western apologists that a market economy leads to political freedom.
In a litchi nutshell, here's the play:
Yang Shangkun, an old army leader whose powerful family was neutralized by Deng, is close to Adm. Liu Huaqing, the nation's top military leader. They may challenge Deng's proteges, party boss Jiang Zemin and Prime Minister Li Peng, by backing economic chief Zhu Rongji or promoting a next-generation politician, Hu Jintao, or by backing Qiao Shi, the former national security adviser and now chairman of the rubber-stamp People's Congress, hereinafter known as "China's Newt Gingrich."
What do 1.2 billion Chinese have to say about all this? Zilch. (Analysts in Beijing, aware of the exclusive accuracy of my prediction of Mao's successor in the 70's, will have to puzzle out "zilch.") And therein lies real instability.
A monolithic, totalitarian state, repressing the spirit of freedom, only seems secure; we have seen how it can suddenly collapse. A noisy, unruly democratic state, drawing on the legitimacy of free elections, is more secure -- no matter how shaky the leadership. That's why Russia is in better political shape than China.

HEADLINE: Stalling on Social Security Makes a Worse Mess;
Seek Cuts Elsewhere

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your chart accompanying "Welfare Debate Will Re-examine Core Assumptions" (front page, Jan. 2) does make Social Security look like a logical candidate for cuts. 
 But if Social Security is a required investment in promised retirement income, then cutting it would be morally reprehensible and tantamount to fraud. This would be criminal behavior if a private organization attempted it.
If, rather, Social Security contributions are a general tax, and benefits are just one of many options for Government, then our country's tax structure is regressive beyond all limits of human reason.
So which is it?
Social Security funds were ruthlessly "borrowed" by Ronald Reagan, when not even the really massive deficits of his years could quite match his lust for armaments.
The deficit over which so many now grieve is a far lower percentage of the gross national product than it was in much of the 1940's and 1950's, when the country prospered, the economy grew, and the real income of workers grew with it.
The need to cut either welfare or promised retirement benefits exists only in the political posturing that is the Willie Horton of the 1990's. If cuts are wanted, one might look in the direction of an arms budget that persists and cries for more, long after the more paranoid minds among us have run out of people to target.
 
(Rev.) LLOYD A. BERG
Staten Island, N.Y., Jan. 2, 1995

HEADLINE: Stalling on Social Security Makes a Worse Mess

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In your Jan. 3 article on House Speaker Newt Gingrich's views on Social Security reform you quote from a C-Span interview in which he acknowledged that the Social Security program will need adjustments to remain solvent and prevent larger budget deficits. This is a welcome change of heart for Mr. Gingrich, who, with fellow Republicans as well as Democrats, effectively put Social Security reform off the table during the 1994 campaign. 
 The problem lies in Mr. Gingrich's timetable. He says re-examination of Social Security must be delayed until early in the next century and cites "a lack of moral authority" in the current generation of politicians as the principal reason for delay.
Social Security is a politically volatile subject that many politicians dare not honestly confront, despite the obvious burden these expenditures place on the budget and on future generations. But in not addressing the issue now, our leaders contribute to a self-fulfilling prophesy about lack of moral authority.
Our elected officials must face up to our entitlements crisis without delay, for we will pay dearly for inaction. Look at the numbers:
* Entitlement programs and interest on the debt consume more than 60 percent of the budget. In 2012, spending on entitlements and the national debt will exceed tax revenues, according to the Bipartisan Commission on Entitlement and Tax Reform. America will be broke.
* Federal outlays are 22 percent of the economy, and revenues are 19 percent. By 2030, outlays are projected to exceed 37 percent of the economy. The same year, spending on Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid and Federal employee pension programs will exceed all revenues.
* In 2013, Social Security (the largest entitlement) benefit payments will exceed taxes collected to pay for the program. Contrary to popular wisdom, Social Security has always been a pay-as-you-go system, which means today's workers are paying the retirement benefits of people who are retired today.
* By 2029, the Social Security trust fund will have been used up because of radical demographic changes. When Social Security was created, there were 17 people working for every person who was retired and receiving benefits. Today there are only 3.8 working people for every retired person receiving benefits.
When Social Security was conceived, average life expectancy was just 63 years, yet people did not become eligible for benefits until they turned 65. Today, the average life span is 77 years, with Social Security eligibility at 67. This means more people receive benefits paid for by fewer workers, and for much longer periods than before.
It is self-defeating to wait until the next century to address the complicated and explosive issue of Social Security reform. By then, our nation will not possess the resources to meet the challenge equitably. The time to start making tough choices is now.
 
MICHAEL HOLTZMAN
New York, Jan. 4, 1995
 
The writer heads New York State Concord Coalition, a national organization dedicated to eliminating Federal budget deficits.

HEADLINE: For Whitman, A Political Star Adding Luster

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Wedged between Alexander and Kemp and only coincidentally to the left of Dole and Gramm, buttons touting Gov. Christine Todd Whitman for President are doing a brisk business this year at Political Americana, a Washington store that sells Presidential political memorabilia.
"Whitman is in with the pack," says Jimmy Warlick, the president of Political Americana and an amateur political prognosticator who has built his business largely around predicting who is politically hot with the public and who is not. "Right now, Governor Whitman is doing very well. Her buttons are selling good. It's hard to tell whether people are buying them because they view her as a potential Presidential candidate or as a Vice-Presidential candidate, but they are buying them." 
 In the year since Mrs. Whitman took office -- the first woman to run New Jersey's government -- and even before she gives her first State of the State speech on Tuesday, she has skyrocketed to national political stardom.
And while she is quite popular in her home state, she has also worked very hard positioning herself as a national player politically. She went around the country campaigning on behalf of Republican candidates, with the trips paid for in part by her own state's party. These trips garnered Mrs. Whitman a tremendous amount of national media attention.
She sent her State Commissioner of Commerce all over the world in 1994 and has her own plans to visit Canada and Mexico this year, setting the stage for the kind of international exposure that a national candidate needs. Today, Newt Gingrich, the new House Speaker, praised her as a model of leadership for the new Congress. And though she and a key adviser, Malcolm S. Forbes Jr., the publisher and longtime champion of tax cutting, are coy about it, other political observers believe that Mrs. Whitman is moving herself toward the national political stage.
"Everybody knows she has certainly been preening herself for national office," said Gary Nordlinger, president of Nordlinger Associates, a Washington-based political consultancy that works with Democratic Party candidates.
"She has given speeches all over the place to Republican groups," Mr. Nordlinger said, "and she has campaigned across the country for Republican candidates in the off-year election this year, which are all the traditional signs for people who want national attention."
So far, whenever the subject of national office arises -- particularly the picture of Mrs. Whitman as an attractive Vice-Presidential choice -- she has responded with the politically obligatory brushoff.
"I'm tired of it," Mrs. Whitman said. "It's hard for some people to understand that I just don't pay a whole lot of attention to it because to me it's so silly, it's so outside the realm of possibility that it's not something that you should waste time thinking about it."
But, still, she leaves the door ajar.
"My brother keeps getting on me, saying you have to believe you can be a good governor to be governor," she said. "I hope I can be a very good governor for the state of New Jersey. Does that necessarily translate into doing something on the national scene? Well?"
The national political scene has long been on the mind of Mr. Forbes, even before he agreed to lead an economic advisory group for her 1993 campaign. He is chairman of Empower America, a Washington group affiliated with, among others, Mr. Gingrich.
The friendship and political bond between Mrs. Whitman and Mr. Forbes goes back to their childhood, when their wealthy families, both with deep Republican Party roots, were neighbors. Those ties have since grown considerably more sophisticated. Over the years, Mr. Forbes has sidestepped elected politics for himself and has instead been content to play an unofficial but nevertheless very influential role in the political fortunes of Mrs. Whitman and others.
In November, after Mrs. Whitman gave a showcase speech at the Republican Governors Association meeting in Williamsburg, Va., Mr. Forbes followed her to the stage to deliver a speech of his own.
But Mr. Forbes says the Governor is not consumed by national political ambitions.
"Whatever she may think in her mind, Christie has not put the buzz out, she has not called me up and said, 'How should I position myself?' " Mr. Forbes said.
"I imagine Phil Gramm, Lamar Alexander and others have been saying very nice things to her," Mr. Forbes said. "That's part of the mating dance. If you are not carrying the plague, outsiders will say nice things about you if they want your support. The question is who is going to get the ring in the morning, and you really can't tell at this point."
That has not stopped Mr. Forbes from offering Mrs. Whitman advice on the broader points of politics while pointing out where others, most notably George Bush, have failed.
"One of the arguments that really impressed her was that she had to have her own agenda, that if she just won the election without an agenda, she would be cut to pieces," Mr. Forbes said.
An important part of that agenda, co-written by Mr. Forbes, has been a tax-cutting program that has been Mrs. Whitman's springboard to the national political scene. She has also positioned herself at the forefront of the debate over abortion, where her stance is in favor of abortion rights, and she supports changes in the welfare system. And today she was in Washington with fellow Republican governors pressing for action on two constitutional amendments: one requiring a balanced budget and another prohibiting the Federal Government from passing mandates on to the states without coming up with the money to pay for them.
"If the price that I have to pay to finally stop all this speculation," Governor Whitman said in a recent interview, "is to stop doing things that I think are right for New Jersey and not speak out on some of the major issues, I'm not willing to pay that price."
The New Jersey Republican Party was willing to pay the price for many of Mrs. Whitman's 1994 campaign trips for Republican candidates outside New Jersey. Why?
"What the Governor wants, the Governor gets," a senior party official said.
From Rhode Island to California, Mrs. Whitman campaigned for 22 Republican candidates for major office and raised $3.5 million for their races -- collecting a wealth of political i.o.u.'s and political exposure along the way. And on Election Day, 18 of her candidates won, including George E. Pataki in New York and John G. Rowland in Connecticut.
Mrs. Whitman has also pursued an aggressive campaign to make New Jersey what she calls "business friendly." Not coincidentally, senior officials in the State Commerce Department say, the effort may also be opening the way for her to speak out on foreign affairs. Her Commissioner of Commerce and Economic Development, Gualberto Medina, has made a string of trips to Mexico, Canada, the Netherlands, Germany, Britain and Russia -- and State Commerce Department officials speculate that besides courting trade, he may be paving the way for visits by Mrs. Whitman.
Mrs. Whitman has already said she will visit Canada and Mexico in 1995 as the head of a state trade mission to expand business under the North American Free Trade Agreement and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
"Nobody runs for Vice President," said Mr. Nordlinger, the Democratic political consultant. "But if you rattled off a half-dozen people who would be good Vice-Presidential candidates, Whitman would be on the list. But those decisions are 18 months away. Whatever her long-term future is will depend on how she will wear on the people of New Jersey."
So far, Mrs. Whitman is wearing extremely well with the majority of New Jersey residents and with a host of Republicans who have at least considered the idea of running for President.
Both Bob Dole, now the Senate majority leader, and Jack F. Kemp, the former Federal Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, made sure that their campaign trips to New Jersey during last year's United States Senate race included a courtesy visit with Mrs. Whitman. Mr. Alexander, the former Tennessee Governor, former United States Cabinet member and Presidential hopeful, has also visited the State House in Trenton.
Even for a politician, Mrs. Whitman has enjoyed a year of an almost embarrassing richness of attention.
Newsweek magazine listed the New Jersey Governor as one of the six most influential Republicans in the nation. (The others were Mr. Dole; Mr. Gingrich; Rush Limbaugh, the talk-show host and author; William Kristol, the Republican strategist who was chief of staff for Vice President Dan Quayle, and Ralph Reed, leader of the Christian Coalition.)
People magazine called Mrs. Whitman one of the 25 most intriguing people of 1994.
And then there are Mr. Warlick's buttons.
"My theory is when you do a telephone poll with voters, people might not be so straightforward," said Mr. Warlick, who has conducted a button poll among customers at his Political Americana stores during the last two Presidential elections, coming within 2 percent of the margin of Bill Clinton's victory in 1992. "But when people put three dollars down for a button, they are not apathetic."
Right now, Mr. Warlick said, Mr. Alexander's buttons are the hottest, while sales of Mr. Dole's buttons have been steady.
"Kemp has dipped," he said. "Whitman is the only woman in the pack and she is doing well."

HEADLINE: Group Homes, Havens for the Mentally Ill, Fight Mistrust

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SOMERS, N.Y.

 BODY:
The smell of ashes still lingers over a placid country road here seven weeks after someone set fire to a driftwood-gray house chosen as a home for 12 mentally ill men.
The fire in November at 6 Manor Lane, which authorities have ruled an arson, staggered residents, even those opposed to the arrival of the men. 
 William C. Harding, the Town Supervisor, said he told opponents of the home, "You've got bigger problems than you had before." He continued, "You now have someone who's crazy enough to set a house on fire."
But ultimately the arson has not changed many feelings in Somers, a northern Westchester County town, not even Mr. Harding's.
In December, two weeks after the fire, more than 100 residents crowded into Town Hall to protest the proposed group home. Two days later, the town board, including Mr. Harding, voted unanimously to ask the sponsoring agency, Rehabilitation Support Services, to delay the project until another site in Somers could be found. A hearing is now likely before the State Mental Health Commissioner.
For more than a decade, state-financed group homes -- ordinary houses with a dozen or so residents and 24-hour staffing -- have formed the heart of the state's effort to treat the mentally ill outside the locked wards of mammoth hospitals. In New York State, more people now live in group homes and supervised apartments (13,575) than in mental hospitals (9,075). The reason is as much financial as anything else. The yearly cost of keeping a patient in a group home is about $35,000, compared with $120,000 for hospitalization.
But as the battle in Somers and similar ones in the Westchester towns of Greenburgh and Mount Pleasant testify, the coming of a group home is not yet taken as nonchalantly as the arrival of a new neighbor. Indeed, there have been a half dozen cases of arson associated with group homes on Long Island alone in the last decade. As a result, state and county officials are increasingly reluctant to finance group homes.
[The arrest of a mentally ill New York City man who had escaped from a state hospital and was then charged with pushing a woman to her death under a subway train on Jan. 4 provided new ammunition for those who oppose such homes. But advocates for the mentally ill say group homes do not accept violent felons. They also say the incident points out the needs for more such intensively supervised community programs that monitor residents' medication and condition.]
In December 1993, the State Legislature allocated $153 million of the savings from hospital-bed closings for psychological and social support for people in group homes and apartments. But none of this so-called "reinvestment" money was earmarked for new group homes. Group-home operators say the decision was a concession to the political reality that opening group homes is more difficult than dispersing the mentally ill in apartments.
The problem with the apartment approach, said Dr. Peter Campanelli, president of Institute for Community Living, a group-home operator, is that "not everybody is ready to live in an apartment." Many require the daily supervision available in a group home, he indicated.
Whenever the site of a group home is chosen, neighbors have expressed fears about violent encounters or worries about finding buyers for their own houses. A woman who three years ago opposed a group home near her house in Yorktown admits there have been no problems, but she is still concerned.
"Maybe it's selfish to worry about property values, but we don't have much else," she said, speaking on condition of anonymity. "This is where our money is."
Group home residents are familiar with such opposition. The 12 men waiting to move into the Somers house have been living since 1988 in a spacious hilltop mansion called Pleasant Ridge in Wingdale, N.Y. -- 45 miles north of New York City -- that used to house the director of the nearby Harlem Valley Psychiatric Center. The hospital was shuttered in February, and the group home is being closed since the residents no longer have easy access to the services once available at the hospital.
"The whole thing is an outrage," said one of the men, Rich, 32, a former Larchmont resident, who Rehabilitation Support Services insisted could not be completely identified. "I understand that economically they're afraid of being hurt, that their property values will go down. We live in a house right now that has great value. If you walk around the house, you'll see nothing misplaced. Great care is taken and we choose to live here."
The men all have what they call the "double trouble" of histories of drug or alcohol abuse on top of manic depression or other mental illnesses that they temper with medication. But none has a history of violent crimes and there have been no violent episodes, said Carol Bianco, director of program development for Rehabilitation Support Services.
Several men work part time, and all spend part of their days at drug and alcohol treatment programs, at therapy or at a social center. They divide cooking and cleaning chores. The home has a staff of nine counselors and social workers.
Rich is pursuing a master's degree in social work at New York University. Before his mental illness was diagnosed, he graduated from Iona College and owned a limousine business. "I was having lots of problems inside," he said. "I got a lot of money and proceeded to put that money into heroin."
The men take vacations together and last summer rented a house in Ocean City, N.J., where, Rich said, "We cooked hamburgers and hot dogs like everyone else." Sometimes, the men say, personal problems lead to relapses into drinking or drugs. But the staff and their fellow residents, they say, are teaching them to avoid such setbacks.
"I always thought I'd be able to make it, but I didn't have the skills," said another resident, Michael, 34, of Mount Vernon. "You come into this house, you learn how to cook, how to clean, how to keep yourself presentable. I never knew how to do any of that. I was always running the street."
The 12-room, $510,000 house in Somers where these residents still expect to live is much like any of the other older homes on Manor Lane. It is in a bucolic section of Somers, a middle-class town of 18,000 just a generation removed from its blue-collar roots.
"It's a back street full of houses where folks have scrimped and saved their entire life to move into a beautiful, expensive house, and they're concerned that this doesn't fit with the character of their homes," said Mr. Harding, the supervisor.
On Nov. 22, a week after Rehabilitation Support Services notified town officials of its plans for a home, someone broke into 6 Manor Lane and poured a kerosene-like accelerant near the back door and staircase, then lighted a match. The walls were severely damaged and the floor is still blackened with ash, but the structural beams are intact, and the state has pledged to finance the necessary repairs.
More than a week after the fire, someone invaded the house once more and stole its furnace and water heater. No arrests have been made.
"I'm embarrassed to admit that this would happen in Somers," Mr. Harding said. But, he added, "It does not mitigate the fears and concerns of people on Manor Lane."
Richard Taylor, an electrician who lives next to 6 Manor Lane, accuses Rehabilitation Support Services of pushing ahead without sufficiently telling the town about the psychiatric and criminal backgrounds of residents and the training of the staff. He said he worried that an untrained worker assigned alone at night would not be able to deal with quirks in the behavior of a former drug addict or alcoholic.
"If this was a home for autistic children, I'd be there swinging a hammer," he said. "But they're ramming it down our throats without giving us the answers to our questions."
Mr. Harding and Mr. Taylor have both visited Pleasant Ridge to see their prospective neighbors, and Mr. Harding said he was impressed with the residents' struggle to resume industrious lives. He particularly enjoyed meeting a resident named George who had attended his alma mater, Marist College in Poughkeepsie. George reminded him that there was a mental hospital next door to Marist and the campus joke was that if things got out of hand, that's where students would end up.
"I did," George said.
Not every neighbor on Manor Lane is adamantly opposed. A woman who lives a few doors away, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said she had two small daughters and only wanted to be assured that no one had a "background of hurting children." But she is familiar with mental illness because her husband's brother has lived in a group home and, she said, "He's a sweetheart. He wouldn't hurt anyone."
Steven Greenfield, executive director of the Association of Community Living, an organization of group-home operators, said that in six years there have been two murders involving the 15,000 people who have passed through group homes in New York State. In one case the victim was a staff member, in the other a resident. He also pointed to several studies that found property values did not decline after a group home opens in a neighborhood.
"The people with mental illness are no more violent that the rest of the population and, in fact, tend to be more victims than victimizers," he said.
When a state hearing is held, Mr. Harding says the town will argue that it has enough institutional housing, with four group homes for the retarded and a residence for youthful offenders. That is the only argument that can block a group home. Rehabilitation Support Services vows it will not be turned back.
"It's an act of terrorism against a group of individuals," said Bill Schwarz, a spokesman for the organization. "A crime has been committed here and it would send a dangerous precedent if we didn't move forward."

HEADLINE: E. Ira Marienhoff, High School Teacher, 72

 BODY:
E. Ira Marienhoff, who taught social studies in New York City schools for nearly five decades, died on Dec. 17 in the hospice of Beth Israel Hospital. He was 72 and lived in Teaneck, N.J.
The cause was cancer, said Dr. Anthony Miserandino, the principal of Hunter College High School, where Mr. Marienhoff taught history, political science and economics for the last 28 years. 
 Before joining Hunter, he taught at the High School for Music and Art, the Machine and Metal Trades High School and George Washington High School.
He also wrote a textbook with Roy Sampson and William Mortenson, "The American Economy," which was used by high school students in the early 1970's.
He received an undergraduate degree from City College in 1942 and a master's degree in history from Columbia University Teacher's College in 1948.

HEADLINE: PULSE;
Tourism

 BODY:
Tourism accounts for more than $20 billion in economic activity each year, and spending by visitors generated about 268,000 jobs in the region in 1992, according to a study released last month by the Port Authority. The report is the second part of the Port Authority's study of the economic impact of the arts and tourism on the New York-New Jersey region. While tourism in the area is expected to continue to grow, the region is facing increasing competition for visitors.
Promotion seems to be helping in the tourism industry. The state travel office budgets in New York and New Jersey for fiscal 1992-93 were $11 million and $5 million. Visitor spending in 1992 generated tax revenues of $630 million in New York and $130 million in New Jersey.

HEADLINE: Modest Rally Seen for Dollar in '95

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
After a year of unexpected weakness, the dollar is set to appreciate modestly against other major currencies this year, in the view of many bankers and economists. The rally, they say, will be helped by the expectation of a narrowing United States trade deficit and pledges by the Republicans controlling Congress to start slaughtering sacred budget cows.
But in an age of global capital flows where the bias is still against the dollar, the American currency is not set to regain the strength it showed in the 1980's, when it reached 277.65 yen and 3.4525 marks to the dollar, or even the modestly bullish values at the beginning of the 1990's, when the dollar reached 159.90 yen and 1.8350 marks. 
 "The dollar remains structurally weak," said Robert D. Hormats of Goldman, Sachs International, pointing to America's history of persistent trade deficits that keep dollars pouring out of the country as imports of foreign goods exceed exports of American products. American investors are also discovering the allure of markets abroad and selling dollars to buy foreign currencies, stocks and bonds.
At the end of last week, the dollar was at 101.37 yen to the dollar, up from 99.58 at the end of 1994 and its highest New York close since August. Against the mark, the dollar was at 1.5650, up from 1.5495 at the end of last year but below its recent high of 1.5814 on Dec. 21.
A rise in the dollar would have varying effects. For the Federal Reserve, it could reduce inflationary pressures as foreign goods become less expensive and American producers hold back some price increases of their own to remain competitive. Trips abroad would be less expensive for American tourists.
On the other hand, American exports would be a little more expensive -- and a little less competitive -- abroad. But because the dollar is rising from record low levels, the impact should not be that severe.
The widespread expectation now is that as the Federal Reserve continues to raise short-term interest rates in 1995, foreign investors should find the dollar more attractive. In addition, imports will slow and exports pick up as the European and Japanese recoveries gather steam.
This will reduce America's current account deficit -- the balance of its trade and investment income flows with the rest of the world -- and strengthen the dollar.
The financial crisis in Mexico may also give the dollar a bit of help in coming weeks if it slows the flow of American investment into other emerging markets around the world.
"Eventually, additional Fed tightening moves, moderating inflation concerns, improving trade performance and a new decline in long-term U.S. bond yields should provide the U.S. currency with a modest lift versus European currencies and the yen," says Solomon Brothers chief economist, John Lipsky.
It is anyone's guess how far the Republican majority in Congress will go in carrying out the pledge it made in its "Contract with America" to cut the Federal budget deficit significantly while reducing taxes and increasing military spending.
But anything they do this year to start bringing down that deficit in 1996 "should have an immediate good expectational effect on the dollar," said Mr. Lipsky, who expects to see the dollar trading by year-end around 1.60 marks to the dollar and 108 to 110 yen.
A year ago most experts believed 1994 would see a rising dollar as the American economy cooled and there was a rise in exports to a recovering Europe and Japan, narrowing the trade gap. At the same time, Japan would continue to invest its export surplus in dollar securities. "That was definitely the consensus, but it never happened," said Stephen Roach, co-director of global economy at Morgan Stanley.
The American economy kept growing more vigorously than expected while the Japanese virtually stopped buying American securities altogether as the dollar sank to a record low against the yen.
From being worth 1.76 German marks and 113 Japanese yen at its 1994 high early last year, the dollar declined to a low for the year of 1.4909 marks and 96.61 in the fall before turning up a little at the end of the year. For 1994 as a whole, the dollar fell by 10.9 percent against the mark and 11 percent against the yen.
For many market watchers that late-year uptick in the dollar's fortunes was significant because it appeared to reflect the Republican election victory and the Federal Reserve's unexpectedly sharp monetary tightening in November, the two basic reasons for anticipating a stronger dollar in 1995.
"The Fed tightening and the Congressional elections had a good influence on foreign confidence," notes Mickey Levy, chief economist with Nationsbank Capital Markets Inc.
How far and how fast the current account deficit will contract remains a matter of some dispute, raising doubts as to exactly when the dollar will move unambiguously onto a firmer track.
As economies strengthen in Europe and Japan while the American economy slows, Robert Solomon, a former chief international economist at the Federal Reserve and now with the Brookings Institution in Washington, said that he expected a "considerable improvement" in the current account deficit, predicting that it could fall to "well below $100 billion" from $138 billion last year. This would slow the dollar outflow and help bolster the dollar.
But David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago, believes full order books will send American imports soaring this year, pushing the deficit on foreign trade alone up from $157 billion in 1994 to $200 billion this year, with a decrease coming only in 1996.
The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the Paris-based club of rich industrial nations, sees even larger numbers in its latest forecasts published in December. These show the current account deficit rising to $173 billion this year and only slipping back marginally to $169 billion in 1996.
The key to a dollar revival, many experts say, will be a sense in financial markets that the Federal Reserve has tightened monetary policy enough to lower economic growth to the Fed's target range of around 2.5 percent and that the next move in American interest rates will be downward.
"The bond market is the best bellwether for the dollar" said Geoffrey Bell of Geoffrey Bell & Company, a New York investment advisory firm. "Fund managers are interested in total returns, not yields. When bond prices are weak, they keep away from that currency. But when interest rates turn down, you'll see investors piling into the dollar."

The Economy
 With incomes, jobs and confidence increasing, the American consumer is still going strong. Total consumer spending rose about 4 percent after inflation in 1994, faster than in all but two years in the 1980's. But whether consumers will be able to sustain that pace is a matter of debate. [Page A1.] 
 Top Republicans in Congress and Vice President Gore will stake out competing positions about the best way to rewrite the nation's 60-year-old telecommunications laws. [D1.]
 Before the break in the F.C.C's auction of licenses for wireless communications, which began last month, bids had been rising at a tortoise-like pace. Then Craig O. McCaw, the cellular pioneer, tripled Pacific Telesis's bid for a Los Angeles license. [D1.]
 Property-rights advocates are growing in strength and numbers, with environmental laws as their chief target. Since the late 1980's, about 600 property-rights groups have been formed. [A1.]
 Congress's practice of exempting itself from many civil rights, work safety and employment laws may soon end. But it is unclear whether the changes will make much of a difference. [B8.]

HEADLINE: A Personal 'Chronicler' for Newt Gingrich

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
In appointing an outspoken political supporter and former colleague from Georgia as the new House historian, Newt Gingrich is also gaining something no Speaker has ever had -- a personal "chronicler."
The new historian, 47-year-old Christina Jeffrey, an assistant professor of political science at Kennesaw State University in Georgia, where Mr. Gingrich once taught, said that her husband, Robert, also a professor from Georgia, would be "chronicling the Speaker and doing for the Republicans what academics did for F.D.R." 
 "It hasn't been done as well by Republicans and has never been done on a day-to-day basis for a Speaker," she said, "and Newt is very interested in that."
She said her husband, an assistant professor of political science at Dalton College in Georgia, would work without a salary. "This is an economy move for the House," said Mrs. Jeffrey, who will make $ 85,000 a year. "They are getting two academics for the price of one."
Nonetheless, the new House historian said today in a telephone interview that while she was an avid supporter of Mr. Gingrich, she would run the historian's office in a bipartisan manner.
Mrs. Jeffrey was actually named House historian by Mr. Gingrich in mid-December, but her appointment was never officially announced and did not become public until a few days ago.
Thomas Mann, a Congressional scholar at the Brookings Institution, said the husband-and-wife team "raises all the questions about a Gingrich machine being lodged in the House."
"I look in amazement at how effective he has been and see the extraordinary transition he has led, and then I get disappointed in his lapse in judgment," Mr. Mann said. "This is a very questionable appointment."
The dispute over the historian's office comes just as criticism was subsiding over a $ 4.5 million advance that Mr. Gingrich had planned to accept for writing two books. Under pressure, Mr. Gingrich backed off the book deal, announcing that he would instead accept only a $ 1 advance, plus royalties, for the books.
The status of the historian's office has been shrouded in confusion since the week after Christmas, when its ousted employees said that the office had been abolished in an economy move by the new Republican majority and that they were packing their belongings.
But in an interview with C-Span that was recorded Dec. 30 and broadcast on Jan. 2, Mr. Gingrich said the office had not been abolished. "There will be an Historian's Office," he said, and he wanted it to help educate the public about the House. He did not mention that he had already appointed a supporter of his as the historian and that she and her husband had already rented a town house in suburban Washington.
Mrs. Jeffrey said today that as a political scientist at Kennesaw, situated in Mr. Gingrich's Congressional district north of Atlanta, she had supplied student interns for his district office. But she did not come to know him, she said, until he began teaching his course, "Renewing American Civilization," at the college in 1993.
While other professors opposed allowing a highly partisan elected official like Mr. Gingrich to teach at a publicly financed college, Mrs. Jeffrey supported him. "I like Newt's ideas," she said.
Mrs. Jeffrey said today: "I stood up for academic freedom and freedom of speech. The people involved in that controversy admitted the problem was Newt and his ideas. It would have been no problem if it was Sam Nunn. This was content-specific."
The course was financed by the Progress and Freedom Foundation, a conservative research organization started by a longtime associate of Mr. Gingrich, and had links to his political action committee, Gopac, which in the past kept its donors secret. The course and its financing are now being reviewed by the House ethics committee.
Mrs. Jeffrey said she believed in secret campaign financing because it protected contributors from revenge by incumbents. "I believe in leveling the playing field," she said. "I think incumbents have an unfair advantage, and that includes Newt Gingrich, and the disclosure laws increase that advantage.
"If I understand Gopac," she added, "it's a way of getting around the campaign finance disclosure laws so people can contribute to challengers and they aren't necessarily identified as an enemy of the incumbent. I would support doing away with most campaign finance disclosure laws."
She stated similar views in a letter to The Atlanta Constitution last fall, and that opinion is one of the reasons the appointment is already drawing criticism on Capitol Hill. Representative David E. Bonior, a Michigan Democrat who is now the minority whip, said it showed "poor judgment." Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, called it "tacky." Mr. Gingrich could not be reached for comment yesterday.
Mrs. Jeffrey received her master's degree and doctorate in political science at the University of Alabama.
She said she agreed completely with Mr. Gingrich's ideas for the office.
"Considering what the Speaker wants to do with the job," Mrs. Jeffrey said today, "I think I'm a perfectly logical person to do it. As a political scientist, I don't have any problem with patronage, as long as people are qualified, and elected officials ought to appoint people who share their vision, and I certainly fit that description."

An article yesterday about the appointment of Christina Jeffrey as historian for the House of Representatives misstated her title at Kennesaw State College in Georgia. She is an associate professor of political science, not an assistant professor.

HEADLINE: 2 Parties Do Balancing Acts on Budget

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
The new leader of the Senate's 47 Democrats said today that he was "absolutely" willing to make a detailed proposal to balance the Federal budget by 2002, just as his party's leaders are demanding of Congress's new Republican majority.
Still, the Democratic leader, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, did not say he would actually do so. Instead, he and other Democrats indicated that they would not offer any budget-balancing plan until Republicans did. 
 And Republicans indicated that they would not present their own plan to erase the deficit -- at least not until Congress passed a constitutional amendment mandating a balanced budget, and perhaps not even then.
With some variations, this is pretty much what Republicans and Democrats have said in debates about the steadily growing Federal debt for close to a decade. Mr. Daschle and other leaders of both parties said it again in interviews on television news programs today, but it is more important now because a balanced-budget amendment may well pass Congress this year.
If so, one side or the other, or both, will either have to make good on its promises or find a way around them.
The White House says that the deficit has fallen from the $ 305 billion a year projected when Mr. Clinton took office to an estimated $ 203 billion in the fiscal year that ended in September, largely because of a growing economy and the $ 450 billion package of spending cuts and tax increases that Congress enacted in 1993. But without further restraints, fiscal experts say, the deficit will resume its rise in 1996.
The comments by Mr. Daschle today were notable because he is the sole Democrat in the party's leadership who supports a balanced-budget amendment, and who voted for one in the Senate last March. President Clinton and the House minority leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, have argued that an amendment with a specific deadline for wiping out the deficit could lead to drastic cuts in programs that millions of Americans need.
Mr. Gephardt called the amendment "a pig in a poke" last week, arguing that it was irresponsible for Republicans to promote a balanced-budget amendment without telling citizens what painful spending cuts would be needed to achieve that goal.
Today, on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," Mr. Daschle was asked several times whether, as a supporter of a balanced-budget amendment, he was willing to offer the same kind of plan to end the deficit by 2002 that the White House is demanding of Republicans.
"Absolutely," he said. "Ask the Republicans if they're willing to join us."
Asked what that plan would include, Mr. Daschle replied, "We are willing to put that on paper; we're willing to work with them to make sure that it happens." But he then accused Republicans of "flipping around like fish on a deck right now, not willing to be specific with regard to how they're going to do it." He did not return to the subject of his own deficit-cutting plans.
Speaking on the same program, Mr. Gephardt said moments later: "Tom is willing to do that. We agree on how this should be done. People have a right to know in the country what this means in their life."
But Mr. Gephardt did not say when or how Mr. Daschle would offer such a plan, either.
For their part, Republicans who appeared on television today were little more specific.
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority whip, said Congress would receive a Republican proposal this spring to cut $ 300 billion to $ 350 billion from the deficit over the next five years, a figure he called "a real serious down payment" on the deficit problem.
But by some reckoning, it will require much more -- $ 1.1 trillion in spending cuts or tax increases, or both -- to balance the budget in the seven years that most proposals for a constitutional amendment envision.
Mr. Lott and other Republicans, like Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, who appeared today on the ABC News program "This Week," suggested some ways to come up with part of that money. Those tactics included proposals from Republican governors that Mr. Lott said could save $ 147 billion over five years, and a suggestion by Mr. Gramm that the Education Department be abolished and half of its budget given back to the states.
But when Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, was asked whether a realistic balanced-budget plan would demand deep cuts in most agencies and programs, he replied: "Well, there's all kinds of complexities because we haven't divested ourselves yet from the mythology of what is called current services baseline budgeting. So what's a cut? I'd have to ask that question."
Mr. Armey also said Republicans were unlikely to offer a specific plan for erasing the deficit until after the amendment was considered, because offering a plan first would cause too many political problems.
In a separate development, both Mr. Gephardt and Vice President Al Gore -- who appeared on the CBS program "Face the Nation" -- voiced strong support for an increase in the minimum wage. But Mr. Gore said the President has yet to decide what to do. Mr. Clinton is reported to be considering increasing the $ 4.25-an-hour wage floor by $ 1.
"It's farther behind reality than it's been in 20 years," he said, "so there's a very strong argument for it. And I think there's a consensus building in the country."
Back on NBC, the wage proposal led to a brief but intense debate between Mr. Gephardt, who called it a just reward for millions of hard-working people, and Mr. Armey, who asserted that it was a vote-getting stunt at odds with good economic policy.
"What they're saying," Mr. Gephardt said of the Republicans, "is that people that work at Wal-Mart and McDonald's should not get any increase in the minimum wage."
"Dick, you're in a state of denial," Mr. Armey responded.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 11, 1995, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about Congressional debate over a balanced-budget amendment misstated the extent of its support among Democrats. While Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Senate minority leader, supports such an amendment, he is not alone. Others, including Senator Wendell H. Ford of Kentucky, agree with him.
