HEADLINE: A Retreat on Denying Welfare to Immigrants

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9

 BODY:
House Speaker Newt Gingrich today backed away from his party's plan to deny food, health and welfare benefits to hundreds of thousands of low-income immigrants who are in the country legally.
He said Republicans would "revisit" the plan to drop legal immigrants from welfare rolls, but said sponsors "should take a fairly significant responsibility" for the immigrants they bring to the United States. 
 "I think legal immigration has given America many of its most dynamic and creative citizens," Mr. Gingrich said at a news conference to promote the restaurant industry's role in welfare change, "and I think that we would be a very, very self-destructive country if we sent negative signals on legal immigration."
As he spoke, Mr. Gingrich was surrounded by restaurant managers, chefs, owners and corporate officials who began their careers washing dishes, sweeping floors and making salads.
Herman Cain, president of the National Restaurant Association and Godfather's Pizza Inc., promised that his industry would give welfare recipients jobs, training and a chance to gain economic success.
The "Contract With America," the blueprint on which many Republican candidates ran for the House in the last election, includes a welfare bill that would impose time limits and work requirements on welfare recipients while stripping most legal immigrants of public assistance.
Last week, an analysis of the Republican plan by the Social Security Administration found that at least 400,000 legal immigrants would be denied benefits from Supplemental Security Income, a welfare program for the elderly, blind and disabled.
The Republicans estimated savings from its ban on welfare to immigrants at $22 billion over five years.
But today, Mr. Gingrich said Republicans believed they could save much more by freezing welfare spending, collapsing hundreds of social programs and turning over much of the responsibility for the poor to the states, in block grants.
"The governors have just told us they are prepared to accept a cap for five years, which gives us $40 billion," Mr. Gingrich said. "The governors are prepared to say to us if we will radically decentralize, give them the job, they will do the job."
Under current law, the affidavits of support that sponsors are required to sign are legally unenforceable, said Dan Stein, executive director of the Federation for American Immigration Reform, a group that advocates tougher immigration requirements.
Mr. Gingrich said, "I have no problems saying if you're going to sponsor somebody to come to the U.S., we're prepared to make that sponsorship real and binding."
He said sponsors could be held liable for the immigrant for three to five years, but declined to say that the Republicans had had a "change of heart" on the issue.
"We did not control the Congress," he said. "We didn't have access to the resources. We were trying to find the least destructive way to pay for a very, very important program."

HEADLINE: Tons of Cocaine Reaching Mexico in Old Jets

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 9

 BODY:
In a daunting new turn in the traffic of Colombian cocaine into the United States, smugglers are buying old passenger jets, taking out the seats and using the planes to fly huge amounts of the drug into Mexico, American and Mexican officials say.
Traveling at night with their lights off, the Boeing 727's and French-made Caravelle jets are believed to be carrying as much as six tons or more of cocaine on a single flight. 
 The cocaine is then transported overland into the United States, where the wholesale value of such a load is about $120 million.
"This is creating new economies of scale," said a senior American official, who, like others, discussed the development on condition he not be identified. "They are able to bring tremendously large amounts of cocaine in on a single aircraft."
Although the traffickers have occasionally used 727-type aircraft of their own or smuggled their cargoes on passenger airlines in the past, drug-enforcement officials say a more ominous pattern has developed over the last eight months.
In that time, six such planes are confirmed to have landed in Mexico with big loads of cocaine bound for the United States. But drug-control radar and intelligence reports suggest that many others may have landed, unloaded and escaped back to Colombia, officials said.
Before the planes set out, false identification numbers are often painted or pasted over the old ones. The radar transponders that allow them to be tracked easily by air-traffic controllers are shut off. Whatever their flight plans, they file none.
The jets fly much faster than most of Mexico's drug-interdiction aircraft, mainly smaller Cessnas, and are inexpensive enough, in a market glutted with newer planes, for the traffickers to abandon them on a remote airstrip if they need to. Officials say that even when they are detected by the radar surveillance planes that the United States regularly flies over the Caribbean, the flights are difficult to catch.
There is no clear evidence that the traffickers' use of jets has yet had any significant effect on the amount of cocaine smuggled into the United States. But even so, the advent of the jets has raised new tensions between the United States and the Governments of Colombia and Mexico, American officials and foreign diplomats say.
American officials say the flights could not possibly take off from airports in Colombia and on the Colombian island of San Andres, in the Caribbean about 110 miles east of the Nicaragua, without the assent or aid of the local authorities. But the officials say their protests have been all but ignored by the Government of President Ernesto Samper.
"San Andres is completely in the hands of the traffickers," a senior American official said. "And the Colombian Government is doing zero about it."
The landings in Mexico have heightened American suspicions about collusion with the traffickers by Mexican aviation officials and a fast-growing Mexican airline with ties to one of the most prominent old-line politicians in the governing party. American officials say they take for granted the traffickers' corruption of police forces in Mexico, through which about two-thirds of all Colombian cocaine is believed to enter the United States.
Mexican law-enforcement officials respond that they are just as concerned about the flights as their American counterparts but have limited resources to stop them. Despite greater controls on airports and the sale of aircraft fuel and new efforts by the military to shut down clandestine airstrips, Mexico seized only about 18.3 tons of cocaine in the first eight months of last year, down from 46.2 tons in 1993.
Some American officials have suggested that the Mexican Air Force might use its F-5 fighter planes to pursue the jets. But a Mexican official, noting the Government's longstanding concerns about the potential for corruption in the armed forces if they are given drug-interdiction duties, said that the military would "absolutely not" be used.
After years in which smugglers flew tons of drugs into northern Mexico and directly into the southwestern United States in small planes, the Drug Enforcement Administration began building an elaborate curtain of radar and aircraft to keep them out. Although the barricade proved notoriously porous, it eventually forced the traffickers to land their planes deeper in Mexico.
Over the last two years, after the D.E.A.'s so-called Northern Border Response Force grew more effective in its coverage of the Mexican mainland in coordination with the Mexican Attorney General's office, the traffickers took to flying and air-dropping cocaine into southern Mexico from Guatemala and El Salvador. The loads are usually then transported to the United States border in cars and trucks.
Mexican and American law-enforcement officials say they are also seeing a worrisome rise in cocaine smuggling on big container ships. Mexican officials said the Attorney General's office was planning to open new offices in the ports of Veracruz, Acapulco and Ensenada in order to check the ships more closely.
Yet even after seeing cocaine parachute drops, trafficker-owned container ships and drug-bearing submarines, some American officials say they have been impressed by the brazenness and sophistication of the jet flights.
"It's almost predictable that they would start doing it," one official said. "But it's still amazing."
Officials familiar with the flights said the first, an old Boeing 727, landed in late May at an airfield used by the Mexican airline Taesa near the town of Lagos de Moreno, in the central state of Jalisco.
Two officials said Taesa employees at the field told the police that drug traffickers waiting for the jet forced them to light the runway and then let them go after the plane unloaded its cargo and took off.
A spokesman for the airline, Jose Henonin, denied that its employees had anything to do with such a flight. Still, the incident renewed suspicions among American agents that drugs were being moved on planes or through airfields used by Taesa, a Mexican airline founded in 1988 by Carlos Hank Rohn, the eldest son and business manager of one of Mexico's most powerful politicians, Carlos Hank Gonzalez.
In a long career in public service, Mr. Hank Gonzalez has amassed a fortune estimated at well over $1 billion. Taesa officials say his son has sold his 51 percent interest in the airline to his partners, who were longtime pilots for the family, but some competitors question whether the family ties have really been cut.
A flight into Mexico on Aug. 4 caused even greater concern among American officials. A French-made Aerospatiale Caravelle jet, similar to the 727, landed on the airstrip of an old mining company near the desert town of Sombrerete, in the north-central state of Zacatecas.
As the plane touched down, its landing gear broke, and federal highway police officers, alerted by Mexican drug-enforcement officials, reported that the cargo, estimated at six to eight tons, was being taken away. Only about 2.5 tons of the drug were recovered, however, prompting suspicions that the local or federal authorities might have been working with the smugglers.
A Mexican official familiar with the case said it was likely that traffickers had gotten away with some of the load. He strongly denied that the police had taken any of the drug or had anything to do with the traffickers' escape.
In another case, investigators found the traffickers' ingenuity at a new level. On Nov. 22, officials said, a plane, apparently a 727, dropped a cargo near the town of Hidalgo del Parral, in the northern state of Chihuahua. This time, they said, the plane landed on a mile-long airstrip fashioned by compacting the hard dirt of the desert with a steamroller.

HEADLINE: Singapore Judge Orders U.S. Scholar and Paper to Stand Trial

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Putting aside protests from the Clinton Administration, a Singapore judge ordered today that an American scholar and an American-owned newspaper be tried on criminal contempt charges involving an opinion article that criticized "intolerant regimes" in Asia.
The State Department has formally protested the contempt charges brought against the scholar, Christopher Lingle, and The International Herald Tribune, which published an article by Mr. Lingle on Oct. 7 in which he noted that some Asian governments use "a compliant judiciary to bankrupt opposition politicians." 
 After a daylong hearing, Justice Goh Joon Seng found today that there was adequate evidence for prosecutors to pursue a full trial beginning next week against Mr. Lingle and The Herald Tribune, a Paris-based newspaper that is owned by The New York Times and The Washington Post. The Herald Tribune publishes a regional edition in Singapore.
Lawyers here say Judge Goh has the power to impose heavy fines and even jail terms in the case.
Although Mr. Lingle's article did not mention any country by name, Singapore's Attorney General, Chan Sek Keong, argued in court that Mr. Lingle's reference to a "compliant judiciary" was clearly aimed at Singapore, and that Mr. Lingle and the newspaper should be held in contempt because the article "scandalized" Singapore's court system.
"Such allegations are calculated to undermine the authority of the courts, public confidence," Mr. Chan said. "The passage implied that the judiciary was party to a subtle scheme to suppress public dissent."
A number of opposition politicians have been driven to financial ruin after losing defamation cases brought by senior officials of Singapore's governing People's Action Party, including the former Prime Minister, Lee Kuan Yew. The Government has insisted, however, that judges in those defamation cases made their findings based on the facts, not because they bowed to pressure from the ruling party.
Mr. Lingle, an economist who was employed at the National University of Singapore, left Singapore last fall and returned home to Atlanta, and has since announced that he will not return here. He was not represented in court today.
The other defendants -- The Herald Tribune; its publisher, Richard McClean; its Asia editor, Michael Richardson, and a Government-controlled Singapore company that prints the local edition -- were represented in the hearing.
Mr. Richardson, an Australian who has lived in Singapore since 1971, has said through his lawyer that while he edited the article by Mr. Lingle, it did not occur to him that the offending passage about a "compliant judiciary" referred to Singapore.
A spokesman for The Herald Tribune said the paper would have no other comment outside the courtroom until after the trial was over.
Last month, The Herald Tribune published a "clarification" in which it apologized "unreservedly" to the Singaporean judiciary and to Mr. Lee. The clarification said that Mr. Lingle's article "could by reason of facts later drawn to our attention be understood as suggesting that Mr. Lee Kuan Yew had sought to suppress political activity in Singapore by bankrupting opposition politicians through court actions."
Despite the apology, Mr. Lee filed a separate libel suit against the newspaper and Mr. Lingle. The Attorney General said today that the apology amounted to "an admission of liability" by the newspaper.

HEADLINE: Cultural Groups Mobilize To Take On the New Congress

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
Alarmed by growing attacks on Federal support for the arts, cultural groups around the country are mobilizing to press their case directly to the avowedly hostile House Republican leadership. Their message: The arts don't cost; they earn.
The effort to sell the arts as not just balm for the soul but as a boon to local economies drew representatives of some 50 national arts and humanities groups to a meeting last week in Washington, where they formed a new "cultural advocacy" coalition. Another group set up a 900 telephone number to raise money for messages to Senators and Representatives. The chairman of the President's Council on Arts and the Humanities, John Brademas, said yesterday that he would make his own appeal later this week. 
 Around the nation, arts councils and museums and opera and dance companies have begun surveying their benefactors and trustees for well-connected business people, Republican or otherwise, who might have the ear of influential legislators.
Newt Gingrich, the new House Speaker, has made no secret of his antipathy to the long-standing system of Federal grants to arts organizations and artists. He and Congressional allies have vowed to pare if not end the subsidies doled out by the National Endowment for the Arts, which is to distribute $167.4 million this year, down from a high in 1979 of what today would be more than $300 million. Other Government financing programs for humanities and museums are also under critical scrutiny.
There are additional uncertainties in New York State, where the new Republican Governor, George E. Pataki, has yet to put his own stamp on the State Council on the Arts, either formally reappointing the long-serving chairwoman, Kitty Carlisle Hart, or naming a successor.
"Everybody's nervous," said Robert T. Buck, director of the Brooklyn Museum, which has received more than $2 million from Washington over the last two years for special programs and exhibits. Though the grant is only a small part of the museum's $17.5 million annual operating budget, it is considered vital. "We are counting on these monies," Mr. Buck said. "We are planning our projects with their support."
In an effort at solidarity, representatives of the American Association of Museum Directors and about 50 other arts, civic and labor organizations from the United Conference of Mayors to Opera America and the A.F.L.-C.I.O. met last week at the offices of the National Assembly of Local Arts Agencies to plan strategy.
"We're sharing what our Congressional friends are thinking, and figuring out collective ways of communicating," said Bob Lynch, president of the assembly and a former college instructor in poetry and writing.
He said the coalition would portray the arts as a $37 billion industry employing 1.3 million people, or 1.5 percent of the work force, and generating tax revenues of $3.4 billion. Although nonprofit arts groups are routinely misperceived as subsisting primarily on charity, he said, they actually generate 60 percent of their budgets with cash sales: tickets, T-shirts and the like. Most of the rest is raised privately. Even those groups that are subsidized by the National Endowment for the Arts average grants valued at less than 2 percent of their budgets.
"Those are conservative Republican principles," said Mr. Lynch, whose 3,800-member assembly is coordinating but not directing the coalition.
Another umbrella lobbying group, the Arts Alliance, last week set up a fund-raising toll number -- (900) 370-9000 -- with a message soliciting money for a campaign to sway Congress with the same economic argument.
"If the curtain doesn't go up, restaurants and taxis suffer and printers don't get paid," said the alliance's executive director, Judy Golub.
Similarly, the American Council for the Arts, another lobbying group, has been calling news organizations with figures on the economic impact of the arts.
Leading figures in arts philanthropy and education are also lending support to the effort. Though Mr. Brademas heads the President's arts committee -- a citizens and Government advisory panel to stimulate private and public support of the arts -- he said he had also been working on his own to organize "friends of the arts" in support of the two national endowments (arts and humanities) and the Institute of Museum Services, which helps defray operating expenses. Mr. Brademas, who has served as a Representative from Indiana and as president of New York University, said he would speak out on the issue in a program on Thursday at the National Gallery of Art.
For his part, Mr. Gingrich has said that while he supports free exercise of the arts, he does not believe that they should be taxpayer subsidized. In fact, he says, artists would be freer without Federal involvement.
Even managers, benefactors and trustees of large arts institutions that receive proportionately small Federal grants deplored cutbacks or a cutoff, saying the contributions stimulate other giving.
"The N.E.A. validates the arts in America; it's the Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval," said Ardis Krainik, general director of the Lyric Opera of Chicago, which is getting some $600,000 from the Government this year toward its $30 million operating budget. She recalled that a large cut in arts funds was also sought when President Reagan took office, but that Republican allies on the boards of arts groups proved persuasive in rolling back the effort.
Martin E. Segal, chairman of the New York International Festival of the Arts and former chairman of Lincoln Center, said arts groups were best advised to make their case for Federal funds through influential members of their boards rather than by scattershot lobbying of Congress, and he indicated that such efforts were already under way.
The president of Lincoln Center, Nathan Leventhal, said that although the Federal contribution made up a bare 1 percent of the performing arts complex's $340 million budget (which is roughly double the arts endowment's entire budget), it helped. Besides, he said, the endowment's contribution amounts to 66 cents a year for every American. "We spend more on military bands than on the arts in this country."
Like a number of others, Mr. Leventhal attributed the anti-financing backlash to recent controversial artworks that offended religious and conservative sensibilities.
Beverly Sills, the chairwoman of Lincoln Center, said: "I can't believe that out of thousands and thousands of grants they would latch on to two or three they found objectionable, whoever 'they' are."
"What happened after the $750 toilet seats?" she said in reference to military overcharges. "Did we attempt to shut down the Pentagon?"
To one major recipient of Federal arts and humanities grants, WNET/ Channel 13 in New York, one of the nation's largest public broadcasting stations, the threatened cutback or cutoff was particularly ominous.
Although the station gets about a fourth of its $100 million budget directly or indirectly from Washington, by its nature it cannot fight for funds, said its president, William Baker.
"Our strength is our weakness," he said. "We're very apolitical. We're not left or right and we feel uncomfortable at lobbying for anything, including ourselves."
The station could not be self-sustaining, Mr. Baker said, because its programs were "not economically viable." Fully half the schedule consists of children's programming, he said, and 9,000 schools a day used WNET programs in their curriculum. Public broadcasting has been threatened before, he said, but never so directly.
For all the concern among arts groups about Republican leaders in Washington, there was praise for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has maintained city arts financing even in the face of severe budget problems. Ellen V. Futter, director of the Museum of Natural History, said that Republicans in New York City had been "extremely sensitive and highly sympathetic to the arts."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Robert T. Buck, director of the Brooklyn Museum.; William Baker, president of WNET/Channel 13. (Photographs by Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Buys The Peso, Yet Bolsa Takes Dive

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 9

 BODY:
The Mexican stock market suffered its worst loss in more than five years today, as investors reacted negatively to the decision by Mexican authorities to raise short-term interest rates sharply and begin using an $18 billion international credit line to bolster the peso.
The stock market -- formally the Bolsa de Valores -- dropped 149.88 points, or 6.65 percent, to close at 2,104.05. It was the exchange's worst single-day loss since October 1989. Nothing that happened last year -- including the rebellion in Chiapas state, two high-visibility political assassinations or the uncertainty of a presidential election -- affected the stock market as much as the peso crisis seemed to today. 
 While stock prices plummeted, the peso itself strengthened somewhat, closing at 5.375 to the dollar, up 7.8 percent from Friday, when it closed at 5.795. Yet, most investors seemed unimpressed, attributing the peso's gain to the decision by Mexico's central bank to draw on its international credit line. The bank asked the United States and Canada to buy pesos in an effort to strengthen the currency.
The stock market here also reacted to what was seen as a brutal tightening of credit by the Mexican central bank. The bank is attempting to slow the flow of money out of Mexico and push up the value of the peso. But with currency losses exceeding 35 percent since mid-December, the fear is that a weaker peso might send inflation in this country out of control.
Overnight interest rates paid by banks on peso deposits doubled today, to 50 percent. Analysts said many banks and brokers pulled their money out of the stock market to take advantage of those higher rates, and other investors saw the tightening of credit as a sure sign that Mexican industrial companies would suffer even more than had been expected.
"With rates flying as high as 50 percent, it's almost guaranteed that no company can survive," asserted Kenneth R. James, senior vice president of James Capel Emerging Market Sales. "What you saw today was local investors telling you this whole thing is out of control."
Most analysts were less pessimistic than Mr. James. While short-term interest rates are steep, they do not immediately affect the rates paid by Mexican corporations or individuals. But under normal economic conditions, they are seen as important indicators of broader interest-rate trends. Today, some people considered the 50 percent rate a painful but encouraging sign that Mexican authorities were committed to taking steps required to attract capital to Mexico.
At first, the stock market here rose on news that United States authorities had entered the currency markets to purchase pesos for dollars. But analysts said that was because investors did not immediately understand that the Americans and Canadians were entering the market not on their own initiative, but at the request of the Mexican Government.
Later in the day, the Mexican central bank said that it had drawn $500 million of its credit line from Washington and $83 million (Canadian)-- about $59 million United States-- from Ottawa.
Much of today's stock market decline reflected a concern by traders that the Government actually had to use the credit line. "The real advantage of a credit line is psychological," said Eduardo M. Cabrera, manager of Latin American strategies for Merrill Lynch & Company. "Once you use it, investors realize that it is a finite amount." Mr. Cabrera said he believed that the selling was overdone today.
Several analysts said it was not clear whether the Mexican central bank had used its own money today to help stabilize the peso, or had just relied on the money from its North American trading partners. Mexico's reserves have shrunk from $28 billion last February, to $6.15 billion as of Dec. 31, to $5.55 billion on Friday.
In total, foreign nations and international financial institutions have made available about $18 billion for Mexico to use in solving its current crisis. In addition to $9 billion from Washington and $1.5 billion (Canadian) from Ottawa, the package includes $5 billion from the Bank for International Settlements and $3 billion from foreign commercial banks.
Most analysts said the market's big worry continues to be the Government bonds known as tesobonos that are paid in pesos but indexed to dollars. A total of $685 million worth of these bonds mature this week. Next week, the total rises to $942 million, and climbs further to $1.3 billion in the final week of January.
Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz said last week that the Government was working with American investment banks and brokers to develop a series of longer-term, high-yield bonds that would encourage investors, many of them foreign, not to withdraw their money when their holdings matured. But the new bonds have not yet reached the market.
Some analysts think that the Government will have to draw on the credit line again Tuesday to prop up investor confidence. Luis R. Luis, chief of emerging-markets research at Scudder, Stevens & Clark in Boston, said that while the high overnight interest rates and the use of the international credit line would help stabilize the peso, "it will come at a huge cost to the stock market."
Marla S. Marron, an analyst at Salomon Brothers in New York, said it was unrealistic to expect the Mexican Government not to use the available credit to stabilize the peso.
"What people will be watching now as the tesobonos come due," Ms. Marron said, "is whether investors actually make the determination to buy into the Government's emergency economic plan," and thus keep their money in Mexico, rather than withdraw it.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Traders on the floor of the Mexico City stock exchange, which suffered its worst daily loss in more than five years, as investors appeared to react negatively yesterday to a sharp rise in short-term interest rates. (Associated Press)(pg. D6)

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1501 words

HEADLINE: County's Crisis Is Conservatives' Lab

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif.

 BODY:
Orange County, in bankruptcy, has become the laboratory that some conservatives have always hoped for.
Because the taxpayers wouldn't stand for it, the county cannot turn to tax increases to help cover a $2 billion loss from a risky investment portfolio that went bad. That means the county will need to reduce the size of government -- a long-held conservative goal -- well beyond anything done elsewhere. 
 For starters, this would mean selling to private investors such public assets as the local airport and some landfills as well as cutting employees and the services they provide.
"I believe that less government is the best form and that too many people depend on government," said Gaddi Vasquez, the new chairman of the county's Board of Supervisors. "If ever there were the optimal conditions to make the changes that many have yearned to make, this is it. We must seize the moment."
But as the county undertakes these changes, its anti-tax stance could hurt it. To cover its losses, the county may have to return to the credit markets for more money. Yet Wall Street wants to be assured that Orange County will do whatever is necessary, including tax increases, to pay back its lenders.
"The message to lenders is, 'We'll pay you back if we've got it, but don't ask us to go out of our way,' " said Richard Larken, director of municipal finance at the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the bond-rating agency. "Yes, they've got an ability to pay. But that is a moot issue. What matters is their willingness to pay."
Still, reducing the size of government and returning to the credit markets are at the center of the county's recovery plan. And many conservative policy makers are excited by the chance to put into practice some of their longstanding ideas, like a gigantic selloff of public properties.
The Orange County Lincoln Club, comprising Republican business leaders, has asked the Reason Foundation, a libertarian policy group in Los Angeles, to help them work on promoting the sale of the John Wayne Airport, assorted buildings and parcels of property, parks and several landfills.
"To get the dollars the county needs, they've got to sell assets in a big way, and that is where history will be made," Robert Poole, president of the Reason Foundation, said. "We're likely to see more dramatic privatization in Orange County than anywhere else, because they've run out of the easy alternatives."
Mr. Poole estimated that the county could have a "realistic goal" of $1 billion in asset sales. "For a municipality to sell $1 billion in assets is big news," he added.
The downside of selling assets is that the sales will not help ease the immediate cash shortage. Mr. Poole estimates that significant asset sales will take at least six months to a year to accomplish. The county's financial advisers say a $172 million budget gap must be closed within six months to maintain a least a modicum of financial credibility.
Having ruled out tax increases -- "dead issue; next question," Mr. Vasquez said bluntly -- the county faces a bind. Other than tax increases and spending cuts, the only significant option is to borrow money. But lenders say the anti-tax attitude makes it difficult for investors to be confident of being repaid.
John H. Sawyer, general manager of the Orange County Employees Association, which is seeing layoffs among its members, said, "When you live in the midst of a county of such success and affluence, a certain smugness develops that insulates citizens from a feeling that anything can go wrong."
Orange County has a gross economic output of $68 billion a year, larger than the economies of Greece, Thailand or the Philippines. Despite this underlying economic strength, the county government's budget had been built more on investment earnings than on taxes -- highly unusual in municipal finances.
"There's very strong resistance to tax increases here," Marian Bergeson, a newly elected county supervisor, said. On the day Ms. Bergeson and other supervisors were sworn in, many vowed not to raise taxes. Others expressed reluctance to make spending cuts beyond the $40.2 million already announced. Mr. Vasquez says the county will announce more cost-cutting measures soon, including asset sales and, possibly, employee layoffs.
"Our record $40.2 million in cuts are as far as we could go and still deliver services to the county," said Brad Gates, the county sheriff and a member of a three-member team recommending cuts in county services. "We stopped at the point when we could not deliver any more essential services."
Besides the problems at the county level, 186 cities, local agencies and school districts in the county lost money in the investment fund. Many of them have delayed road improvements, laid off lawyers for the poor, frozen hiring or cut other services. Already at least one school district has declared a "financial state of emergency" and cuts in school budgets are expected.
One option being widely discussed is to ask noteholders who are due $600 million in July to wait longer for their money. While the terms of any such arrangement have not been determined, officials here are openly raising the possibility of lengthening the maturity of some of these notes.
Officials also say that longer-term borrowings may be needed to cover investment losses, which total $700 million for the county government alone. "Borrowing is likely to play a significant role in Orange County's recovery," Bruce Bennett, the county's bankruptcy lawyer, said.
But some credit market experts say investors will ask this question: Why would anyone lend to Orange County when its residents do not seem willing to raise the revenues to pay back lenders? It has long been a tenet of municipal finance that behind any bond lies the willingness of the issuer to raise taxes, if necessary, to protect bondholders.
Daniel Heimowitz, director of the public finance group at Moody's Investors Service, noted that in other municipal crises new taxes were always imposed and dedicated specifically to the new bonds that helped bail out the government. For example, in New York City, a dedicated sales tax backed the Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds issued during the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's; in Philadelphia, additional income taxes supported borrowings that averted a default, and in Chicago, two property tax increases prevented a default of school bonds.
"The posturing in Orange County of no new taxes is not helpful in finding a solution," Mr. Heimowitz said. "They are going to have to show that they have the intention of taking their wealth and directing it to make good on their losses."
Orange County, like all other local governments in California, is unable to increase property taxes because of Proposition 13, the tax-limitation measure approved by voters in 1978. Given that, the county's only realistic choice would be to increase sales taxes, perhaps by a percentage point or so, dedicating the revenues to repaying bondholders. But no one is expecting anything like that.
On Friday, Moody's lowered its rating on the county's debt securities to "below investment grade," in effect, labeling them junk bonds.
"It is clear that each debt-service payment will be decided by the county on a case-by-case basis, depending on whether they have the cash or not," said Barbara Flickinger, a Moody's assistant director, who attended a recent briefing by Orange County officials.
Existing bondholders are waiting to see what will happen. "We're going to try to deal with an impending default on these notes by achieving some form of a workout with the noteholders," Mr. Bennett, the bankruptcy lawyer, said. In a workout, the borrower and the noteholders negotiate a schedule for repayment, often extending the deadlines and reducing the amounts due.
"The county may go to the noteholders and say, 'We don't have the money to pay you back,' " said Zane Mann, publisher of the California Municipal Bond Adviser, a newsletter. "So they might give them more paper. But the money still has to be paid back. The county either has to cut services more, raise taxes or isolate some income to assure repayment of the debt."
Some people, however, predict that a point may come where service cutbacks are so severe that attitudes will change, even here.
Mark Baldassare of the University of California at Irvine, who has been studying Orange County since 1982, observed: "The basic attitude is that there is plenty of waste in government and there is no need to raise taxes. That's a constant backdrop. But people here are also particular. They are educated and skeptical of government. They need to be convinced that government has done all it can, and then they might decide there are some circumstances where taxes are warranted."
Chris Varelas, a Salomon Brothers investment banker who is advising the county, asked: "What happens when they call 911 and get a recording? They might define things differently."

GRAPHIC: Photos: "There's very strong resistance to tax increases here," said Marian Bergeson, above, an Orange County supervisor. With her was William Steiner, another supervisor. Gaddi Vasquez, right, chairman of the Board of Supervisors, has ruled out higher taxes. (Photographs by Mindy Schauer/Orange County Register)

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
A Shift by Bullish Investors Prompts a Decline in Prices

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
A broad array of commodity prices fell yesterday, led by steep declines in orange juice, coffee and wheat futures, in which previously bullish investors became disappointed sellers.
The Commodity Research Bureau's index fell 1.59 points, to 233.65. 
 January orange juice sank 6.3 cents on the New York Cotton Exchange to settle at $1 a pound, the lowest level for a nearby contract in three months.
"There was disappointment over the market's technical performance and the lack of significant cold weather in Florida, which is already in the hard freeze period," said Celeste Georgakis of Dean Witter.
Coffee prices were also undermined by a letdown after recent bullish rumors that Central and South American coffee producers would restore a withholding plan inaugurated last year as a way to firm up prices.
March coffee lost 5.85 cents on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange to 169.10 cents a pound.
After a week of uncertainty about the plans by large coffee growers to renew the export retention program, investors decided to sell.
There was general skepticism about whether Brazil and Colombia, the world's top two coffee producers, would participate in the plan.
Commodity funds were big sellers of wheat contracts, after a Government report showed that the speculative funds were increasingly acquiring long positions, a prescription for a sudden selloff. March wheat dropped 11.25 cents, to $3.83 1/4 a bushel, on the Chicago Board of Trade.
On other markets, crude and heating oil prices sank, as winter weather that was warmer than normal continued to reduce demand. February crude oil fell 27 cents, to $17.40 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange, while February heating oil shed 1.19 cents, to 48.33 cents a gallon.
But copper prices rose to new contract highs, helped by strong underlying fundamentals from booming economic sectors that used the most copper. March copper jumped 2.75 cents, to 139.05 cents a pound, on the Commodity Exchange in New York.

HEADLINE: Stocks End Day Mixed; Inflation Data Awaited

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Stock traders stayed on the sidelines yesterday in advance of the Labor Department's release of the December Producer Price Index today and the Consumer Price Index tomorrow.
The price data will go far in calming or alarming traders over the course of inflation, the economy and the interest-rate policy of the Federal Reserve. The Fed's policy-making meeting is scheduled to begin Jan. 31. 
 If the data point unambiguously to increasing inflation, traders may conclude that not only will the Fed raise interest rates later this month, as widely expected, but will also continue to do so throughout the year.
As a result of the anticipation, stocks closed mixed but little changed, bond prices fell, the dollar dropped sharply and the price of gold inched up a little.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 6.06 points, to 3,861.35, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 0.15 point, to 460.83. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 2.40 points, to 752.09.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was below normal, with 279.3 million shares changing hands, about 4 percent below last year's daily average of 290 million shares.
Unlike most sessions, where stock prices track bond prices, the price of American equities seemed to follow the fate of the dollar much more closely and the dollar was having a bad day. The dollar fell sharply against most major currencies in part because of continuing turmoil over the Mexican peso.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yesterday morning that it was buying pesos to help support the foundering Mexican currency, which has lost 40 percent of its value since Dec. 19. Such purchases by the New York Fed have the effect of increasing the supply of dollars and thus driving its price down.
The fate of the dollar is significant for stock investors because the dollar's value will influence whether foreign investors will want to buy assets valued in dollars, like stocks. The dollar was also weakened by fears of new trade tensions between the United States and Japan and by a strong German mark.
The Dow Jones has gained 0.7 percent in the first five days of trading this year, but fallen 0.06 percent in terms of marks. Since June 1985, the dollar has fallen about 50 percent against the mark.
Pillsbury, a unit of Grand Metropolitan of London, agreed to buy Pet Inc. for $2.6 billion. Pet is a food processor whose brand names include Old El Paso Mexican food and Progresso Italian food. Pet established a 52-week high of 25 3/4 before closing at 25 1/2, up 5 3/8. It was also the most active stock, at 16.1 million shares.
The Deerbank Corporation, a savings and loan, also established a 52-week high of 43 before closing at 42 3/8, up 9 5/8. Deerbank agreed to be bought by NBD Bancorp for $120 million in stock.
Duracraft, a maker of heaters and humidifiers, rose 4, to 34, after management met with securities analysts, several of whom raised their 1995 profit estimates.
Harleysville Savings Bank in Harleysville, Pa. fell 5, to 21, after it reported first-quarter earnings of 68 cents a share versus a profit a year ago of 61 cents. The earnings apparently disappointed some investors but earnings projections for the company were not immediately available for comparison.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.01 point, to 251.58, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining stocks by 1,188 to 1,011. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 1.05 points, to 434.17.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 17 fell, led by Union Carbide, which dropped 1 1/8, to 29 3/8. Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 235 rose, led by Ford, which rose 5/8, to 28 7/8.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Fall as Price Data Are Due

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday as investors worried that inflation reports due this week would continue to suggest that rising interest rates had not yet slowed the economy.
To subdue future inflation, the Federal Reserve, which raised short-term interest rates six times last year, may continue ratcheting rates up this year. 
 The debt market was also kept on the defensive as the dollar tumbled in world currency markets. The dollar slid against the Japanese yen after Walter F. Mondale, the American Ambassador to Japan, said that the United States would consider trade sanctions on Japan it it did not agree to import more American goods during trade talks in Washington.
The 30-year bond fell 7/32 , to a price of 9521/32 for a yield of 7.88 percent, up from 7.86 percent on Friday.
George R. Mateyo, chief executive of the Carnegie Capital Management Company, Cleveland, said market expectations for today's producer price report for December ranged from a gain of five-tenths of a percent to seven-tenths of a percent.
But Mr. Mateyo said he did not think the figure would be that high. "We're looking instead for a gain of three-tenths of a percent in the P.P.I," he said, adding that he expected an increase of three-tenths or four-tenths of a percent in the Consumer Price Index, which is to be reported tomorrow.
"With the Mexican situation not entirely solved and the Fed expected to act at its next Federal Open Market Committee meeting this month," Mr. Mateyo said, "we could easily find ourselves going from 8.10 percent on the high end of trading for long bonds to 7.65 percent on the low side over a 30-day period. It's a tremendous trading range, but it also represents a lot of trading opportunities."
He also noted that given problems with derivatives and the Orange County, Calif., bankruptcy, enough negatives remained to stifle buying. "But that's what makes markets," Mr. Mateyo said, "the uncertainty."
The Treasury's weekly bill auction drew strong demand yesterday, as the average rate rose to 5.87 percent for a three-month bill, from 5.78 percent last week, and the six-month bill rose to 6.42 percent, from 6.37 percent. Traders report that noncompetitive bidding, representing retail interest, continues to be impressive at these auctions, with strong demand driven by the attractive yields now that the market has priced in what it expects will be a 50-basis-point -- or one-half percentage point -- rate increase by the Fed at its next monetary policy meeting at the end of the month.
Banks, by comparison, are offering a rate of 3.83 percent for a three-month certificate of deposit and 4.48 percent for a six-month C.D., according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index.
On the long end of the market, traders and investors expect bond yields will once again break above 8 percent sometime this quarter before the Fed's six inflation-fighting rate increases begin slowing the economy sufficiently. Because inflation erodes the value of fixed-income investments, investors are reluctant to buy bonds with long maturities.
Investors as a rule sell the long maturities and buy shorter maturities to get away from market volatility. The yield on a two-year note rose 7.66 percent, as the gap between it and the 30-year bond yield narrowed 2 basis points, to 22, from Friday. Two weeks ago, the spread was just 12 basis points. According to analysts, a wider spread typically reflects increased investor concern that the Fed is not raising interest rates fast enough to subdue inflation.

HEADLINE: Consumers Again Raise Credit Debt

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Consumers used their credit cards freely in November, contributing to an increase of $12.88 billion in total installment debt during the month, the Federal Reserve said today.
Every major category of credit, from new-car loans to credit card balances, grew as total debts climbed for a 24th consecutive month. 
 November's rise, at an annual rate of 17.3 percent, was up from an $11.64 billion, or 15.9 percent annual rate, expansion in credit during October. It was the largest monthly increase since a $15.1 billion jump three months earlier in August.
The big rises in consumer credit during both October and November lend weight to analysts' estimates that the economy's pace of growth may have accelerated to a rate as high as 5 percent a year in the closing quarter of 1994.
The year "has begun with a full head of steam," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist with the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. "Consumer spending, capital expenditures, inventories, commercial construction and exports are barreling ahead," he said.
Consumer spending on goods and services continues to grow despite the efforts of the Federal Reserve to slow the pace of the economy. The Fed has raised short-term interest rates six times since February and is widely expected to increase rates again at the end of the month.
Auto credit outstanding climbed in November by $4.77 billion, at an 18 percent annual rate, after rising $2.88 billion, at a 10.9 percent annual rate, in October.
Credit card debt shot up in November by $6.72 billion, at a 24.6 percent annual rate, compared with a $4.88 billion October advance, at an 18.2 percent annual rate.
Other credit, which includes consumer bank loans for things like boats, trailers and vacations but not real estate mortgages, increased by $1.39 billion, at a 6.8 percent annual rate, down sharply from a $3.88 billion, or 19.3 percent, October increase, the Fed said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Takes Sharp Drop On U.S. Efforts to Aid Peso

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply against leading currencies yesterday, weighed down by United States efforts to halt the slide of the Mexican peso and by renewed worries about trade tensions between the United States and Japan.
The dollar was also weakened by the strength of the German mark, which has gained as investors have fled political turmoil in Italy and Spain. 
 The dollar tumbled against the yen in its steepest one-day drop since Aug. 18, after the United States Ambassador to Japan, Walter F. Mondale, said the United States might impose trade sanctions on Japan if trade talks failed. Mr. Mondale spoke in Washington, where negotiations with Japan are being held.
The comments prompted fears that the Clinton Administration would revive an earlier trade strategy of talking up the value of the yen against the dollar. A stronger yen would make Japanese exports more expensive.
"The U.S. brought out the trade-sanction bogyman and that hurt the dollar," said David De Rosa, director of foreign-exchange trading at the Swiss Bank Corporation.
Concern about the Federal Reserve's dollar sales for pesos also drove the dollar lower. The Fed said yesterday morning that it was selling dollars for pesos on behalf of the Bank of Mexico. The Fed sold an estimated $75 million to $150 million for pesos in two rounds, traders familiar with the Fed's action said.
The Fed's trades "certainly won't make anyone buy dollars," said Richard Vullo, currency sales manager at Bayerische Hypotheken und Wechsel Bank. "Granted, the intervention is against the peso, but the Fed is still selling dollars," he said.
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar fell to 99.91 Japanese yen from 101.37 yen on Friday. The dollar also fell to 1.5375 German marks from 1.5643 marks.
Pressure on the dollar from the mark has come as the German currency has surged to record highs against the Spanish peseta and the Italian lira. In Spain, the markets have slumped as the Socialist Government has been rocked by a scandal. In Italy, there has been political uncertainty since the Dec. 22 resignation of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi. The mark, the currency of the Continent's strongest economy, often benefits from political turmoil in Europe.
In other currency trading, the dollar fell to 1.2840 Swiss francs, from 1.3105 francs on Friday. The British pound rose to $1.5640 from $1.5495. But the Canadian dollar fell to 70.96 United States cents from 71.41 cents.

HEADLINE: John P. Mackin, 54, Benefits Executive

 BODY:
John P. Mackin, a senior vice president and director of the government division of the Segal Company, a New York-based employee benefits consulting firm, died on Friday at his home in Croton-on-Hudson. He was 54.
The cause was cancer, said Martin E. Segal, the company's chairman emeritus. 
 An economist by training, Mr. Mackin joined the Segal Company in 1965 and for many years was the editor of its annual survey of state employee health benefit plans that is published and circulated among state legislators and government officials.
He received an undergraduate degree from the University of Miami and a master's degree and Ph.D. in economics from the University of Wisconsin in Madison.
He is survived by his wife, Patricia; his mother, Rosetta Mackin of Coral Gables, Fla.; two sons, John D., of Manhattan and Michael A., of Denver; two daughters, Deborah E., of Croton-on-Hudson and Stephanie L., of New Orleans, and four sisters, Dixie Parkin of Islamorada, Fla., Mollie Fleshman of Atlanta and Sara Sanderson and Kathleen Aissen, both of Miami.

HEADLINE: NEEDIEST CASES;
Mother of 4 Finds Help And Sheds Long Misery

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
Not long ago, he followed her home from church and discovered where she had moved to escape his abuse. But he stopped at the corner, and Sonia K. believes he will not come any closer to her new apartment and the life she has begun there.
She was 13 when they emigrated from Belize together, leaving their families and childhoods behind. She loved him then, and said she would follow him anywhere. A year later, they had a baby daughter, and it seemed all the world was within their grasp. 
 But by the time Ms. K. was 21, her boyfriend had developed health problems that she said affected his personality. He had become angry and controlling, and refused to let her out of his sight. She says he never beat her or the children, but the emotional abuse they suffered was almost as bad.
"He didn't want me to make friends, and he wouldn't let me go anywhere without him," she said in a small voice. "Slowly, it got worse and worse."
The problems peaked in the winter of 1993, when Ms. K.'s boyfriend was unemployed and harassing neighbors in their Washington Heights building. The family was evicted, she said, and they spent a week at the city's Emergency Assistance Unit in the Bronx.
"It was January, freezing cold, and we were sleeping on benches with a lot of other people," said Ms. K., who is now 26. "It was one of the lowest times in my life."
Then the family moved into a city shelter in Harlem, where she said they shared a tiny, roach-infested apartment. They spent more than a year there, and Ms. K. joined a church in the neighborhood. But all the while, her boyfriend was becoming more difficult.
One night last March, he threatened another shelter resident with a butcher knife. When the police arrived, he barricaded himself in the apartment with Ms. K. and the children. That episode, she said, was the turning point.
"They took him to jail, and they said I would have to give up the children if I let him come back," she said. "I knew I had to get away from him."
The next day, Ms. K. filed for a restraining order against her boyfriend. She also called her parents in Belize, whom he had not let her contact in six years. Later that month, the Child Welfare Agency referred her to the Children's Aid Society, one of the charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, now in its 83d year.
Darleen Brown, a social worker with the society's prevention services unit, started counseling Ms. K. and her children, who are 12, 9, 7 and 5. With her help, they found a three-bedroom apartment in a Harlem brownstone. In June, the family moved in. They had lost all their furniture when they were evicted, so the society bought them a couch, dressers, linens and kitchen equipment. The rooms are small and dark, but Ms. K. has hung lace curtains and pictures of the children, and there is no trace of the misery she left behind.
"I prayed real hard for so many years, and finally my prayers were heard," she said the other night as her children watched cartoons in their living room. "We are just happy to have a place of our own."
Ms. Brown still visits the family twice a month, and Ms. K. recently completed a parenting class sponsored by the society. Before, she said, it was hard to concentrate on the children because of her boyfriend's behavior. But now she is focusing all her energy on their well-being. Among other things, she is trying to help them recover from their past.
"They feel bad because their father is on the streets now, and he has no one," she said. "I tell them he still loves them even though he's sick, and what happened isn't their fault."
Ms. K. receives public assistance, but she is taking a computer class and plans to return to school and find a job. She has made friends through her church, and said she finally has the emotional support she lacked for years. When she sees her children's father on the street, she said, she feels more sorrow than fear.
"He watches us sometimes, but he doesn't come near," she said. "He knows he can't come near."

HEADLINE: State of the State Message Salutes a Year in the Life

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 9

 BODY:
New Jersey state government is slimming down just as the economy is adding jobs in private business, and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman accepted credit for both developments in her State of the State Message, whose text was released here today.
In a document that could just as well have been called "The State of My Administration," Mrs. Whitman offered no new initiatives and no surprises; instead she devoted a 30-page booklet to her administration's still sometimes vague plans to wring savings and better services out of state and local government. 
 Despite Mrs. Whitman's blunt Republican devotion to fiscal restraint and smaller government, the Governor's message committed the state to social and economic agendas usually associated with Democrats: improving failing schools, lifting economically stagnant cities, breaking the dogged poverty of many households, and slowing the spread of AIDS.
The Governor has, after a year in office, made a name for herself in national Republican politics as an executive who has so far managed to balance two ideas that usually seem contradictory -- cutting taxes while expanding the state's responsibilities.
However, her political opponents point out that to fulfill her pledge of reducing state taxes 30 percent during her administration, the most painful cuts are yet to come, and for that reason her budget message in two weeks may be considerably more revealing than today's broad policy paper.
Mrs. Whitman took pains to repeat her administration's commitment to ethnic and gender diversity and tolerance under a program, begun last summer, called "Many Faces, One Family." And she surprised no one by restating her determination to cut taxes further:
"My biggest promise is based on a simple premise: when tax rates go up, jobs disappear and state revenues go down," she said. "We will continue to cut taxes in New Jersey because our people deserve tax relief and because it will provide more of what every family needs: jobs and economic opportunity."
Today's State of the State Message followed custom by recapitulating the administration's last year and by pointing in only general terms to the future. Mrs. Whitman will deliver a shorter version of the same report in a speech to the Legislature at noon tomorrow, and her press office said today that the speech may include some ideas not mentioned in the formal report released today.
"The state of the state is one of promise," the Governor wrote in a cover letter for the document. She said the state has added nearly 60,000 jobs in the last year, the fastest job growth since the boom years of the 1980's. Her four-year, 30 percent income tax cut reached the half-way point toward completion in the first of the year, when the latest round of cuts brought the reduction in income tax rates since her inauguration to 15 percent, for a savings to taxpayers of $625 million per year.
The Governor has already committed herself to continuing the tax cut plan, and the only question remaining is how big a cut she will propose for the 1996 tax year. That information, and a more detailed accounting of the costs of her other programs, will be outlined in her Jan. 23 budget message.
"With our economy brightening, more families are feeling confident about their futures," Mrs. Whitman said in her statement. "But not everyone is better off. Although we've added tens of thousands of jobs, more than a quarter million New Jerseyans remain out of work. Despite spending far more per pupil on education than any other state, we rank 35th in S.A.T. math scores, 38th in verbal scores, and 49th in the percentage of school funding that reaches the classroom."
By the Governor's own account, the Whitman administration is still a work in progress, with numerous important policy initiatives awaiting the recommendations of advisory groups whose work Mrs. Whitman reviewed in her report. The Dredged Materials Management Team is trying to balance the environmental and economic trade-offs of dredging Port Elizabeth, she said. The Government That Works Task Force is reviewing which state programs work and which should be scuttled. Urban Coordinating Councils are intended to involve inner-city poor in still-undecided economic development programs. Another commission is studying the Garden State's farm issues.
Mrs. Whitman repeated her intention to try a state-financed voucher program in Jersey City schools, despite only lukewarm interest in the effort in the Legislature and a full-blown campaign to defeat the plan by the teachers' union.
In a cryptic catch-phrase Mrs. Whitman often favors, the Governor said of the voucher plan today, "We have nothing to fear but success."
One of Mrs. Whitman's strengths as a politician has been her ability to connect her policies to the lives of New Jersey's citizens, and she used that approach again today. Throughout her report, she scattered short letters written by New Jerseyans who supported her programs: Edwin A. Reimon of Jersey City wrote to thank her for fostering opportunities for minorities to bid on state business; Marla and Robert Laverty of East Windsor urged her to crack down on child molesters like the one charged in the slaying of Megan Kanka of Hamilton last summer, and Marty Sullivan of Fair Haven asked for more help for the cities.
In the opening paragraph of her message, the Governor went so far as to note that as she was taking the oath of office last Jan. 18, a baby named Monica Monique Spencer was being born in Jersey City. The Governor saluted Monica, a one-year-old administration to a 1-year-old citizen of the state, in her closing statement as well: "I'd like to think that in these past 12 months, because of a growing partnership between government and the people it serves, Monica's prospect for a life of personal achievement and public good have brightened."

LENGTH: 537 words

HEADLINE: Feeling Poor in a Rich Economy

 BODY:
Like matter and antimatter that coexist in the universe, two economies appear to exist side by side in the U.S. One economy has generated stagnant earnings for the average American over the past 20 years, producing a frustration that turned against the party in power last November.
The second economy is measured in buoyant statistics: Production has grown steadily for four years, unemployment has fallen to levels as low as any during the past 20 years, and consumer confidence has risen to record levels. Even beleaguered cities like Detroit and Chicago have achieved fiscal stability. 
 There are two ways to explain how these mirror-image economies can coexist. One is that statistics do not always reflect common experience. Recent economic gains, though substantial on average, have been concentrated among high-income families and selected regions like the Southeast. The wages of most workers -- those with high school educations -- have languished or, after accounting for inflation, fallen over recent decades. Similarly, city budgets -- excluding New York's -- are moving into surplus. But part of the reason is a decision to cut back desperately needed services. That cities have, in times of fiscal exigencies, turned their backs on inner-city schools is no cause for celebration.
High expectations are another factor that can produce frustration amid seeming plenty. The U.S. economy exploded after World War II. Productivity, the long-term basis for earnings, roared upward at two or three times its usual pace. Americans developed the notion that the halcyon days of the 1950's and 60's would continue and that their children could expect to live substantially richer lives than their parents did. A decade later OPEC helped send the economy down, but back-to-back recessions did not so easily shatter firmly entrenched expectations.
The sober lesson from historians is that the good fortune of the 50's and 60's was odd and unlikely to be repeated. But even as expectations catch up with reality, frustration will not dissipate quickly. Important pockets of the country may not rebound soon. California is racked by defense cuts; Wall Street follows the roller coaster of stock and bond markets. Foreign competition threatens the jobs of white-collar managers through no fault of their own -- a threat that had until now been mostly reserved for factory workers. Poverty is increasingly entrenched in urban ghettos, immune so far to public policy and, alarmingly, to the general health of the economy.
Productivity grew at a 3 percent clip annually after World War II, but only by about 1 percent a year since 1973. That is the economy that causes frustration. The political consequence is sobering because there is no obvious remedy.
The G.O.P. promises tax cuts and less regulation, which is almost surely unrelated to sweeping long-term forces in the economy. President Clinton had a deeper answer -- to steer public and private spending toward productivity-enhancing investment in training and education. But his policies might not make a dent in living standards for a generation. The voters took out their anger on Mr. Clinton. By 1996 they may be looking for other targets.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: U.S. Effort to Return Farm Land to Natural State Wins Praise

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
WITH the Endangered Species Act under assault by political conservatives and property-rights advocates, another federally sponsored approach to saving wild creatures' habitats has quietly won broad praise and is being widely promoted as a successful alternative.
It is the Conservation Reserve Program, a provision of the 1985 farm bill that pays farmers to take land out of production and return it to something approaching a natural state. 
 Under the program, 36 million acres of habitat, mostly in the country's midsection, have been restored at a cost of about $1.6 billion a year. The decadelong effort is credited by wildlife experts with, among other things, helping to reverse a steep decline in North America's duck population by greatly expanding the birds' nesting grounds.
The program embodies a conservation principle long held dear by conservatives and proponents of market solutions to environmental problems: inducing property owners to become willing stewards of ecologically valuable land by offering them financial incentives.
By contrast, say advocates of this approach, the Endangered Species Act forces landowners to give up the economic use of property containing the habitats of critical species without compensating them. Sometimes, critics say, property owners resort to pre-emptive strikes by simply destroying habitat before it can be formally declared the home of an endangered species.
The issue is expected to get a thorough airing in the new Republican-dominated Congress, since both the Endangered Species Act and the farm bill, including the Conservation Reserve Program, are up for reauthorization this year. Property-rights advocates have many allies in Congress, including some conservative Democrats, and it appears certain that they will press the attack on the Endangered Species Act.
The Conservation Reserve Program, on the other hand, enjoys wide support, including that of Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, the new chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee. Advocates of the market approach to conservation, both environmentalists and political conservatives, in theory favor extending the principle of financial incentives from the farm bill to the Endangered Species Act. But that would cost more, and so is problematical given the Republicans' announced determination to cut spending. For that matter, it is not certain whether the Conservation Reserve Program will continue to be financed at its present level.
Some conservationists say Congress's treatment of the issue will reveal much about the professed commitment to species protection that usually accompanies conservatives' denunciations of the Endangered Species Act. If they are not willing to put up the money to provide market incentives for conservation, "then I think their professed goal of protecting endangered species will be revealed as a sham," said Michael Bean, an advocate of the incentive approach who specializes in conservation issues for the Environmental Defense Fund in Washington.
In the meantime, the Clinton Administration has announced that as 10-year contracts under which farmers enrolled their property in the Conservation Reserve Program begin expiring next year, some of the program's funds will be withdrawn from acreage where the conservation benefits are determined to be marginal and redirected to land where the conservation payoff is higher. A number of proposals have been made to link this redirection of money directly to the protection of endangered species.
For instance, the Pacific Rivers Council, a regional organization devoted to protecting and restoring aquatic ecosystems, has proposed that some funds be redirected to the Pacific Northwest, where they would be used to encourage farmers to protect and restore stream-side vegetation and flood plains necessary to the survival and reproduction of dwindling salmon populations.
The National Marine Fisheries Service is expected to propose soon that the coho, one of the most important and formerly most abundant species of Pacific salmon, be listed as endangered throughout much of its range. Using Conservation Reserve Program money to protect parts of watersheds on private property on the coho's behalf would be "a tremendous step forward," said Bob Doppelt, the Pacific Rivers Council's executive director. It could also remove much of the potential sting for landowners if and when the coho is declared endangered.
Interest groups representing other areas of the country and other types of ecosystems have also expressed interest in obtaining Conservation Reserve Program funds. Whether a competition develops remains to be seen. Ducks Unlimited, a private conservation group based in Memphis whose interests have been handsomely served by the Conservation Reserve Program, is not opposed to some redirection of money, said Jeff Nelson, the organization's chief biologist. While the organization would, of course, like to see the middle of the country remain the primary target of the program, he said, more efficient use of the funds might allow expansion to other areas.
"There's a good chance you could get the same environmental benefits for 75 percent of the cost if it were made more efficient," he said.
The various uses that might be made of the funds do not compete but rather complement one another in terms of the overall conservation goal, said Tom Hebert, the deputy undersecretary of agriculture for natural resources and environment. The problem, he said, is how to "meet all these laudable objectives with one program and with funds that are not unlimited."
Senator Lugar recently criticized the Department of Agriculture's plan to extend and retarget Conservation Reserve Program contracts on the ground that it was an attempt to extend the program's financing administratively rather than by Congressional appropriation. Mr. Lugar is determined to reassess the program to make sure that it delivers "the best environmental bang for the buck," said a spokeswoman, Minda M. Markle. No decision has yet been made on redirecting some of the funds, she said.
The program's original purpose was to take fragile, highly erodible land out of production at a time when Government stocks of grain were soaring. But as farmers planted grass and trees and allowed natural vegetation to return, conservation benefits began to emerge. Millions of acres of wildlife habitat were regenerated and water quality was improved, benefiting countless species large and small, from freshwater mussels to big-game animals in the West. Improved water quality and wildlife habitat were subsequently included as goals of the program.
Many farmers joined the program partly because taking the acreage out of production improved crop prices. Whether owners of more valuable lands would respond to incentives of this order -- typically, $50 per acre per year -- is uncertain.
In any case, a large body of literature exploring the efficacy of financial incentives for conservation and advocating their use has emerged in the last few years from conservative research groups and environmental organizations.
"I, of course, applaud the idea" embodied in the Conservation Reserve Program, said Dr. John Baden, an economist at the University of Washington in Seattle who is the chairman of the Foundation for Research on Economics and the Environment. The organization promotes "freedom and ecological integrity" by searching for economic means to achieve environmental ends.
At the same time, the incentives approach is advocated by Hank Fischer, the northern Rocky Mountains representative of the Washington-based Defenders of Wildlife. Mr. Fischer, based in Missoula, Mont., directed a 1993 study on building economic incentives into the Endangered Species Act. Given the present political climate, he said, "probably the more likely route at this stage is to take existing programs and modify them." In that regard, he said, "people with lands with endangered species ought to receive priority" in the redirection of Conservation Reserve Progam funds.
"I don't think expansion of the Conservation Reserve Program is in the cards," he said, "but I think retargeting is."

HEADLINE: CLINTON & CONGRESS;
Let's Privatize Congress

BYLINE: By Arthur Miller; Arthur Miller's last play was "Broken Glass."

DATELINE: ROXBURY, Conn.

 BODY:
It is great news, this idea of selling a House office building now that the Republicans are dissolving so many committees and firing their staffs. But I wouldn't be surprised if this is only the opening wedge for a campaign to privatize Congress. Yes, let the free market openly raise its magnificent head in the most sacred precincts of the Welfare State.
The compelling reasons for privatizing Congress are perfectly evident. Everybody hates it, only slightly less than they hate the President. Everybody, that is, who talks on the radio, plus millions of the silent who only listen and hate in private. 
 Congress has brought on this hatred, mainly by hypocrisy. For example, members are covered by complete Government-run health insurance -- while the same kind of coverage for the voters was defeated, with the voters' consent and support, no less.
The voters, relieved that they are no longer menaced by inexpensive health insurance administered by the hated Government, must nevertheless be confused about not getting what polls show they wanted.
The important point is that even though they are happy at being denied what they say they want, they also know that the campaign to defeat health insurance was financed by the big private health insurance companies to the tune of millions of dollars paid to Congressional campaigns. The net result is that with all their happiness, the voters are also aware of a lingering sense of Congressional hypocrisy.
Health care is only one of many similar issues -- auto safety, the environment, education, the use of public lands, etc. The way each issue is decided affects the finances of one or another business, industry or profession, and these groups naturally tend to butter the bread of members of Congress.
We can do away with this hypocrisy by making Congress a private enterprise. Let each representative and senator openly represent, and have his salary paid by, whatever business group wishes to buy his vote. Then, with no excuses, we will really have the best representative system money can buy. No longer will absurdly expensive election campaigns be necessary. Anyone wanting the job of Congressional representative of, say, the drug industry could make an appointment with the council of that industry and make his pitch.
The question arises whether we would need bother to go through the whole election procedure. But I think we must continue to ask the public to participate lest people become even more alienated than they are now, with only 39 percent of the eligible voters going to the polls in November.
A privatized Congress might well attract a much higher percentage of voters than the present outmoded one does because the pall of hypocrisy would have been stripped away and a novel bracing honesty would attract voters to choose whichever representative of the auto or real estate industries or the date growers they feel most sympathy for.
Once Congress is privatized, the time would have come to do the same to the Supreme Court and the Justice Department. If each Justice were openly hired by a sector of the economy to protect its interests, a simple bargaining process could settle everything. The Auto Industry Justice, wishing to throw out a suit against General Motors or Ford, could agree to vote his support for the Agribusiness Justice, who wanted to quash a suit by workers claiming to have been poisoned while picking cabbages.
Some will object that such a system of what might be called legalized corruption would leave out the public and its interests. But this is no longer a problem when you realize that there is no public and therefore no public interest in the old sense. As Margaret Thatcher once said, "There is no society," meaning that the public consists of individuals, all of whom have private interests that to some degree are hostile to the interests of other individuals.
Possible objections: the abstract idea of justice would disappear under a system that takes only private economic interests into account. Secondly, the corporate state, which this resembles, was Mussolini's concept and resulted in the looting of the public by private interests empowered by the state.
Objections to the objections: we already have a corporate state. All privatization would do would be to recognize it as a fact.
Conclusion: we are in bad trouble.
