HEADLINE: THE 104TH CONGRESS: DIARY;
Developments in Congress

 BODY:

HOUSE -- Alan Greenspan, the head of the Federal Reserve Board, offered Republicans a painless way to cut the budget: changing the way the Government calculates inflation. He told a joint meeting of the House and Senate Budget Committees that the Consumer Price Index now exaggerates annual inflation by 0.5 to 1.5 percentage points, leading to higher payments for Social Security and Government pensions and lower revenues from those taxes that are pegged to inflation. Correcting those estimates, Mr. Greenspan said, could save the Federal Government $150 billion over five years.
Republicans welcomed his suggestion, but it did not distract Democrats from demanding that Republicans "show us the fine print," as Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri and House minority leader, put it. 
 Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, told the House Ways and Means Committee that the Administration would support separating children from their parents in some cases in which the parents repeatedly refused to work while receiving cash welfare benefits.
While calling for many changes in the House Republicans' welfare proposals, Dr. Shalala sought common ground with the Republicans on other points. "We are committed first and foremost to insuring that everybody who can work does work," she said. If able-bodied women refused to comply with work requirements, she said, they should lose their welfare benefits, and the children could be taken away from the parents by state authorities and placed in foster care or group homes or put up for adoption.
 
SENATE --The Senate debated, but did not act on, legislation that would subject Congress to most of the same civil rights and employment laws that private employers must already obey. The House acted on the measure in 20 minutes last week.
Robert E. Rubin, nominated by President Clinton to succeed Lloyd Bentsen as Treasury Secretary, won swift and unanimous approval from the Senate without debate, only hours after he had appeared for a cordial confirmation hearing before the Finance Committee.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN MEXICO DEEPENS DAMAGE IN LATIN MARKETS

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Any hope that the Mexican Government's austere economic recovery plan and an international loan package would calm the nation's financial markets seemed to evaporate today as the stock market here plunged and the peso flirted with a new low against the dollar.
The damage in Mexican financial markets carried over to other Latin American stock exchanges, with some losses exceeding 8 percent 
 There was growing concern here that the emergency plan announced last week by President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon was not strong enough to stabilize the peso and avoid uncontrolled inflation.
The Government's agreement with Mexican labor and business to hold down wage and price increases now seemed threatened by indications that inflation this year would far exceed official estimates -- making it likely that labor unions would demand wage increases higher than the 7 to 10 percent they have been offered.
Some analysts predicted that the Government would have to ask for even more help from its trading partners, particularly the United States. One option would be for Washington to help renegotiate Mexico's debt and then guarantee bonds issued by the Mexican Government to help pay that debt. This is essentially what the United States Government did to help Mexico out of its 1982 debt crisis.
Mexican officials were in Japan and Britain today, negotiating for further funds to add to an $18 billion international credit line that Mexico can tap to support its sagging currency and meet its debt obligations.
On Monday, Mexico used the credit line to buy pesos and, it hoped, bolster their value. But today, the currency continued to slide, closing at 5.85 pesos to dollar, a one-day decline of 8.1 percent. Since the forced devaluation and floating of the peso late last month, the currency has deteriorated against the dollar more than 40 percent.
Talks also continued with the International Monetary Fund and other international groups in an attempt to restore Mexico's financial health and line up additional money.
The turmoil in the markets today was set off by different sparks -- including a Government debt auction that failed to attract enough investors, and a short-term interest rate of 50 percent that may have prompted stockholders to sell those securities and instead buy short-term Government bonds and notes.
All this reverberated in other Latin American markets, as traders tended to view Latin America as a monolith. Exchanges in Argentina, Brazil and Peru all reported huge one-day losses. In New York, the American depository receipts of Telefonos de Mexico, the telephone monopoly, were the most actively traded issue, skidding to a new low.
"It was very near a panic" in Mexico, said Jonathan E. Heath, a financial consultant in Mexico City. "Nobody was buying anything."
United States Treasury and Federal Reserve officials in Washington refused to discuss the Mexican crisis. Of the $18 billion credit line, the United States has put up $9 billion, and the possibility of further American assistance is now considered limited. Direct aid would have to be approved by Congress, and the new Republican majority appears to have little enthusiasm for foreign aid.
Mexico's stock exchange was roiled by these and other perceptions throughout the day, and by early afternoon was down as much as 11.3 percent. At that point, the Government started buying stocks to help stabilize the market, which eventually closed at 1,972.33, down 131.72, or 6.26 percent, from Monday's close.
The selloff followed a 6.65 percent decline on Monday and left the Mexican market with a drop of 31.5 percent, in peso terms, since its record high level of last February.
Investors today were also said to be concerned by reports from the southern state of Chiapas that a confrontation between local officials and angry peasants had resulted in an exchange of gunfire and several deaths. Officials said that the rebel Zapatista army had not been involved in the shooting.
Today was the third straight Tuesday in which the stock market recorded sharp declines. That reflected uncertainty among investors both in Mexico and in the United States over what the Government would do with $28 billion in bonds that come due this year. Each Tuesday in recent weeks, the Government has tried to auction new bonds with little success. The bondholders must be paid in pesos, but the amounts they receive fluctuate with the dollar exchange rate, and thus represent a high risk for Mexico.
At present, Mexico's international reserves stand at about $5.5 billion. Even with the $18 billion credit line from the United States and other nations, Mexico has access to less than $24 billion.
Officials here have said that they intend to offer new, more attractive bonds in about two weeks to entice investors to keep their money in this country. But after today's dismal stock and bond performances, some analysts thought that the Government would have to make those alternatives known much sooner.
"If anything, what happened today may accelerate events," said Jorge O. Mariscal, manager of the Latin American Equity Group at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "There still is not a very good sense that these guys are in control of the situation."
Mr. Mariscal and other analysts said that the interest rates now offered by the Government, ranging from 20 to 50 percent, did not sufficiently outweigh the risk of further deterioration in the peso's value. Although the Government's own estimates of inflation for 1995 are less than 20 percent, many private economists think it could reach as high as 40 or 50 percent.
At those rates, even interest of 50 percent on short-term Government debt notes would be unattractive.
The Government tried today to auction $400 million in bonds pegged to the peso-dollar exchange rate. However, it was able to sell only $63 million of that, despite an interest rate of 20 percent.
The Government's actions in response to the financial crisis have been focused on strengthening the peso, not the stock market. The central bank has raised interest rates to induce investors to consider buying a relatively small amount of Government bonds trading today in secondary markets. With rates as high as 50 percent, the Government hoped to bolster the peso in that separate arena.
But the high short-term interest, payment of which is guaranteed by the Mexican Government, hurt the stock market by luring away investors' money.
"The Government is not worrying about the stock market right now," said John F. H. Purcell, managing director of Emerging Markets Research at Salomon Brothers in New York. "At this point, they probably view the market as a short-term problem that they're going to take care of in the future."
United States investors in the bellwether Telefonos de Mexico were among those battered in today's brutal stock trading. American depository receipts of Telmex were the most widely traded issue on the New York Stock Exchange, plunging $3.125 to close at $33.375. At its peak last February, Telmex sold for $75 a share.
Analysts said many investors had followed J. P. Morgan's downgrading today of Telmex from a "strong buy" to "market performer," which means that the company could no longer be expected to outperform other Mexican stocks.
"Portfolio managers were saying that their chances of recovering in 1995 are not too good," said Bette A. Massick of S. G. Warburg in New York. "They probably decided to dump Telmex now and maybe get back in later on."
President Zedillo met with legislators here this morning and told them that Mexico would come out of the current crisis stronger than before. Yesterday, he announced a new set of austerity measures, including a prohibition against first-class airline travel for Government officials. 

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Stocks Plunge in Region
 SAO PAULO, Brazil, Jan. 10 (Reuters) -- Latin American stocks plunged today in volatile trading in reaction to the deepening financial troubles of Mexico.
The Argentine stock market fell 9.59 percent, while Brazil's leading stock index dropped 9.86 percent. Peru's smaller market plunged 8.42 percent -- all of those selloffs well exceeding the 6.26 percent fall in Mexican stocks.
Not even Chile, considered one of the most solid economies in the region, survived the market turmoil. The leading Chilean stock index fell 4.86 percent.
"It a total regional panic on the part of both local and foreign investors, sophisticated and unsophisticated investors alike," said Brian Barish, head of Latin American equity strategy at Lazard Freres. "Everybody is basically freaking out."
Many Latin American stock markets have fallen since Mexico devalued its peso on Dec. 20, though individual country markets have bucked the trend from time to time, rising unpredictably. In all of today's financial carnage, for instance, the Colombian stock market 0.39 percent.
Today's plunge stemmed in large part, analysts said, from selling by mutual fund managers who were raising cash by salvaging profits in Latin America's better-performing markets. "If you're getting redemptions in a Latin America fund or global fund, you'd probably sell what you have a profit in, and that's Brazil, Peru and Chile," said Rod Harada, Latin America analyst at Nomura Securities.
There were obvious fears that Mexico's problems could spread to other Latin American countries.
Argentina's Economy Minister, Domingo Cavallo, met with bankers in New York today in an attempt to convince them that the Argentine economy was sound and that there was no risk of a devaluation.

HEADLINE: THE 104TH CONGRESS: THE OVERVIEW;
As Parties Skirmish Over Budget, Greenspan Offers a Painless Cure

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
As Democrats kept demanding that Republicans spell out their plans for cutting the budget, the head of the Federal Reserve Board offered them an initially painless way to do it: changing the way the Government calculates inflation.
Alan Greenspan told a joint meeting of the House and Senate Budget Committees that the Consumer Price Index now exaggerates annual inflation by 0.5 to 1.5 percentage points. That leads to higher payments for Social Security and government pensions and lower revenues from those taxes that are pegged to inflation. 
 Mr. Greenspan said correcting those estimates could save the Federal Government $150 billion over five years, which could be used for tax cuts or spending without increasing the deficit.
A change in calculating the Consumer Price Index could cost typical Social Security recipients $3.49 to $10.47 a month. Phil Gambino, a spokesman for the Social Security Administration, said today that the current average monthly benefit is $698. One and a half percent of that, the high range of overestimating cited by Mr. Greenspan is $10.47, while 0.5 percent of it, his low estimate, is $3.49.
It would also affect pensions tied to the rate of inflation and union contracts with automatic adjustments based on inflation. The index is calculated by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, and it would be politically difficult for the Labor Department in a Democratic Administration to move directly to change those estimates.
Republicans welcomed his suggestion, even though it could bring attacks from the Social Security lobby, one of the nation's strongest. It also failed to distract Democrats from keeping up a drumbeat of demands that Republicans "show us the fine print," of their budget balancing plans as Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the minority leader, put it.
Mr. Gephardt, testifying first before the House Budget Committee and then before the Ways and Means Committee, argued that a constitutional amendment to require a balanced Federal budget should be approved only if supporters would first spell out the cuts they would make to reach that goal. He said he would introduce an "honest budget bill" to require such accounting.
Orrin G. Hatch, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, said supporters of any proposal like Mr. Gephardt's were "not serious about a balanced budget amendment because they know that kills it."
His committee today put off a vote on the proposed amendment for a week, and opponents began to speak hopefully of their chances of defeating it in the Senate. It would take 34 votes to deny the measure the two-thirds majority required for a constitutional amendment, and 33 of last year's 37 opponents are still in office. They hope the "honest budget" argument can win them a few more critical votes. The House Judiciary Committee plans to vote on the amendment Wednesday.
Another House committee actually began the process of cutting spending. The Appropriations Committee began looking for ways to take back money that has already been committed for spending in the current fiscal year. Representative Robert L. Livingston of Louisiana, the chairman, said "we are looking for billions" in cuts.
Mr. Gephardt also told the Ways and Means Committee that Democrats were working on a tax plan with fewer tax breaks and fewer tax brackets. He said he would not go as far as many Republicans who favor a "flat tax," with only one rate for all taxpayers. But he said he could back a "flatter tax," under which most Americans except those with very high incomes would pay only about 10 or 11 percent.
He said he ultimately favored this approach because most efforts to change social policy through tax incentives had failed. "I don't think you can micromanage society through the tax code," he said. But in the short run, he urged a tax cut for workers earning less than $75,000 a year.
The Greenspan proposal was an unusual departure for the Fed chairman, who habitually declines to advise Congress on budget matters. Mr. Greenspan volunteered that changes in the index would cut spending and increase tax revenues and thus help reduce the deficit.
That would help solve the Republican problem of trying to balance the budget without formally raising taxes.
Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who heads the House Budget Committee, initially said after hearing Mr. Greenspan's that the Government's calculations of the Consumer Price Index should be adjusted. He said he had already discussed the idea with Representative Bill Archer, the Texan who heads the Ways and Means Committee.
"We will attempt to incorporate accurate C.P.I. estimates," he said. Later, during a break in the hearing, he was more cautious in speaking to reporters. "Clearly the fact that we may have been overstating the C.P.I. and may have been having more entitlement spending than mandated under the law is something we are going to look at very, very carefully."
The idea that the C.P.I. overstates annual inflation is not original with Mr. Greenspan. The Congressional Budget Office estimated late last year that it exaggerated inflation by from 0.2 to 0.8 percentage point. Top Labor Department officials have also acknowledged that the index is an exaggeration.
It is calculated by the Bureau of Labor Statistics and adjusted about once each decade, so that it fails to capture fully such changes as suddenly successful inventions like television sets in the early 1950's or the introduction of more sophisticated computers, which reduce prices and enhance efficiency.
Mr. Greenspan based his $150 billion estimate on a one percentage point reduction in the Federal Government's inflation estimates. "If the annual inflation adjustments in the indexed programs and taxes were reduced by one percentage point," he said, "and making the admittedly strong assumption that there are no other changes in the economy -- the annual level of the deficit will be lower by about $55 billion after five years, with cumulative five-year savings, I might add, of about $150 billion."
The Bureau of Labor Statistics is now working on a regular revision of the price index, a process likely to take another year or two to complete.
A more direct approach, one Mr. Greenspan suggested as a possibility today, would be for Congress to pass a law providing that current laws that adjust benefits based on the Consumer Price Index be amended so that the adjustment would be lower by a percentage point, or half a percentage point.
Such an approach would be almost certain to invite opposition from groups representing Social Security recipients, who are probably the nation's most effective lobby.

HEADLINE: Moscow Reaches for Moral High Ground as Truce Fails

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 10

 BODY:
With its ground troops tightening their grip on the besieged city of Grozny, Russia today declared a 48-hour cease-fire, but it collapsed within hours.
The reprieve to battle-weary combatants in Grozny, the Chechen capital, was scant. But the politically battered Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, seized on the cease-fire declaration to try to win back some of the international and domestic support that has drained away during the brutal month-old Russian military operation. 
 Even as Russian troops exchanged fire with Chechen rebels in the center of Grozny, Oleg Lobov, the secretary of Mr. Yeltsin's security council, told reporters in Moscow that the Russian proposal, which included an offer of amnesty to Chechens who laid down their arms, was a "historic moment" and "generous offer" to allow the rebels to "come to their senses" before a final Russian offensive.
Mr. Yeltsin, whose reputation was tarnished dramatically after he sent troops to restore Russian rule in the oil-producing, mostly Muslim republic, was working hard today to appeal to critics at home and abroad, painting the short-lived cease-fire as Russia's effort to give peace a chance.
In Moscow, representatives of the Organization of Security and Cooperation in Europe said that the Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, had told them that Russia would allow a fact-finding delegation from the 52-member security organization to visit Chechnya soon. Moscow had previously rejected such requests by foreign governments.
The Russian Government also said it would begin an independent inquiry into whether the armed forces had continued to bomb civilian targets even after Mr. Yeltsin had ordered a halt in the air strikes. Russian air raids on Grozny, which have killed hundreds of civilians and destroyed apartment houses and schools, horrified Russians and eventually prompted the United States and other countries to criticize Moscow's actions.
In an effort to recruit alienated Russian politicians into his tent, Mr. Yeltsin offered the Speakers of both houses of Parliament permanent seats on his security council, which until now has been made up of Cabinet ministers and national security advisers. The Speakers eagerly accepted.
The invitation, made on the eve of an emergency session on the Chechen crisis in the lower house of Parliament, seemed aimed at easing Mr. Yeltsin's strained relations with the country's elected officials.
But Yegor T. Gaidar, the liberal leader in Parliament who at one time served in the Cabinet and spearheaded Mr. Yeltsin's economic reforms, said his Russia's Choice faction would sponsor legislation to win back for Parliament some of the powers he had helped Mr. Yeltsin strip away.
"Our initiatives are aimed at blocking all legal ways for the Government to go ahead with hostilities in Chechnya," Mr. Gaidar said in a news conference.
Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, who was recently assigned to head negotiations with the Chechen leadership, met with Chechen emigres in Moscow and assured them that he was working on a plan to "resolve the Chechen conflict without the use of force." He added, "Our key task is to stop the bloodshed."
Russian television reported that Mr. Chernomyrdin also met privately today with Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, the leader of Russia's ultranationalist party. Mr. Zhirinovsky's press office did not confirm the meeting. Throughout the crisis, the firebrand politician has been unusually silent, torn between his unbridled contempt for Mr. Yeltsin's leadership and his nationalistic desire to see Chechnya's bid for secession squelched.
But Sergei A. Kovalyov, the dissident who heads Mr. Yeltsin's commission on human rights and who first suggested the cease-fire in a phone conversation with Mr. Chernomyrdin, bitterly denounced the Russian Government's amended version of it as an ultimatum.
Mr. Kovalyov, who had hoped the truce would allow the removal of casualties from the battle zone, said he would return to Grozny to help evacuate the wounded. He had spent two dangerous weeks in the city drawing public attention to the hundreds of civilians killed in bombing raids and artillery attacks. He has been Mr. Yeltsin's most outspoken critic.
Described in Moscow as a humanitarian action aimed at exchanging captured, wounded and dead soldiers, the cease-fire declaration did not bring gunfire in Grozny to a halt, although a brief lull was reported in heavy fighting was reported. The Interfax news agency reported that some wounded and dead soldiers were evacuated from the bombed-out and blackened presidential palace during that lull, and that trucks delivered bread and water to the building.
"The cease-fire declaration is to some extent a recognition of public sentiment about the war," said Sergei Rogov, a military expert at the U.S.A.-Canada institute in Moscow. "Russians have been tremendously shocked by all this -- it's a new experience for us to watch civil war in Russia on our television sets."
Mr. Rogov predicted that Russian troops might still be able to seize Grozny within a week while claiming that, with the truce offer, they had given peace a chance. "It will be a hollow victory," he said, referring to his belief that a prolonged guerrilla war in Chechnya would spread to other volatile regions of the Caucasus. "But this will allow some politicians in Moscow to claim victory."

Relief Team Held Up
 UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 10 (Special to The New York Times) -- A United Nations relief team, waiting to fly into of Chechnya, has been forbidden permission to leave Moscow for two days, and the only explanation offered is that weather conditions make landing in the area too dangerous, a United Nations spokesman said today.
The spokesman said that other aircraft had been allowed to take off and land in the area.
The Russian Federal Migration Service, which is responsible for refugees, requested relief aid from the United Nations for Chechnya on Dec. 27. Two planeloads of medical supplies, food parcels and plastic sheeting have been waiting to depart from the Netherlands and Turkey as soon as the United Nations team has viewed conditions in Chechnya and prepared an assessment of the needs of the region's civilian population.

HEADLINE: U.S. May Ease Economic Curbs On North Korea This Month

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
As part of an effort to get North Korea to dismantle its nuclear weapons program, American officials said today that they planned to ease some economic restrictions against North Korea in the next two weeks.
In addition, the officials said they planned to urge nations in Europe, the Middle East and Southeast Asia to help finance new power plants for North Korea. 
 Administration officials welcomed the announcement that North Korea made on Monday to end its ban on trade, financial transactions and telephone links with the United States. These officials said the United States would soon reciprocate, most likely by easing its four-decade-old embargo against North Korea, a move called for in an agreement last October settling Washington's dispute with North Korea over its nuclear program.
In the October agreement, North Korea promised to freeze, and ultimately dismantle, its nuclear power program in exchange for a pledge to provide it with the two light-water reactors. The spent fuel from those reactors is far harder to turn into weapons-grade material than the fuel from North Korea's existing graphite reactors.
Winston Lord, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asia, said that the Administration had not yet decided which restrictions to ease. But State Department officials said the October agreement calls for easing the sanctions on trade, telecommunications links or financial transactions.
Administration officials acknowledged they were moving gingerly on easing restrictions in light of the recent incident in which North Korea shot down an American helicopter. One pilot died and the other pilot was released only after tense negotiations between the two countries.
State Department officials met here today with Japanese and South Korean diplomats to discuss the best way to raise $4 billion to finance the two new light-water nuclear reactors for North Korea. American officials said they hoped to persuade as many countries as possible to join Japan, South Korea and the United States in financing the project. Japan and South Korea are expected to put up the major part of the money.
Robert Gallucci, the Administration's chief negotiator with North Korea, plans to go to Europe later this month to seek additional financial pledges, while Thomas C. Hubbard, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for East Asia, will travel to Southeast Asia to do likewise. Other officials will visit Persian Gulf countries as well as Australia and New Zealand to urge them to contribute.
The White House also announced today that it would send officials to the North Korean capital of Pyongyang from Jan. 31 to Feb. 4 to examine sites to set up a liaison office there. Under the October accord, the two countries promised to establish liaison offices.
Fearing that Republicans in Congress might block the North Korea agreement, Administration officials said today that they hoped Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama of Japan, who arrived in Washington today for a visit, would impress upon Congressional leaders that his country strongly backs the agreement.
"One of the questions we've been getting from Republicans is, how come you're so strongly in favor of the agreement when the South Koreans and Japanese don't like it," a State Department official said. "It will be useful for Murayama to tell the Hill that Japan is strongly in favor of the agreement."
In addition, the Administration has sent Walter F. Mondale, the Ambassador to Japan, to Capitol Hill to help shore up support for the accord. Sen. Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, has said Congress will hold hearings to examine the agreement, especially the Administration's promise to provide some economic aid to North Korea.
Under the agreement, the Administration promised to furnish North Korea with 50,000 tons of heavy oil by Jan. 21, a move intended to help provide the country with energy until the new reactors are built. The agreement calls for foreign countries to provide North Korea with 500,000 tons of oil per year for approximately 10 years.

HEADLINE: Photos Show Iraqis With Stolen Kuwaiti Arms

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 10

 BODY:
The United States offered the Security Council pictures today to prove that when Iraqi troops moved toward the Kuwaiti border last October they were armed with advanced equipment stolen from Kuwait during the Persian Gulf war.
The presentation, complete with detailed lists of captured equipment still believed to be in Iraqi hands, was Washington's opening salvo in a review of sanctions imposed on the Government of President Saddam Hussein. Under a 1991 Security Council resolution, Iraq must return stolen Kuwaiti property before sanctions are lifted. 
 Iraq has said in the past that the missing Kuwaiti equipment was destroyed or not under its control. The chief United States delegate to the United Nations, Madeleine K. Albright, challenged that assertion today with satellite photographs showing some of the material, including armored personnel carriers and missile launchers, deployed with the elite Iraqi Republican Guards. Hardware and vehicles of Russian and American origin were included.
"This equipment had been used in an offensive capability during the October events by the Republican Guard," Ms. Albright told reporters after the closed-door Council session. "This is not latent equipment, but equipment that is being used to enhance the capability of the Iraqi military."
Pressure is building in the Council to begin relaxing a web of sanctions and embargos that has crippled Iraq's economy. A more comprehensive review will take place in March, when Russia and France are expected to propose formally that sanctions be lifted piecemeal as Iraq meets certain demands.
The United States and Britain strongly oppose rewarding Iraq in any way until President Hussein has demonstrated good faith as well as technical compliance.
British and American diplomats seized on a new report today by Rolf Ekeus, leader of a team monitoring the destruction of Iraqi weapons, which again proved that Baghdad had been withholding information on its past chemical weapons program.
"Miraculously, after his rather tough report in December, the Iraqis found a lot more material," Sir David Hannay, Britain's chief delegate, told reporters after the briefing by Mr. Ekeus. "They always do seem to find a lot more material when they have to."
Sir David said that by confronting the Iraqis, Mr. Ekeus had elicited confirmation of information found elsewhere about the extent of their chemical weapons program in the mid-1980's.
"We are still adrift post-1987," he said, adding that there were also problems with machine tools apparently used in ballistic missile systems that would have to be destroyed and some questions remaining about the history of Iraq's biological weapons.
During her Council briefing, Ms. Albright showed photographs of 29 launchers for Soviet-era Frog-7 short-range missiles deployed at Taji, in southern Iraq. Before the gulf war, Iraq was believed to have only 25. She also showed Russian armored personnel carriers code-named BMP-2, and mentioned that the Soviet delegate, Sergei V. Lavrov, could attest to their qualities.
Lists of captured equipment, prepared by the United States and Kuwait, were distributed to Council members. Among the missing equipment are about 1,750 Jeeps and Land Rovers, at least 2,000 trucks, 4,000 TOW antitank missiles, ambulances, firefighting vehicles, buses, motorcycles and thousands of radios.
Kuwait had both Soviet and American equipment in its arsenal, as did Iraq. But Kuwait had certain models of Soviet-made arms and tracked vehicles that Iraq did not possess. That rules out the possibility that at least some of the weapons and vehicles photographed in October were Iraqi all along, and not Kuwaiti, a Kuwaiti diplomat said.
Security Council Resolution 686 of March 2, 1991, requires that Iraq "immediately begin to return all Kuwaiti property." A similar demand was made in Resolution 687 the next month.
The Council also demanded that Iraq release prisoners and account for Kuwaiti citizens listed as missing after the war. Russia has been trying to help Iraq speed up accounting of the prisoners and missing Kuwaitis, Mr. Lavrov told reporters.
Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev of Russia was instrumental in talking the Iraqis into a formal recognition last year of Kuwait in its postwar borders. That important step, coupled with progress in accounting for Iraq's weapons of mass destruction, led to increased pressure from Russia and France to begin lifting or easing sanctions.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
 Mexico's rescue plan failed to calm its markets. Stocks plunged, and the peso continued to weaken. Mexican officials sought additional funds in Japan and Britain and there were indications more U.S. help might be needed. [Page A1.] 
 Wall Street firms will be allowed to compete in Japan for the right to manage pension funds under a trade accord. [A1.]
 Wall Street's interest in Japanese pension funds is tempered by a realization that cultural and economic obstacles remain. [D5.]
 American apples appeared on Japanese grocery shelves for the first time in decades. Apple imports had been blocked by the health concerns of Japanese fruit inspectors. [A3.]
 
Business Technology
 Two technologies are vying to become the industry standard for digital videodisks. The new generation of disks could become a universal storage medium, working in computers, music machines and video players. [D1.]
 
Companies
 Sony has begun overhauling its movie business, shifting much of the oversight of its studio operations from Hollywood to New York. Sony is looking to reduce its risks after writing off $3.2 billion on its movie businesses in November. [D1.]
 Merrill Lynch sought to account for its Orange County dealings. In a memo to employees in Southern California, the firm disclosed some of the correspondence between a salesman and the former manager of the California county's investment fund. [D1.]
 I.B.M. plans to buy back $1.1 billion of its series A preferred stock. The buyback indicates that the company's outlook is probably better than when the shares were issued, analysts said. [D4.]
 A former Duracell chief was picked to run Borden. The new chief executive, C. Robert Kidder, is an aggressive marketer from the Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company roster of managers. [D4.]
 A Johnson & Johnson subsidiary said it would plead guilty to destroying documents related to a Federal investigation into whether it sold its acne medicine as a wrinkle cream. [D4.]
 A hotel chain based in Singapore is in discussions to invest in the Plaza Hotel, which is controlled by Donald J. Trump. [D4.]
 
The Economy
 Producer prices rose a modest 0.2 percent in December. [D1.]
 Changing the way the Government calculates inflation has been proposed by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chief. [A1.]
 A majority of Americans favor increased regulation of cigarettes, according to a poll done for the Tobacco Institute. [A14.]
 Robert E. Rubin was confirmed as Treasury Secretary. [A19.]

 Treasury prices rose, bolstered by a report showing modest inflation on the producer level. [D6.]
 Stocks retreated after an early rally prompted by the producer price report. The Standard & Poor's 500 rose 0.85 point. [D8.]

 Heating oil prices declined. [D17.]

HEADLINE: Americans Say Gains Won't Come Quickly

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
An agreement to open a range of Japanese financial markets to foreign competition was not greeted with unbridled enthusiasm by American money managers yesterday, even though the accord gives them access to more than $1 trillion of pension fund assets.
Even as they expressed pleasure that the agreement to open Japan's private and public pension funds to foreign firms had finally been reached, representatives of some of the nation's largest brokerage firms, mutual fund companies and investment banks said enacting the agreement could prove even more difficult than the negotiations that produced it. 
 "The key to any agreement is implementation," said David Strongin, vice president and director of international finance at the Securities Industry Association. "But to the extent the agreement does provide procedural protections, that is significant. Basically, it makes the laws more open and more fair."
Even with the agreement, officials at American firms said, the economics of pension fund management in Japan are far different than in the United States. It will take years to generate significant profits from the business, they added.
Compounding that problem is the Japanese investment culture, in which longstanding financial and economic relationships between pension funds and their managers remain formidable barriers to entry.
Still, executives at American firms said they were happy to have the chance.
"For the first time in quite a while, we have some agreements that on their face open up new opportunities," said Robert Pozen, general counsel and managing director at Fidelity Investments. "This is the first major progress in years."
Until the Japanese pension funds form a substantial base of business -- something that could take as long as a decade to accomplish -- doing business with them is unlikely to generate significant returns, because fees are relatively low and the costs are high.
"The margins are thin because newcomers in Japan normally get a small amount of exposure, like $10 million to $20 million," one senior executive in New York for a Japanese securities house said, speaking on the condition of anonymity.
"And unlike sponsors of American pension funds, Japanese pension funds require a lot of different services from their managers," the executive said. "It is very time-consuming and costly. Any serious manager has to be patient, and has to respond to all those requests."
Under the terms of the agreement, foreign firms will have more access to public pension funds than to corporate pension funds.
Public pension funds are the fastest-growing segment of the pension fund market in Japan, Mr. Strongin said. By the end of the decade, those funds may have around $400 billion of assets.
Foreign firms had some access to the corporate pension fund market before the agreement, and they may see competition freed up a bit more. But trying to forge a niche between big Japanese companies and their fund managers will be a challenge.
"This is very much a relationship-driven business," said a Wall Street analyst who follows Japanese companies, "because the companies which have asset management relationships are often clients in other businesses, and shareholders as well. The links are extremely tight."
George A. Murnaghan, a vice president at Rowe Price-Fleming International, said: "We will not be able to establish ourselves in Japan tomorrow and expect to see significant assets coming to American firms. The concept of giving money to non-Japanese asset managers will evolve over time. And that has more to do with Japan's culture than the law."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Merrill Cites Warning to Big County

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
In a belated effort to defend itself against the heavy criticism it has received since Orange County, Calif., declared bankruptcy last month, Merrill Lynch & Company released letters yesterday showing that it had warned the county as early as 1992 about the risks that its ill-fated investment fund was taking.
The letters were to the Orange County treasurer, Robert L. Citron, whose management of the county's investment fund led to more than $2 billion in losses and touched off the county's bankruptcy and current financial crisis. 
 The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating Merrill for possible fraud in connection with its dealings with Orange County. In addition, holders of some of the county's notes underwritten by Merrill have filed suit against the Wall Street company, which had done business with Orange County for more than two decades.
While the documents shed some new light on the relationship between Merrill and Mr. Citron, they also raise new questions and leave others unanswered.
Merrill for the first time released some of the correspondence between Mr. Citron and Michael G. Stamenson, the Merrill salesman whom some blame for masterminding the county's ultimately disastrous investment strategy.
The key to the strategy was to borrow heavily against the fund's assets, making big bets that interest rates would remain low. The fund also bought derivatives, which are financial instruments whose value depends on the performance of underlying assets like stocks or bonds.
The correspondence discloses that Merrill warned Mr. Citron as early as 1992 that he might be taking too great a risk with the county fund. In March 1993, Merrill offered to buy back at a profit to the fund all the derivative securities that Merrill had sold to it.
The derivatives purchased by Mr. Citron were extremely vulnerable to large losses if there was a sharp jump in interest rates. But Mr. Citron, in his April 26, 1993, response, declined Merrill's offer, saying that he was aware of the volatile nature of the fund's investments.
"It is typical -- but nonetheless disingenuous -- that some now maintain that they were not aware of the potential risks involved in the county's investment strategy," Daniel P. Tully, Merrill's chairman and chief executive, wrote to the company's employees in Southern California yesterday in a memo in which he referred to the warning letters.
David Wiechert, Mr. Citron's lawyer, declined late yesterday to comment directly on the correspondence, which he had not seen. But he said that Merrill itself was being disingenuous by trying to keep itself at arm's-length from Mr. Citron.
"For Merrill Lynch to distance themselves from this crisis, would be akin to Exxon distancing themselves from the Valdez," he said, referring to the Exxon Valdez oil tanker that ran aground in 1989, spilling oil in Alaska's Prince William Sound.
Among the unanswered questions, Mr. Tully's memo does not mention the $600 million one-year note underwritten by Merrill for Orange County last July which was deposited into the fund only a short time before rising interest rates began drying up its cash. If Merrill was aware of the risks the fund was taking, why did it agree to underwrite the notes? And why did it not include in its prospectus for the issue the kind of warning that it sent to Mr. Citron?
Merrill has said that all the proper disclosures were made in the offering document circulated to investors.
Mr. Tully also asserted that the derivatives it sold Mr. Citron were not "as exotic or high-risk as some accounts have inaccurately described them." But if this was the case, the company did not say why it had offered to buy them back?
In a June 1993, letter, Mr. Stamenson, the Merrill salesman, explained that the company was making the offer to allow Orange County the opportunity to lower its risk at a profit.
"While the decision is yours to make, it was our hope to assist you in bringing the O.C. portfolio in line with a risk that is less leveraged and better positioned to perform in the event of unanticipated movements in interest rates," Mr. Stamenson wrote.
But Mr. Citron would not be swayed. "It was only after extensive consultation with highly placed Merrill Lynch officials by conference call, in person, and in writing well over a year ago that we felt secure in investing an even larger percentage of our portfolio in derivative securities," he wrote in April 1993.

HEADLINE: Businesses Face the Facts of Curbs on Smoking

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
After months of fighting it, businesses have begun dealing with the reality of the smoking law signed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday.
Frank's, an Italian steakhouse in Manhattan's meatpacking district, is moving around the corner to a new space with enough room for a segregated smoking lounge. Chanterelle, the elegant TriBeCa restaurant, says it deeply regrets not being able to allow a practice it thinks it has been able to control, but will comply with the law and refer all complaints to City Hall. 
 Leisure Time Bowling in the Port Authority Building welcomes the new restrictions and promises to enforce them aggressively. But Bowlmor Lanes on University Place despairs over having to confine smokers to designated areas. "I'm not the police," said Theodore Bournis, who owns the alley. "There's nothing I can do, believe me."
Mayor Giuliani signed the law after a heated two-hour hearing yesterday that featured, on one side, business representatives who said the city's restaurant and hotel trade would suffer, and on the other, a bartender and a beauty queen in a rhinestone crown who said they resented second-hand smoke.
The law goes into effect on April 10. It strengthens current law by imposing further restrictions on smoking in restaurants and work places and, for the first time, extends restrictions to outdoor areas like parks and stadiums. The old law allowed smoking in contiguous smoking areas in restaurants seating more than 50 people and did not regulate smoking in restaurants seating 50 people or less. The new law allows smoking only in restaurants seating 35 or fewer people.
In work places, the new law restricts smoking to separately ventilated smoking rooms and to private offices, as long as no more than three people are present and all agree to allow it. The old law did not regulate the number who could be smoking at any one time in private offices.
Across the city yesterday, many restaurants and business places said they were unsure what the law would mean or how they would respond to it. Others, like Chase Manhattan Bank, which has a single smoking lounge for 5,000 employees, said it already complies. And still others, grumbling, said they would comply.
The Mayor had left little doubt during yesterday's hearing that he would sign the measure. More than 100 cities and 4 states have passed no-smoking ordinances for public places. "This is where the rest of America is going," Mr. Giuliani said. "New York City is going to get there a little bit slower than others and a little bit faster than others."
William Althaus, an official of the Smokers Alliance, a smoking group that claims 200,000 members in the city, said he and his allies had entertained no hope of changing the Mayor's mind. "We're here to plant the seeds of doubt," he said. "We want economic data collected to be used to evaluate the harm of this law within a year."
During the 10 months the law was debated in the Council, officials heard from lobbyists and business people who said the law could put some restaurants out of business. Philip Morris, which has its headquarters on Park Avenue, said it would consider leaving town.
In November, the Council loosened some of the original restrictions. Philip Morris said yesterday that it was examining its options, and a spokeswoman, Ellen Merlo, emphasized that any decision would be made in accordance with "courtesy and good manners."
She said the company already has policies to safeguard the 70 percent of its employees who do not smoke. "We don't believe nonsmokers should be subjected to smoke if they don't want to be," she said.
At Frank's yesterday, the restaurant's owners swore they would never ask their most elderly patrons -- one of whom, they say, is 104 and has been coming in since the restaurant's inception -- to extinguish their beloved stogies.
But they are careful to emphasize that they plan to comply fully with the city's new law, after they move from their current address at 431 West 14th Street around the block to a new location on 15th Street, which will feature a smoking lounge, designed in scrupulous compliance with the new regulations.
"Some customers have been smoking cigars in here since before I was born," said Christopher Molinari, whose family has owned the restaurant for three generations.
At Chanterelle, at 2 Harrison Street, Karen Waltuck, the owner, said she was sad that her customers could no longer have everything they want. "We like to take care of people's vices too," she said.
But she added: "In a way, it's nice to have all the responsibility taken from us as far as this question is concerned. But that's not something I'm seeking."
Diners at the restaurant also criticized the law. "Like Fidel said, I enjoy a good Havana after my meal," said James Brown, a business executive. "I think it's very discriminatory."
At another table, William Higgins, a portfolio manager, agreed: "In my own view, the legislation is discriminatory, and I speak as a nonsmoker. I begin to feel solidarity with a new oppressed class, the smoker."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Frank's, a restaurant on West 14th Street in Manhattan, plans to comply with New York City's new tobacco regulations with a segregated smoking lounge. Steven Molinari, above, the restaurant's general manager, enjoys a cigarette in the meantime.; Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani signed new legislation to curb smoking in most public places in the city after a heated two-hour hearing at City Hall yesterday. "This is where the rest of America is going," Mr. Giuliani said. (Photographs by Edward Keating/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "AT A GLANCE: Curbing Smoking"
 Mayor Rudolph Giuliani signed a bill yesterday banning smoking in virtually all public places. The law, the Smoke-Free Air Act, will take effect April 10.Below are the law's major provisions.
 
RESTAURANTS
 Smoking will be prohibited in the dining areas of all restaurants seating more than 35 people; it will be confined to the bar area (see below), enclosed smoking lounges serving only beverage and private functions. Restaurants wiht seating for 35 or fewer people are exempt.
 
BARS
 
1. In stand-alone bars, smoking will still be permitted.
2. In restaurant bars, smoking will be permitted if:
 a. The bar area is at least six feet from the indoor dining area or the bar area is separated from the indoor dining area by a solid floor-to-ceiling partition.
 b. The smoking lounge and bar do not exceed 25 percent of the combined area of the dining, beverage service and loung areas.
 c. The seating in the bar area where food service is offered is limited to (1) no more than 15 percent of the first 100 seats where food service is offered and (2) no more than 10 percent of any seats over 100 where food service is offered.
 d. The smoking lounge and bar are not the sole indoor waiting areas for patrons.
 
WORK PLACES
 All employees will be required to restrict smoking to one separately ventilated smoking room on each floor. Smoking will also be permitted in private enclosed offices as long as no more than three people, including the occupant, are present and all consent.
 
SPORTS ARENAS AND RECREATIONAL AREAS
 Smoking will be prohibited in outdoor seating areas. Smoking will be permitted in separately ventilated smoking lounges as long as those lounges do not exceed 25 percent of total lounge space. Smoking will be permitted in separate smoking rooms in the viewing area, as long as the rooms do not exceed 25 percent of total seating. In addition, smoking will be permitted in enclosed bars, private box seats and suites, enclosed areas of the concourse (not to exceed 25 percent of the total concourse area) and some unenclosed concourse areas.
 
DAY CAR CENTERS
 Smoking will be prohibited at all times in both indoor and outdoor areas of day care centers.
 
SCHOOLS
 The current ban on smoking in indoor areas in pre-primary, primary and secondary schools remains unchanged. In all other schools, smoking will be permitted only in separately ventilated smoking rooms for employees and students.

HEADLINE: Suspect Told Police He Found Firebomb in Bag

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

 BODY:
The paper bag was crumpled up on the floor in the subway car when he first saw it. He looked in and saw two jars containing what looked like chicken soup. Suddenly, it just "went up." And he was on fire.
That is the account Edward J. Leary gave detectives as he was being arrested in the firebombing that injured 40 people on a crowded subway train in Manhattan three weeks ago, according to a court document released yesterday. 
 The document, which was released as Mr. Leary was arraigned yesterday in his room in New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, is the first official account of what he told the authorities about the incident on a southbound No. 4 train on Dec. 21. He pleaded not guilty to charges of attempted murder, assault, attempted grand larceny and possession of a weapon.
In interviews a few hours after the firebomb went off and the next day, when he was arrested, Mr. Leary, a 49-year-old unemployed computer expert, told the police he was on his way to leave his resume with an employment agency when the bomb ignited.
He told Detective Michael Sapraicone on Dec. 22 at the hospital that he usually avoids subway cars that "smell" of "homeless people" and found himself in a car that was crowded.
"He stood in the center of the train where he saw a brown paper bag on the floor," the detective wrote. "It was crumpled up. He kicked it towards the back door where he stood by it."
Detective Sapraicone wrote: "I asked him why he kicked it. He said because he had dropped his resume. It had fallen under the bag. He looked into the bag. It had two jars in it that looked like it was chicken soup."
The train pulled into the station and the doors opened. "As he picked up his resume," Detective Sapraicone wrote, "the bag just went up."
Detective Sapraicone said that Mr. Leary could not understand how anyone could do "such a terrible thing," and that he noticed that Mr. Leary "looked as if he had a tear in his eye."
When the detective pressed on, saying it was good for a person to own up to his mistakes, Mr. Leary "sobbed and shook his head and a tear came out of his left eye. He then said, 'You have the wrong guy.' "

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Stay Low, With Gain for '94 Only 1.7%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Despite hefty cost increases for many industrial materials, the prices of finished goods rose only modestly in December, the Government said today. For all of 1994, the advance in the inflation index for goods at the final stage before reaching consumers was just 1.7 percent.
Producers thus continued to absorb higher manufacturing costs, as fierce competition in many industries has largely prevented them from passing increases along to customers. 
 But while visible inflation remains largely at bay -- up only two-tenths of 1 percent last month -- economists said they did not expect the fresh data to dissuade the Federal Reserve from further increases in short-term interest rates. That is because of fears that unless the economy cools off, the higher costs at the earlier stages of production could feed into a broader rise in inflation.
The main concern is at the earlier stages of production, where prices for intermediate goods, like a bolt of cloth, and for crude goods, like raw wool or cotton, have risen substantially in recent months.
After two consecutive years with increases of only 1 percent, the Labor Department's index of intermediate goods climbed 4.4 percent during 1994. And even though the prices of intermediate goods rose a moderate three-tenths of 1 percent last month, they jumped six-tenths of 1 percent when the wide-swinging food and energy components were removed.
And crude goods, though also up three-tenths of 1 percent for the month, jumped 2.5 percent without food and energy. That lifted the so-called core crude prices 17 percent higher than the December 1993 level.
"While price pressures at the finished goods level remain remarkably benign, we feel the Fed is paying closer attention to what's happening to prices at the crude and intermediate stages," said Joseph Liro, economist at S. G. Warburg. "These prices are forward looking measures."
Separately, the Commerce Department reported that wholesale inventories increased for a fifth consecutive month in November, while sales were slightly lower. Inventories held by merchant wholesalers grew 1.2 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $235.12 billion, after a sharply revised rise of 1.5 percent in October.
The steady rise in stocks of goods on hand in the final months of 1994 indicated that wholesalers were anticipating strong holiday sales. It also helped overall economic growth in the closing quarter by keeping production at brisk levels.
The department's report on consumer price inflation for December is scheduled to be published on Wednesday. Economists expect an increase of about three-tenths of 1 percent, meaning that 1994 is all but certain to be the third consecutive year with inflation at less than 3 percent.
Still, there is little doubt now that earlier-stage price pressure on industrial items like aluminum and copper are too strong to be fully contained. Durables used in manufacturing climbed 1.4 percent last month, after an increase of 1.7 percent in November. Those prices are now 9.8 percent higher than a year ago, nearly four times the 1993 increase, the department said.
"This is slowly filtering through -- and that's likely to continue," said Robert T. McGee, economist at the Tokai Bank Ltd. in New York. "It's a case of moving from no inflation to low inflation."
The finished goods index was dominated in December by gyrations in which a big leap in food prices was offset by sharply lower prices for energy.
Food rose 1.6 percent. In contrast, energy tumbled 1.5 percent, as gasoline prices fell 4.5 percent, to reverse an increase in November. Nearly one-third of the decline for gasoline reflected an adjustment for quality improvement, the introduction of reformulated fuel needed to meet environmental standards in certain parts of the country.
Though many companies are being squeezed by higher costs, some find no price pressures in either direction.
"We haven't seen any" significant increase in costs, said Billy T. Burney, president of the Burney Valve Company, a small maker of oilfield equipment in Sulphur Springs, Tex. But, he added, demand in the industry is so sluggish that "if there were any, we couldn't pass them on."

HEADLINE: New Tax Cut Is Promised By Whitman

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman promised a third round of tax cuts in her first State of the State address today, but she opened at least a semantic crack in her no-new-taxes pledge by saying she needed to renew an expiring vehicle surcharge to keep a state transportation fund afloat.
Mrs. Whitman also beat a temporary retreat on her vaunted school voucher plan for Jersey City by postponing for another year the measure, which had been meeting increasing resistance among legislators. The Governor appointed a study team to examine the idea until next year, when, she promised, she will move ahead with the program to give parents a free, subsidized choice of public or private schools in the city. 
 These concessions to political and fiscal reality hardly dampened Mrs. Whitman's exultant mood as she and her fellow Republicans in the majority in both houses of the Legislature awarded themselves the credit for New Jersey's steady economic recovery.
The Governor drew nothing but cheers from the Republicans when she delivered a rhetorical back of the hand to the former Governor of New York, Mario M. Cuomo, a Democrat who frequently derided Mrs. Whitman's tax policies as he campaigned unsuccessfully for re-election last fall.
"A year ago, the Governor of New York looked at New Jersey and laughed," Mrs. Whitman said as knowing smiles turned to laughter and applause from the Legislature's Republican majority. "He said our plan to cut taxes and stimulate economic growth would never work. Well, today New York has a new Governor, George Pataki, and he has a copy of our plan on his desk. And nobody's laughing at New Jersey anymore!"
Democrats responded to the speech by reiterating their view that Mrs. Whitman's real interest was in national office and that any cuts she makes in state taxes and spending would have to be made up by raising local property taxes.
"The Governor's obvious theme is when in doubt, announce another tax cut," said John A. Lynch, the Senate Democrats' minority leader. "It's simple and it makes for a good sound bite, especially when you're talking to a national audience and not to New Jersey residents who have to pay the bills."
Whatever these detractions, the Governor's address was buoyant to the point of braggadocio: as a result of her policies, she said, her state is a regional leader in job growth and New Jersey has become a lodestar for tax cutters around the nation.
"We are growing faster than New York, faster than Pennsylvania, faster than Connecticut," she said, calling the state "the pocket of hope in the region.
It was the first time Mrs. Whitman had delivered a State of the State address. Her inauguration last year came a week after the formal opening of the Legislature, when the State Constitution calls for such a report. The Governor issued a report on the State of the State on Monday, but it lacked both the political edge and the fiscal news of the speech delivered at noon today.
In addition to the auto registration fee and school voucher issues, Mrs. Whitman repeated her promise to cut the state income tax rate again in her next budget, which is to be released on Jan. 23. She did not say how much the cut would be.
Mrs. Whitman also pledged to work for a variety of other changes in government: the merger of the Motor Vehicles Division into the Department of Transportation to save money, a guarantee to refund permit application fees to companies whose paper work is not cleared by a state regulator on schedule, a limit on the ability of state and local police and firefighters to win large wage settlements through binding arbitration, a revision of the state tort law to discourage frivolous lawsuits, and creation of a $40 million public-private Community Development Bank to finance small-business loans for urban areas.
Mrs. Whitman's new timetable on her voucher plan, a founding tenet of her administration, came after a year of pressure from the Legislature. The state teachers' union is raising money especially to fight the measure, and Assembly members, up for election this fall, were concerned that the Governor's plan required them to take political risks for a city outside their own districts.
The issue will instead be studied by a 15-member advisory commission for a year. Mrs. Whitman said she would, in any case, introduce legislation to begin the program for the 1996 school year.
Mayor Bret Schundler of Jersey City, a rising Republican star like Governor Whitman, could barely conceal his disappointment at the postponement of a plan he had made his own. "Justice for our children will never be secured as long as their futures are in the hands of politicians who, as a group, will always be primarily concerned about their next election," the Mayor said in a statement.
Asked whether he was referring to Mrs. Whitman as well as the legislators, the Mayor said, "I'm trying to say, all politicians."
Democrats also accused Mrs. Whitman of playing politics by pretending that the motor vehicle fee was not a tax.
The state began charging a surcharge on motor vehicle registrations in 1990, under Gov. Jim Florio, to bail out a bankrupt bad-driver insurance fund. The insurance fund's deficit will be paid off, but now the Whitman administration has been casting about for sources of money to renew the Transportation Trust Fund, an $850 million-a-year subsidy program for road and bridge building and mass transit.
Extending the registration surcharge will produce $120 million a year, and the Governor will also seek a constitutional amendment to shift to the transportation fund an additional 3 cents of the existing state tax of 10.5 cents per gallon on motor fuel, for an additional $193 million a year. Currently, 2.5 cents of the fuel tax is earmarked for the fund.
Mrs. Whitman quickly rejected any idea that the surcharge extension amounted to a tax increase. "No," she said of that notion, "because we are not raising them, we are extending an existing fee, and we are doing it in a way that guarantees that we will not see fare increases in New Jersey Transit in the foreseeable future."
Besides taking credit for streamlining the state's regulatory system last year, the Governor noted that she had created an economic development commission whose plan to improve New Jersey's business climate is to be released on Wednesday. The commission is one of several set up by the Governor to work on state problems, with members drawn from business, education, labor and other nongovernment groups.
On Thursday, Mrs. Whitman plans to convene a meeting of state employee union leaders to solicit their ideas on the budget, for example.
"We are getting so good at bringing everyone to the table that we're thinking about offering our services to Major League Baseball," Governor Whitman joked during her address today. "But they haven't called yet."

HEADLINE: THE 104TH CONGRESS: WELFARE;
Clinton Has Tough Plan on Refusal to Work

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, told Congress today that the Administration would support separating children from their parents in some cases in which the parents repeatedly refused to work while receiving cash welfare benefits.
Dr. Shalala made the statement while testifying for more than two hours before the House Ways and Means Committee, which plans to recommend a comprehensive bill to revamp the nation's welfare system. 
 The Secretary, like other Democrats, called for many changes in the House Republicans' welfare proposal. But on some issues, she sought common ground with the Republicans.
"We are committed first and foremost to insuring that everybody who can work does work," Dr. Shalala said. If able-bodied women refuse to comply with work requirements, she said, they should lose their welfare benefits, and the children could be taken away from the parents by state authorities and placed in foster care or group homes or put up for adoption.
Dr. Shalala's comments came today as she offered an explanation and interpretation of the President's welfare bill, sent to Congress in June. Her comments were drawn out of her by Republican members of the committee.
Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the panel, said the Administration's position was somewhat similar to a Republican proposal that would make Federal money available to states "to establish and operate orphanages."
Dr. Shalala, along with Hillary Rodham Clinton and other Democrats, have harshly criticized the Republicans for proposing greater use of orphanages. And Administration officials said today that there was little similarity between their proposal and the ones made by Republicans like Speaker Newt Gingrich.
But Representative Pete Stark, Democrat of California, said the difference between the plans of the Administration and the House Republicans was only a matter of degree. "When you cut off welfare because the parents don't comply with work requirements, you're punishing innocent children, and that's unacceptable," Mr. Stark told Dr. Shalala.
On other issues, Dr. Shalala urged Congress to be wary of proposals to give states a lump sum of money for welfare and food assistance. The danger with such "block grants," she said, is that the amount of money will not automatically grow to meet the need in time of recession.
The House Democratic leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, told the committee that if Congress turned large amounts of money over to the states, it should set performance standards and demand specific results. "Let's tell the states that in return for a welfare block grant, they must insure that children in the poorest families -- say, those under 90 percent of the poverty level -- all have decent nutrition, housing and health care," Mr. Gephardt said.
Republicans said they were reconsidering their earlier proposals to cut off welfare and social service benefits for legal immigrants. But they said they might let states cut off such assistance.
Mr. Gephardt said he favored a tax cut for all workers earning less than $75,000 a year -- a simple credit, not tied to the number of children in a family or the amount of college tuition paid by the family. President Clinton and House Republicans have proposed a tax credit of $500 for each child. In addition, Mr. Clinton has proposed a tax deduction up to $10,000 a year for amounts spent by a taxpayer on college tuition.
Mr. Gephardt said House Democrats were working on proposals for a "flatter tax," with fewer tax breaks and fewer tax brackets. He said he had concluded that efforts to achieve social policy goals through tax laws had largely failed.
"I don't think you can micromanage society through the tax code," he said.

HEADLINE: Murray N. Rothbard, Economist And Free-Market Exponent, 68

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

 BODY:
Murray N. Rothbard, an economist and social philosopher who fiercely defended individual freedom against government intervention, died on Saturday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. A resident of Manhattan, he was 68.
The cause was a heart attack, said a friend, Lew Rockwell. 
 Mr. Rothbard, who was born in New York City, received his Ph.D. in economics from Columbia University in 1956. From 1963 to 1985, he taught at New York Polytechnic Institute in Brooklyn.
Mr. Rothbard was the author of some two dozen books and many articles on economic theory. At the time of his death, he was a professor of economics at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, and vice president of academic affairs at the Ludwig von Mises Institute at Auburn University in Alabama.
The Ludwig von Mises Institute is named for an Austrian economist who fled the Nazis and became Mr. Rothbard's mentor. Mr. Rockwell, who is the head of the institute, called Mr. Rothbard "the founder of right-wing anarchism."
Mr. Rothbard's admirers consider "Man, Economy and State," a 1962 book whose thesis is that the free market is the extension of the natural order, to be one of his most influential works. But Mr. Rothbard probably caused bigger stirs with his free-flowing, often acerbic observations.
In his view, for instance, Khrushchev and Eisenhower were on equal moral footing because the actions of both had caused many deaths. And, as he wrote in opinion pieces, the wage and price controls imposed by President Richard M. Nixon in 1971 signaled that "fascism came to America," and that American farmers were not noble tillers of the soil but "businessmen, no more and no less, no more noble or wicked than other entrepreneurs."
Mr. Rothbard is survived by his wife of 41 years, JoAnn.

HEADLINE: NEW JAPAN ACCESS FOR WALL STREET

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
The United States and Japan reached a broad accord today to open a range of Japanese financial markets to foreign competition, allowing American investment firms for the first time to vie for the right to manage nearly a trillion dollars in Japanese pension funds.
The accord was reached just hours before Japan's first Socialist Prime Minister, Tomiichi Murayama, landed here for a meeting with President Clinton on Wednesday. 
 Wall Street brokerage houses and investment advisers have complained for years about a web of government regulations and corporate relationships that froze them out of the world's second-largest pool of pension funds. They greeted the accord with guarded optimism, questioning whether in practice they would get more than a narrow slice of the market. [Page D5.]
The last-minute agreement allows both Washington and Tokyo to avoid a repeat of the embarrassment that surrounded the last visit of a Japanese prime minister to Washington. That meeting in February resulted in a nasty disagreement and a breakdown in negotiations that lasted nearly eight months.
Clinton Administration officials hailed the financial services agreement today as further evidence that their high-pressure negotiating strategy has produced major changes. There have been agreements involving half a dozen industries, all except the one that probably means the most to the American economy -- autos and auto parts.
Japanese officials, in turn, expressed hope that the agreement would deflect the focus of the Wednesday meeting away from last year's record $60 billion trade gap between the United States and Japan. Their aim is to turn to the problem Japan most wants addressed at the session: finding a way to keep the 50th anniversary of the end of World War II in August from turning into an exercise in recrimination.
For Mr. Murayama, who is holding onto power by only a thread, the financial services accord is also a chance to show that he can manage a relationship with the United States, which, as a Socialist, he once denounced as harmful to Japan's interests.
For years American investment advisers and brokerage houses have cited Japan's restrictions on the management of pension funds as a prime example of regulations intended to keep foreigners, along with Japanese newcomers, out of a lucrative market.
Rules issued by the Japanese Finance Ministry, the most powerful organization in a bureaucracy that runs the economy largely unchallenged by politicians, allowed only trust banks and insurance companies to manage pension funds. While there are some foreign entries in both markets, they have been prohibited from managing the bulk of the funds.
The United States Treasury has estimated that foreign firms manage just 1 percent of the assets held by Japanese pension funds.
Under the accord reached today, Tokyo's regulations would be wiped away beginning later this year. In perhaps the biggest achievement, Japanese firms would be required for the first time to disclose details of how well their fund managers perform in handling pensions.
Until now, Japan's pension funds have gone to great lengths to obscure any measurement of their performance. If the numbers were made public, American companies have long contended, they would show that Japanese fund managers significantly underperform their foreign competitors.
"This is an area that U.S. firms are very good at, and it is a very dramatic opening," said Frank N. Newman, the Acting Treasury Secretary. He has been filling the post until action was taken on the nomination of Robert E. Rubin, whom the Senate confirmed tonight as the next Treasury Secretary.
Under the accord, American and other foreign firms would have unlimited rights to compete to manage the roughly $200 billion in public pension funds for Japanese government employees. They would also have expanded access to roughly $130 billion in new assets in the private pension market, but other parts of that market would remain off limits. There would be varying levels of access to specialized Japanese pension funds.
Japan also agreed to drop its requirement that foreign investment firms offer a wide range of services, a rule that effectively excluded the many American firms that specialize in limited product lines, like bonds or annuities.
The Japanese also won some concessions. At the insistence of the Finance Ministry, which jealously guards its control over Japan's largest financial institutions, foreign investment advisers will have to maintain some formal connection with a trust bank or an insurance firm. "It makes sure that the Finance Ministry is not cut out of the loop," one American official said today. "The old-line Japanese firms will still take their slice."
Treasury officials said they could not estimate the extent of the revenues American firms could expect or how much of the market they were likely to get. But they said Japan had agreed to a series of "benchmarks" -- an artful term used in trade negotiations to sidestep Japanese complaints that Washington wants to manage trade to guarantee a certain market share for American firms. The benchmarks are supposed to measure how much the fund-management market has been opened to competition.
But penetrating that market will still be an enormous task. Many of the pension funds are managed by Japanese banks and insurance companies with strong ties to companies and government agencies that control the pension pools. Those ties, called keiretsu relationships, have often proved practically impossible to unknot, even after the conclusion of government-to-government agreements.
A senior Treasury official, briefing reporters today on the condition he not be identified, said Washington had an explicit right to withdraw privileges from Japanese financial institutions operating in the United States if the agreement was not fulfilled.
"It is our experience, though," the official said, "that Japan has always lived up fully to its commitments in the financial services arena."
