HEADLINE: Early Gains in Stocks Pared in Late Trading

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market rallied early in heavy trading yesterday only to retreat for just a small gain at the end of the session, despite a Government report indicating scant inflation at the wholesale level.
An inflation-is-coming comment from a Federal Reserve official helped depress stocks, as did the continuing turmoil in Mexico, whose troubles spread to depress markets throughout Latin America, including those of Brazil and Chile. 
 The uncertainty of the market was reflected in the stocks of the New York Stock Exchange. The number of advancing stocks exactly equaled the number of declining stocks at 1,145 against 1,145.
But the American stock market may rally in earnest today, if the Consumer Price Index, scheduled for release this morning, also indicates scant inflation. Moreover, Latin America's troubles may spell good news for American stocks and bonds, analysts said.
"Tomorrow we could see the market rally as fresh money comes in from the stocks and bonds being sold in the emerging markets," especially Latin America, said Bill Allyn, director of listed equities trading at Jefferies & Company.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 5.39 points, to 3,866.74, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 0.85 point, to 461.68. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 4.43 points, to 756.52.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was above normal, with 351.3 million shares changing hands, about 21 percent above last year's daily average of 290 million shares.
The big news of the day was the Labor Department's report of a 1.7 percent increase in the December Producer Price Index, in line with analysts' expectations and relatively modest, given the strength of the economy in the fourth quarter. Prices for tobacco, beef and gasoline even fell.
The leading stock indexes climbed steadily until 1:30 P.M. or so, when Lawrence B. Lindsey, a Fed governor, said in a speech in Washington that the outlook for wholesale inflation in 1995 was "not as favorable" as that of 1994. He also said that the job-creation rate of the last two months, when nearly three-quarters of a million jobs were filled, could not be sustained "for an extended period."
Meanwhile, the other big news of the day -- the turmoil over the peso -- battered Latin American stocks traded in the United States. Telefonos de Mexico, the most active stock yesterday at 16.6 million shares, set another 52-week low of 32 1/2 before closing at 33 3/8, down 3 1/8. The shares of Grupo Televisa of Mexico, a broadcasting company, also set a 52-week low of 21 3/8 before closing at 21 3/4, down 3 3/8. And Compania de Telefonos de Chile also established a year's low of 70 before closing at 70 5/8, down 5 7/8.
Motorola, the wireless-telephone and semiconductor company, set a 52-week high of 63 before closing at 61 3/4, up 2 7/8. It reported after the market closed Monday that fourth-quarter profit had risen more than 50 percent over the quarter a year ago. Texas Instruments, another semiconductor company, also rose sharply. Its shares closed at 75 1/4, up 3 5/8.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.11 point, to 251.69, and the American Stock Exchange market value index rose 0.32 point, to 434.49.

HEADLINE: Bonds Gain on Modest Inflation Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday, aided by a Government report that producer inflation rose only modestly last year and by a firming of the dollar in world currency markets.
The price of the 30-year benchmark issue rose 6/32 of a percentage point, to 95 27/32 , for a yield of 7.86 percent, down from 7.88 percent on Monday. Bill rates declined sharply, with a three-month bill off by nine basis points, to 5.73 percent, and a one-year bill down five basis points, to 6.73 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. 
 Doug Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst for Technical Data in Boston, said the market's positive response yesterday was more widely felt in the shorter maturities, where he believed the real buying was going on. "I suspect the buying was tied to the producer price report, which showed declining price pressures," Mr. Burtnick said. "But than we still have the consumer price data due Wednesday."
The Labor Department said its Producer Price Index rose just two-tenths of 1 percent overall in December and two-tenths of 1 percent for the so-called core rate, which excludes food and energy prices. For all of 1994, producer prices were up just 1.7 percent.
The market consensus for today's Consumer Price Index is an increase of three-tenths of 1 percent over all and in the core rate.
For some market participants, yesterday's soft inflation data suggested that the Federal Reserve may decide to raise short-term interest rates only half of a percentage point at its Federal Open Market Committee meeting Jan. 31 and Feb. 1.
Some traders said that the buying of Treasury bills was probably helped by the plunge in the Mexican stock market over the last two days. Some of the investors fleeing that stock market may have put their money into United States Government securities, and more specifically the bills market.
"Investors and traders are looking more towards the plain vanilla type markets, like Treasury securities," Mr. Burtnick said.
While yesterday's trading could be interpreted as somewhat positive for bonds, he cautioned that there were still plenty of additional economic data due soon that could sour the market, including today's consumer price report.
While the producer price data for December indicated that finished-goods inflation remained subdued, the core rates at the intermediate and crude levels of production suggested that there could be inflationary pressures in the pipeline, according to Elliott Platt, director of economic research at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases;
Fears the Safety Net for Poor Is Fraying

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
As politicians engage in a vociferous battle over welfare reform, others are airing their opinions in a subtler fashion. In letters to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, dozens of donors have criticized plans to cut government funding for social service programs. Fearing that the nation's safety net for the poor is fraying, many have increased their gifts to the fund.
"We have doubled our contribution this year because it seems the neediest ranks may swell, judging by the harsh rhetoric of some politicians," wrote Jim and Jackie Perry of Wilton, Conn., who sent $200. "With all the talk of reducing the budget deficit, it seems that those who need help the most may be the hardest hit by cuts in funding for shelters, soup kitchens, counseling and job training." 
 When she sent $100 to Neediest Cases instead of her usual $50, Isabel Andrews enclosed a terse note of explanation.
"Because of the increasing calls for help this year and because of all those 'lean and mean' mouthings of pompous government prigs, I am doubling my contribution to the fund this year," wrote Miss Andrews, who lives in Massapequa, L.I. "Should I win the lottery, I will share it with you."
Since the early years of this century, the Neediest Cases Fund has helped thousands of people lift themselves out of poverty. Although the campaign has raised slightly more money than last year at this time, there have been fewer donors, indicating that many New Yorkers are still feeling the aftereffects of the recession. As of last Friday, 7,221 individuals and foundations had contributed to the fund, compared with 7,897 last Jan. 7. This year's campaign will end Feb. 28.
Many Neediest Cases donors have expressed frustration with the House Republicans' "Contract With America," especially its proposal to place impoverished children in orphanages.
"Please earmark the enclosed check for a family in danger of disintegration," wrote Howard and Phyllis Berk of Manhattan, who sent $200. "Perhaps it will help keep a child with his or her parents instead of headed for an institution (read 'orphanage')."
"Too often, the answer to making New York's streets safe and hospitable is to clean them up by locking people up in prisons and orphanages," Mr. and Mrs. Perry wrote.
Even at a time when many middle-class families are struggling, the threat of budget cuts has only intensified their sense of social responsibility. In a letter he sent with his 30th annual donation, R. Gnanadesikan pondered why his urge to contribute was stronger than ever this year.
"The perception of political leaders these days seems to have a harsh edge toward the less fortunate in society, and there is an unseemly competition on seeing who can come up with the meanest solutions to long-standing problems," wrote Mr. Gnanadesikan, who lives in Chatham, N.J., and sent $150. "Thank you for reminding us to the contrary that all of us, the more and the less fortunate, are inextricably bound together."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Traders' Flight to the Mark Further Weakens the Dollar

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against many leading currencies yesterday, hurt as investors continued to flee the Spanish peseta and Italian lira for the safety of the German mark.
"The dollar got caught in the crossfire of mark-buying for peripheral European currencies," said Tom Hoge, corporate currency trader for the Bank of New York. "While that's going on, it's tough for the dollar to gain any headway against the mark." 
 The peseta dropped to a record low against the mark amid worry that the Cabinet of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez might fall. Mr. Gonzalez has vigorously denied accusations of Government involvement with antiterorist death squads aimed at Basque separatists.
The lira also dropped to a record low against the mark. Political uncertainty in Italy has intensified since Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi resigned on Dec. 22.
The Portuguese escudo fell along with the peseta. The Portuguese and Spanish economies are closely linked by trade, and their currencies often track one another.
To sell these less actively traded currencies against the mark, traders must sometimes sell them first against dollars and then sell the dollars for marks. That circuitous transaction weakens the dollar against the mark.
Yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.5292 marks, its lowest level since Nov. 11, before recovering later in New York. It ended the day at 1.5325 marks, down from 1.5375 marks on Monday.
The dollar rose to 100.09 Japanese yen from 99.91 yen. It got some support after Japan agreed to allow American brokerage houses and investment advisers to compete for business from Japanese pension funds, said Jeffrey Yu of Sanwa Bank in New York.
The peseta's weakness prompted speculation that the currency might have to be devalued within the exchange rate mechanism of the European Monetary System. The system was created to keep eight European currencies trading in a range. Members' central banks are required to buy and sell their currencies to keep them within those prescribed bands.
In other trading, the Canadian dollar fell yesterday to an eight-year low of 70.69 United States cents, amid concern that the Canadian central bank had not raised short-term interest rates sufficiently to compete with rising rates in the United States. In New York, the Canadian dollar settled at 70.91 United States cents, down from 70.96 cents on Monday.
The pound slipped to $1.5620 from $1.5640. The dollar fell to 1.2825 Swiss francs, from 1.2840 on Monday.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Deadline Passes But Players Get New Offer

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE 

 BODY:
The deadline was dead, but the possibility of a hockey season was still alive last night when the National Hockey League offered yet another "final" collective bargaining proposal to its locked-out players' union. Only one issue -- the age when veterans would be eligible for free agency -- divided the sides, and only two years of it were in dispute.
The proposal came after two days of intense negotiations and two conference calls among divided and emotional team owners. Gary Bettman, the N.H.L. commissioner, presented the revised offer to Bob Goodenow, executive director of the N.H.L. Players Association, at a meeting in Manhattan. 
 Goodenow and other union bargainers took the document back to their hotel rooms and were expected to study it overnight, consult with the rest of their bargaining committee by telephone to Toronto in the morning and then respond to Bettman.
Although some executives around the league implied that the proposal was a take-it-or-leave-it ultimatum, this wasn't made explicit in a statement issued by Arthur Pincus, a league spokesman.
"Gary Bettman was directed to present a revised proposal to the N.H.L. Players Association and to effectuate the cancellation of the 1994-95 season if a new collective bargaining agreement is not reached promptly," Pincus said.
Pincus didn't make clear if this meant that a new deadline had been established or if the revised proposal left room for further compromise. Last Saturday, when offering another proposal with somewhat different details -- which he also called "final" -- Bettman had said the remainder of the season would be canceled if there were no agreement by noon yesterday. But that deadline passed with negotiations in progress.
It would appear that the union is left with three options:
(1) Accept the deal as written
(2) Suggest another meeting and another compromise
(3) Reject the proposal, head back to Toronto, and see if Bettman and the owners are willing to call off the season over the free-agency differences.
Another question, for examination in the future, is Bettman's relationship with his employers after almost two years in the job. His stated goal was to obtain a salary cap or a payroll tax or some other system linking payrolls to revenues.
The players steadfastly fought against that, calling it a deal breaker, and the league ultimately dropped this concept from the negotiations. Although Bettman's aggressive tactics won numerous, significant concessions to establish a drag on salary inflation, it would appear from recent owner votes, and the heated debates that accompanied them, that many teams aren't happy with the deal he has fashioned.
During yesterday's first conference call, Bettman presented the owners with what he and Goodenow thought was the basis for a settlement. But the owners, some often angry during the two-hour session, rejected the plan and several of them criticized Bettman.
Most vocal among them was Abe Pollin of Washington. Also finding fault with the terms were Bill Wirtz of Chicago, Mike Ilitch of Detroit and the owners of Canadian teams that play in smaller cities.
Several people who heard the call, but who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said they were embarrassed for Bettman, and one suggested that such treatment of a chief executive might lead the commissioner to re-consider remaining in his current position.
As for the free-agency issue, the latest owner offer, approved by a 17-9 vote during yesterday's second conference call, mandates that players will become unfettered free agents at the age of 32 for the first three years of the contract and at the age of 31 for the second three years of the contract. In addition, the proposal would allow either side to re-open the contract in either 1997 or 1998.
Earlier in the day, Bettman had taken a slightly different proposal to the owners, one that called for free agency to begin at age 32 in the first year of the contract and at age 31 for the remaining five years. The owners voted that down by a 14-12 vote.
Over this proposal, the owners and their top executives listened and debated, sometimes angrily, for about two hours. After getting revision suggestions by fax machine, Bettman then composed the latest offer to end the lockout, which has delayed the start of the season since Oct. 1.
The free-agency provision was to be the only significant gain for the union in a struggle during which the owners have demanded and received many concessions over the previous agreement, particularly in the areas of entry-level salary caps, harsher arbitration rules and weakened free-agency opportunities for most players. Some union members feel that, in view of these givebacks, they deserve freedom in the marketplace after more than a decade of service to a team. The owners and Bettman have said they need a drag on salary inflation to avoid losing money.
Other major differences appeared to be settled.
The owners wanted a new right to walk away from two arbitration awards per team each year. The players had offered one such option. The two sides apparently compromised on three per team over two years. Players in this category will become free agents, but may have the right to rejoin their former teams at a predetermined rate of pay that is less than the arbitration award.
As for the rookie salary cap formula, the players wanted a maximum of $900,000, applied to any round of the draft. The owners demanded $825,000 for the first round and lesser rates for lower rounds. The compromise appeared to be at $850,000, with no difference between rounds.
It is also thought that the two sides had reached a compromise on the age of the entry draft. The players wanted age 18, as has been the case for many years. The owners wanted age 20; the settlement was at age 19, with 18-year-olds having the option to volunteer.
These provisions, and all the others, are tentative and could change with any change in the age for veteran free agency. It is all part of a package, as Bettman frequently said, with each piece linked with the others. The players also asked for retroactive pay to replace some wages lost when locked out; it wasn't known if they were able to gain any of this.
Along with Chicago, Detroit and Washington, much of the opposition to veteran free agency was thought to be from teams in small markets in Canada. Owners such as Marcel Aubut of Quebec and Peter Pocklington in Edmonton have said the recent league proposals don't do enough to help them compete with teams from larger cities and those who deal in more valuable American dollars. It's a plea that gets lukewarm support from players, especially in larger markets.
Mike Richter, the goalie for the Stanley Cup champion Rangers, said, "I guess if we can have some of the larger teams pay for the mistakes or shortcomings of the smaller teams and still come up with a deal, I guess that's what we're aiming for now."
The Canadian teams have said they fear that free-agency opportunities will encourage players to leave small markets in Canada for teams in bigger cities in the United States.

HEADLINE: Clinic Violence Sets Off Push For Wider Abortion Training

BYLINE: By SUSAN GILBERT 

 BODY:
THE anti-abortion violence that has helped cause a critical decline in the number of places where women can go to end unwanted pregnancies has also inspired a ground swell of activism among doctors and medical students intent on reversing the trend.
"We have been making progress," said Dr. Wendy Chavkin, editor of The Journal of the American Women's Medical Association, which devoted its December issue to the shortage of doctors willing to provide abortions. "The most recent shootings have not weakened our resolve." 
 Efforts are being made on several fronts to teach more doctors how to perform abortions. In 1993, Planned Parenthood of New York City started a training program for residents and practicing doctors. Using that program, six New York City hospitals that had not offered abortion instruction to residents began doing so within the last year or two: Lenox Hill Hospital, Long Island Jewish Medical Center, New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, Methodist Hospital of Brooklyn, New York Downtown Hospital and Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. Planned Parenthood of New York City has helped 15 clinics around the country start similar programs.
In addition, the American College of Graduate Medical Education, the organization that sets requirements for residency programs, is scheduled to vote next month on a proposal to make abortion training mandatory for residents in obstetrics and gynecology. And more medical schools are for the first time offering courses on abortion, primarily because students have demanded them through a new national organization called Medical Students for Choice. Among these medical schools are Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons in New York, the University of Pennsylvania Medical School in Philadelphia and the University of California at San Francisco Medical School.
To be sure, these efforts constitute an uphill battle. The number of doctors available to perform abortions has fallen by 8 percent since 1988 and the percentage of obstetric and gynecology residency programs in this country that require abortion training has declined to 12 percent, half what it was in 1985, according to the Alan Guttmacher Institute, a nonprofit group that does research on reproductive issues. Eighty-four percent of counties in the United States now have no doctor who performs abortions.
"The activism against abortion providers has made doctors who were trained to perform abortion afraid to continue doing so, and it is the reason why many residency programs don't offer abortion training," said Dr. Robert H. Gifford, assistant dean for education and student affairs at Yale University School of Medicine, one of the few medical schools that offer elective courses on abortion and that require clinical instruction for obstetrics and gynecology residents.
Another reason for the declining number of residency programs that require abortion training is that fewer hospitals are performing abortions, and hospitals are where most residency programs are based. The Guttmacher Institute found that hospitals, which provided more than half of all abortions in 1973, accounted for just 7 percent of abortions in 1992. Although many hospitals no longer offer abortions because of economic reasons (they have trouble competing with abortion clinics for patients because their costs are much higher) political pressure has played at least as big a role, Dr. Gifford said.
"Fewer hospitals provide abortion because influential donors who oppose abortion won't give money if they do," he said. The result of the provider shortage that all these factors have created is that "the quality of care women get is being compromised," he said.
It is that realization that has attracted residents to the Planned Parenthood training initiative. (Practicing physicians can also enroll on their own.) Thirty-three doctors, mostly from the six New York hospitals, have completed the five-week program and 23 others are going through it now. Each participant spends 8 to 10 days at a Planned Parenthood clinic in Manhattan, Brooklyn or the Bronx attending lectures, observing and assisting with abortions and, after the first weeks, performing the procedures.
"We're anxious to learn how to do this," said a third-year obstetric and gynecology resident from New York Downtown Hospital who completed the program last month but would not give her name because of her fear of violence. "Most of the ob-gyn residents I know plan to perform abortions," she said.
Dr. Charles Lipton, a former Army surgeon, came out of retirement last year to take the Planned Parenthood course because of a memory from the days before abortion became legal. "When I was a resident at the Hahnemann University ob-gyn clinic in 1962, a 13-year-old girl who had been raped came in wanting an abortion," he said. "When she was told she couldn't have one, she went home and committed suicide.
"My decision to get in touch with Planned Parenthood for abortion training was in response to the murders of Dr. Gunn and Dr. Britton," he said, referring to the doctors who worked at abortion clinics in Pensacola, Fla. "I want to go on the road and perform abortions in needy areas."
The murder of Dr. David Gunn nearly two years ago was one of two events that gave rise to Medical Students for Choice, a national student group that has made inroads for increased abortion instruction at every level of medical education. The other event was an anti-abortion mailing that, at about the time of Dr. Gunn's murder, went to the homes of one-third of medical students around the country. The mailing, seemingly intended to intimidate the students, was a 12-page comic-book-style publication of gruesome cartoons depicting abortionists. It came from a group called Life Dynamics Inc. in Texas.
Many students were frightened because the anti-abortion group knew where they lived, said Jody Steinauer, a third-year medical student at the University of California at San Francisco who helped found Medical Students for Choice. "But most students, even the pro-lifers I know, were mainly offended," she said. "Dr. Gunn's murder and this mailing made us wake up. They made us realize that we're potential abortion providers, but we don't have enough education on abortion in medical school to make a choice on whether we want to be providers or not."
Courses on abortion have always been scarce at medical schools. But the group, which has members from 105 of the country's 126 medical schools, has persuaded several schools to incorporate abortion instruction in their curriculums.
The University of Pennsylvania Medical School, for example, has an elective course on clinical abortion for fourth-year medical students. The University of California at San Francisco Medical School gives third-year medical students the option of watching abortions and abortion counseling. Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons offers a lecture on the history and practice of abortion for third-year students. Thomas Jefferson Medical College has invited doctors who perform abortions to speak to the students about what they do and why they do it.
"My generation has no consciousness of what things were like before abortion was legal -- hospital floors full of women with perforated uteruses because of botched abortions," said Eliza Byers, a second-year student at the Jefferson medical school who is a member of Students for Choice. "A lot of medical students today don't want to do abortions because doctors are getting shot. They think of doctors who do abortions not as doctors but as abortionists. They think abortion is for promiscuous girls. We're trying to destigmatize abortion."
A major step in that direction that is under consideration would be a requirement that all obstetric and gynecology residents learn how to do abortions, unless they have religious or moral objections. "It's being considered because of a perception that abortion is being overlooked by obstetricians and gynecologists," said Dr. Paul O'Connor, executive secretary of the residency review committee of American College of Graduate Medical Education. "Medical Students for Choice and the American College of Obstetricians are behind it. It's likely to be passed."
Dr. Gifford of Yale said the requirement would ultimately help protect doctors and patients from violence. "The political reality is that abortion is isolated, and that makes providers easy targets," he said. "If abortion could be more a part of obstetrical practice and not isolated into abortion clinics, we'd be a lot better off."

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
To Earn Subsidies, Must Art Be Useful? Must It Be Sweet?

BYLINE: By PAUL GOLDBERGER 

 BODY:
"All art is quite useless," wrote Oscar Wilde, but of course he never encountered the National Endowment for the Arts, which is predicated on the premise that the arts are the most useful thing in the world. They solve social problems, they keep people happy, they make communities shine with enthusiasm and, best of all, they inject a shot of money into sagging economies. The arts establishment in the United States operates on a nearly messianic certainty that the arts are not merely good, but good for you.
Is it really so? Surely the economic impact of the arts is real. The explosion of interest in culture in the United States over the last generation has turned the arts into a potent industry. Study after study shows the multiplier effect of arts dollars, sowing prosperity all through the economy. The Metropolitan Museum is now the most popular tourist attraction in New York, where big exhibitions fill not only its own coffers but also those of hotels and restaurants. People clamor to get seats for major events at Lincoln Center and Carnegie Hall. The arts are for everyone, and everyone seems to be for the arts. 
 Except, of course, on Capitol Hill, where the new Republican majority, building on years of discomfort among conservatives about Federal support of the arts, seems increasingly hostile to keeping the National Endowment in business. The endowment's entire appropriation is only $167 million, but no $167 million anywhere in the entire Federal budget is debated with such intensity. To the endowment's opponents, this comparatively tiny sum of money is a vast boondoggle, a pork barrel for the cultural elite. To the endowment's supporters, it is anything but a gift to the elite; it is money that spreads the pleasures of art around and assures that the experience of culture will be accessible to all.
The situation is rife with paradoxes, not the least of which is the way in which the arts establishment has tried to save its skin by portraying art as sweet and lovable, leaving to the endowment's opponents a much more realistic view of art as challenging and difficult. Both sides claim to represent the democratic ideal, which is why $167 million, which is a mere fly speck in the Federal budget, is given such overwhelming symbolic importance by both sides. The endowment's minuscule budget, less than half of what it costs to keep Lincoln Center going for a year, less than a quarter of what the city of Berlin spends on arts subsidies annually for a population that is less than 2 percent of that of the whole United States, is often portrayed as the crucible for the future of the arts in this country.
End the endowment and we will stop the free ride for unpopular artists and get back to the good kind of art that pays for itself, goes the conservative argument. We end the endowment at our peril, retorts the other side; without it, the arts will be finished and we will become a nation of philistines.
The likelihood is that the sky will neither fall nor rise if the endowment's modest appropriation disappears. Art will go on, as it always has. But if the endowment is sharply cut or eliminated altogether, the nation will be sending an important signal about its attitude toward culture, which is that it expects it to play by the rules most other things do, and pay for itself.
It sounds, on the surface, as if it couldn't be more fair. Why shouldn't culture do what other things do, and take care of itself? The only problem is that it doesn't work, as history proves. Culture has never been able to support itself. There is a reason that the popes and the Medicis hired Michelangelo, that royalty paid Mozart to write concertos, that the histories of creativity and of patronage are intimately intertwined. The marketplace has never been a testing ground for artistic validity; history shows few correlations between what is popular enough to pay for itself and what is good enough to last.
Subsidizing art runs against the grain of American independence, the tradition of self-reliance that seems so often to tie into populism. But that very populist instinct often contradicts what art strives to do, which is not to coddle but to challenge. Great art is rarely created with popularity in mind, and when it manages to achieve tremendous appeal, it is often nothing more than a miraculous accident.
Surely the saddest aspect of this moment is the way in which the arts establishment, to fight the political opposition it faces, has been forced to retreat into a position of defending the popularity of art and denying its challenge. Jane Alexander, the earnest and determined chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Arts, has labored mightily to convince Congress and the voters that the endowment is spreading sweetness and light throughout the country, that art is bringing happiness to all who are touched by endowment grants.
But the Republicans are not so quick to buy this, and maybe they are right. They know the arts at their most vital are something other than sugar-coated candy. The arts often undermine, they often seek to be subversive to established orders, and the opposition to the endowment wants to protect the country from this evil, or at least make sure that government funds play no part in propagating it. Picasso may be easy to swallow now, but he wasn't in 1910. Why should our tax dollars support the next crazy radical to come down the pike?
The ultimate paradox is that now, at a time when public interest in the arts is greater than ever, the arts establishment has come to promote what is fundamentally an anti-intellectual view of culture, while the right-wing opposition operates from a more sophisticated view. The opponents of the endowment who complain loudly about the homoerotic photographs of Robert Mapplethorpe or the urine-drenched crucifix of Andres Serrano, hostile though they may be to any esthetic messages in these works, are actually more accepting of the notion that art consists of ideas and not merely pretty pictures, that it is more than entertainment and that it often seeks to challenge society's standards.
The arts establishment, engaged in the act of trying to protect the economic interests of cultural organizations and institutions that depend on masses of people attending, has increasingly been blurring the line between art and entertainment. These supporters of the arts endowment increasingly see culture in terms of what is consumed, not in terms of what is created. How else to protect their turf? Yet in doing so, they abandon to the other side the very view of art that they should be holding most dear, a recognition of art as creativity and challenge.
Today, as advocates attempt to save the endowment by portraying art as democratic, accessible and unthreatening, it is left to their opponents to see it in terms of creativity, and to admit the tremendous, terrifying power that art at its most intense can possess.

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:

HEADLINE: Governor Whitman at Year One

 BODY:
Christine Todd Whitman's first year as Governor of New Jersey has been marked by tax reduction and national celebrity. With her fellow Republicans in control of both houses of the Legislature, she had no trouble starting the tax cuts she promised. With her fresh appeal, she campaigned far and wide for Republican Congressional candidates last fall and got herself far-and-widely mentioned as potential for "national office."
On those counts she had a good year, but she has yet to undertake many initiatives that would entail serious controversy. She has, in large part, ducked the hard work of cutting popular programs and relied too much on one-shot budget gimmicks to pay for popular tax cuts. 
 Whitman-watchers will recall that she handled her first crisis deftly when her campaign manager, Ed Rollins, boasted about -- but later denied -- lavishing cash on black churches to discourage get-out-the-vote efforts for Gov. Jim Florio. Mrs. Whitman immediately denounced Mr. Rollins and reached out to the offended black clergy.
Powerful personal instincts have also served her well on the abortion issue. A believer that women have the right to choose, she has publicly implored her party to drop its anti-abortion stance, and continues to do so.
National economic recovery has helped her. As she noted in her State of the State address yesterday, New Jersey is growing faster than its big neighbors. Tax cuts may well have contributed to the faster growth, as she contends; so presumably have her efforts to accommodate private industry.
Her tax pledge remains the centerpiece of her agenda -- 30 percent reduction in the state's personal income tax in three years. Of that, 15 percent is already in place, and she is expected to propose an additional 5 or 10 percent cut in her fiscal 1996 budget on Jan. 23. But keeping the budget balanced while cutting state revenue takes imagination.
A large part of the first year's reduction was covered by reducing contributions to public pension funds and other one-shot maneuvers. Naturally, she avoids proposing new taxes, but yesterday she said she wants to keep an old one that is expiring -- a temporary surcharge on motor vehicle registrations. Governor Florio had proposed repealing it early, because it was not needed. Now Governor Whitman, who made her name and won her office fighting for lower taxes, proposes not reducing this one.
On spending, she has basically held the line, at roughly $15 billion, but hard cuts and layoffs are expected now. Democrats try to attribute local property tax increases to her tightness with state aid, but there is no clear proof of a link. Rather, she rates credit for dispatching state experts to help local governments control their own budgets.
Mrs. Whitman's first year was smooth. But she has pledged to attack failing schools, stagnant cities, poverty and AIDS while shrinking taxes and government. Tougher battles lie ahead.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Japan Fatigue

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN; Bob Herbert is on vacation.

DATELINE: HONG KONG

 BODY:
Here is a little-known fact for you: In the 1930's, three-quarters of the cars in Japan were Fords. World War II and 50 years of Japanese protectionism reduced that to zero, but Ford is now spearheading a resurgence of U.S. car sales in Japan. Ford boosted its Japan sales by 198 percent this year by improving quality, acquiring 300 showrooms, letting Japanese auto writers drive across America in a Taurus and even sponsoring the Hiroshima professional soccer team, which won the national championship with the Ford logo on its jerseys. Last year Ford sold out its allotment of Mustangs for Japan in two months.
This is not a Ford commercial. But the Ford example is worth highlighting because it comes at a time when so many other U.S. businesses are giving up on Japan, saying that it is just too expensive and aggravating to keep trying to break into the closed Japanese market. Better, they argue, to focus sales -- and U.S. trade diplomacy -- on more open emerging markets in Indonesia, Malaysia, China and India. They call this "Japan Fatigue," and it is a virus that has infected large segments of the U.S. business community and Government. 
 Nothing could be more wrongheaded, and President Clinton should use his meeting today with Japan's Prime Minister, Tomiichi Murayama, to make clear that he too hasn't caught the dreaded disease. The Japanese quietly believe they have worn the Clinton team down. Here's why Mr. Clinton should tell them they are wrong:
First, commerce is like tennis. If you don't play with better players you never get better yourself. If American designers and salesmen are not in Japan following Japanese product research and development and competing against the best Japanese companies for some of the world's most sophisticated consumers, they will never beat their Japanese competitors in China, India or Indonesia either. "If Ford can win in Japan, Ford can win against Japanese cars in the U.S., Europe and Asia," says Konen Suzuki, the renegade Toyota executive who now heads Ford Japan and tools around Tokyo in his white Mustang.
Second, if a U.S. company, like Ford, cedes the huge Japanese market to Toyota, that means Toyota can safely reap all sorts of profits at home, amass a financial war chest, then use that to cut prices on what it sells abroad and to outspend others for new plants in Thailand or China to tie up those markets as well.
Third, there is a lot of ambivalence in the U.S. public today about the merits of free trade. There is no way any administration can maintain the fragile consensus for free trade if Japan, the world's second-largest economy, continues to get away with murder -- using hidden quotas, opaque regulations and business cartels to block U.S. imports.
Fourth, the Japanese claim that Ford's success proves what they have been saying all along -- that if U.S. companies just came up with better products and more effort they could break into Japan. That's only half true. Yes, the products and effort have to be there, but if it were not for U.S. Government pressure on Tokyo to squeeze its car dealers to give more showroom space to U.S. autos, Ford never would have broken in there, says Mr. Suzuki. Economists complain that such government pressure to open markets constitutes "managed trade." You bet it does. In the managed Japanese economy you are either managed in or managed out. (Ford's Japan sales, despite its upsurge, are still less than 1 percent of the Japanese market.)
Finally, the tide of history in Japan is turning our way. I went to the new Toys "R" Us superstore outside Tokyo. It was packed with holiday shoppers hauling away bargains while the Muzak played Motown hits. Thanks to their recession, Japanese consumers are eager to be Kmart shoppers. They want the sort of U.S.-style retail competition and discounting they have never had. This is no time to turn away from this market. You don't get better playing tennis with Malaysia; you don't get rich either. It would be a shame if the only thing produced by 20 years of Sisyphean U.S. trade policy toward Japan was to open the Japanese market for Korean contractors, German auto makers, French farmers and Japanese discounters.

HEADLINE: Israelis and Arabs Back Regional Bank

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's push for a regional development bank in the Middle East moved ahead today when Israel, Egypt, Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization jointly proposed to set it up..
At a meeting here, officials from more than 30 countries hailed the Israeli-Arab plan, saying it should go far toward overcoming opposition to the idea from the European Union and Saudi Arabia. 
 The diplomats say a regional bank is needed to finance major infrastructure projects like highways and water purification and to foster economic cooperation.
After a two-day meeting at the State Department, representatives from 39 countries and financial institutions agreed to set up a group to work out details for creating the bank. The group is also supposed to propose a separate institution to promote regional economic cooperation.
Joan Spero, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, said the Administration's goal was to win approval for such a bank at a high-level meeting scheduled for October in Amman, Jordan.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Urges New Agenda For Cities: Self-Reliance

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
Positioning himself for the nation's new Republican era, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday called for New York to become a model for how other cities can solve their own problems if freed from state and Federal mandates that tell them what services to provide.
In his second annual address to the City Council, Mr. Giuliani began to lay out the bare bones of what he called a "new urban agenda" of self-reliance that he is expected to describe further at Yale University next week. Aides said the Yale address would be the first of many national appearances by the Mayor devoted to urban affairs. 
 While just months ago Mr. Giuliani had crossed party lines to support Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, an icon of Democratic liberalism, and spoken skeptically of the Republican House leadership's "Contract With America," the Mayor yesterday tried to move back into his party's fold. He called the Republican ascendancy in Washington and Albany an opportunity to restructure city government.
"We are asking of New York City precisely what we are asking of people on welfare and everyone else in the city: self-reliance," Mr. Giuliani said. "The old agenda was based on looking to others to solve our problems -- look to Albany, look to Washington, someone will come along and bail us out. The new urban agenda should declare that we can solve our own problems, without direction from state or Federal authorities."
Speaking in the vast City Council chamber, Mr. Giuliani devoted much of the address to a summary of his achievements in his first year in office, pointing to reduced crime and the first decline in city spending in 16 years. He said he had defied the "conventional wisdom" that he would not succeed.
Often accused by critics of being too combative, Mr. Giuliani also pledged to cooperate more with the City Council as he draws up a plan in the coming month to close a gap of $500 million or more in the current budget. Through much of 1994, the Mayor and the Council clashed over his efforts to cut billions from the budget, a fight that eventually wound up in court.
Instead of presenting the Council with a "fait accompli," Mr. Giuliani said to the audience full of Council members that the plan would be negotiated in advance so it "incorporates your views, your ideas, your thinking, and hopefully we can agree completely."
Mr. Giuliani's olive branch to the City Council was welcomed by Speaker Peter F. Vallone. Yet the Democrat also expressed some caution, since the speech came a day after the Mayor's most recent confrontation with the City Council -- over the issue of removing fire boxes on city streets.
On Tuesday, Fire Commissioner Howard Safir said the administration would begin dismantling the city's fire boxes within days even as a Council committee approved a bill seeking to delay the plan for three months while Council members reviewed it.
Mr. Giuliani also singled out labor leaders and individual lawmakers for praise, among them several black officials -- Representative Charles B. Rangel, Councilwoman C. Virginia Fields and State Senator David A. Paterson -- with whom he had clashed in his first months in office.
Mr. Giuliani's call for self-reliance and a new urban agenda came toward the end of a 53-minute address that was interrupted by applause 30 times. But even as the Mayor urged New York to stand on its own he also put new packaging around an idea long espoused by Democrats -- that the city and its downstate suburbs send billions of dollars more in tax money to Albany and Washington than they receive in aid.
"It's time for New York City and cities across America to get rid of the stereotype that portrays us as a drain on the national economy," he said. "We are not." United States Senator Daniel P. Moynihan, a Democrat, has been making the same case for 18 years.
Yet rather than seek new aid, Mr. Giuliani instead put his focus on the elimination of Federal and state requirements that affect such major items as the amount the city must spend on the poor and how much money it must devote to schools.
He is expected to follow up today with a long list of Federal, state and court mandates that he wants removed or modified. It ranges from the state requirement that the city pick up half the non-Federal share of Medicaid, at a cost of $2.4 billion, to a state formula setting the minimum the city can spend on education, to a court order establishing the supply of toilet paper that must be kept in foster homes, according to a report prepared by the administration.
The Mayor gave few specific initiatives for the coming year in which the city, struggling with the worst fiscal problems since its brush with bankruptcy in the 1970's, again faces a $2 billion budget deficit.
Continuing his emphasis on fighting crime, Mr. Giuliani, a former Federal prosecutor, vowed an intensified effort to combat drugs, focused on drug buyers as well as dealers and on drug use among young people. He said drug abuse by youths was largely to blame for the increase of serious crime in schools by 15.5 percent in the 1993-94 school year over the previous year and around schools by 47.5 percent, even as citywide crime statistics declined drastically.
"So today, I would like to make it very plain to everyone listening, to buyers as well as sellers of drugs, that our policy will be to arrest and prosecute not only those who sell drugs, but also those who buy drugs because they create the demand that is helping to destroy the lives of other people," he said.
Police Commissioner William J. Bratton said later that drug fighting had been "the mantra for the past year" and that ways to expand the policy were still being developed.
Foreshadowing the expected centerpiece of his second budget, Mr. Giuliani said the city would need to cut $1 billion or more from welfare and health care spending on the poor. And he again asked for changes in how school system budgets and for a reduction of bureaucracy in the Board of Education.
"Let's face reality," he said. "New York City's public school system isn't working. That's not an accusation. It's a fact. I believe in facing facts, not pretending, particularly when the lives and education of our children are at stake."
Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines, who was recently reappointed by the Board of Education over Mr. Giuliani's objections, did not attend the speech.
The Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer; Manhattan's Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger; and Public Advocate Mark J. Green, Democrats who are considered possible challengers to the Mayor in 1997, each said Mr. Giuliani had spoken in generalities and not provided a full accounting of how he would lead the city out of its fiscal problems and at what cost to services.
"Here we're facing the greatest fiscal crisis and service crisis in at least 20 years; yet the Mayor appears largely interested in again touting crime data and trouncing the Board of Education bureaucracy," Mr. Green said. "It is an act of self-denial to talk up self-reliance on the same day the administration is quietly planning to close an estimated 10 day-care centers that service poor kids and working mothers who would otherwise find themselves on the welfare line."
Ms. Messinger said, "Noble sentiments and setting a tone and defining an image are important when you're giving the State of the City, but they're not sufficient." She said that even while the Mayor was defining education as a priority, Manhattan Community College was being forced by the city's budget problems to cut by 50 percent its incoming class for next year.

HEADLINE: Clinton Is Confident U.S. Trade Deficit With Japan Will Narrow

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
After two years of confrontational meetings with a succession of Japanese leaders, President Clinton changed his tone today, expressing confidence that his Administration's blitz of recent accords with Tokyo would soon bring down the United States' $60 billion trade deficit with Japan.
In its businesslike quickness and its low-key style, the meeting between Mr. Clinton and Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama, a 70-year old Socialist who abandoned many of his party's principles in a deal last summer that propelled him from obscurity to the Prime Minister's office, seemed to reflect the Administration's battle fatigue in its dealings with Tokyo. 
 Mr. Clinton's aides insist that he has lost none of his verve for pressing Japan for major reforms in its economy and major new openings of its markets. Today, they noted, he pressed Mr. Murayama for quick progress in talks over autos and auto parts, which make up more than 60 percent of the trade imbalance. On Tuesday, the two countries reached an agreement to partially open Japan's financial services markets to greater foreign participation.
In recent weeks, however, several officials close to the negotiations have acknowledged that the White House has lost any hope of speedy changes in Japanese economic policy. When Mr. Murayama's advance team submitted a draft communique last week that would be issued at the end of the meeting. American officials rejected it out of hand because it made no mention of trade or Japan's contribution to the building of nuclear power reactors in North Korea, part of the deal to dismantle the Communist country's nuclear weapons project. But rather than fight, they just decided to issue no communique at all.
Today Mr. Clinton steered far away from the kinds of comments he made two years and three prime ministers ago, when he told the first Japanese leader who visited him, Kiichi Miyazawa, that broad cooperation "can happen only if we make real progress on the trade deficit." Instead, he spoke of cooperation between the two nations that "no one could have dreamed of 50 years ago, or perhaps even 20 years ago."
Those were words the Japanese desperately wanted to hear, and it even mollified some Japanese diplomats who had complained privately that the 2-hour meeting, with no full press conference or big welcome, was a snub compared to the treatment of past prime ministers visiting here.

HEADLINE: Jobless Data Show Blacks Joining Economic Recovery

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Unlike other economic recoveries in which blacks were often left behind, the current upswing helped push the unemployment rate for blacks to below 10 percent last month for the first time in more than two decades.
"In the scramble for jobs in 1994, blacks were winners for the first time in many years," said Andrew Brimmer, a former Federal Reserve Bank governor who now runs a consulting concern in Washington. 
 Indeed, officials say the unemployment rate for black adults dropped faster in 1994 than it did for white adults and that black employment prospects appear better now than they were during the upswing of the late 1980's.
Even during the robust economic recovery of the late 1980's when the white unemployment rate was -- as it is now -- under 5 percent, black unemployment never dipped below 10 percent, and sometimes topped 12 percent.
"In the last 20 years there was a higher floor for black unemployment," said Everett Ehrlich, Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs. "It appears to have been around 11 percent. We've broken through that barrier conspicuously in this recovery."
Economists and other analysts of labor trends say they are uncertain whether the 9.8 percent unemployment figure for blacks in December -- as against the 4.8 percent overall rate for whites -- was an aberration or a sign of increased long-term job security for more African-Americans.
"I hope that it's a signal of a turn-around in the jobs prospects for African-Americans," said Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich. "Unfortunately the data are not altogether clear."
Even with the decline in the overall unemployment rate for African-Americans, the rate for black youths from 16 to 19 years of age is 34.6 percent -- as against 14.7 percent for white youths.
"You can celebrate the fact that it's below 10 percent," said Thomas J. Plewes, associate commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which publishes the jobless rate. "But both in terms of an unemployment rate that is twice as high for blacks and more than twice as high for young people, there is still a very long way to go."
Mr. Plewes noted that the unemployment rate merely measures the percentage of the labor force that has looked for a job in the four weeks before the monthly survey is taken. A more meaningful index, he said, is the employment population ratio, which measures what percentage of people at least 16 years old -- and not in jail or confined in some other way -- are working.
Using this measure, which includes those who are not actively looking for employment, 23.9 percent of black youths are working, as against 48.5 percent of white youngsters.
"What's going on is that young blacks are not getting a lot of exposure to labor market, still," Mr. Plewes said.
The news of the sharp decline in the black unemployment rate brought a muted response from some civil rights organizations. Cheered by the news of improvement of black employment gains, they stressed the large number of blacks who have simply dropped out of the labor market and are therefore not counted in the unemployment statistics.
"We're pleased by the report, but skeptical of its true significance," said Wade Henderson, legislative director of the N.A.A.C.P. "It only covers people who are actively in search of work. Many in the African-American community, having been frustrated by long periods of unemployment and an unreceptive -- and often hostile -- job market have been discouraged and are no longer actively seeking jobs."
Still, the black jobless rate was the lowest it has been since August 1974 when it reached 9.9 percent. And the drop below the 10 percent barrier represents a milestone for the economy as a whole and for African-Americans. Blacks traditionally have had the hardest time finding and keeping jobs and the improvement in the rate reflects the vigor of the economic recovery.
Harry Holzer, a professor of economics at Michigan State University, said, "It's been known for a long time that the best thing you can do to bring down the unemployment rate for blacks is to bring them down for everybody. If you believe that blacks are the last hired and first fired, then the tighter you can get a labor market, the more disproportionally good effect you will have on black unemployment."
One factor in the reduction in the black unemployment rate has been the revival of the manufacturing sector, Mr. Brimmer said. During the strong recovery years from 1985 to 1990 the economy saw a slight decrease in the number of manufacturing jobs, and from January 1989 to September 1993 more than 1.5 million manufacturing jobs disappeared.
But since a higher proportion of black workers are employed in manufacturing than are white workers, they benefited significantly from the 301,000 manufacturing jobs that were created in the last 16 months.
"In the 1990 recession, blacks lost jobs substantially because of the cutback in manufacturing, where they were heavily concentrated," Mr. Brimmer said. "When expansion started this year, black employment lagged for long time but in the last year they have made major gains."
Mr. Brimmer cautioned that the relatively rosy picture in black employment rates could turn dark this year if the economy slows down under the weight of higher interest rates. "This is a cyclical pattern," he said. "If we hit another recession and if the cutback in factory jobs is substantial, than black gains will erode. Whether these gains persist will depend entirely on whether a high rate of growth in the economy is maintained."

HEADLINE: Hanoi to Accept Refugees Now in Germany in Exchange for Aid

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BONN, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Germany said today that it would soon begin forcibly repatriating some of the 40,000 Vietnamese immigrants here illegally, and that Hanoi agreed to accept them by 2000 in exchange for increased trade and economic aid.
About 60,000 other Vietnamese whose status as refugees or immigrants has been recognized would not be affected, officials said. 
 The accord will eliminate a legacy of the cold war and enable Germany to compete more effectively with the United States and Japan in the emerging market economy in Vietnam, but official rejected criticism that the agreement sacrificed human rights for business aims.
"There are about 20,000 Vietnamese whose applications for asylum have been rejected, and these would be the first to be considered for repatriation," said Bernd Schmidbauer, who helped negotiate the agreement. "We assume there will be some Vietnamese citizens who will want to go back voluntarily, but we do not know exactly how many there will be."
Phan Huy Oanh, a Vietnamese refugee who has lived in Europe for 20 years, said, "Only a small percentage want to go back voluntarily."
Long delayed by Vietnam's refusal to guarantee that the returnees would be welcome, the agreement commits Germany to provide $130 million in aid over the next two years, part of it to help the refugees get a new start in Vietnam.
Bonn will also make available $65 million next year to underwrite risk insurance for German investment projects and exports to Vietnam. Daimler-Benz A.G., the automotive giant, said today that it was planning to build a $70 million bus factory in Ho Chi Minh City (formerly Saigon).
West Germany offered political asylum to thousands of Vietnamese during and after the Vietnam War, which ended with a Communist victory in 1975. Others were Vietnamese workers and their families brought in as laborers and students by Communist East Germany in the 1980's.
There were about 62,000 Vietnamese in East Germany when Communism collapsed in 1989, and about 12,000 stayed after unification in 1990 despite a Government offer of a plane ticket and $2,000 cash for every one who agreed to return home.
In 1993 Germany eliminated a constitutional guarantee of an asylum hearing for anyone who could get into the country and apply.

<rr>Old Glory in Hanoi
 BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 11 (Special to The New York Times) -- United States diplomats say they are within days of raising an American flag over a modern nine-story office building in Hanoi, the Vietnamese capital, to mark establishment of limited diplomatic ties 20 years after the last American diplomats were forced to flee Vietnam.
The building is expected to be opened this month after the signing of an agreement on American and Vietnamese properties seized at the end of the Vietnam War.
"We've already got the flag here, and it's ready to go up," said an American diplomat in Hanoi, speaking on condition that he not be named.
The building is expected to be converted into an embassy when the two countries establish full diplomatic relations, although that move is thought by some diplomats to be months away, if not years. The United States has said that it will withhold full diplomatic relations until there is further progress in determining the fate of more than 1,600 Americans still listed as missing in action in Vietnam.

HEADLINE: THE 104TH CONGRESS: WELFARE;
Republicans' Philosophical Discord Stalls Plan for Changes

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Negotiations over the future of the nation's welfare programs have been slowed by the emergence of deep philosophical disagreements between Republican governors and Republican members of Congress.
In general, participants in the negotiations said, governors want the fewest possible restrictions on their use of Federal money to help poor people with the costs of food, shelter, clothing and child care. By contrast, conservative Republican members of Congress say they want to regulate use of the Federal money to change the behavior of welfare recipients, to reduce out-of-wedlock births and to penalize welfare recipients who refuse to work. 
 The Republican governors and members of Congress agree that the states should have much more flexibility in designing and operating welfare programs. They also agree that each state should receive a lump sum of Federal money for purposes defined by the Federal Government in only the broadest terms. But they disagree on many details, including whether states should be allowed to cut their own spending on welfare.
"What some of the governors want is for us to put the Federal money on a stump in the middle of a forest in the dead of night," said an aide to the new House Republican leaders.
Gov. Terry E. Branstad of Iowa, a Republican, said the Republican governors shared the goals and values of the new Republican majority in Congress. But in an interview today, Mr. Branstad said: "We don't want Congress to replace liberal prescriptions with conservative prescriptions. We don't want to see Federal bureaucrats replace liberal micromanagement with conservative micromanagement."
The priorities of House Republican leaders were set forth in the original version of their welfare-overhaul proposal, the Personal Responsibility Act, which would have denied welfare benefits to noncitizens, to the children of unmarried women under 18 and to children whose fathers had not been identified to the state. But in the last two weeks, Speaker Newt Gingrich of Georgia has embraced proposals by Republican governors who simply want to replace the existing welfare programs with the lump sums known as block grants.
Republicans say the Federal Government would save money because, under the block-grant proposal, it would freeze or cut spending on programs that would otherwise grow steadily.
Governor Branstad said that Congress could hold governors accountable for use of the money, but should not impose new requirements. For example, he said, Congress should not require states to maintain their current levels of welfare spending. "I don't think there should be a maintenance-of-effort requirement," he said.
Thirty of the 50 governors are Republicans, and Congress, now dominated by Republicans, is listening to their advice as never before.
A proposal sent to Mr. Gingrich by the Republican Governors Association says, "G.O.P. governors support block grants in three major areas of welfare and social spending: Aid to Families with Dependent Children/ cash assistance, food and child care." The Republican governors said they wanted to explore block grants in five other areas: child welfare, social services, employment and training, health and housing.
Confidential records of the negotiations obtained from Republican governors and members of Congress show disagreements in these areas:
*Under the House Republican proposal, "states cannot use Federal dollars for cash aid to minor mothers giving birth outside marriage." The Republican governors' proposal has no such requirement, leaving states free to set policy as they choose.
*House Republicans would require states to "limit receipt of cash benefits to a specific number of years," probably two to five years. The governors' proposal has no such requirement.
*Under the House Republican proposal, at least 20 percent of welfare recipients would have to participate in work programs by the year 2002. The Republican governors' proposal contains no such requirement.
*House Republicans stipulate that as a condition of receiving Federal money, states must spend "at least as much on child care as they did" last year. The governors' proposal contains no such requirement.
*Under the governors' proposal, "the block grant is an entitlement to states," meaning that each state would be automatically entitled to a lump sum of Federal money for welfare each year. Under the House Republican proposal, "the block grant is not an entitlement to states."
*Republican governors want to eliminate an unusual provision of the Medicaid law that prohibits states from reducing welfare payments below the levels in effect in May 1988. The Congressional proposal does not discuss this issue.
The Republican governors said that the food stamp program, the school lunch program, the Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children and the Meals on Wheels program for the elderly should all be consolidated in the block grant for food and nutrition. They listed Head Start as one of a dozen programs to be consolidated in the child care block grant.
John Truscott, press secretary for Gov. John Engler of Michigan, said the governors and Congressional leaders were close to agreement on block grants. But he said the agreement could founder if Congress insisted on dictating details such as a prohibition on welfare benefits for unmarried teen-age mothers.
"Decisions like that should be made at the state level, not in Washington," Mr. Truscott said. "We would not choose that route. Our welfare reforms in Michigan are based on incentives, not a punitive approach. We're not going to punish innocent children."
Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont, a Democrat who is the chairman of the National Governors' Association, said Mr. Gingrich and other Republican Congressional leaders were negotiating with "a handpicked group of governors" who did not reflect the views of the association.
"I'm adamantly opposed to putting school nutrition programs into a block grant," said Mr. Dean. "Nowhere in the Republicans' 'Contract With America' does it say that starving schoolchildren is one of their aims."
Mr. Dean also voiced a fear that millions of people could suffer hardship if the welfare and food stamp programs were converted to block grants and no longer expanded automatically to meet the additional need in time of recession. In such a case, he said, the states would have to "raise taxes or throw people in the streets."
Michael J. Horowitz, a senior fellow at the Hudson Institute who is advising House Republicans on welfare policy, said the block grants would be a great step forward.
"But in the long run," he said, "states cannot get protection against Federal intrusion if they use Federal revenue. Conservatives should ultimately be shooting for a federalism in which the Federal Government surrenders sources of revenue equal to the cost of the Federal programs being turned over to the states, as we proposed in the Reagan Administration."

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Blame for the Cold War Falls on the Soviet Side

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
Those on the political right who have been inveighing against the leftish tendencies of PBS documentaries can find solace in "Messengers From Moscow," an account of the cold war that echoes decades of messages from Washington that Soviet ambitions were behind the long East-West confrontation.
Relying on recently opened Soviet archives and testimony from former high Soviet officials and apparatchiks, the four-hour retrospective centers on Kremlin machinations in the pursuit of power. The first program, tomorrow night, deals with postwar Europe, particularly Germany, which Stalin saw as the key to a Soviet takeover of the Continent. 
 Reminiscences of Vyachelsav M. Molotov, Stalin's Foreign Minister, who died in 1986, set forth his boss's goal "to expand the limits of our motherland as far as possible." And Wolfgang Leonhard, a German refugee from Hitler, tells of being sent back to his devastated country in 1945 as part of a team of commissars to make sure that control remained in Moscow's hands. The main tactic, in Germany as elsewhere in Europe, says this messenger from Moscow, was to beat down or co-opt the Social Democrats, the Communists' main opponents on the ascendant left.
A former high-ranking French Communist, Auguste Lecoeur, defines the real meaning of the benign sounding "united front" that seemed so appealing to many on the left, even in the United States: "In a united front there'd be just one party, controlled of course by the Communist Party. It was a way of getting rid of the Socialist Party completely." This aged stalwart remembers Stalin as "a terrific guy," "a wonderful fellow with a nice sense of humor."
For no good reason, the program goes in for peculiarly lighted scenes of a movie projector showing pictures of Molotov in his last days, and E. G. Marshall's heavy narration seems to have been influenced by old radio shows about the F.B.I. But newsreels of the time are reminders of the ruined Germany into which the Soviet Army moved (the red flags hung out in welcome had been made from pieces of Nazi flags) and of the staged rallies that masked political takeovers in much of Central and Eastern Europe.
By this account, the United States was compelled to move from a desire for cooperation to economic and military confrontation as Soviet intentions became clear. The narrator credits the Marshall Plan (named for George C., not E. G.) with blocking Soviet intentions in West Germany. Stalin, says E. G., created "a world of enemies."
Next week, "Messengers From Moscow" turns to Asia and the complicated relations between Mao Zedong and Soviet leaders that figured in Soviet involvement in the Korean War. Moscow's role in the Cuban missile crisis and the Vietnam War is covered later, and the series ends with the collapse of the Soviet economy and the Communist ideology.
This steadily interesting, emphatically nonrevisionist history, written, produced and directed by Daniel Wolf, a former BBC man, was paid for in part by conservative groups like the Lynde and Harry Bradley Foundation and the John M. Olin Foundation. Doubtless some historians will find it overly kind to the United States. Fine. Let them have a hearing, too. As long as PBS keeps opening up debate on a reasonably serious level, it is earning its keep.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Prices for Natural Gas Drop As Mild Weather Continues

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Natural gas futures traded at their lowest price in more than two and a half years yesterday as a decline linked to mild winter weather in much of the country continued.
Analysts said the slide appeared to be slowing after seven consecutive sessions of losses, but new forecasts for above-normal temperatures in the Midwest and Northeast through at least Jan. 21 offered little hope for a price recovery. 
 "It's the winter that never was -- unless you happen to live in California or the Rockies," said Tom Knight, a trading manager in New York for Fina Oil and Chemical.
On other commodity markets, crude oil futures rose strongly and precious metals advanced. The Commodity Research Bureau's index rose 0.54 point to 234.41.
Natural gas for February delivery finished 0.2 cent lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange at $1.437 for 1,000 cubic feet. Prices recovered after falling early in the session to $1.375, the lowest price for near-term deliveries since April 28, 1992.
Natural gas demand is running as much as 22 percent below normal in the Northeast and 19 percent below normal in the Midwest this winter because of mild temperatures, Jon Davis, a Smith Barney meteorologist, said.
"Everybody's way below normal, and from this point on it's hard to change these numbers," he added.
Meanwhile, crude oil, gasoline and heating oil futures rallied in response to weather-related problems in loading North Sea crude onto ships, and weekly industry data showing tighter American supplies.
February crude oil rose 35 cents, to $17.72 a barrel; February heating oil rose 0.60 cent, to 47.98 cents a gallon, and February wholesale unleaded gasoline rose 0.88 cent, to 54.54 cents a gallon.
Elsewhere, gold and silver futures rose strongly on the Commodity Exchange of New York as the financial crisis in Mexico spurred investment buying of precious metals, long regarded as a safe haven in troubled times. February gold rose $2.20, to $377.30 an ounce, while March silver rose 5 cents, to $4.735 an ounce.
