HEADLINE: A Pay Raise's Impact

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration, which appears to be advocating a higher minimum wage as one of its major policy objectives, is doing so at a time when most economists find less damage from raising the minimum wage than they once did.
A chief argument against raising the minimum wage, among both economists and politicians, is the fear of job losses. The threat is that employers will dismiss thousands of workers on the ground that they lack the skills to be worth more than the minimum wage, which is $4.25 an hour. But nearly all these estimates of job losses have shrunk as research continues. 
 "The main thing about this research is that the evidence of job loss is weak," said Robert M. Solow, a Nobel laureate in economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "And the fact that the evidence is weak suggests that the impact on jobs is small."
That does not quiet the debate. The new Republican leaders in Congress have vowed to reject any bill to raise the minimum wage, invoking the prospect of job losses as the chief reason. Representative Dick Armey of Texas, House majority leader, said last week that he not only opposed an increase in the minimum wage, but would also like to repeal the law.
Still, Vice President Al Gore and the House minority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, in recent appearances have publicly supported a higher minimum wage. President Clinton may endorse the move this week or next.
"Lifting the minimum wage is one of several major initiatives designed to lift the wages of all working Americans," a senior Administration official said. He ranked its importance with the President's recent tax cut proposals for middle-income families.
For all the political controversy surrounding the minimum wage, economists who study the issue have managed to agree on several key findings. These agreements help to explain why the minimum wage debate, as Mr. Gephardt put it, has become "a metaphor for the differences between Democrats and Republicans."
Contrary to popular wisdom, for example, economists have found that only one-third of the roughly four million minimum-wage earners are teen-agers. The rest are adults older than 25, a significant number of whom -- some say as many as 45 percent -- provide nearly half of their families' incomes. Raising the minimum by 75 cents an hour, the amount being considered by the Administration, would bring a gain in living standards, but only for those who do not lose their jobs.
Economists have also found that raising the minimum wage produces a net gain in total income. That is, the total income growth for minimum-wage workers who keep their jobs exceeds the income lost by those who lose theirs.
The gains in income, for some economists and politicians, can thus outweigh the loss in jobs. "If your objective is to make work pay well enough so that it takes fewer wage earners in a family to keep the family out of poverty, then raising the minimum wage is a worthy goal," said Henry J. Aaron, an economist at the Brookings Institution.
That is a goal mentioned by Administration officials. But for many Republicans and for Finis Welch, a labor economist at Texas A & M University, saving jobs should be the higher priority. "We are in effect telling unskilled people that if they are not worth the wages we set, they cannot work," said Mr. Welch, who added that he believed most employers would do little to train low-skilled workers so they could become more valuable and eventually worth the higher minimum wage.
But Mr. Welch and other economists agree that a higher minimum wage tends to lure people out of idleness and into jobs by making work more valuable than, say, the alternative of government welfare programs. As a result, the cost of low-income workers shifts a bit to business from the public sector.
Finally, there is agreement that a higher minimum wage has a ripple effect, pushing up wages for those earning as much as 50 cents more than the previous minimum. More than 5.5 million workers, or nearly 5 percent of the workforce, receive wages within 50 cents of the minimum, which rose to $4.25 in 1991 from $3.80. That's one reason that business regularly opposes increases in the minimum wage.
Yet the principal battle cry against raising the minimum wage -- job losses -- is no longer as powerful an argument as it once was. A decade ago, most studies concluded that 1 percent or more of all minimum wage workers lost their jobs for each 10 percent increase in the minimum wage. The most recent studies put the job losses at less than 1 percent, or roughly 40,000 people if Congress were to increase the current minimum by 75 cents, a jump of nearly 18 percent.
Some studies go even further. Two Princeton University economists, David Card and Alan Krueger, contend that there is little evidence of any job loss at all from increasing the minimum wage. Mr. Krueger recently became chief economist at the Labor Department, where he is an adviser to Robert B. Reich, the Secretary of Labor and a principal advocate within the Clinton Administration of lifting wages at the low end of the job ladder.
By contrast, Mr. Welch at Texas A & M insists that the traditional view about job loss is still correct. His new study, done with two colleagues, Donald Deere of Texas A & M and Kevin M. Murphy of the University of Chicago, was made public on Sunday at the annual meeting of the American Economic Association in Washington. It estimated that a 10 percent rise in the minimum wage between 1989 and 1991 produced job losses of at least 1 percent of all minimum wage workers. That would be roughly 60,000 people if the current minimum were raised by 75 cents.
Alone among the most recent studies, said Charles Brown, a University of Michigan labor economist, "the Welch findings go back to an older thesis that there was a bigger job impact when the minimum wage rose."
President Clinton promised, in the 1992 election campaign, to raise the minimum wage. But he took no action while he pursued a health insurance bill. Now Administration officials argue that raising the minimum, which has lost a third of its purchasing power since 1979, would help narrow the wage gap between low- and middle-income workers.
Professor Solow of M.I.T. agrees. "When the minimum wage has deteriorated so much in purchasing power," he said, "there are probably enough people who would be worth the higher wage and would not lose their jobs."

HEADLINE: MEXICO'S FINANCIAL TURMOIL: THE MARKETS;
Remarks by Clinton Halt Slide of Stocks

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 11

 BODY:
President Clinton's willingness to lend Mexico more money to overcome its economic crisis reassured investors today and buoyed the Mexican stock exchange after two days of steep losses.
The peso recovered some strength, closing at 5.675 to the dollar, compared with Tuesday's close of 5.85. Mexican companies and funds on the New York Stock Exchange rebounded in active trading. 
 Interest rates on Mexican Treasury certificates rose to 40 percent from about 33 percent last week as the Government offered higher rates to attract investors. Yet, demand for the notes was tepid.
On the stock market, the intense volatility of the last few days continued today in spite of the surprising turnaround. At one point in midmorning, the Mexican stock market was down 6.7 percent, exceeding Tuesday's 6.26 percent loss. But investors began feeling more confident after Mr. Clinton's backing.
"The U.S. offer to be lender of last resort to Mexico is very comforting," said Soraya Betterton, manager of Latin American equities at G. T. Capital Management in San Francisco. "What he said was that however many billions it takes, for however long it takes, the United States will be willing to fund Mexico's short-term funding needs."
Mr. Clinton said "it is in America's economic and strategic interests that Mexico succeeds." He was prepared, he said, to increase the $9 billion the United States had already committed to assisting Mexico.
Stock exchanges in other Latin American countries followed Mexico's lead and also recovered some today. Argentina, Brazil and Chile all posted gains, after heavy losses Tuesday.
Throughout the three and a half weeks of the crisis, the biggest worry of many investors has been the $28 billion worth of Mexican Treasury bonds that are indexed to the dollar and scheduled to fall due in 1995. Foreigners hold 80 percent of those bonds and have recently redeemed some of them for dollars, rather than rolling them over, pulling their money out of Mexico.
Mexico can draw on an $18 billion international loan package, but in recent days even this has not been sufficient to calm the market. President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon said today that additional help from "the multilateral financial organizations, of which Mexico is a member" would be announced soon.
In his speech, Mr. Zedillo recognized the dangers of an unsteady market, but he predicted that additional help would put things in order. "We are confident that in a few days, we will have been able to stabilize the main financial factors, including the exchange rate," he said.
A team from the International Monetary Fund has arrived in Mexico to work with the authorities on the possibility of a loan for as much as $1.6 billion. President Clinton asked the fund to help Mexico as quickly as possible, but officials there say it will take at least six weeks for a loan decision to be made.
Mexico has already started drawing on the $18 billion loan package, which includes $9 billion from the United States. On Monday, it borrowed $500 million from the United States and the equivalent of $59 million from Canada.
Mexico will have six months to repay the United States at interest rates equal to the three-month Treasury bill rate, which is slightly above 5.5 percent. Mr. Clinton offered today to give Mexico more time to repay the loans, if such a move became necessary.
The Mexican Government's focus has been on shoring up the peso and keeping money from flowing out of the country -- today offering 40 percent for 28-day Treasury notes, and 44.9 percent for those extending to 90 days.
However, even at those rates, the supply of notes exceeded demand. Buyers took 57 percent of the 1.3 billion pesos worth of 28-day certificates.
Although the stock market here regained some ground, many analysts remained worried by its continuing unpredictability. "I've never seen such volatility before," said Patricia Tyler, an analyst at S. G. Warburg in New York.
The exchange's price index swung more than 200 points during today's trading, finally settling at 2,027.87, up 2.82 percent. Despite the modest rally, the Mexican exchange is still down from the beginning of the week, the result of a combined 12.5 percent drop Monday and Tuesday.
Francisco Drohojowski, a portfolio manager with Ethos Capital Management in New York, said the market was still running on panic.
"Rationality is not prevailing on Wall Street," he said, "Now we are truly getting into a hallucinatory mode. It's panic, but a very unfounded panic."
The peso crisis has already forced some companies to adjust their outlook for 1995. Volkswagen de Mexico has decided to suspend production for the last week of January to compensate for an expected reduction in demand caused by the devaluation.

LENGTH: 1114 words

HEADLINE: MEXICO'S FINANCIAL TURMOIL: THE FALLOUT;
Argentina Striving To Regain Confidence

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 11

 BODY:
As Mexico's financial crisis continues, and markets around Latin America are jolted, Argentina has been hit hardest among the Latin nations.
Although Argentine stocks rebounded today, the financial markets have plummeted in recent days and short-term interest rates have spiraled, sending officials scrambling to allay investor concerns. 
 Finance Minister Domingo Cavallo has been meeting in New York this week with bankers and investors, trying to convince them that while Argentina's economy closely resembles Mexico's, their fates are not interwined.
In a recent interview here, Mr. Cavallo said, "In Argentina it is impossible to have the sequence of events that occurred in Mexico last year." He argued that there were distinct structural differences between the economic policies of the two countries. And he added that Argentina would have no trouble meeting its future debt payments.
Unfortunately, Mr. Cavallo said, nervous investors tended to view Latin America as a monolith because many Latin nations had undertaken similar economic reforms with varying success. Argentina and Mexico have both opened their economies to foreign investment and have privatized state industries. Both also have huge current-account deficits, which makes them dependent on flows of outside capital.
"That explains the reason investors are very nervous when they hear the words Latin America after what happened in Mexico," Mr. Cavallo said. "Many think that what happened in Mexico is destined to be repeated elsewhere, but nothing could be further from the truth when it comes to Argentina."
He said that while the stock and bond markets had declined, overall investment remained strong and the economy continued to expand. Still, if stocks and bonds continued to be depressed over the long haul, there would be a significant increase in the cost of credit for public projects and private business and this would result in less growth for 1995.
"Argentina shouldn't have a crisis like Mexico's," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington. "The current-account deficit is smaller, and the reserves are higher, and the domestic money supply is dollar-backed."
While analysts and economists agreed that Argentina was not Mexico, they warned that if Argentina did not regain investor confidence, it faced a daunting choice: much slower economic growth or a currency devaluation.
"We do tend to think of Argentina as different from Mexico," said Lawrence Goodman, a Salomon Brothers economist, but the spillover from the Mexican peso crisis has "impaired investor confidence that is absolutely critical for Argentina's continued success."
"There is clearly a risk here of capital drying up quite dramatically, which could effectively send the Argentine economy into a period of very slow growth," he said.
The main distinction between the two countries is Argentina's exchange-rate policy, or convertibility plan, which fixes the peso by law at a 1-to-1 ratio to the dollar and prohibits printing of local currency unless it is backed by new capital.
Officials have said that under the plan, every Argentine peso in circulation is backed by a dollar reserve in the central bank and that transactions can be performed in either currency. Mexico never had such a system, and last month, under market pressure, it decided to let the peso float freely. Since then, the Mexican peso has declined 39 percent against the dollar.
Mr. Cavallo attributed much of Mexico's problems to a sharp reduction in the level of foreign reserves last year just as the Government greatly expanded domestic credit. "That dangerous combination is impossible under the rules of convertibility," he said, "because in the case of Argentina, whenever there is a reduction in reserves, there has to be a necessary contraction in the printing of local currency."
Eduardo Tapia, director and country manager for Baring Securities here, said Argentina's convertibility law provided an open window on the level of foreign reserves that back up the monetary system and protect against the flight of capital. "If Argentina sticks to its convertibility plan, it seems virtually impossible," Mr. Tapia said, for the Argentine peso to suffer a devaluation.
Analysts and economists agreed that the peso-dollar parity was the cornerstone of the country's economic liberalization and that uncoupling the two would have dire effects, perhaps echoing conditions being experienced in Mexico. Mr. Cavallo said that a devaluation was "no way out, but added: "How can you devalue if you are ready to have the whole economy functioning in dollars? It imposes a tax on the people and reduces living standards."
Argentina's convertibility plan, which took effect in 1991 with other economic changes, opened the economy to international competition and investment, reducing inflation to less than 5 percent today from more than 5,000 percent in 1989. Economic and industrial growth since 1991 have been among the highest in the world -- 6 to 9 percent a year, fueled by significant increases in investment and productivity.
Last year, Argentina had new capital investment equal to 20.2 percent of its gross domestic product, the total of goods and services, of which 3 percentage points was from abroad and 17.2 points worth from local investors, according to Mr. Cavallo.
Under the most optimistic assumptions for this year, he expects investment to equal 21.5 percent of the gross domestic product, with 2.6 percentage points of that coming from abroad and the remaining 18.9 points to be financed locally.
He acknowledged, however, that the crisis of confidence set off in Mexico, combined with the possibility of still higher American interest rates, might make it harder for Argentina to continue attracting foreign capital.
In an effort to obtain capital and balance the budget, Mr. Cavallo said Argentina would sell $3 billion of state assets this year, including hydroelectric and nuclear power plants and a petrochemical plant, inviting foreign companies to bid directly.
On what he called the optimistic assumption that foreign confidence revived quickly, Argentina hoped to attract enough outside capital to finance an $8 billion deficit in its current account -- the difference between what Argentines take in from exports and what they pay for imports, plus the amount needed to meet foreign debt obligations -- allowing the economy to continue growing at 6.5 percent this year.
On the pessimistic assumption that foreign capital became harder to find, the Finance Minister said economic growth would fall to 4.5 percent, its lowest level since 1990.

HEADLINE: MEXICO'S FINANCIAL TURMOIL: THE ASSISTANCE;
White House Moves to Increase Aid to Mexico

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration moved today to increase its aid package for Mexico, warning members of Congress that more money may be needed for new, subsidized loans.
Declaring Mexico's prosperity and stability to be an important American interest, President Clinton also said today that the United States was ready to increase its existing $9 billion line of credit for Mexico and give it longer to repay the money. 
 Mexican stocks rose sharply and the peso recovered a bit following the President's declaration, his first official response to the peso's plunge. But interest rates in Mexico continued to climb.
Lawrence Summers, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, told lawmakers at a closed-door meeting this evening that the Administration was looking into ways to provide subsidized loans to Mexico for the first time, according to a Congressional aide who insisted on anonymity. The aide did not know how large the loans might be. Treasury officials had no immediate comment. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, joined Mr. Summers at the meeting.
The current line of credit is not technically subsidized because the Mexican Government is required to post an equal sum in pesos as collateral. The credit line also uses money from discretionary funds at the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve. These funds receive little Congressional oversight.
Subsidized loans might require Congressional action because a 1991 law requires that Congress appropriate an amount equal to the subsidy of each loan. The Clinton Administration presented top members of Congress with a plan that they said would not require any appropriation because Mexico would cover the subsidy. But Congressional leaders neither accepted nor rejected the idea, asking Mr. Summers to refine the concept.
In 1992, the Bush Administration briefly considered a similar plan to require Israel to pay fees equal to the subsidy value of Federal guarantees for $10 billion in loans for the construction of housing in Israel. But the Bush Administration ended up persuading Congress to appropriate the subsidy money.
The President said in his statement this morning: "We have a strong interest in prosperity and stability in Mexico. It is in America's economic and strategic interest that Mexico succeeds."
During a news conference this afternoon with Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama of Japan, Mr. Clinton also praised Mexico for working with the United States on illegal drug and immigration issues. Solving Mexico's current troubles is important for the rest of Latin America, he added. "Mexico is sort of a bellwether for the rest of Latin America and developing countries throughout the world," he said. "So we have to work on the confidence and the liquidity crisis, and I think that it's in our interest to do so."
On Tuesday, stock markets across Latin America plunged in response to Mexico's problems. They stabilized today. Many economists have played down the risk of trouble spreading beyond Mexico because few Latin American countries have trade deficits nearly as large as Mexico's. The trade deficit, while not the only factor, is widely considered to be at the root of the peso crisis.
Administration officials left vague how much extra money the United States might lend following President Clinton's comments today. That prevented financial markets from determining whether the credit line would be enough to cover Mexico's enormous need for cash to prop up the peso and redeem Government bonds.
The Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve made the $6 billion line of credit available to Mexico on Dec. 22 and expanded it to $9 billion on Jan. 3. Mexico borrowed $500 million of this money on Monday.
The current rules for the line of credit require that Mexico repay all loans within six months, at an annual interest rate equal to that on the three-month Treasury bill. President Clinton indicated today that Mexico would be given longer to repay the money if it needed more time.
"If appropriate, I am prepared to authorize the extension of the maturity of our existing credit facility and to increase those commitments to assist Mexico in meeting its short-term financial obligations," the President said in his statement.
The President also called on the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank to lend substantial sums to Mexico. An I.M.F. negotiating team arrived on Tuesday night in Mexico City, but it could take two months or more to strike a deal because Mexico allowed its previous lending program with the fund to expire in 1993. Details of a new program must be negotiated from scratch.
The World Bank already lends $1.5 billion a year to Mexico, and has flown two dozen advisers to Mexico City in the last week to help the Mexican Government prepare for the sale of state-owned enterprises to raise money.
There has been some criticism from Congress and even within the Federal Reserve over the way the Administration is freeing up funds for the bailout package.
Half the money for the Mexican line of credit is coming from Federal Reserve currency dealings and the other half from the $20 billion Exchange Stabilization Fund, a highly unusual Treasury Department account that is largely exempt from Congressional oversight. The Exchange Stabilization Fund can be spent by the Treasury Secretary, "for the purpose of stabilization of the exchange value of the dollar and maintaining orderly exchange arrangements."
A Treasury official who insisted on anonymity said that the current assistance to Mexico was legal because the department was trying to maintain order in foreign exchange markets.
Seeking to forestall any Congressional criticism of today's pledge of further assistance, President Clinton called the Republican and Democratic leaders of the House and Senate on Tuesday night, White House officials said.

HEADLINE: MEXICO'S FINANCIAL TURMOIL: THE COSTS;
For American Corporations, a Tie That Binds Too Tightly

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DALLAS, Jan. 11

 BODY:
These days, Mexico's troubles are increasingly becoming the United States'.
The risks presented by the rapidly growing Mexican operations of American corporations seemed clear today as more companies announced setbacks. The Federal-Mogul Corporation, a maker of auto parts, said its 1994 and 1995 earnings would fall short of analysts' estimates partly because of the peso's decline and the slumping Mexican economy. The company's stock fell $5.375 yesterday, to $17.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 Banks and drug makers thought to face Mexican tangles, including Citicorp, J. P. Morgan, Warner-Lambert and Schering-Plough, saw declines in their share prices of a dollar or more.
Under a new trade pact that took effect last year, many American companies have been treating Mexico, like Canada, as part of a unified North American market. Gary Hufbauer, a trade expert at the Institute for International Economics in Washington, said the financial panic in Mexico should remind American companies that Mexico remainedmore similar to Thailand or Indonesia than to Canada.
"If anybody was thinking that Mexico had entered the population of developed countries," he said, "this takes care of that expectation."
Some companies, including General Electric and General Motors, said they had shielded themselves against the peso's decline. But even these companies fear a decline in Mexican demand for their products.
"It's going to hurt," John F. Smith Jr., chief executive of G.M., said in an interview. "The market in Mexico will no doubt fall off significantly."
While the Mexican Government is trying to impose a 60-day price freeze, companies like General Electric and Chrysler have asked officials to permit increases to offset their dollar costs.
Chrysler says its Mexican sales have nearly halted. The dollar costs of importing cars and parts, the company said, now sometimes exceed the company's retail car prices in pallid pesos.
"In some cases we just cannot be offering products for sale until we work out the pricing with the Government," said James D. Donlon, the controller of Chrysler. He was speaking from home, stricken by the flu or perhaps by devaluationitis. "It's what made me sick," he said.
Among the companies that have already said that the peso's collapse has hurt their earnings are Mattel, Chemical Bank, Kimberly-Clark, the Russell Corporation and Pilgrim's Pride, a poultry processor.
Kimberly-Clark, which is deducting $39 million from 1994 earnings, said the devaluations were forcing its Mexican unit to pay more pesos on its dollar debts and on imports of wood pulp that go into Kleenex tissues, diapers and other products.
Although Kimberly-Clark has looked at investing in financial instruments that rise in value as the peso declines, the costs of hedging are prohibitive because so few investors want to take the opposite side, betting on a rising peso. "Those who are willing are going to charge you a huge premium for the privilege," said Tina S. Barry, a spokesperson for Kimberly-Clark.
Mattel, taking a $20 million pretax charge against 1994 earnings, had an opposite problem: fewer dollars in rather than more pesos out. The peso plunge caught Mattel just at the height of the Christmas season, when its Mexican customers owed the most. Their peso debts are now worth fewer dollars.
General Electric, having ridden out 99 years of Mexican tumult, has become adept at smoothing its course. The output from its Mexican plants passed $1 billion last year; G. E. Capital, its financial arm, has invested more than $400 million in the last three years.
The company, which had expected a peso devaluation, went to the expense of hedging. G. E. Capital has concentrated on financing projects like real estate or export-oriented companies that can pay their debts in dollars.

HEADLINE: Another Year Of Little Rise In Inflation

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Despite fears of inflation that have dominated economic policy in the last year, consumer prices for 1994 rose only 2.7 percent, the fourth consecutive year in which inflation failed to advance any more than 3 percent or so, the Government said today.
Consumer prices in December crept up just two-tenths of 1 percent, held down by a rare decline in the cost of housing. 
 Looking at the figures apart from the volatile food and energy sectors, the so-called core inflation rate rose last year at the lowest rate since 1965. The core rate was 2.6 percent last year, after a rise of one-tenth of 1 percent in December.
Particularly impressive last year, some analysts said, was the modest rise in prices in the service sector, where inflation was only 2.9 percent in 1994, compared with 3.8 percent in 1993. Traditionally, that labor-intensive area has been more prone to inflation than manufacturing, where production is highly mechanized and subject to intense competition that helps keep down costs.
"The forces of disinflation are really powerful," said Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley. He called the slackened price pressures in services a "breakthrough" that would likely mean that inflation remained in check.
Mr. Roach noted that inflation in services was running two full percentage points less than at the comparable stage in 1986, when the business expansion of the 1980's was nearing its fourth anniversary.
He and other analysts cited a number of factors for the economy's resistance to inflation, from consumer bargain-hunting to cost-conscious companies that are finally reaping the productivity benefits of investments in computers and telecommunications equipment like voice mail and fax machines.
"Everybody's got a laptop at work and a PC at home," said Irwin L. Kellner, senior economic adviser to the Chemical Bank in New York.
But while the prospects may seem bright, the extent to which inflation actually increases in the future primarily rests with the Federal Reserve. By raising interest rates in a bid to prevent the economy from overheating, the Fed is hoping that its restraining effect will offset sharp increases in various commodity prices and the prices of goods at intermediate stages of the production process.
The economy is now believed to have speeded up in the fourth quarter, to a pace roughly twice the 2.5 percent or so it can sustain in the long run. Consequently, the Fed is widely expected to raise short-term interest rates again soon. The most likely time, analysts said, is at its next policy meeting in three weeks.
Still, a few more voices are warning that the Fed risks overdoing its credit tightening in the face of continued subdued inflation and the acknowledgment, from the chairman of the Fed, Alan Greenspan, on down, that the Consumer Price Index significantly overstates price pressures.
"Monetary policy makers must tread lightly in 1995," said James Coons, chief economist at the Huntington National Bank in Columbus, Ohio. "One more 50-basis point hike in the Federal funds rate, to 6 percent, may be warranted. But any increases beyond that level would begin to put the expansion at risk."
A dire warning came from R. David Ranson of H. C. Wainwright & Company in Boston. He told clients this week that the last Fed increase, on Nov. 15, made a recession "virtually inevitable" in 1996.
While the overall inflation results for December were as expected, causing little reaction in securities markets, some components of the index raised eyebrows. Housing, which accounts for 41 percent of the index, posted its first decline since 1986, as the price of hotel rooms and other out-of-town lodging eased. New cars were unchanged in price, after seasonal adjustment, despite increases announced by producers.
Pushing in the other direction, however, was a second sharp rise in the cost of medical care in the last three months -- six-tenths of 1 percent in both October and December. Some analysts suggested that may reflect the death of health care legislation, which occurred in late summer.
Still, medical inflation for 1994 as a whole retreated to 4.9 percent, continuing the moderation from a peak of 9.6 percent in 1990. That was the lowest annual increase since 1972, when Federal price controls held much of the American economy in their grip.
The 2.6 percent core rate of inflation, which removes the erratic food and energy components, was down from 3.2 percent in 1993 and the lowest since a rise of 1.5 percent in 1965. Food, which accounts for 16 percent of the C.P.I., rose 2.9 percent last year. Energy, accounting for 7 percent, rose 2.2 percent.
For December, food and beverages jumped nine-tenths of 1 percent, mainly reflecting an increase of 11.6 percent for fresh fruits and vegetables, partly because of crop losses from tropical storm Gordon in the Southeast. Gasoline was unchanged last month, but would have risen nine-tenths of 1 percent had it not been for an adjustment for the introduction of reformulated fuel in many areas.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Maurice Saatchi Is Forming A New Independent Shop

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
Eight days after Maurice Saatchi's ouster as chairman of Saatchi & Saatchi led him to quit the world's fifth-largest agency company in anger, the colorful British advertising executive is forming his own breakaway shop.
Mr. Saatchi, 48, whose roller-coaster career has made him one of the most significant industry figures of the last quarter century, said yesterday that he would start an agency with three top executives who resigned in solidarity from the Saatchi & Saatchi Company on Monday. 
 "Events have moved much more quickly than anyone could have imagined," Mr. Saatchi said in a statement. "In order to avoid any more uncertainty, I have decided to announce the foundation of a new agency."
Not since 1979, when Carl Spielvogel and William Backer left the Interpublic Group of Companies to open their own shop, have such well-known senior executives departed for as high profile a start-up. Mr. Saatchi is expected to open the new agency in London around May 1, and he is expected to be joined at some point by his once and future colleagues David Kershaw, Bill Muirhead and Jeremy Sinclair, or "the Three Amigos," as the British media have dubbed them.
Mr. Saatchi's decision to start anew -- underscored by the working name of his entrepreneurial enterprise, the New Saatchi Agency -- is another stunning blow for his former employer since institutional shareholders unhappy with his tenure as chairman convinced the Saatchi & Saatchi board to depose him Dec. 16. He rejected an offer of a less prominent position and left the company Jan. 3.
Saatchi & Saatchi's difficulties were compounded when an important advertiser with longtime ties to Mr. Saatchi, British Airways, said it would review its account and cancel its contract, effective in May, with the London office of the company's flagship agency, Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide. A second client, Mirror Group Newspapers, said it would leave without a review, and a third, the Dixons Group retail electronics chain, said it would begin a review.
Although British Airways said it might re-sign with Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising U.K., its account, with billings estimated at $125 million, and that of Mirror Group, with billings estimated at $5 million, are expected to be the foundation of Mr. Saatchi's new venture.
Top Saatchi & Saatchi executives from Britain and the United States meeting in London intensified their bitter tones against the ex-chairman and his compatriots.
"There are a lot of great people who work for Saatchi all over the world, and a lot of them are extremely angry," said Michael Bungey, chief executive at Bates Worldwide in New York, the other big Saatchi & Saatchi international agency.
Referring to Mr. Saatchi and the three other executives, he added, "This is a callous attempt to totally destabilize the company that provided them their livelihood."
Thomas Russell, a private investor in Sarasota, Fla., who is a nonexecutive director at Saatchi & Saatchi, said, "Maurice's attack on the company now is outrageous."
"The people remaining in the agencies are angry at Maurice, and now it's personal," he added. "They're going to service accounts like our clients have never seen."
Mr. Russell defended the board's decision to oust Mr. Saatchi after the large shareholders complained, saying it averted "a protracted proxy fight" by "over 70 percent of the shareholders who would've voted" for Mr. Saatchi's removal.
However, Sir Tim Bell, a leading British public relations executive who is Mr. Saatchi's spokesman, said the ensuing dislocations prove that if "you can't have a successful company without financial men," it is also true that "you can't have an advertising business without advertising men."
"You can't have the dominance of one over the other," he added. "There has to be a partnership."
The crisis underscores the tempestuous and volatile nature of the ad business and the crucial role that personal relationships play.
In a touch reminiscent of the soap operas on which Saatchi & Saatchi agencies buy so much commercial time, the company even charged yesterday that Mr. Saatchi and his brother, Charles, who co-founded the company in 1970, removed 15 filing cabinets from their London office. (The cabinets have since been returned.)
"I wish these people would go away and let us do business," said Martin Puris, president and chief executive at Ammirati & Puris/Lintas in New York, referring to all sides in the clamorous dispute.
"They've done more harm than we've managed to do in the last 100 years," he added. "Industry critics who say the advertising business is flaky and catastrophe is around the corner will say, 'Aha!' "
Mr. Saatchi's attempt to recreate the success he and Charles enjoyed until the late 1980's -- Saatchi & Saatchi was once the world's largest agency company -- also jeopardizes the delicate recovery from the financial difficulties that resulted when the Saatchis' grandiose expansion plans fell prey to the recession.
"The profit recovery at Saatchi & Saatchi will be delayed by a year by virtue of whichever accounts leave," said Alan J. Gottesman, advertising industry analyst at Paine Webber in New York.
In addition to the executives who resigned Monday, four more who worked on the British Airways and Mirror Group accounts, all at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising's London office, left yesterday. Other clients, like Mars Inc. and the Conservative Party in Britain, have previously announced reviews of their accounts, and rumors circulated in London that accounts like Toyota and the new national lottery were shaky, too.
And the price of Saatchi & Saatchi shares on the London Stock Exchange has plunged about 24 percent so far this week. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, American depository receipts equal to three shares each fell for the third-consecutive day, losing 62.5 cents, or about 12 percent, to close at $4.75.
In its counterattack, Saatchi & Saatchi is pointing out the daunting obstacles the breakaway executives face: the restrictive covenants, long-term contracts and noncompete clauses that bar them from recruiting clients or employees.
Michael Henman, a Saatchi & Saatchi spokesman in London, said: "Suffice it to say that all the people who have resigned are bound by employment contracts they will be required to fulfill. We will be making use of those legal covenants to make sure our business will not be damaged by their departure."
Sir Tim, in response, played down the importance of those restrictions.
"Nobody's going to hold them a year, two years, three years," he asserted. "It's pointless." Besides, Sir Tim added, Mr. Saatchi considers his contract void because he believes "he was dismissed."
A second defensive strategy for Saatchi & Saatchi is to replace defectors quickly. Five executives at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising U.K. were promoted to replace the four who resigned yesterday (all likely to land at Mr. Saatchi's new shop.) To replace Nick Hurrell and Moray MacLennan, joint managing directors, Adam Crozier, vice chairman and executive media director, and Tamara Ingram, group director, were named to the new positions of joint chief executives. And to replace two creative directors who left, Simon Dicketts and James Lowther, three new creative directors were named: Cliff Francis, Adam Kean and Richard Myers.
A final Saatchi & Saatchi counterthrust has been to raise doubts about Mr. Saatchi's abilities to find the funds for an agency, given the company's severe financial problems after what Mr. Russell called his "ill-fated acquisition binge."
Similarly, Mr. Spielvogel, who retired in October from Bates, the successor to the agency he and Mr. Backer founded and subsequently sold to Mr. Saatchi, said, "With his track record, who would back him?" Mr. Spielvogel, who often crossed swords with Mr. Saatchi, added, "If Maurice had worked at it the first time, he wouldn't have to work at it the second time."
Sir Tim, in response, said the new Saatchi agency "is being financed by Maurice Saatchi personally." Mr. Saatchi and his brother, who has remained at Saatchi & Saatchi as a consultant, early last week sold all their remaining Saatchi & Saatchi stock, 1.8 million shares, raising about $4 million.
Two potential sources of financing mentioned by advertising executives yesterday denied any involvement with Mr. Saatchi. Richard McGowan, a spokesman for Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York, said, "We're absolutely in no way involved whatsoever."
And Richard Humphreys, a friend of Mr. Saatchi's who is president at the Adcom Inc. investment firm in New York, said that neither Adcom nor N. W. Ayer & Partners, of which Adcom owns 60 percent, was involved with the start-up.

HEADLINE: Mexico's Crisis Drags Down U.S. Stocks

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
To traders, the peso loomed larger than inflation yesterday. The stock market rallied for all of 10 minutes because of a report showing moderate inflation. But the continuing financial crisis in Mexico quickly dragged down stock prices as traders wondered which American companies would be hurt by the declining peso.
"Some stocks are taking a hit even though nothing has come out yet that even hints that they're going to take a hit," said Paul L. Hennessey, a senior trader at Boston Company Asset Management Group, which manages about $18 billion worth of stocks. 
 After rising 16 points following the release of the December Consumer Price Index, the Dow Jones industrial average fell for almost two hours before rising somewhat the rest of the day.
The Dow closed at 3,862.03, down 4.71 points, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 0.01 point, to 461.67. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 0.78 point, to 755.74.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy, with 346.3 million shares changing hands. This was about 16 percent above this year's daily average of 297 million shares.
The Mexico debacle clearly worried traders. One of the biggest decliners of the day was Federal-Mogul, whose share price hit a 52-week low of 16 3/4 before closing at 17 1/2, down 5 3/8.
Federal-Mogul said after the market closed Tuesday that its 1994 full-year earnings, while likely to exceed 1993 earnings by 30 percent, would still fall short of Wall Street expectations by some 6 to 8 percent.
Besides rising raw material costs and higher interest rates, Federal-Mogul on Tuesday cited as a cause of the profit slowdown the "severe devaluation of the peso."
The company, a huge maker of auto parts, is still looking forward to a strong year. For 1995, Nelson Publications' survey of Wall Street analysts, taken before the peso crisis, put Federal-Mogul's mean estimate of full-year earnings at $2.19 a share, up from $1.57 in 1994.
Citicorp shares, and for a time BankAmerica, were down sharply in active trading, perhaps because of their dealings with Mexico. Citicorp fell 1 3/8, to 40 3/8; BankAmerica fell as low as 39 7/8 before closing at 40 7/8, down 1/2.
Also, J. P. Morgan fell 1 3/8, to 56 3/8, and Bankers Trust fell 1, to 56 1/2. But Chemical Bank and Chase Manhattan, other money-center banks with dealings in Mexico, were unchanged.
Judah Kraushaar, a bank analyst with Merrill Lynch, said stock traders were overreacting to any possible Mexico problems. He said the total Latin American exposure, in terms of loans, bonds and other potential problems, was far less than the exposure in the 1970's and 1980's.
For these six international banks they range from 16 percent of equity for BankAmerica to 40 percent for Bankers Trust, with Citicorp at 23 percent, he said.
"The market is in a panic mode," Mr. Kraushaar said.
The biggest Mexican stock advanced yesterday. The most active stock, at 16.6 million shares, was Telefonos de Mexico, whose American depository receipts gained 2 1/4, to 35 5/8. Telmex has traded at least 10 million A.D.R.'s a day for 14 of the last 15 sessions. Each of its A.D.R.'s represents 20 shares.
The Mexico debacle overshadowed good inflation news. The Labor Department's December Consumer Price Index echoed the mild December Producer Price Index of Tuesday. The C.P.I. rose two-tenths of 1 percent from the month before.
A few stocks rose sharply. Apple Computer established a 52-week high of 48 before closing at 46 3/4, up 31/16 , on continuing speculation about a buyout of the company, this time by I.B.M. Earlier speculation had centered on Oracle and other companies. I.B.M. declined to comment.
Xtra, a trucking company, jumped 4 5/8, to 50 1/2, after the company's largest shareholder, Tiger Management, said it was exploring ways to increase shareholder value, including sale of the company.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Are Up On New Price Report

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday for the second consecutive session after another report showing moderate inflation.
The Commerce Department reported that the Consumer Price Index rose two-tenths of 1 percent in December. The so-called core rate, which excludes the volatile categories of food and energy prices, rose one-tenth of 1 percent. 
 The 30-year bond initially gained as much as 16/32 , or about $5 for every $1,000 invested, after the Government said inflation rose at a 2.7 percent annual rate last year, the same as for all of 1993.
Although the report showed moderate inflation, the bond market still expects the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates after its policy-making committee meets at the end of the month.
The price of the 30-year bond ended 4/32 higher. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 7.83 percent, from 7.86 percent on Tuesday, and the lowest since last Wednesday.
Bill rates were also lower yesterday, narrowing the yield spread between the short and long maturities. Typically a narrowing of the spread between the two-year note and a 30-year bond suggests that investors are feeling more confident that the Fed will continue to raise interest rates to subdue inflation.
Yesterday's report on consumer prices and Tuesday's report on producer prices suggested to some in the market that the Fed would need to raise short-term interest rates by only half a percentage point.
Some investors had been afraid that the inflation numbers would come in high, said Theodore Ake, government trading manager for Kemper Securities Inc. in Chicago, and that as a result, the Fed would be forced to raise rates at least 75 basis points at end of month. The soft numbers in the consumer price report alleviated the pressure that the Fed would have to aggressively tighten credit, he said.
The market was also bolstered by the turmoil in the Mexican financial markets, he said. "There is money flowing out of those markets, some of which may be flowing here."
Another positive for the market was technical. Many traders are "in a short position, or more simply, selling more than they own, betting rates are going higher," Mr. Ake said. "Most of those traders are looking at information that we may not get for another two to three weeks yet."
"Market expectations that the Fed will tighten and an expected increase in the supply of securities from the Treasury's next quarterly refunding is expected to weigh heavily on market," he said. "So there are dealers who are going to be short because they are expecting downward pressure on prices."
In other trading, municipal bonds were higher for the third day this week amid a scarcity of new bonds for investors looking to reinvest some of those coupon and principal payments coming this month.
Traders report that demand is strong as the visible supply is down from last year. The amount of bonds scheduled to be sold in the next 30 days is $2.2 billion, down 66 percent from the corresponding time a year ago.
The average yield to maturity of the Bond Buyer's index of 40 municipal issues fell 3 basis points, to 6.84 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
Among the day's largest issues was a $90 million sale of debt by the Minnesota Public Facilities Authority through competitive bidding won by Merrill Lynch.
The issue was priced to yield up to 5.80 percent for a bond due in 2005. Before the sale, Standard & Poor's raised its rating on the $231 million of water pollution control revenue bonds the authority has outstanding to AAA from AA-.
Traders said the new rating would save the state money because higher ratings reduced the cost of borrowing.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Despite the turmoil in Mexico, some companies have seen gains.

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
IN the rubble of the Mexican stock market, it has been almost impossible to make dollars by owning Mexican stocks. Only one large company has seen its value rise enough in pesos to offset that currency's collapse against the dollar since its first devaluation on Dec. 19.
And few stocks have gained even in pesos, no surprise considering that Mexico's leading index has tumbled 9 percent in pesos since then. In dollars, the loss has been 45 percent, even with yesterday's rally, which sent the market up 2.8 percent in pesos and, with the peso also bouncing back, up 6 percent in dollars. 
 Mexico remains a wild market, suitable only for those with a willingness to incur the risks attendant with huge volatility. But it is clear that some companies stand to lose less than others, and some might even gain, from the problems now confronting the country. And a look at companies that have done well, compared with those that have done especially badly, shows the bets investors have been making on what will happen after Mexico stabilizes.
The winner is Transportacion Maritima Mexicana, the country's largest maritime shipping company. It says 92 percent of its revenues, but only 70 percent of its expenses, are in dollars. As a result, it expects profits to improve.
The company has two classes of shares, traded in both Mexico and as American depository receipts on the New York Stock Exchange, and differing only in voting rights. One class is up 16 percent, to $7 from $6, in New York, while the other has risen 12 percent, to $5.75 from $5.125. In pesos, they are up 75 and 59 percent, respectively.
Even Transportacion Maritima, however, has suffered a bit since the end of 1994. It clearly benefits from the fact that it keeps its books in dollars. But while the sinking peso may stimulate Mexican exports, imports seem likely to plunge, perhaps damaging the company's business.
Another relatively good performer is Corporacion Industrial San Luis. Since the devaluation, it has risen 37 percent in pesos and fallen 16 percent in dollars. But it has gained a bit in dollars since the new year began.
The company has an unusual combination of businesses: silver mining and auto parts. Each of them, however, arguably could benefit from the peso's devaluation. Many of their costs are in pesos, while most of their revenues are from exports and denominated in other currencies. That could be a recipe for rising profits, even though the company will eventually have to raise salaries for Mexican workers.
Industrias Penoles, which claims to produce 11 percent of the world's silver, has also done relatively well. It has lost 21 percent in dollars during the debacle, but gained 29 percent in pesos.
Those two companies have more in common than silver. Neither of them trades in New York, through A.D.R.'s. That may have hurt them a bit when Mexico was soaring, because it was harder for Americans to buy them.
But it also means that panicking foreigners have had fewer shares to sell. In general, companies with A.D.R.'s seem to have suffered more than companies without them during the selloff.
Tubos de Acero de Mexico, which operates a steel plant in Veracruz, has also found some support. Its production costs, in dollars, seem likely to fall, while its revenues on exports can rise. But it also does business in Mexico, where buyers may have to cut back on projects. In pesos, its price has soared 37 percent. But its A.D.R.'s, traded on the American Stock Exchange, have fallen 24 percent during the period.
The worst performers in Mexico are the ones dependent on both the Mexican economy and appropriations from the Mexican Government, which is going to have to pull in its horns. Grupo Mexicano de Desarrolla has fallen 65 percent in dollars since the crisis began, while Empresas ICA has lost 61 percent of its value.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains Against Mark As Peseta and Lira Recover

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the German mark yesterday as turmoil in European markets abated, easing demand for marks.
Recoveries by the Spanish peseta and the Italian lira helped the dollar rise from Tuesday's eight-week low against the mark. 
 The weak European currencies "got a little bit of a reprieve, so the dollar held in there a little better than expected," said Ken Nixon, currency adviser for the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in New York.
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.5365 marks from 1.5325 marks on Tuesday and edged up to 1.2880 Swiss francs from 1.2825 francs. The British pound fell to $1.5600 from $1.5620. But the dollar slipped to 99.96 yen from 100.09 yen.
On Tuesday, the dollar slumped against the German currency as investors sold pesetas and lire for dollars and then sold dollars for marks. Traders use the dollar in the transaction because the other currencies are less actively traded against one another.
Investors had fled the peseta and lira for the safety of the mark -- the currency of Europe's strongest economy -- because of domestic political turmoil in Spain and Italy.
But the lira recovered yesterday on speculation that an interim government would emerge in Italy today, when President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro is expected to announce the appointment of a new Prime Minister-designate to succeed Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, who resigned last month.
The peseta rose after Moody's Investors Service said it might upgrade ratings of Spanish debt because local budget deficits appeared poised to shrink.
Though higher, the peseta and lira could resume their tumble against the mark if political problems persist.
"Political problems will continue in Italy and Spain," Mr. Nixon of Harris Bank said. "And that hurts the dollar."
In other currency trading, the Canadian dollar continued to weaken. The currency has been weighed down by concerns about the country's fiscal and monetary policies and by worries over the the Quebec separatist movement. Investors are concerned that Canadian interest rates are not high enough to compete with rising rates in the United States.
After falling to an eight-year low on Tuesday, the Canadian dollar settled at 70.83 United States cents in New York yesterday, down from 70.91 cents on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Journal;
Separated at Birth

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
Was it last week's photo of those huge heads side by side at the White House, each gleaming with the identical Doublemint smile? Or was it the new Speaker's compassionate opening address to the House in which he felt poor people's pain? Or was it the television debut of Kathleen Gingrich, colorfully strong-willed Middle American Mom, who is as unapologetic about her cigarette addiction as the late, great Virginia Kelley was about her two-dollar bets?
Whatever clue you find most compelling, the evidence keeps mounting that Bill Clinton and Newt Gingrich were separated at birth -- never mind the three-year age difference. And now that we've had two weeks of Newt in ascendancy, the similarities between the two men seem less superficial than predictive: the Speaker's behavior increasingly seems to follow the President's as Vermont once did Maine. 
 Some of the biographical parallels are trivial. It's not terribly telling that both men are Baptists, overeat, own '67 Mustangs, participated in student protests and once worked for candidates (McGovern, Rockefeller) more liberal than they are. Nor is it a surprise that these two ambitious boomers both smoked dope and ducked Vietnam.
But the more we learn about Mr. Gingrich, the more his twinship with the President becomes too idiosyncratic to dismiss. Both men are self-invented American archetypes, presenting a persona more at odds with their origins than Mark Twain was from Samuel Clemens. As Bill Clinton, the man from Hope, was actually born William Blythe and mostly raised in unidyllic Hot Springs, so Newt Gingrich, son of the resurgent G.O.P. South, was born Newton McPherson and, in his mother's words, raised as "a Yankee" -- originally in Harrisburg, Pa., and later at Army bases all over the map.
Dig deeper, and you find that both the President and the Speaker were favored eldest children, brought up by tough mothers who survived spouse abuse. As boys, neither knew his biological father and both had difficult relationships with their adoptive fathers. As adults, both had marital troubles of their own.
Strong and doting mothers, broken homes, tenuous roots -- how do these traits play out in men who finally realize their largest ambitions for power? If Mr. Gingrich's Speakership to date is any indication, nurture overrides even ideology. Though he's been king of the Hill only since New Year's, the Speaker is already looking Clintonesque.
His maiden speech, with its magnanimous bows to Democrats and its empathy for the victims of racial and economic injustice, could have been written by Clinton the compulsive conciliator. Since then, Mr. Gingrich has talked far too much on his and the equally narcissistic President's preferred medium of television, risking Mr. Clinton's level of overexposure. The Speaker's once-rigid backbone is also suspect; this week one of his most fervent journalistic supporters, The Washington Times, used the verb "waffles" in a headline to describe his flip-flop on a "Contract With America" plank denying welfare to legal aliens.
And let us not forget the not-really-aborted book deal, so reminiscent of Clinton-family investment windfalls back in Arkansas, or Historygate, the Gingrich replay of Travelgate. The question raised by this affair is not so much whether the Speaker's short-lived choice for House historian, Christina Jeffrey, has crackpot views about teaching the Holocaust, but why Mr. Gingrich gave jobs to so obviously ill qualified a Georgia crony and her husband (Bloodworth-Jeffrey?) in the first place -- and in secret. Is Kennesaw State College now a talent pool for the House as the Rose Law Firm was for the White House?
The Speaker and the President do differ on occasion. While Mr. Clinton plays the sax on TV, Mr. Gingrich would rather blow his own horn. The President is an Elvis idolater while the Speaker is said to impersonate Red Skelton. And though Mr. Clinton tends to moralize in psychobabble, Mr. Gingrich's verbal soporific of choice is cyberbabble.
So identical twins they're not, no matter how lookalike their negative poll numbers or how much they battle like siblings. Indeed, their reconciliatory impulses may yet lead them to converge in the political center for compromises that each is certain to sell us as "change."

HEADLINE: MOGUL HOMES

BYLINE: By MITCHELL OWENS 

 BODY:
In 1895, when locomotives drove the American economy, a railroad scion named George Washington Vanderbilt built the ultimate bachelor pad: a 175,000-square-foot chateau with 225 rooms. It remains the largest home in the United States. A century later, microchips rule, and Bill Gates, the founder of Microsoft, and his wife are settling for just 34,000 square feet, most of it underground. The number of rooms? Who knows? Their architects aren't talking. Given inflation (and considering the wall-to-wall high-tech gadgetry that is being installed), the Gates house will probably be up to the mogul standard set by Biltmore -- costing around $30 million. So if you ever strike it rich, here's a primer to kingpin style. MITCHELL OWENS

HEADLINE: Bally Gaming Sale Plan Rejected by Regulators

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER 

 BODY:
A Louisiana gambling commission has rejected a bid by Bally Gaming Inc. to sell slot machines to a planned casino in the state, after finding that the company's management and directors had allowed it to be infiltrated by "elements of organized crime".
In a decision by its president this week, the Louisiana Economic Development and Gaming Corporation said Bally Gaming apparently knew that two Louisiana companies with which it had a business relationship had ties to organized crime. 
 Bally Gaming also advanced large sums of money and credit to one of the companies, Worldwide Gaming of Louisiana, without a proper business plan or controls for accountability, according to the agency, which regulates land-based gambling.
Louis Tavano, a spokesman for Bally Gaming, which is based in Las Vegas, Nev., said the company rejected the decision and planned to appeal it before the agency's full board.
"We reject any finding by anybody that our board was not diligent in conducting our affairs or that our board was infiltrated by organized crime," Mr. Tavano said.
Bally Gaming was seeking a license to sell about 500 slot machines and related computer equipment to a planned casino in New Orleans that will be operated by the Promus Companies. Robert Dowd, a spokesman for Promus in New Orleans, said the company had decided to look elsewhere for the equipment.
A temporary version of the casino, which will be the nation's largest, is expected to open in April.
"If the board said you can't do business with them, you can't do business with them," Mr. Dowd said.
The news of the gaming board's action shook the stock of Bally's corporate parent, Bally Gaming International Inc. The shares plummeted $ 1.50, to $ 8.50, in Nasdaq trading yesterday.
If the company is unable to overturn the commission's decision on appeal, Bally Gaming could find it more difficult to get state licenses to sell gaming equipment elsewhere.
Bally Gaming is no longer connected with the Bally Entertainment Corporation, a casino operator based in Chicago, which spun off its slot machine unit in 1991. Bally Gaming machines are currently used, among other places, on riverboats in Louisiana.
Last May the United States Attorney in New Orleans indicted 17 men, including various members and associates of the Marcello, Gambino and Genovese crime families, on Federal racketeering charges in connection with allegations that organized crime had infiltrated Worldwide Gaming and Route Operators of Louisiana, a subsidiary.
Worldwide Gaming had an agreement with Bally Gaming to distribute gaming equipment. Bally Gaming agreed to furnish Worldwide Gaming with about $ 20 million of credit, inventory and cash, Federal prosecutors have said.
But rather than repaying Bally, officials of Worldwide Gaming skimmed profits from their video poker operations, prosecutors contended.
Both Worldwide Gaming and Louisiana Route Operators filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in 1993. They are now under the control of a court-appointed bankruptcy trustee, who was not available for comment yesterday.
The decision of the gambling commission stands in contrast to the conclusions of Federal prosecutors, who described Bally Gaming as a victim of the profit skimming. They also said the company had cooperated fully in the case.
A spokesman for the Louisiana Economic Development and Gaming Corporation declined to comment on its initial finding or discuss any matters connected to its inquiry. But it appears that Bally Gaming is in part paying a price for the actions of its former president, Alan Maiss.
Last month Mr. Maiss, who resigned from Bally Gaming in 1993, pleaded guilty to charges that he failed to tell Federal authorities he knew that a key official of Worldwide Gaming and its subsidiary was an associate of organized crime. Mr. Maiss, who was also a director of the subsidiary's parent, was also apparently aware that Christopher Tanfield, the Worldwide Gaming official, was not licensed in Louisiana to distribute video poker machines.
Mr. Tavano, the Bally Gaming spokesman, said that whatever Mr. Maiss might have known, he did not share that knowledge with other people at the company.
"To the best of my knowledge, everything that Bally knew was reported to the company," he said.
But information about Worldwide Gaming's possible ties to organized crime had appeared in news reports going back to 1992. That year, The Village Voice reported that Christopher Tanfield, a founder of Worldwide Gaming, was an associate of Eugene Gilpin, an amusement park operator who was convicted for his role in running a gambling operation for the Genovese crime family.
In addition, Bally Gaming's officials conducted their own internal inquiry of Worldwide Gaming and debated on at least one occasion the wisdom of getting involved with individuals associated with organized crime, The Times-Picayune in New Orleans has reported.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 28, 1995, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Jan. 12 about the denial of a gaming license to Bally Gaming Inc. by Louisiana regulators misstated the charge to which Alan Maiss, the company's former president, pleaded guilty. The charge was that he failed to tell Federal officials that Christopher Tanfield, the president of the company that distributed Bally's video poker machines in Louisiana, was not licensed to conduct gambling business in that state. Mr. Maiss did not plead guilty to failure to tell Federal officials that he knew Mr. Tanfield was a reputed associate of organized crime.

HEADLINE: THE 104TH CONGRESS: CONGRESSIONAL ROUNDUP;
G.O.P. TAX PLAN MAY LACK SUPPORT

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
It is starting to look as if a major subparagraph of the House Republicans' "Contract With America" -- one that is intended to make it almost impossible for Congress to raise taxes -- lacks enough Republican support to survive.
And it now appears that a more moderate proposal has the best chance of winning House approval, and perhaps Senate approval, too, as part of the balanced budget amendment to the Constitution. 
 On a Capitol Hill day that Republicans devoted almost wholly to showcasing their agenda and feuding with Democrats, the politics of the balanced-budget amendment debate sounded a lone off-key note.
The House took the day off. The Senate met but spent the day in languid discussion of a Republican proposal to prevent states from bearing the costs of carrying out Federal mandates, and it took only procedural votes.
By contrast, the balanced-budget amendment was the object of maneuvering, as support appeared to diminish for the clause in the Republican leaders' version of their amendment that would require that all tax increases be approved by a three-fifths "supermajority." Current law requires only a simple majority of voting lawmakers to increase taxes.
Last week, in its first session, the House voted to change its own rules to require a similar supermajority for passage of any bill that would increase taxes. But that change applied only to the House and, unlike a constitutional amendment, can easily be reversed.
When the House Judiciary Committee voted on Tuesday to approve a balanced-budget amendment, the supermajority requirement for tax increases was part of it. But in an interview, a senior Republican aide who spoke on condition that he not be named said that such a hurdle to future tax increases "ain't gonna fly" when the amendment reaches a House vote, later this month.
And Representative Charles W. Stenholm, a conservative Democrat from Texas, said today that he has secured the backing of at least 65 Democrats for an amendment with a lower barrier to tax increases.
That is significant because constitutional amendments require approval by two-thirds of each chamber of Congress, a number that Republicans cannot muster without at least 53 Democratic votes in the House. The Republican leadership's version of the amendment has little Democratic backing in either the House or the Senate.
Mr. Stenholm said today that his amendment "is the only one that's got a chance of passing" in the new Congress.
Republican leaders in the House stopped short of admitting that. But an aide to the House majority leader, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, said that lawmakers will get a chance to consider both versions of the amendment when the matter comes to the floor, and the most popular version will be adopted.
Mr. Armey told reporters on Tuesday that he "can live with" Mr. Stenholm's less restrictive version of the amendment, the newsletter Congress Daily reported today.
Mr. Stenholm's amendment, also sponsored by Representative Dan Schaefer, a Colorado Republican, would require an absolute majority of senators and representatives -- that is, a majority of the total membership of each house -- to approve a tax increase before it becomes law.
An identical measure was considered in both the House and the Senate in the last Congress, but failed to pass. The current version favored by the Republican leadership -- the three-fifths version -- is getting its first review. "A strong component of Democrats, and even some Republicans," oppose it, said Jane Guerrero, an aide to Mr. Schaefer.
"Some freshmen want the three-fifths," she said. "But the choice is our version, or no version, and the leadership agrees. Once the freshmen realize that's the lay of the land, we'll say it's what we can get."
 
Welfare
 Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, affirmed today that House Republicans wanted to end welfare and food stamps as entitlement programs, which pay benefits to anyone who meets certain eligibility criteria. "We will end entitlements as we have known them," he said.
The Republicans want to replace them with lump sums of money, paid to the states as block grants.
Mr. Archer and Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr., chairman of the subcommittee that will begin considering welfare legislation on Friday, said that they still wanted to make immigrants ineligible for Federal aid under Medicaid, welfare, school lunch programs and other programs.
Republicans proposed such a prohibition as part of their Contract With America. The prohibition would apply to legal and illegal aliens. The House Speaker, Newt Gingrich, said recently that he was reconsidering the proposal. But Mr. Shaw, a Florida Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Human Resources, said he did not take Mr. Gingrich's "offhand comment" as an instruction to revise the legislation.
At a hearing of the Ways and Means Committee today, two Republican Governors, George E. Pataki of New York and William F. Weld of Massachusetts, praised the tax and welfare proposals in the contract. Mr. Weld said he was willing to accept less money from the Federal Government for welfare programs if he had more flexibility in running the programs.
But Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont, a Democrat, expressed concern, saying that "kids will be the victims" if they lose their entitlement to welfare benefits. "In the next recession, children will be the ones in trouble," said Mr. Dean, who is chairman of the National Governors' Association.
 
Line Item Veto
 The Republican effort to give Presidents their first-ever veto over individual items in Federal spending bills -- a proposal the White House supports -- got decidedly mixed reviews from a dozen politicians, budget analysts, anti-waste muckrakers and other experts.
Senate and House committees are considering bills that would effectively give a President control over even the smallest Federal expenses by allowing him to simply wipe unpalatable spending items out of budget bills after the legislation has been signed into law. Both versions would also let the President delete special-interest tax breaks from tax bills.
In both cases, what would follow amounts to a political pas de deux: The Senate and the House of Representatives would have a limited time (20 days in the House version) to restore the repealed expenses by a majority vote; the President could veto that restoration, and each house would then have to override the veto, by a two-thirds vote, to keep the spending items intact.
Politicians and officials of government-watchdog groups generally liked it. Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, said studies show that Congress has larded military-spending bills with $50 billion in non-military spending over the last six years, and he argued that a line-item veto would help put a stop to it.
Governor Weld testified that he had wielded the line-item veto in his state more than a thousand times, mostly to cut pork-barrel spending put in legislation to win someone's vote.
Forty-three-states have some form of line-item veto; the former Governor of Arkansas, Bill Clinton, used it 11 times during his tenure.
Amid all the fervor, however, even supporters sounded some cautionary notes.
The White House budget director, Alice M. Rivlin, testified that President Clinton supports legislation giving him the broadest veto power of spending that Congress can devise -- or, roughly, what the present bills contemplate. But Ms. Rivlin advised the lawmakers not to expect Mr. Clinton to use the veto much, or to achieve great savings with it.
"I'd think it would be a relatively small proportion of discretionary spending that would be a candidate for the line-item veto," she said, adding that Mr. Clinton would wield it as a "targeted" weapon on spending he felt was particularly egregious, not as a broad brush to wipe out vast amounts of spending he dislikes.
Others said the bills being studied cede an extraordinary amount of legislative power to the White House with no guarantee, they said, that future Presidents would use it responsibly.
The legislation gives the President power not only to strike expenses listed in the text of Federal spending bills, but also to dip into individual spending accounts and eliminate projects that are not explictly listed in the bills themselves. Moreover, a President would be able to save his spending cuts from a hostile Congress -- and avoid a vote on the House or Senate floor -- if he could round up enough votes to bottle up a veto message in committee.
Robert Reischauer, the director of the Congressional Budget Office, testified that only 11 of the 43 states with line-item vetoes give that much power to their chief executives. And studies show that most governors use the veto not to hold down spending, but to enforce their own spending priorities over those of legislators, he said.
Norman Ornstein, the veteran analyst of Congress at the American Enterprise Institute, a Washington research organization, advised lawmakers drafting legislation to look to Presidents like Lyndon B. Johnson and Richard M. Nixon, who could use the Federal budgets as blunt instruments to bend others to their will.
"What you're dealing with, more than anything else here, is a transfer of power, not a case of spending restraint," Mr. Ornstein said. "Be careful about how much power you want to move."
Both the House and Senate panels plan votes on final versions of their bills later this month. If they pass -- as expected -- the full House will take up the issue on Feb. 6.
