HEADLINE: A Pataki-Whitman Honeymoon Hits a Bump, on Port Authority

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
All last fall, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey acted as political pathfinder for George E. Pataki, plugging the elixir of tax cuts to New York voters on the campaign trail and praising the era of Republican good feelings that would reign across the Hudson once Mr. Pataki was installed in Albany as Governor.
But Mr. Pataki has been Governor less than two weeks and already the two sides are sniping at each other. The cause is Mr. Pataki's intention to nominate one of his political allies, Conservative Party leader George J. Marlin, to head the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the multibillion-dollar economic development engine -- builder and operator of airports, bridges and tunnels -- that the two states share. 
 Mrs. Whitman's aides say she was perturbed both by the choice of Mr. Marlin, who is inexperienced in management on the scale of the Port Authority, and by the fact that she expected to be consulted, but learned of the appointment in a call from a reporter. Her first formal notice from the Pataki administration was a fax of Mr. Marlin's resume on Monday.
By tradition the executive director of the Port Authority is a New Yorker picked by Albany, and the chairman is a New Jerseyan chosen in Trenton, but part of the process has always been the courtesy of consultation, aides say.
Today Mr. Pataki's people were offering no apologies. "If she has concerns, she can certainly relate those concerns," said Zenia Mucha, Mr. Pataki's director of communications, when asked for a comment by reporters. "But the fact of the matter is, this is the Governor's appointment to make. The Port Authority is a massive bureaucracy that needs to be reined in and what the people there are trying to do is preserve their very existence. They're all overpaid. The productivity level is as low as it's ever been and we want some changes. And we think George Marlin is the person to make those changes."
Mrs. Whitman has organized a meeting in Newark with Mr. Pataki for Friday, their first get-together since the New Yorker became Governor. Its purpose is to remind Mr. Pataki, among other things, that, as one of her aides put it, the full name of the Port Authority includes the words "and New Jersey."
Ms. Mucha's statement left Mrs. Whitman's staff open-mouthed. "If this is how they feel, there's no need for a meeting," one of them said. Carl Golden, Mrs. Whitman's spokesman, refused to be drawn in, however.
"The Governor is not going to have anything to say about this until after the meeting tomorrow," he said.
The first clouds in the stormlet formed last weekend when Governor Pataki rather clumsily, it seemed to the Whitman camp, used the New York governor's traditional right to appoint the Port Authority's director as coin for the repayment of political debt to Guy V. Molinari, the Staten Island Borough President who was an early supporter in the Governor's bid for office last year.
While the Whitman people did get advance notice of the offer to Mr. Molinari, they were told it was only tendered because Mr. Molinari had agreed beforehand to bask for a day in the glory of it all and then decline for personal reasons, according to Whitman aides.
Already unsettled by the Molinari feint, Whitman administration officials were astonished by the Marlin punch.
"Our understanding was that, before any public discussion took place of any potential appointees, there would be some consultations with us," a ranking Whitman aide said on condition of not being identified. "And then all of a sudden out comes this fellow Marlin.
"I'm not suggesting that the Governor is upset or irritated," the aide went on, "only that we expect to be consulted on this matter."
The Whitman camp has made it clear that New Jersey would not seek to block the Marlin appointment, although each governor has the statutory right to veto any action by the authority's Board of Commissioners. Instead, Mrs. Whitman's aide said, the Governor planned to propose that one or more deputies with strong fiscal and public management backgrounds be installed to assist Mr. Marlin.
"I think through inexperience the Pataki people got the idea that this was their appointment and that Whitman, if she was consulted, would go along," the Whitman staff member said. That was before today's statement from the Pataki administration, however. A Whitman adviser suggested that he felt Mr. Pataki ought to disavow the statement that the choice of director was his alone, and apologize to the Port Authority staff.
The Port Authority operates the region's three airports and the cross-Hudson tunnels and bridges, and has traditionally operated as the only agency with the financial power to build long-term, high-risk projects. It owns the World Trade Center, for example, a project that was derided as a fiscal white elephant when it was built, but which has since turned into a cash machine for the authority.
The authority's officers prize its autonomy from the two states' often fractious politics. There was speculation here -- and it may have been hinted at in Ms. Mucha's statement -- that someone within the authority's World Trade Center headquarters leaked Mr. Pataki's choice of Mr. Marlin in an effort to scuttle it.

HEADLINE: Initial Claims By Jobless Up

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing for first-time state unemployment benefits climbed by 17,000 last week, to 355,000, the Labor Department said today in a report showing that the job market may not be as strong as previously thought.
The total for the week that ended last Saturday was up from a revised 338,000 the previous week, and well above the 327,000 that Wall Street economists had forecast. The department said it was the highest total since the week that ended on July 16, when claims reached 390,000. 
 The four-week moving average, which smooths out weekly fluctuations and is considered a more accurate indicator of jobless trends, rose to 334,750 from a revised 326,750.
A total of 2,510,000 people were receiving state benefits in the week that ended on Dec. 31, the department said.

HEADLINE: Stocks Finish Mixed As Peso Worries Persist

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
After seesawing in active trading, the stock market closed mixed but essentially unchanged yesterday, as worries persisted about the economic crisis in Mexico and new worries emerged about the home mortgage business.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 3.03 points, to 3,859.00, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 fell 0.03 point, to 461.64. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 0.77 point, to 756.51. 
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was normal, with 312.6 million shares changing hands, about equal to this year's daily average of 313 million shares.
Turmoil in the international currency markets did not help the American stock market. The United States has committed itself to lending dollars to Mexico so the Mexican central bank can halt the fall in the peso's value. But the United States commitment prompted a flight by currency traders out of dollars yesterday and into less debt-laden currencies like the German mark and the Japanese yen.
A less valuable dollar makes stocks and bonds in the United States less valuable and therefore less attractive to foreign investors. The dollar has fallen about 1.5 percent in value against the yen and 3 percent against the mark since the Mexican crisis began last month.
The weaker dollar hurt the bond market. Yesterday, the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose to 7.88 percent from 7.83 percent, indicating that bond buyers were demanding a premium for long bonds. Yields and prices move in opposite directions.
The effect of previous increases in long-term interest rates hurt the mortgage business. The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, which is the nation's largest source of home mortgages, reported earnings below Wall Street expectations. The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, creates securities from home mortgages. Its shares fell sharply after news of the Fannie Mae earnings.
Both developments signaled profit worries for the housing business, which is highly sensitive to changes in interest rates. Shares of Fannie Mae dropped 4 5/8, to 70 7/8, while those of Freddie Mac fell 2 3/8, to 51 3/8.
Citicorp, which has major dealings with Mexico and Latin America, went out of its way yesterday to deflect market suspicions that the peso crisis would hurt earnings. Releasing its earnings several days early, Citicorp again denied problems in Latin America. Nonetheless, shares of Citicorp fell for the second day, closing at 39, down 1 3/8.
Other stocks fell for other reasons. Tech Data established a 52-week low of 11 3/8 before closing at 11 7/8, down 4. The computer distributor acknowledged a disappointing outlook for fourth-quarter earnings.
Meanwhile, Xerox rose 4, to 103 7/8, after the company said it would increase its stake in Rank Xerox, a European joint venture. Analysts said the move would help profits.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index closed unchanged at 251.72, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining stocks 1,128 to 1,057. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 0.23 point, to 434.89.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 15 fell, led by Caterpillar, which fell 1 1/8, to 56 3/4. Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 184 fell.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ford Raises Many Prices

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Jan. 12

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company said today that it was raising prices on some of its hottest-selling models in the United States by as much as $444 and increasing prices in Mexico by 10 percent in response to the recent plunge of the peso.
The company said the price increase affected all vehicles Ford builds in Mexico. Prices in Mexico will also rise for vehicles imported from the United States and Canada. 
 In the United States, Ford said it raised prices on these models: the Ford Escort and Mercury Tracer; the Ford Mustang; the Bronco sport utility vehicle; the Econoline and Club Wagon vans; the Ranger compact pickup, and the F-series truck, the nation's best-selling vehicle in 1994.
Ford said that some of the price increase reflected higher equipment costs, like the addition of a driver's-side air bag on the Ranger, and that some of it paralleled recent price increases announced by other car makers. Ford also raised destination and delivery charges an average of $15.

HEADLINE: Orange County in Suit Against Merrill Lynch

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Seeking to recover some of its bankruptcy losses, Orange County, Calif., sued Merrill Lynch & Company today, contending that the brokerage firm sold risky and unsuitable securities that are barred by California law.
The long-awaited lawsuit, which asks for $2 billion in damages, is the first in what is expected to be a series of claims against the brokers, bond lawyers and financial advisers who did business with Orange County. 
 In response to the suit, Merrill Lynch quietly sold $1 billion in collateral from securities in the ill-fated investment portfolio that it had been holding. Lawyers representing Orange County sought to block the move by rushing to the bankruptcy court today, but they were apparently unsuccessful. Other brokerage firms with exposure to the fund sold their securities at least a month ago, helping to prompt the bankruptcy.
In a suit filed in United States Bankruptcy Court in Santa Ana, the county supervisors contend that Merrill Lynch sold Orange County's former treasurer, Robert L. Citron, a variety of highly risky securities for the county's ill-fated investment pool that are not permitted under California law. The suit contends that Merrill Lynch knowingly allowed Mr. Citron to borrow securities beyond permissible debt levels.
The suit also contends that Merrill Lynch misrepresented the securities it was selling, in violation of the anti-fraud provisions of United States securities laws.
"Merrill Lynch abused the trust and confidence of the people of the county," said Gaddi H. Vasquez, chairman of the Orange County Board of Supervisors. The Wall Street firm, he said, encouraged "the investment of public funds in volatile financial instruments that were neither authorized by law nor suitable for the investment of taxpayer dollars."
A spokesman for Merrill Lynch in New York called the contentions "absurd."
James Wiggins, the Merrill Lynch spokesman, said: "The supervisors knew exactly what the leverage was. This reminds me of the classic Claude Raines line in 'Casablanca': 'You mean there's gambling going on here?' "
Orange County declared bankruptcy last month, after losing more than $2 billion in its investment fund that made aggressive bets on interest rates using borrowed securities and a risky trading strategy.
James W. Mercer, a lawyer representing the county, said the fund, which had borrowed about $13 billion, was limited by state law to borrow no more than $1.5 billion, the size of its annual revenues. In addition, he said, the borrowings used to leverage the size of the fund were used for speculation and not simply to "supplement income," which is the only use permitted by California law.
Mr. Mercer, a lawyer with Howrey & Simon in Los Angeles, said the lawsuit was based on the precedent established by San Jose in its case against Paine Webber in a similar case.
Merrill Lynch is also facing a barrage of lawsuits in the Orange County bankruptcy, but this is the first one from the county. Other lawsuits have been filed against the firm by the holders of Orange County securities and by some of the 187 municipalities in California that invested in the Orange County fund.
Merrill Lynch is also being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which is looking into the possibility of fraud in Merrill Lynch's dealings with Orange County. The brokerage firm's chief salesman to Orange County, Michael Stamenson, is scheduled to testify next Tuesday along with Mr. Citron before a state Senate committee in Sacramento.
Merrill Lynch, in a written statement, said it would "contest the lawsuit vigorously." It said Orange County's political leaders "for years reaped high rewards," adding: "Now they want to deny the risks. In effect, they're saying, 'Heads we win, tails you lose.' "

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
S.E.C. Studies Problems
 WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (Bloomberg Business News) -- Some local governments across the country have put themselves into financial problems like that in Orange County, Calif., the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Arthur Levitt Jr., said today.
Citing confidentiality laws, Mr. Levitt declined to disclose the number of local governments with financial crises that the S.E.C. was studying. But, at a House Energy and Commerce Committee hearing on the situation in Orange County, he made it clear that the commission was reviewing some municipalities that faced problems because of inappropriate investments.

HEADLINE: On First Washington Trip, Pataki Walks a Tightrope

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
On a frenetic first lobbying trip to Washington today, Gov. George E. Pataki found himself caught between his instinct to show loyalty to the new Republican leaders of Congress and his need to protect his state from the potential impact of their budget-cutting policies.
To balance those interests, Mr. Pataki expressed his support for the central fiscal tenets of Speaker Newt Gingrich's "Contract with America," saying he favored balancing the Federal budget, cutting taxes and replacing Washington's antipoverty programs with block grants to the states. But he conditioned his support by seeking guarantees that none of those measures would reduce the Federal government's traditional level of support for New York. 
 "We need to control government," Mr. Pataki said while testifying before the House Ways and Means Committee. "We don't need to pass the buck from one level of government to another."
After Mr. Pataki testified before the committee, he was squired through the Capitol by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, his political patron. They sped through meetings with Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan; Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, and Mr. Gingrich before joining New York's congressional delegation for lunch in a Senate dining room.
When Mr. Pataki emerged from lunch for a scheduled news conference, he found that Representative Charles B. Schumer, the videotropic Democrat from Brooklyn, had already staked a claim to the bank of microphones in a Capitol corridor. "We've got to get a hook to keep Schumer out of there," a passing Mr. Dole said to Mr. D'Amato and Mr. Pataki as they waited for Mr. Schumer to finish. "I tried to tackle him but I couldn't get him."
Throughout the day, Mr. Pataki brushed off warnings that the Republican Congressional agenda would force deep cuts in Federal aid to the states, and that urban states like New York would be most vulnerable.
Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont, a Democrat who testified with Mr. Pataki before the Ways and Means Committee today, projected that should the balanced budget amendment be passed, New York would stand to lose $ 11.2 billion in annual Federal aid by 2002, the year such an amendment would take full effect. Mr. Dean, the chairman of the National Governors Association, said that New York State taxes would have to be increased by 24 percent to compensate for the loss in Federal funds.
Mr. Pataki, however, dismissed those figures as "hypothetical." And rather than dwell on the potential for danger, he went to Capitol Hill armed with a profit-sharing proposal that he said would give New York and other states new incentives to rein in Medicaid spending, thereby helping the states and the Federal government balance their respective budgets.
Although the cost of Medicaid is shared by the state, local and Federal governments, the states largely control the amount that is spent by setting reimbursement rates for health care providers and by determining which medical services will be covered. Mr. Pataki proposed that any savings generated for the Federal Government by state decisions to cut Medicaid be shared with the states.
"If we can lower the costs to Washington of some of our entitlement programs through changes we make, why doesn't Washington share that savings with us to create an incentive?" he asked.
Mr. Pataki said a program that would allow the state to keep 20 to 25 percent of the Federal savings would help encourage his Legislature, which has a Democratic Assembly and a Republican Senate, to enact his proposed cuts. When he presents his budget on Feb. 1, Mr. Pataki plans to recommend cutting about $ 1 billion of the approximately $ 6 billion in state tax revenue that is spent annually on Medicaid, a reduction that would generate about $ 2 billion in savings for the Federal government.
After his 15-minute meeting with Mr. Pataki, Mr. Gingrich said he was "very interested in pursuing the idea of a savings incentive plan for local governments." He added, "We're going to have a meeting on this right away."
Mr. Dole added: "These are ideas we ought to take a look at. They may work."
Democratic congressmen from New York City greeted Mr. Pataki with far less enthusiasm, with many saying that he should take a hard line against the Republican congressional agenda. After listening to Mr. Pataki's testimony to the Ways and Means Committee, Representative Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan said: "Was that testimony? I didn't want to embarrass him but I don't recall that he endorsed the contract, he didn't talk too much about what it might mean for New York State, and he didn't talk about what happens if there's a recession."
Mr. Rangel said that Mr. Pataki should be fighting for minimum standards for entitlement programs and guarantees that the Federal government would raise the amount of social services block grants to states in times of rising poverty and unemployment.
Mr. Schumer echoed Mr. Rangel's advice. "The contract is certainly not going to be good for New York State," he said. "Being a realist, I wouldn't expect a new Republican governor of New York to attack it publicly. But I would hope he would work behind the scenes to blunt it."

HEADLINE: Workfare Not Just a Program To Save Money, Adviser Says

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's senior adviser on a new program to make more able-bodied, childless welfare recipients work for their benefits and to scrutinize new applicants more aggressively said yesterday that the main focus of the initiative was not to save money.
The adviser, Richard J. Schwartz, said the program, which Mayor Giuliani initially promoted as a major budget-cutting measure, was intended to "restore integrity" to the public assistance system by screening out people who try fraudulently to qualify for benefits. In addition, he said, the workfare plan would "build a sense of reciprocity" by requiring those who are physically able to work for the city in exchange for their grants. 
 "This program is not built around how much we expect to save," said Mr. Schwartz, who has previously estimated that within a year the plan would save the city about $80 million annually from Home Relief, the public assistance program that serves primarily childless adults.
Mr. Schwartz's comments were clearly aimed at minimizing expectations that the new welfare initiative would be critical in reducing the city's looming budget gap. His remarks came on a day when he and other city officials led reporters on a tour of the offices at 330 Jay Street in downtown Brooklyn where Home Relief applications are to be examined more thoroughly and applicants interviewed more attentively.
The city spends about $381 million to cover benefits for the roughly 244,000 people currently receiving Home Relief, which is mandated by the state and paid for jointly by the city and the state.
"We believe in the final analysis, when the program is fully operational, there will be some kind of savings," Mr. Schwartz said. "It's possible they will be very modest. It's possible we will not save any money. The economy could deteriorate and many more people than we anticipated could legitimately qualify for Home Relief. These are factors out of our control. The factors within our control are building integrity and a philosophy of reciprocity, and that is regardless of the financial payoff.'
Through the new program, which began to be phased in on Jan. 3, city officials said they expect about 15 to 20 percent of new applicants and existing recipients to be found ineligible for benefits through a tougher screening process that will now include unannounced home visits, a rigorous hourlong interview and computer checks to verify Social Security numbers, credit ratings, bank accounts and tax records.
Officials also expect to cut welfare rolls when people fail to report for mandatory work assignments, possibly because they have undocumented jobs they did not report.
Mr. Schwartz said the cost to the city for the program was about $15 million a year -- $10 million for the salaries of 270 fraud investigators and about $5 million for other expenses, like supervising work assignments and remodeling the Jay Street offices.
He said that as of Jan. 3, about 90 of the 270 new fraud investigators had begun the new in-depth investigations, called Eligibility Verification Reviews. The city takes about 45 days to notify people whether their applications for Home Relief have been approved. The next 90 investigators are to begin work on Feb. 1. Mr. Schwartz said the program was to be fully operational by March 1.
So far, only 2 of the city's 40 income maintenance centers, where people first apply for Home Relief and other forms of public assistance, are sending people for the new eligibility reviews within two weeks of their applying for benefits. Those centers are the Waverly and Amsterdam Centers on the West Side of Manhattan. People applying now at the other centers are to have similar evaluations within 60 days.
At the same time that the city is imposing a new welfare initiative, the city's Human Resources Administration has proposed cutting city spending on welfare by $270 million -- or more than a quarter -- for the 1996 fiscal year, which begins on July 1. In a document submitted to the city budget office, the agency suggested eliminating many special grants intended to help poor people in emergencies and to prevent homelessness, city officials said.
Among those grants are emergency utility funds to help people avoid cutoffs of electricity, restaurant allowances for those who have no kitchen or who live doubled up with friends or family, moving expenses for welfare recipients leaving a shelter or moving to a bigger apartment, and brokers' fees for those moving into a new apartment.

HEADLINE: LEADERS OF G.O.P. IN CONGRESS BACK CLINTON ON MEXICO

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
President Clinton won approval from top Congressional leaders today for what is expected to become an enormous package of loan guarantees to rescue the Mexican economy.
The agreement, described by the White House as a significant test of bipartisanship in a foreign financial crisis, is aimed at trying to keep Mexico's growing financial crisis from erupting into a clash with the Republican majority and dissident Democrats. 
 The new Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich, and the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, agreed to a rescue plan put together by the Clinton Administration that will require Mexico to pay a fee, similar to an insurance premium, to the United States for taking the risk of guaranteeing Mexico's debts. The plan avoids a potentially raucous Congressional argument over foreign aid by allowing Congress to approve the guarantees without allocating funds from the Federal budget.
But the Administration refused to say how much the loan guarantees would total. Officials clearly hoped that the announcement alone would restore the confidence of private investors and commercial banks, making use of the guarantees unnecessary.
"We agreed to do what is necessary to restore financial confidence in Mexico without affecting the current budget at home," Mr. Clinton said in a joint statement with the Republican leaders and the minority leaders of the Senate and House, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri.
Vice President Al Gore; the new Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, and the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, also attended the White House meeting.
The announcement came today after it became clear that an $18 billion credit line for Mexico, created last week by the United States, Canada and several other nations, would prove insufficient to stem the crisis created by a 35 percent devaluation of the peso.
In Mexico City, reports today that Washington was working on the huge aid package, which was rumored to total as much as $40 billion, helped push the Mexican stock market up 4.5 percent from Wednesday's close.
Investors in Mexico were encouraged that the action might bring the economy back from the brink of collapse and took the chance to buy stocks at what might turn out to be bargain-basement prices after a 12.5 percent drop earlier this week.
 The Mexican peso also strengthened today, closing at 5.45 to the dollar. That is 4 percent above the close on Wednesday.
Despite the last two days of market gains and peso recovery, however, analysts say Mexico is far from overcoming its crisis.
"When you have the market moving as much as it has on rumors, it shows that there still is a lot of uncertainty," said Walter T. Molano, an economist at CS First Boston in New York. "I'd expect to see a high level of volatility throughout January, and then gradually diminishing into February."
The Administration acted out of a fear, White House officials said, that if the currency crisis escalates further, it could ripple throughout the rest of Latin America and perhaps into the markets of other developing countries in Asia that are highly dependent on foreign investors.
Moreover, they are concerned that a resurgence of inflation in Mexico could result in political turmoil there, perhaps leading to uprisings among workers angry that prices for necessities are beginning to soar.
They also fear the impact of the crisis on the United States. Immigration authorities have already warned that a sharp economic downturn in Mexico could cause a flood of illegal immigrants across the border in search of dollars that are now far more valuable once they are converted into pesos back home.
Mr. Clinton is also trying to save one of his Administration's greatest economic successes: The North American Free Trade Agreement.
After hailing the agreement in recent weeks as a huge boon for American workers, creating an export market for American goods and thousands of new jobs for its workers, Administration officials now concede that exports to Mexico could grind to a slow halt unless the peso recovers. Labor unions are already warning that the American market will be flooded by Mexican goods that have suddenly become 30 percent cheaper.
"If Mexico's economic growth slows or stops because of this crisis," one of Mr. Clinton's top economic advisers said, "the impact on trade, on immigration and the whole strategy of spreading free trade in the region could be enormous."
Already, many of the Democrats and some conservative Republicans who opposed the free trade accord because they saw it as a threat to American jobs are contending that the crisis has vindicated their view.
Other political leaders said that American taxpayers should not be asked to clean up after the mess created by what they said was incompetent management by Mexico's past and current leadership.
Jack Kemp, who is considered a possible candidate for the 1996 Republican nomination for President, said neither the Clinton Administration nor the Congress should join in "Mexico's repudiation of more than 30 percent of its national debt, which is all that devaluation means."
He added, "The only people who benefit are the wealthiest people of Mexico, whose inherited wealth is held in dollar assets and whose debts have been held in pesos."
The joint announcement at the White House tonight consisted largely of another in a series of statements of support for the Mexican Government, asserting that "the United States has an important economic and strategic interest in a stable and prosperous Mexico."
After the statement was read by the White House press secretary, Michael McCurry, Mr. Rubin, the Treasury Secretary, and Mr. Greenspan, the Fed chairman, took the podium. Their entrance into the the room was carried by Cable News Network, which was broadcasting the briefing session live. But they insisted on speaking only under the condition that any quotations be attributed only to United States officials.
The officials deflected any effort to quantify the loan guarantees, and denied that they would be open-ended. But at the same time, they would not describe any limits to the loans, leaving the impression that Mexico could buy more guarantees from the United States if its troubles worsened over several months. The guarantees would presumably cover loans far larger than the $18 billion in credit lines that the United States and others have already established, even though Mexico has only used a fraction of that amount so far.
Later in the evening, a senior United States official, asked about estimates that the guarantees could cover loans totaling anywhere from $15 billion to $40 billion, said the estimates were "in the right basic ball park."
The current rescue plan is modeled on a $10 billion program that the Bush Administration set up several years ago for Israel to help it borrow money for the construction of housing for refugees fleeing the former Soviet Union.
At the heart of the Administration's plan -- and the rationale for contending that it will cost taxpayers nothing -- is the kind of calculation that insurance companies make when they guarantee a home mortgage. The fee charged will be based on an estimate of the odds, perhaps anywhere from 1 in 20 to 1 in 100, that Mexico will actually default on its loans.
If it did default, American taxpayers would be the losers, and the United States would have to pay off billions of dollars in debt. If the loans are repaid, however, the Treasury will be the winner, pocketing the fee that Mexico pays.
The package announced tonight was largely the work of Lawrence Summers, a Harvard economist who now serves as Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, and Mr. Greenspan, who is ordinarily not a visible participant in top policy decisions. But his open association with the policy seemed intended to lend the Federal Reserve's credibility to the plan for the benefit of Republicans and the financial markets.

HEADLINE: THE 104TH CONGRESS: WELFARE;
War Over an Overhaul Appears to Be No Contest

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Scarcely believing how much ground they have lost in the past six months, advocates for welfare recipients are beginning to regroup for what is widely expected to be an uphill battle against an array of Republican proposals to fundamentally restructure poverty programs.
They face these immense hurdles: A public clearly fed up with the ineffectiveness of existing welfare programs; a Democratic Party on Capitol Hill still reeling from its losses in November, and an Administration eager to identify itself with "welfare reform" that has at times seemed reluctant to challenge major elements of the Republican plans. "The silence of the White House is startling," the Rev. Jesse Jackson said in an interview this week. 
 Moreover, some of these advocates and their allies say, they cannot hope to engage in a war for public opinion even remotely like the one waged in the last great struggle over social policy -- health care. "Low-income people don't send generous checks to advocacy groups to represent their interests," said Jennifer Vasiloff, executive director of the Coalition on Human Needs, an alliance of about 100 social welfare, charitable and religious groups that was originally created in 1981 to try to counter the Reagan budget cuts.
"You have a lot of organizations that operate on a shoestring trying to get information out," she said. "This is not the health care debate, where you have monied interests with a great stake in the outcome."
For all of that, the advocates and their allies have begun generating news conferences, reports and news releases, trying to change the terms of the debate, which will escalate when hearings begin on Friday in the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Human Resources. That panel is expected to begin writing and voting on actual welfare legislation next month, and the full House is committed to voting on a welfare overhaul as part of the Republicans' agenda for the first 100 days.
As the process lurches on, the advocacy groups hope to shift the attention of a frustrated public away from the mothers on public assistance and toward the children who, these groups argue, would be the ones truly punished by many of the proposals now being advanced. Among those proposals are automatic time limits for welfare, the denial of benefits for the children of unwed teen-age mothers and capping the spending growth of several major welfare programs.
"When the American people voted for change, and for less government, I don't believe they voted to hurt millions of children, or to make them hungrier or homeless, or to take them away from their families," said Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund, at a news conference this week.
Representative Charles B. Rangel, a Manhattan Democrat who is a member of the Human Resources Subcommittee, said, "While we're doing this political thing, whether it's Clinton or Gingrich or Clay Shaw, the bottom line is we're talking about children not being cared for." Mr. Shaw, a Florida Republican, is the chairman of the subcommittee.
"I just cannot believe that as frustrated as the American people are, knowing that the system is breaking down, knowing that it creates a dependency, I just really don't believe that these are solutions they can live with," Mr. Rangel said.
Critics like Mr. Rangel clearly hope to capitalize on the public ambivalence identified in a survey made public today by the Kaiser Family Foundation and Harvard University. It found that two-thirds of Americans supported a time limit on welfare benefits, but only 16 percent would favor it if the beneficiary could not find a job.
Another major part of the liberal critique is targeted at governors. Advocates for welfare recipients hope to persuade the governors that the Republican proposal to replace many of the existing poverty programs with lump sum payments to the states, known as block grants, might sound attractive, but is in reality a fiscal time bomb. No longer would Federal aid to the states automatically expand as the caseload expands, they say, which is the case with the current "entitlement" programs.
"The first reaction of state officials is sometimes an interest in having more flexibility and the belief that with fewer Federal requirements they could do a better job," said Mark Greenberg, who is with the Center on Law and Social Policy, a public interest legal group in Washington that specializes in antipoverty policy. "However, no block grant formula is able to predict a recession -- or to predict accurately the number of people who will need help a year or two or three years in the future."
Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont, a Democrat who is the chairman of the National Governors Association, said that in such a situation, "states are faced with a choice of raising taxes dramatically in a recession, which in this environment is unlikely, or cutting people off, which is basically children." Mr. Dean asserts that in his conversations in recent days, he found considerable uneasiness among Republican governors about this element of their party's plan.
A spokesman for the Ways and Means Committee said the panel's chairman, Bill Archer, Republican of Texas, wanted to explore ways of adjusting for regional differences in times of recession. More broadly, the spokesman said: "Nothing is crueler to our children today than the present welfare status quo. It's not working and it has to be changed."
In fact, a central political reality in the coming struggle is that nobody wants to defend the status quo. Representative John Lewis, a Georgia Democrat who is a longtime advocate for the poor, said: "I think we all believe there must be changes. I think we have to continue to say that we're a caring and compassionate nation, but our compassion and sense of caring doesn't mean that we do something that's inefficient, or something that's not working."
But many liberals seem downright stunned by how fast the debate over welfare has moved to the right, a development that gained even more momentum with the Republican victories in the November elections. "Two years ago, I thought my biggest fight would be against Clinton's proposals," Mr. Rangel said.
So far, many analysts say, there has been no downside for a politician to broadly embrace the idea of "welfare reform." But the same was once true of the health care overhaul, and that ultimately derailed on the details. Sharon Daly, deputy director of Catholic Charities USA, said she had been urging the organization's agencies around the country to meet with their representatives in Congress and to explain those details.
The Child Welfare League, a 75-year-old association of 800 such agencies, is adopting a similar strategy. "We're going to fight like hell," said David Liederman, executive director of the league. "Why go through this exercise to create more poor kids, more orphans, to put more and more children below the poverty line?"

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Bruised in Stampede Of Investors to Yen and Mark

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply against the Japanese yen and the German mark yesterday, accelerating a decline that reflects investor concern about the financial crisis in Mexico and the weakness of currencies in Spain, Italy, Sweden and Canada.
A big concern is that the economies and currencies of emerging-market countries like Mexico will be under pressure this year if investors decide to take their money to countries where the risks of losses are lower. Analysts say the current weakness of currencies in developed countries like Canada and Spain was also sending investors into more stable and stronger alternatives, in this case the yen and the mark. 
 All of these countries -- and the United States -- depend heavily on foreign capital to cover their debt and their trade deficits, making a flight by investors even more damaging.
The dollar has traditionally served as the premier safe haven for investors fleeing economic or political trouble, especially during the cold war. But in the current turmoil, traders say the United States suffers from being sandwiched between Mexico and Canada, two victims of the crisis.
"It's a rolling flight into quality around the world as investors get out of assets they no longer trust," Ravi Bulchandani of Morgan Stanley's international economics department said. "At first, when it was just Mexico in trouble, the dollar benefited. Now the contagion has spread to Asia and everything weak, and the money is moving into Germany and Japan."
Against the yen the dollar dropped 1.4 percent, to 98.60 yen, down from 99.96 on Wednesday. Against the mark, the dollar fell half of 1 percent, to 1.5280 from 1.5365.
The dollar has been falling against the yen and the mark for several days as money flowed into these currencies from emerging market economies in the developing world. Since Friday, the dollar has fallen 2.7 percent against the yen and 2.3 percent against the mark.
But traders said the movement accelerated overnight in Asia, where investors, worried about prospects for the region, moved money out of local currencies and into the yen. While the yen is a traditional safe haven for footloose money in that part of the world, traders say its attraction is increased by Japan's large trade surplus.
Meanwhile, downward pressure has continued on the Canadian dollar, the Swedish krona, the Spanish peseta and the Italian lira as money flowed out of these countries and into the traditional European safe havens of Germany and Switzerland. In New York, the Canadian dollar fell to 70.51 United States cents, from 70.83 Wednesday, its lowest level in almost nine years.
Analysts said many investors were worried that all emerging market economies might face slower growth this year as investor concerns over the Mexican crisis and the likelihood of higher American interest rates reduced the inflow of foreign funds that these countries rely on to finance their trade deficits.
"Earlier assumptions that funds will continue flowing into developing economies with large payment deficits are coming into question," explained John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers. He added: "Investors are pulling back. It becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy."
But another concern, Mr. Lipsky said, is that President Clinton's offer of additional aid to Mexico, combined with the Bank of Canada's efforts to support its currency today, could lead to "large-scale intervention against the dollar."
Many experts said yesterday that the $18 billion credit package central banks and the United States assembled for Mexico last month was not enough to stabilize the peso against the downward pressure generated by maturing short-term foreign debts, as well as a flight of private capital and the selling of foreign-owned stocks.
Last night, the Clinton Administration announced a new package of loan guarantees for Mexico, but did not disclose its size.
"They need $40 to $50 billion probably," said Geoffrey Bell of Geoffrey Bell & Company, a New York investment advisory firm.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Xerox Lifts Stake in Foreign Venture

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 12

 BODY:
The Xerox Corporation said today that it would increase its stake in Rank Xerox, which makes Xerox products for sale in Europe, Asia and Africa, in a $960 million deal.
Xerox will pay its European partner, the Rank Organization of Britain, 620 million in cash for an additional 20 percent share of the company, increasing its controlling stake to 71 percent. Xerox said the deal would increase its share of Rank Xerox's profits to 80 percent from 67 percent. 
 Rank Xerox, based in Marlow, England, makes Xerox products and sells them in Europe, Asia and Africa. With annual sales of $4.6 billion, it accounts for a third of Xerox's total worldwide sales.
Xerox said the transaction, expected to close at the end of March, would improve its earnings potential and expand its global presence. Xerox is the world's second-largest copier company after Canon Inc.
With the increased stake, Xerox "will have more access to European sales and the Far East," said Wendy Abramowitz, an analyst at Argus Research in New York, "and things are going quite well economically in those countries."
Shares of Xerox surged $4, to $103.875, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
Xerox, based here, will assume about $500 million of debt, mostly through commercial paper, to pay for the transaction.
Some analysts speculated that Xerox would eventually acquire the rest of Rank Xerox. Bob Spremulli, an investment officer at the College Retirement Equities Fund, which owns 2.7 million Xerox shares, said if that were to happen, Xerox would own all of Rank Xerox's 50 percent stake in Fuji Xerox, the business entity through which Rank Xerox sells to Japan and Asia. "If Fuji Xerox were ever listed on the Tokyo exchange, Rank Xerox's share could be worth $25 to $30 a share," he said.
For the Rank Organization, the sale will let it trim debt and refocus on its core leisure and entertainment business. The giant British conglomerate owns interests in the Hard Rock Cafe chain and in the Universal Studios theme park in Florida. The Rank Organization said it would report a gain of 325 million, or $508 million, from the sale.
As part of the Xerox transaction, the company also said it would buy the remaining 13.8 percent of A. Kershaw & Sons, an investment company that indirectly owns 19.8 percent of Rank's interest in Rank Xerox, at a price of 11.50 a share.

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
The Migration From the South In 60 Images

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH 

 BODY:
IN the late 1930's and early 40's, the young Jacob Lawrence was a man with a mission: to recount different chapters of the black American experience in visual terms. Reared in Harlem during its cultural flowering and trained in art, Mr. Lawrence had by the age of 20 evolved a slightly archaic, Cubist-inflected style that held abstraction and representation in perfect balance. By 1940, when he turned 23, he had already executed three cycles of small tempera paintings, each numbering around 30 works, which chronicled the lives of Toussaint L'Ouverture, Frederick Douglass and Harriet Tubman.
Mr. Lawrence's activities did not go unnoticed: his work was exhibited not only in group shows but also in two solo shows, and he received a Rosenwald Fund fellowship. With this support, he waded into his fourth and longest cycle early in 1940, executing "The Migration Series," whose 60 captioned images have been reunited for the first time in 20 years in a compelling exhibition that has just arrived at the Museum of Modern Art. A bittersweet saga whose mixture of words and images has a circling, fuguelike rhythm, "The Migration Series" is Mr. Lawrence's greatest achievement. 
 This narrative cycle recapitulates the heroic migration of blacks from the rural South to the urban North in the early decades of this century. By 1915, Jim Crow and poll tax laws were nearly universal in the South; the Ku Klux Klan was pursuing its dreadful business with little opposition, and lynchings were frequent. Shut out economically and politically, often fearing for their safety, blacks, the majority of them poor tenant farmers, voted with their feet.
Over the next two and a half decades, hundreds of thousands crossed the Mason-Dixon line seeking a better life in the cities of the North. Their relocation radically changed American culture, politics and economics, producing, among other things, jazz, the country's first internationally accepted art form, and the Harlem Renaissance, in which Mr. Lawrence came of age.
The migration was a story close to Mr. Lawrence's heart, one that his own parents had lived and that he had often heard as a child. He tells it exceedingly well in "The Migration Series," avoiding both propaganda and sentimentality, distilling an immense saga of political and economic cause and effect -- and aftereffect -- into images in which form, color and sometimes brilliant spatial distortions give the forces of history an uncanny emotional immediacy.
Exhibited in November 1941 at Edith Gregor Halpert's Downtown Gallery in Manhattan and partly reproduced in Fortune magazine, "The Migration Series" was something of an instant success. In short order it was acquired by two museums, the Modern and the Phillips Collection in Washington, which divided the 60 panels according to odd and even numbers. The Phillips originated the current exhibition in 1993.
Happily, the show at the Modern is bracketed by two nearby exhibitions. On Fifth Avenue near 57th Street, the Midtown Payson Gallery has mounted a 44-work survey of Mr. Lawrence's career. Dominated by images of life in Harlem, it provides a fuller picture of his temperament, showing a more relaxed, almost humorous side, as in two works from the late 1930's, and also a penchant, especially strong after 1960, for images with striking decorative patterns, like "Nigerian Series: Meat Market" of 1964.
The Whitney Museum of American Art, at its Park Avenue Philip Morris branch, is displaying "The War Series," a 14-image cycle that Mr. Lawrence painted in 1946-47 after serving in the Coast Guard in World War II. Its emphatic patterns and often Expressionistic sense of form and movement have a character altogether different from the measured ease and flow of the "Migration" images. Less consistent in visual quality and less compelling narratively than its predecessor, "The War Series" nonetheless includes several outstanding images, especially those of P.O.W.'s behind wispy strands of barbed wire, a mourning mother, a boat full of wounded soldiers and finally a depressed black G.I.
A result of these concurrent shows is a kind of Jacob Lawrence festival that no one interested in American art or American history will want to miss. Mr. Lawrence's distinctive ability to render the political in adamantly visual terms is also something that many contemporary artists should attend to.
The center of the festival is unquestionably the Modern's show of "The Migration Series," a work of epic span yet intimate proportions. (Also noteworthy is the show's excellent catalogue, which has several essays and a detailed chronology.) Mr. Lawrence is not a great painter, but in the tiny panels of "The Migration Series," he is a great visual storyteller, a kind of historian in paint.
His style is an astute blend of the overt and the subtle, combining elements of Cubist composition, folk-art directness, Egyptian abbreviation and the narrative acumen of early Italian Renaissance painting. His palette is a spate of slightly off-key, darkened primaries set against carefully textured browns that variously account for barren fields, shanty floors, railroad stations, tenement stairs and factory walls.
Accompanied by terse captions that make their meanings hard and clear, these images amount to more than an excellently condensed documentary account of their subject, a kind of story-book for adults. This is because their full impact comes only with looking, with sorting out the semi-abstract forms and absorbing the different spatial distortions and emotional moods.
As is often noted, "Migration" begins, ends and is regularly punctuated with scenes of railroad stations, crowded with people whose piled belongings often achieve a Cubist complexity. In between are emptier scenes that isolate one or two figures, usually in closed interiors from which there seems to be no escape. In some of the best of these, tables or beds, dramatically tilted, acquire the proportions of life rafts. And there are occasional landscapes, some with withered plants to illustrate that floods and boll-weevil blights also contributed to the migration. Others, like the image captioned "The migration gained in momentum," depict further bunches of people joining forces as they trudge across an open terrain that implies both freedom and miles to go.
Some scenes sum up elaborate systems of exploitation. One, in which a black tenant farmer brings his bag of cotton to the planter for weighing, is captioned, "The migration was spurred on by the treatment of the tenant farmers by the planters," and leaves no doubt as to the latter's intent. Two more depict labor agents from Northern factories signing up black workers who are innocent of the fact they are being hired as strike breakers. But often the rhythm of explanation is broken by statements of stark bluntness, like the simple image of a man and woman at a bare table, whose even simpler caption is, "They were very poor."
Mr. Lawrence's sympathies are complex, and he occasionally resorts to metaphor. An image of a prison's high stone wall punctuated by a single cell-window whose bars are clutched by two white hands is cryptically labeled "The South," as if to imply that discrimination oppressed everyone in the region. And images of race riots, overcrowded tenements and well-dressed Northern blacks (who looked down on the new arrivals) indicate that the end of the arduous journey was not entirely a promised land.
In telling his story, Mr. Lawrence does not shrink from or gloss over its hard truths. Nonetheless, "The Migration Series" is at heart a work of sustaining optimism. This is partly because the tale itself is momentous, the expression of a great collective will, and partly because Mr. Lawrence tells it with such ingenious efficiency, fueled by his sense of mission and secure in his art.
"Jacob Lawrence: The Migration Series" is at the Museum of Modern Art through April 11; "Jacob Lawrence an Overview: Paintings, 1936-1994" is at the Midtown Payson Galleries, 745 Fifth Avenue, near 57th Street, through Feb. 25. "Jacob Lawrence: The War Series" is at the Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, 120 Park Avenue, at 42d Street, through March 24.

HEADLINE: Why We Don't Get Federal Tax Dollars Back;
Leaving Town

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I do not dispute Representative Charles E. Schumer's data about the money to be lost under the Republican "Contract With America" (editorial, Jan. 6). But New York officials are blaming the wrong culprit. 
 During Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's tenure, New York State lost a majority of the Fortune 500 companies who called New York home (down from roughly 75 to 25). Many found the cost of doing business here too high.
This has created two problems: (1) Tax revenues are lower; (2) the number of jobs is shrinking. State and local officials talk about raising taxes to make up the shortfall.
Regardless of what the top Federal tax rate has been, tax revenues have remained constant at 19 percent of gross domestic product. When tax rates are raised, people hide income or lose incentive to work extra hours. In New York these evasions also result in relocation.
As a twentysomething soon to enter a managerial position after graduation, I will be tempted to move outside this city, where I have lived all my life. As a single person here, I will pay close to half of every dollar in taxes. Though half this burden will go to the Federal Government, what incentive have I to stay?
Better services? Probably not. Lower crime? Definitely not! Better restaurants, theaters? Yes, but with the money I save in taxes, I can stay in a hotel after the theater!
New York can lower taxes and be business-friendly or seek more Federal and state money. The choice is obvious.
 
STEPHEN RODOCANACHI
New York, Jan. 6, 1995

HEADLINE: Action at City Hall! Movie Politicians Take Over

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
In a place accustomed to cameras, the spotlight and constant notoriety, the film crews that spent several weekends over the last few months working at City Hall still produced an unmistakable giddiness in even the most blase and cynical of city officials.
The source of the excitement was the shooting of "City Hall," a movie that uses the 183-year-old downtown landmark building as its centerpiece. This week, the film crews were at Gracie Mansion. And with the crews and movie stars roaming about City Hall, the actual inhabitants of the building have been tickled to rub elbows with the fictional ones. 
 Perhaps it was the sight of Al Pacino sitting casually in the same spot where City Council members had argued about a bill a day earlier. Or seeing John Cusack studying his lines on the steps of City Hall, the frequent site of press conferences.
It might be that some public officials were forsaking governmental roles -- if for a moment -- to take smaller parts on the big screen.
In addition to Mr. Pacino, Mr. Cusack, Bridget Fonda and Danny Aiello, the "City Hall" cast includes Jerome X. O'Donovan, the Councilman from Staten Island, who plays the role of Council Speaker. Kevin R. McCabe, the chief of staff to the real Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, and Assemblyman Anthony S. Seminerio of Queens play members of the City Council. Even former Mayor Edward I. Koch has a part, as a television commentator.
Filming, which also took place last weekend, is to continue until next month, although work in City Hall has been completed.
Some two dozen City Hall employees have been delighted to work as extras. "I stood shoulder to shoulder with John Cusack in one scene," said Richard B. Hogan, a City Council sergeant-at-arms who plays the same role in the film. "It has kind of made me interested in doing some acting. I've already made some inquiries about joining the Screen Actors Guild."
Councilman O'Donovan, who has played bit parts in the television programs "Law and Order" and "Equalizer," has a guild card, but his two days on the set of "City Hall" represented his first speaking part. "It was an unbelievable amount of fun," he said. "We shot from 6 in the morning until late at night, longer than my regular days."
But "I don't think I'm ready to give up my day job," he said.
The screenplay for "City Hall" was written by Kenneth Lipper, a Wall Street financier who was a deputy mayor in Mr. Koch's administration. The story is about the aftermath of the deaths of a police officer, a drug dealer and a Brooklyn child, all of whom are killed in a shootout. The event becomes a scandal with reverberations that ultimately consume the municipal powers in City Hall. Mr. Pacino plays the fictional Mayor John Pappas.
Mr. Lipper, the chief technical adviser on the film, said it was important for the film makers to capture the energy of City Hall as a crossroads for government officials, the media and ordinary citizens.
"This is a relatively small facility where so many people from such diverse positions are close enough to bump into each other, interact with each other and feed upon each other," Mr. Lipper said. "We have been trying to capture the look and feel of this place. In addition to the movie being a political thriller, we're trying to communicate what the culture of this building is all about."
The movie is the first to benefit from a decision by John S. Dyson, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, to change city policy and allow filming in City Hall for a fee. The money is to be used for renovation and maintenance.
Many who work in and around City Hall have been captivated by the degree to which the makers of the movie, Castle Rock Entertainment, have tried to replicate the real thing. Because much of the real City Hall is in use around the clock virtually every day, the filming was confined to weekends and to the eastern half of the building, the side used by the City Council.
Judith O. Rubin, who handled protocol in the Dinkins administration, was hired to offer advice on, among other things, how a mayoral dinner would be conducted. Mr. McCabe was hired to offer advice on City Council meetings, and the City Hall security officers were consulted on methods of protecting the Mayor.
The production designers duplicated a mayoral podium, adding a step-stool for Mr. Pacino. Stationery was printed with the city's crest. Historical paintings retrieved from city archives were cleaned and restored by the film makers.
The production designers also roamed antique stores throughout the city to find a desk that most closely resembled the one used by Fiorello H. La Guardia; the authentic La Guardia desk is being used by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
Many in the film's cast did extensive research. Mr. Cusack, who plays an idealistic deputy mayor, spent time with city officials and attended a City Council meeting. He and Mr. Aiello spent time with Anthony J. Genovesi, a Brooklyn Assemblyman and Democratic district leader.
Mr. Pacino spent an entire day with Mr. Giuliani. "He's very nice," the Mayor said of Mr. Pacino. "He's one of my favorite actors, and a very natural, easy person to talk to.
"He was also unobtrusive in the way he went about things, the way he was hiding behind the cameras and watching. None of the press saw him, but he was there throughout an entire press conference."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 17, 1995, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about the filming of the movie "City Hall" in New York City misstated the position of Kenneth Lipper. He is a co-producer of the film, not the writer of the screenplay. It was written by Bo Goldman.

HEADLINE: Wide Rally Sends Dow Up by 49.46

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Wary stock traders, caught off guard by the good news on inflation in yesterday's retail-sales report, suddenly bid prices up in the broadest rally for stocks since last summer.
The unanticipated slump in December retail sales prompted optimism among traders that the Federal Reserve would either raise interest rates only slightly at its policy meeting Jan. 31 and Feb. 1, or might even wait until its next meeting in March. 
 The Fed has raised rates to slow what it regarded as an overheating inflationary economy, but the slump in retail sales may indicate the economy has cooled faster than expected.
Bond prices surged, with the yield on the 30-year bond dropping to 7.78 percent, from 7.88 percent on Thursday. [Page 49.] The price of gold, often a fever chart of market anxieties about inflation, fell sharply. But the dollar was still mixed in international currency markets, a measure of continuing international wariness of the United States rescue of the Mexican economy.
Yesterday's rally culminated a hesitant week when the Dow Jones industrial average barely budged off dead center for four sessions in a row. The Dow jumped 49.46 points, to 3,908.46, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 4.33 points, to 465.97. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index advanced 5.65 points, to 762.16.
The New York Stock Exchange had the largest number of advancing stocks since July 29, when advancing stocks outnumbered declining issues by 1,015. Yesterday, advancing stocks outnumbered declining stocks by 1,680 to 658, or a margin of 1,022. And the number of stocks posting new 52-week highs in price yesterday totaled 52; the new-low total was 46.
"It was a very good day today, considering the last couple of days," said Paul Hennessey, senior vice president for the Boston Company Asset Management Group, which manages $18 billion of stocks.
Mr. Hennessey noted that companies like Citicorp had been able to defuse concerns about the Mexican crisis and raise its falling share price. Yesterday, Citicorp rose 1 5/8, to 40 5/8. And Telefonos de Chile, after falling for several days, gained 3 7/8, to 78.
"The rally can be traced back to the pressure coming off stocks with operations in Latin America and the retail sales coming in and surprising people," Mr. Hennessey said.
"There's still a lot of money coming out of bond funds and a lot of reinvestment dollars being used," said Dudley Eppel, managing director in charge of listed equity trading at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "Also, this market was clearly oversold and there are just fewer people around on a Friday to keep things from getting out of hand, even on the upside."
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was above normal, with 336.7 million shares changing hands, about 7 percent above this year's daily average of 316 million shares.
Stocks rallied so strongly that the Dow jumped 50 points at 3:55 P.M. and the New York Stock Exchange put into effect its so-called circuit-breaker rules designed to slow down high-speed computer-guided trading.
The big news yesterday was the Commerce Department's December report on retail sales. At $191.8 billion, monthly sales during the Christmas season fell one-tenth of 1 percent instead of rising as much as seven-tenths of 1 percent, as Wall Street economists had predicted.
Except for restaurants and bars, which saw a jump in sales, business at a variety of establishments dropped, including department stores, food stores, gas stations, clothing stores and drugstores.
Some stocks increased for reasons unique to them. Quaker Oats was up in active trading because of takeover rumors first reported by Dan Dorfman, the CNBC financial journalist. He reported that Coca-Cola had offered $60 a share, but that Quaker rejected it. Quaker shares rose 4 1/4, to 35 7/8. Coca-Cola, in an unusual statement, scoffed at Mr. Dorfman's reporting, saying, "Dan Dorfman does not have a clue."
Two computer-related stocks fell. Lotus Development, a leading software developer, dropped 1 1/4, to 43, after analysts said a rival, Microsoft, might post strong earnings at the expense of Lotus and others. Mr. Dorfman said that America Online shares could fall more than 15 percent without citing a reason why. America Online, a leading computer information service, dropped 1 7/8, to 50.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 2.23 points, to 253.95, and the American Stock Exchange market value index rose 1.24 points, to 436.13.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 26 advanced, led by J. P. Morgan, which rose 2 3/4, to 59 7/8. Of the 500 component stocks of the S.& P. 500, 313 rose, led by AT&T, which climbed 1 1/4, to 49.
The most active stock, at 10.9 million shares, was again the American depository receipts of Telefonos de Mexico, which gained 3/8, to 36 5/8.

HEADLINE: Rates Tumble on Weak Retail Sales

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Interest rates fell sharply yesterday, pushed lower by surprisingly weak retail sales figures that reduced the odds, market participants said, of a big increase in short-term rates by the Federal Reserve later this month.
Monthly retail sales figures are notoriously volatile and are often subject to major revision. Even so, the one-tenth of 1 percent decline in December sales reported by the Commerce Department, accompanied by a downward revision of a full percentage point to the November sales figures, left most analysts rubbing their eyes in disbelief. 
 "I have a lot of problems with these numbers," said Joseph Liro, chief economist at S. G. Warburg & Company. "There is too much conflicting evidence that says the sales pace was stronger at the end of the year than the Commerce Department said it was in this report."
Nevertheless, the figures set off major sparks in the market. Within 20 minutes from their release this morning, traders had pushed down yields on two-year Treasury notes, a key barometer of expectations on Fed policy, by 20 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Bond prices, moving in the opposite direction meanwhile, rallied by nearly a point, pushing yields down to their lowest level in three weeks.
By late yesterday, the price of the benchmark 30-year bond rose 31/32 , to 9622/32 , for a yield of 7.78 percent, down from 7.88 percent on Thursday.
The drop in rates was even more pronounced among shorter-term maturities.
Two-year notes, offered at a price to yield 7.55 percent late Thursday, rallied strongly after the retail sales figures, and by late yesterday were offered at a price to yield 7.32 percent. Rates on short-term Treasury bills also moved sharply lower.
"For the first time since last February, when the Fed began to tighten monetary policy, market participants are beginning to see the light at the end of the tunnel," said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research and commentary on developments in the fixed-income and foreign exchange markets.
Despite the weak numbers, Mr. McCarthy said, "I still think the Fed will raise short rates by half a percentage point" when its policy-making Federal Open Market Committee holds two days of meetings beginning Jan. 31.
"But now that increase is a debatable issue," he added. "Before these numbers, it was not debatable."
As Mr. Liro of Warburg noted, the sudden weakness in retail sales came as a shock because other recent measures of consumer activity, including healthy car sales and continued strong increases in consumer installment debt, suggested otherwise.
"If they can revise November's numbers down by a full percentage point, they can certainly revise the December numbers up by a similar amount when the January numbers are released," he said. "This sort of thing happens all too often."
Even though he has doubts about their accuracy, Mr. Liro said the retail sales figures were likely to help persuade the Fed to limit any increase in short-term rates to half a percentage point.
"A month ago I would have said there was as much as a 90 percent probability of the Fed tightening in early February," said Steven Roach, co-head of global economics at Morgan Stanley & Company. "Now, I think it is a really close call."
In conjunction with the lower sales figures, Mr. Roach said the Fed would be contemplating a rate increase in the context of continued good inflation news, Mexico's financial crisis and Orange County's problems.
"Those factors will make it the toughest call the Fed has had to make in quite a while," he said.
For nimble corporate borrowers, yesterday's drop in rates provided a useful window to offer new debt, and more than $1 billion in securities were priced.
The day's biggest issue was sold by the Weyerhaeuser Corporation, which offered $300 million of 30-year noncallable debentures through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.
The 8.50 percent debentures were priced at par, or $100, 68 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Tresury's 7.5 percent bonds of 2024 at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A2 by Moody's Investors Service, and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Prices of tax-exempt municipal bonds rose for the fourth day in a row, as cash continued to flow into municipal bond funds. The average yield to maturity in the Bond Buyer's index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds fell to 6.80 percent from 6.85 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains Against Mark But Remains Weak vs. Yen

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the German mark but continued to be weak against the Japanese yen yesterday.
In a stormy week on the currency exchanges, the dollar had fallen sharply against the mark and the yen, as those currencies assumed the dollar's traditional role as a safe haven. Investors fled Italian and Spanish markets for the mark and left emerging markets in Asia for the yen. 
 But yesterday, the strength of the mark waned somewhat as the Italian lira, which has set record lows against the mark since the resignation last month of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, recovered somewhat on expectations that a prime minister-designate would be nominated. Later in the day, President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro named Lamberto Dini, a former top executive of the Bank of Italy, as his choice to lead a new government.
The Spanish peseta also posted gains against the mark. Traders said that there was widespread speculation of Spanish intervention throughout the session but that there was no comment from the Bank of Spain.
With the mark weaker, the dollar was able to climb as high as 1.5385 marks before easing to 1.5337 marks in late New York trading from 1.5280 marks on Thursday.
The dollar continued to feel pressure from the yen as investors moved out of emerging Asian markets and into safer Japanese investments.
The continuing financial crisis in Mexico has prompted investors to scale back holdings in other emerging markets.
"There has been a lot of battering of the Philippine currency and the Hong Kong dollar," said Amy Smith, a currency analyst at the consulting firm IDEA. "The pressure is still very acute and it is helping to keep the yen firm."
In New York, the dollar slipped to 98.50 yen, from 98.60 yen on Thursday.
In other currency trading, the Canadian dollar recovered after hitting its lowest level in almost nine years on Thursday. The Canadian dollar rose to 70.90 United States cents, from 70.51 cents on Thursday.
Anne Pankowski, vice president at Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, said two increases in short-term interest rates by the Bank of Canada this week had helped to restore investors' confidence. But the central bank has been criticized for not raising rates enough to compete with rising rates in the United States.
The dollar rose to 1.2880 Swiss francs, from 1.2815 on Thursday. The British pound fell to $1.5680 from $1.5740.

HEADLINE: Mexico Says It Will Pay Loan Fees

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Mexican officials promised today that the huge package of loan guarantees announced by President Clinton Thursday night would not cost American taxpayers anything because Mexico would pay all the fees involved.
President Clinton's support, with the backing of Congressional leaders, helped the Mexican market to rally today by 4.6 percent, enough to recover losses from earlier in the week. The Mexican peso also strengthened again today as the American dollar fell. The peso closed at 5.25 to the dollar, well above the Thursday close of 5.495. 
 "This is not foreign aid," said a senior Mexican official who spoke about the loan guarantees on the condition that he not be identified. "This is not a transfer of money. It is not going to cost the U.S. taxpayers one cent."
Officials here would not disclose the size of the package, which is reported to run as high as $40 billion. This is in addition to an $18 billion credit line that the United States, Canada and several other countries recently created for Mexico.
If Mexico uses the guarantees, it will issue bonds underwritten by Wall Street and sold to banks and investors. Backed by the United States, Mexico would technically have to pay investors only the United States Treasury rate or a rate slightly higher.
At the moment, a one-year United States Treasury bill pays 6.44 percent interest. A one-year Mexican bond auctioned by Mexico on Tuesday, and pegged to the dollar exchange rate, offers almost 20 percent.
Mexico will also have to pay a fee to the United States for the risk that Mexico may default on the loans. The senior official would not give details on how much that fee would be. But he said Mexico would pay the fee from the proceeds of whatever money it borrowed. In essence, that is what many American homeowners do when they add a bank's origination fee, or points, to their mortgage.
The Mexican stock market ended a topsy-turvy week with a gain of 4.61 percent today. The price index closed at 2,100, up almost 98 points from the Thursday close.
This was a sharp turnabout from the beginning of the week, when the market was battered for consecutive days. Investors expressed doubt that the $18 billion credit line announced only last week was big enough to calm the Mexican market, which is reeling from the effects of a devaluation of the peso. In two days, the market plunged more than 12 percent.
Investor attitudes turned abruptly on Wednesday with news that Washington was willing to give Mexico additional financial assistance. By the end of the week, the exchange price index was 112.5 points above where it started on Monday.
The economic crisis in Mexico has shaken other markets around the world. During the week, rattled investors and fund managers who withdrew their money from Mexico also fled many other markets.
But as Mexico has regained lost ground, so have the other markets. "President Clinton's announcement immediately benefited the peso, which had a spillover effect in the rest of Latin America," said Thomas J. Trebat, head of emerging markets research at Chemical Bank in New York. "We saw strong buying in Mexico today not only by hedge funds, but also some of the big mutual funds."
While Mexico ended the week in a much stronger position than when it began, most analysts do not think the crisis has ended.
"From what we saw in the market today, the loan guarantees have been very positive, but there's a lot that has yet to be done," said Rafael Bello, a vice president at Morgan Stanley in New York. "They've got to go ahead with their privatization plans, continue to have very tight fiscal policy, and more."
But Guillermo Ortiz, the Mexican Finance Minister, said today that the American loan guarantees had not changed the Government's plans to introduce a new longer-term bond within the next two weeks to replace maturing bonds pegged to dollars. More than $25 billion worth of such bonds are outstanding, and the question of Mexico's ability to cover them was at the base of much of this week's uncertainty.
"We are going to take exactly the same steps that we mentioned we were going to take," Mr. Ortiz said in an interview. He acknowledged that the American loan guarantees might have produced enough investor confidence to make replacing the dollar-denominated bonds less urgent.
In a statement released today, Mexico's Finance Ministry indirectly addressed the members of the United States Congress who are trying to place conditions on the loan guarantee package, including a demand that Mexico use its oil resources as collateral.
The statement said Mexico was constitutionally prohibited from using the oil in that way, because it is the nation's sovereign property. But the Government has for 12 years used revenues from oil export sales, or anticipated revenues from such sales, in connection with several kinds of financial transactions.
