HEADLINE: ON WASHINGTON;
America's Front Lawn

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

 BODY:
AS IT BEGAN TO SLEET ON New Year's Eve, I was sitting on a bench across from the White House dreaming of Carole Lombard.
Watching the homeless who live in Lafayette Park drift around, I was reminded of "My Man Godfrey," the 1936 romp in which Lombard, as a madcap New York society girl, looks for a "forgotten man" in a scavenger hunt. Finding one (a down-at-the-heels William Powell) in a city dump on the East River, she offers him a job, asking blithely, "Can you butle?" 
 There are no screwball angels in Lafayette Park. Only a few well-dressed Washingtonians hurrying along the red brick paths. But the forgotten men and women camped near the statue of Andrew Jackson are a little less forgotten this winter. In the past few months, this quiet, pretty square has turned ominous and jittery. Like the scene in Disney's "Fantasia" scored to Mussorgsky's "Night on Bald Mountain," the park seems suddenly alive with macabre spirits, rising up and swirling around an unlucky White House.
"It has been a weird series of things, one after the other," says Bill Pugh, a 64-year-old Marine veteran from California who has made a bench in the southwest corner his home for a year and a half. "I'm beginning to get a little queasy about being here. We have a little rhyme that we put together: 'Now I lay me down in my bed, With the sounds of gunshots going off in my head.' "
Pugh presents himself as the Samuel Pepys of the park, witness to the eerie, violent goings-on. He recalls that he was sleeping on the ground one night in September when he was awakened by a "crunching, slamming" noise as a small plane crashed onto the South Lawn.
"About three minutes after that, this place was covered with every policeman you could think of: D.C. Government, Park Police, the Executive Protection Service, the Secret Service," he said, adding, with the savvy that comes from his milieu: "Actually, it was an F.A.A. slip-up."
Pugh says he was on his bench on Oct. 29 when he saw Francisco Duran stroll down Pennsylvania Avenue, pull a semiautomatic rifle from under his coat and fire through the north gate.
"Real tragic," he says, lighting a cigarette. "It's bad enough on the streets of New York or Los Angeles, but here in front of the White House, that's absolutely obscene."
In December, an unidentified gunman sprayed shots through the window of the State Dining Room. One man was arrested after making up a story about having a bomb in his car; another for trying to climb the north fence of the White House. And, in the most disturbing incident for those who live in the park, the Park Police shot and killed Marcelino Corniel, a homeless man who rushed across Pennsylvania Avenue waving a knife.
"It was a real shock, because he was the last guy we expected would do something like that," Mr. Pugh said. "He used to sit all day and sketch real-life scenes -- trees, birds, pigeons. He seldom spoke to anyone. But something snapped. The officers kept telling him to 'Drop the knife! Drop it!' But he wouldn't. It was just 'Bam! Bam!' "
Mr. Pugh, a compact man with ruddy skin and a yellowy white mustache, is wearing a maroon knit cap, and jeans and gloves with holes. Jazz squeaks from the Sony Walkman hanging around his neck. "My favorite was Stan Getz before he died," he says, waving off some young men offering peanut-butter-and-jelly sandwiches and Christian pamphlets. "Well, everybody loves Stan Getz."
Pugh says he is a retired master gunnery sergeant who served in World War II and the Korean War. He came here from his home in Marina del Rey, Calif., to have a knee operation at the Veterans Administration hospital, then lingered, watching the passing scene. He says he gets a Government stipend, but prefers to stay in the park so he can save money and go to restaurants.
The park has an anthropology every bit as complex as that of the executive mansion across the way. Bill Pugh gets along pretty well with the various cliques, except for one trio of paranoid brothers who accuse him of being a C.I.A. operative sent by William Colby. He tries to steer clear of "the front line" of less stable park residents who gather along Pennsylvania Avenue to receive messages from Mars coming through pots on their heads and to protest various causes, vendettas and conspiracies. (One conspiracy involves the C.I.A. building robotic sleds under the sea.)
Dwight Baird, 44, lying amid his sleeping bag, economic books and cardboard marked with swastikas, announces grandly: "They hate me because I'm white. And I hate them." And, at another point: "My family are fascists. In fact, I've sued them."
The park, which was the front lawn of the White House until Thomas Jefferson turned it over to the public, has long been a symbolic slice of reality in the unreal Federal city. Administration officials and media big shots who never venture into the murderous parts of the city walk through Lafayette Park on their way to lunch at the posh Bombay Club; they glance at the tame sprinkling of homeless people and feel that they've experienced the gritty side of Washington.
An extreme manifestation of this attitude came in 1989, when Government agents lured a drug dealer to the park so they could buy crack for President Bush to use as a prop in a televised speech on drugs. Speech writers wanted the President to be able to claim that drugs were being sold right outside the Oval Office.
Sometimes, as Presidents have grown isolated in crises, they have looked out the window and seen, in the park, the specter of their demise. During the Vietnam era, protesters shouted "Hey, hey, L. B. J., how many kids did you kill today?" as the anguished President stared back, asking advisers, "Why are they doing this to me?"
Not everyone appreciates the park's reputation for free speech. When protesters beat a drum round the clock to protest the Persian Gulf war, President Bush grumped to Republicans, "Those damned drums are keeping me up all night."
But now the mood has grown spooky. Frank J. Fahrenkopf, a former G.O.P. chairman, has demanded that the park be cleaned out so that Americans can "bring their kids to see the people's house without having bums abuse them or yell or scream or see people lying in their own filth."
Bill Pugh says he won't be around to see what happens. He was going to celebrate New Year's Eve at Mr. Egan's restaurant, a few blocks away. "I'll have the hot roast beef sandwich and a couple of drinks -- V.O.," he mused. "By midnight, everybody in the park will be pretty well drunk and will go to sleep.
"In a couple of days, I'm going back to California," he said. "It's been an educational experience. But now I'm getting the heck out of this place."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 20; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1158 words

HEADLINE: WORD & IMAGE;
Dysphemisms

BYLINE: By MAX FRANKEL 

 BODY:
THE START OF A NEW CONGRESS IS A good time to check on the current fashion in political euphemisms -- words that create a soothing image for what in more candid language would be harsh or offensive thought. The substitution of blunter expressions -- a few dysphemisms -- could be salutary.
For example, in the Capitol's changed climate (a liberal euphemism for now that the Republicans control both houses of Congress), you can expect to read and hear less about affirmative action, meaning reparation or compensation for past discrimination, and a lot more about tax breaks for capital gains, meaning the income that mostly rich people earn on certain kinds of investment. You can also expect a lively struggle over words that describe new issues; when referring to certain aliens, some politicians and members of the media will insist on calling them illegal while others cling to undocumented. 
 Not all euphemisms serve a political purpose (propaganda), but many help to conceal a political credibility problem (lie). And some of the most noteworthy evasions have been employed so successfully over a long period of time that they have become embedded in political culture, with hardly a challenge from even the most aggressive (politicians prefer hostile) media. It's those ingrown euphemisms that really hurt.
It would require dangerous idiomatic surgery, for example, to rid the body politic of the term "campaign contribution." Yet when the heads of a business or professional society explain to their stockholders or members why their Washington lobbyist has written such large checks to candidates for Congress, they portray the payment not as a contribution but as an investment. They rarely use the word investment, however, because it so plainly implies the uncomfortable truth that the money has been advanced with the expectation of a profitable return -- a legislative maneuver or vote that serves the economic interest of the donor. Even the possibility of such a return might then tempt the media to be more consistently enterprising in ferreting out the patterns of exchange. And before long, the "contribution" that had become an "investment" would be widely perceived and properly described as a bribe.
Anyone who still doubts that campaign financing has become an organized, institutionalized form of bribery should consider what happened after the election of the new Congress, when major contributors found they had guessed wrong by mistakenly putting most of their money on Democrats. Plainly frightened by the unmistakable Republican threats of retribution -- donors "not on board" were said to have been warned of "the two coldest years in Washington" (extortion?) -- these investors lined up to offer post-election tribute to the winners, whose overdrawn campaign accounts (deficit financing?) were generously kept open for late-comers. Dan Morgan, a consultant looking to help new House members retire campaign debts, told The Washington Post that "a lot of PAC's are saying, 'Whoops, we made a mistake,' and they're trying to redeem themselves" (buy their way back into favor).
In canvassing some of these tardy investors, Michael Weisskopf of The Post found several patterns. "We don't really look at it as an eraser on the pencil [expiation]," said John McKechnie, the political director of the Credit Union National Association, "but as a way of letting the winner know we'd like to be the same friend to [beneficiary of] him as we were to the guy he defeated."
Alfred Gilchrist of the Texas Medical Association offered a further illumination: "You want to let them know your support for the other person wasn't hostile to them. When you get on the late train, it's usually the most expensive ticket." (They really sock it to you when you've missed the boat.)
A further wrinkle was (almost) revealed by Teena Cregan, the chief lobbyist for the National Association of Postmasters. "We'll certainly be looking around to see who is in a leadership position we can work with," she said, meaning, We like to hold back some money till we know which legislators land on the committees that can help us the most.
A FINANCIALLY CHALLENGED POLITICIAN LIKE President Clinton, who is not currently collecting campaign "contributions," can find similar euphemistic refuge in the word "gifts." The ethics laws permit the First Family to accept unsolicited gifts; they were written to accommodate foreign potentates who tender expensive tribute to our Chief of State and ordinary Americans who enjoy sharing trinkets with their President. Surely unintended, but therefore apparently legal, is the President's receipt of substantial gifts of cash.
Thus, when the investigations of Whitewater and Paula Jones's charges of sexual harassment (propositioning?) threatened the Clintons with huge legal expenses, they established a "legal defense fund" to gather gifts of up to $1,000 from concerned Friends of Bill -- mostly lobbyists. Yet even that strategy failed to achieve the goal of millions, so the faithful are searching for a new name for the fund, one that would sanction more active and direct White House solicitation. Little Rock FOB Fund?
Of course, if the President's plight were dysphemistically described as that of a potentially indigent defendant, his needs could be met much more ethically. He could seek the help of a few pro bono lawyers who would, out of conviction or sympathy, see him through these trials without fee. Only a handful of individuals would then incur the President's debt, and watching these few for any sign of a future payoff would be a lot simpler for the media than watching thousands of vaguely identified donors.
 I SHOULD NOT LEAVE THE IMPRESSION that only politicians enjoy a good euphemism. The rest of the citizenry will as easily rise to linguistic bait.
For more than a decade now the voters have rewarded any office-seeker who promises a tax reduction, and the 1996 contenders, led by the President, are in full cry. Judging by the media enthusiasm for these "middle-class tax cuts" (bribes of voters?), you'd think that thousands of dollars instead of a few hundred per family, at most, were in the offing. And hardly anyone has been so rude as to call the proposals a tax expenditure, that is, a proposal to have the Federal Government borrow still more money at rising interest rates to pay the cost of the tax "cut."
A few news reports, it is true, will occasionally observe that any tax reduction would increase the deficit, whose decrease was so recently the object of universal political concern. And fewer still will estimate or, as is customary, underestimate the amount of the added deficit. Most of the media will simply relay the daily babble about the coming "tax cut," grateful perhaps to leave the era of tax increases that were fobbed off by the FOB's last year as spending cuts and in some quarters even as revenue enhancements.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Finding the Bargains Amid the Peso's Decline

BYLINE: By ANTHONY De PALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
AT last count, the battered Mexican peso had lost somewhere near 40 percent of its value against the dollar in less than a month.. Although it may seem predatory to think of bargains while Mexicans are trying to recover from the economic shock of the devaluation, the misfortune of America's neighbor opens a world of possibilities for travelers -- at least for the short term -- especially those willing to explore.
As of Jan. 9, one peso was worth less than 20 cents. If the Government's emergency plan to rescue the economy can be enforced, prices on most items that have not been imported will stay about where they were before the peso dropped. 
 That means that a 200-peso meal for two at Lorenzillo's in Cancun that would have cost a visitor $59 before the devaluation in December now goes for $36. A 75-peso leather hat in Ciudadela market in Mexico City used to cost $22. Now it costs the equivalent of about $13.50.
Of course, no economic stabilization plan can guarantee that prices will not increase, and it's easy for a government to lose control of inflation. Import prices will rise as quickly as the value of the peso falls, and any business that takes in and pays out dollars has started to jack up prices.
Airline tickets to and from the United States are paid in dollars, but Mexican airlines that fly from, say, Mexico City to Guadalajara charge in pesos. Mexicana, one of the country's largest airlines, has said it will not raise fares inside Mexico. The Mexico City-Guadalajara round trip now costs 614 pesos, around $110, down from $180 before devaluation in mid-December.
But in some instances -- for hotel rooms, for example -- prices will not change. In Cancun, room rates at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel have always been in dollars, $245 a night for double occupancy in the January off-season. Patricia Lopez Mancera, a hotel spokeswoman, says room prices will stay exactly where they are. But in the hotel's restaurants, where the prices are in pesos, prices went up about 15 percent on Jan. 1.
The Four Seasons hotel in Mexico City, which bases its rates on pesos, tagged an extra 15 percent on room prices Jan. 1. And some auto rental companies have already increased prices 10 percent.
Still, the cost of a Mexican vacation has dropped substantially. The Mexican Department of Tourism estimates that the devaluation will enable Mexico to increase the number of visitors from the United States by 9 percent, to 7.6 million this year.
Places like Cancun, where 85 percent of tourists are Americans, should see the biggest influx of visitors. But shopkeepers there know that those Americans have dollars that are worth more now, and will be tempted to increase prices or raise their bargaining threshold.
Kirk Whisler, publisher of Mexico Events magazine, suggests that the greatest values will be found away from the crowds. "The colonial cities outside Mexico City are going to be much more economical," he said.
With the value of the peso fluctuating daily, it is worth noting that American Express calculates the exchange rate not on the day a purchase is made, but on the day American Express receives the charge slip.
Finding the right place to change dollars into pesos also can make a substantial difference. Hotels generally have the worst rates. Surprisingly, the exchange booths at the airport in Mexico City are more competetive than most banks. Automated teller machines, if you can find them, generally have the best rates. Mexico doesn't really have a street-corner black market in dollars like other Latin American capitals.
Taxis in the capital are among the bargains -- they have not yet recalibrated their meters. And the innumerable vendors who sell chewing gum at every other corner still charge 1 peso for a box of Chiclets. Because most museums are run by the Government, admission fees can be expected to hold. And the Mexico City subway, clean and quiet, still charges 40 centavos for a limitless ride. That now comes to 8 cents.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1947 words

HEADLINE: POP VIEW;
Newt Age Music

BYLINE: By JON PARELES 

 BODY:
Legislature sets the stage,
Social slaves caught in my rage
 -- Slayer, "Dittohead" 
 AS THE 104TH CONGRESS considers the state of the Union this week, its new Republican majority won't be thinking much about popular music. Oh, maybe another cop-hating rapper will set off an outburst of law-and-order posturing, or the fallout from last year's hearings on Ticketmaster's business practices will allow legislators to act like consumer advocates. But the Congress that has set out to champion what Newt Gingrich, the new Speaker of the House, calls "normal people" probably won't want to go anywhere near the pierced, dreadlocked, angry and angst-laden legions involved in popular music. The odd thing is that the theme of both the new Congress and mid-1990's rock is the same: Revenge of the 'Burbs.
The 1990 census figures showed that a majority of Americans now live in suburbs. The 1994 elections were dominated by white male suburbanites among the 35 percent of the electorate that voted. The Republicans who control the new Congress have interpreted the election results as a mandate for suburban secession: redirecting perceived advantages from cities to suburbs, adding tax breaks and slashing social programs and controlling crime through tougher sanctions. Pop doesn't march or dance in lockstep with electoral politics; nobody's writing hits about welfare cuts or capital-gains tax breaks. But pop reacts to the same cultural currents that sway elections. And in recent years, the pop charts -- themselves a kind of poll on esthetics and attitudes -- have also turned suburban. Punk and hip-hop, the two lasting revolutions of the 1970's, were urban movements, but commercial and musical momentum is now generated outside the cities.
The pop juggernauts of the 1990's for the adult market have been persevering baby-boomer icons and a suburbanized version of country music. Younger consumers have endorsed the mall-rat alienation of grunge and neo-punk, the flailing bitterness of thrash metal and the nonchalant machismo of West Coast rap. The only potential crossovers come from decorous black crooners like Toni Braxton and Boyz II Men, who deliver come-ons and promises of romantic fulfillment, a perennial pop function.
For grown-ups, 1990's pop delivers familiarity and down-home comfort, the sonic equivalent of shag carpet and the recliner. For younger people, pop refracts suburban apathy through brattiness, despair and vicarious brutality; it's a food fight at the food court.
The suburbs mean comfort and isolation, a chance to sample the resources of the city without having to put up with urban noise, squalor and diversity. Geographically and economically as well as culturally, suburbs are defined by their separation from the dangerous and depressing city. They are as much refuges as communities.
Prototypical urban music is pitched to motley crowds and public gatherings, and to build its audience it tries to provide something for everybody. The suburban life carries music out of the public sphere and into the private one. In suburbia, music is enjoyed in cars, in basements, in bedrooms and on cable television. (Music on television, especially, has eliminated the need to visit cities for the latest updates.) The audience is large, but it's atomized; listening mostly takes place alone or with a handful of neighbors, not with strangers. The music calls for cult solidarity instead of one-world dreams.
In current pop, most older listeners want nothing to do with the modern city's frenzy of stimulation or its constant change. They're "normal" and proud of it; other people can be hip. While their radio stations promise as much exclusivity as the best neighborhoods -- "no rap, no hard rock" -- they stick with old favorites, snapping up brand names like Pink Floyd, the Eagles and Eric Clapton.
Or they turn to modern country music, which has abandoned the stark fatalism and troubled faith of country tradition. Good-timey songs about lovin' and cheatin' and dancin' survive, sung by telegenic young men who look as if they wear their cowboy hats to ride the lawnmower. Garth Brooks, the commercial success story of the 1990's, is an avowed fan of Billy Joel, the bard of suburban Long Island; Brooks's songs are domestic dramas that blend down-home country, 1970's pop-folk delicacy and arena-rock pomp. Mary Chapin Carpenter, a million-selling, nominally country performer who sings without a Southern twang, praises the harried suburban housewife in songs like "He Thinks He'll Keep Her."
Country songs have generally avoided grand statements and rather focused on individual stories. When modern country does venture to suggest a community, it envisions honest working men (and, much more rarely, working women) who long for the good old days when harmonious families lived in idealized small towns. It's the same all-American mythos conjured up by Republican rhetoric.
Country performers aren't necessarily party-line conservatives. In 1992, Brooks interrupted his long string of No. 1 country singles to release "We Shall Be Free," a song that insisted on the freedom to "love anyone we choose." Yet despite projects like "Rhythm, Country and Blues" (a hit 1994 album of duets for country and soul singers), country remains almost entirely segregated in both audiences and performers; there are more successful white rappers than there are black country singers. And only in current country music could Tim McGraw make his album a multimillion-selling hit with a single like "Indian Outlaw": "You can find me in my wigwam, I'll be beatin' on my tom-tom."
A diverse city audience might well hoot down such old-fashioned stereotypes. But country songs don't think about cities; their gathering place, for the proverbial Saturday night honky-tonking, is down on the farm or, for sophistication, in the town. Geography aside, the city is a long way away.
Younger suburbanites aren't as sure that they want to avoid the city. For them, suburban calm breeds boredom; isolation leaves them wondering what they're missing. At the very least, surburban album buyers want just enough grit to connote urban authenticity: some abrasive feedback, perhaps, or the latest in gangster slang, or a chance to gather by the thousands and feel rebellious for the annual Lollapalooza tour. They want something that will break through suburban complacency because they don't feel satisfied.
Can suburbs produce new musical ideas as well as consume them? That question hasn't been answered yet. Music has already been factionalizing, with each genre spawning subgenres. Suburban seclusion may accelerate the process, offering fewer opportunities for disparate styles to meet.
If recent history is any guide, a return to conservative economics and Republican moralizing may re-energize the most hostile strains in popular music. Through the 1980's and early 1990's, the Reagan and Bush administrations nurtured rock's angriest genres. Against the official veneer of optimism and 1950's niceness, rock (and increasingly violent horror and action-adventure movies) insisted that rampant self-interest would make for losers as well as winners. Intuitively, people in their teens and 20's may have guessed they'd be stuck with the bill for the high-living 1980's.
THROUGH THE LAST DECADE, thrash bands like Metallica and Slayer created doom-laden narratives about the forces of death -- psychotic killers, war, apocalypse -- as the music virtuosically bludgeoned listeners, insisting that malevolent forces were arrayed against them. Multimillion-selling hard rockers like Guns 'n' Roses lashed out in all directions, offering Reaganite individualism at its Darwinian extreme: "Welcome to the jungle," Axl Rose shrieked. In the song "One in a Million," Rose flaunted prejudices against blacks and immigrants, those longtime urban scapegoats; facing criticism, he later claimed that he was merely speaking in the voice of an invented character, someone straight off the bus in the big city.
Hard rock was music for suburban youth who would be servicing the new service economy, future keypunch operators and fry cooks. If frustration led nowhere, at least they could sing along with the the worst news. Other young rock fans supported a nationwide, grass-roots hard-core movement, in both cities and suburbs, forming punky local bands to bash out complaints. They helped punk-rock survive, below the radar of radio stations and major labels, until its momentum could not be denied. With upgraded melodic skills and musical proficiency, the eventual result was bands like Green Day, which sold three million copies of its third album, "Dookie," in 1994. In one of Green Day's most popular songs, "Welcome to Paradise," Billie Joe, its guitarist, sings a series of letters to Mom. She's back in the suburbs; he has moved to the scary but thrilling city.
Drawing on both hard rock and punk-rock, collegiate types turned suburban malaise and uncertainty inward to create alternative rock, with its complaints, defensive noise, arty tangents and self-mocking irony. As the music trickled out of college towns in the 1980's, suburbanites embraced the ambiguities of R.E.M. and the hypersensitive confessions of Morrissey. And as the Bush Administration wound down, the suburban millions transformed college-town diversions into its own anthems of aimlessness and despair, hurtling bands like Nirvana and Pearl Jam into the top 10. Although grungewear's flannel shirts are already passe in big cities, and rock bands wouldn't think of wearing one, suburban teen-agers flaunt them like uniforms.
Hip-hop, meanwhile, saw its commercial initiative transferred from rap's birthplace, New York City, to the suburban sprawl of southern California. The virtuosic wordplay and noise collages of New York rap, echoing the urban information barrage, gave way on the charts to styles more easily decipherable to outsiders. The rappers slowed down, the music grew smoother and more cinematic, and the words increasingly focused on gangster exploits, from entrepreneurship in the crack trade to sexual boasts to gunplay. Although hip-hop as a whole still offers myriad messages, most of its commercial pace setters are now gangster rappers.
Early gangster rap may have provided a dose of artful reportage, a vision from within the urban purgatory and a reminder of the results of decreased Federal support to cities. But in recent years, the style has become nearly formulaic, and it increasingly functions to provide thrills from a distance to listeners who wouldn't dream of visiting South-Central Los Angeles. More and more raps warn people who aren't from the ghetto to stay out. But through gangster rap, suburbanites can purchase a vision of the inner city that suits their most alarmist fantasies, where belligerent young men carry guns, the women are irresponsible tramps or welfare mothers, and the police are despised and ineffectual. It's as scary as any 1994 campaign advertisement.
Fear of the city is inseparable from fascination; the city may be perceived as deadly, but it's not dull. And denial of the city, as heard in current country, leads to resentment when urban problems won't just go away. The suburbs remain dependent on the cities, but that dependence creates friction.
One of 1994's left-field hits -- released on a small independent label by a new band from Chicago -- was Veruca Salt's "Seether." In it, Nina Gordon and Louise Post sing about an anger that won't be held back, no matter how hard they try. "Seether is the center of it all," they sing. "Can't fight the seether." Tell it to the Democrats.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 28; Column 5; Arts & Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1499 words

HEADLINE: POP MUSIC;
A Saxophonist Who Doesn't Wear Armani

BYLINE: By JOSEPH HOOPER 

 BODY:
BEGINNING IN THE EARLY 80's, the trumpeter Wynton Marsalis rejuvenated and refashioned jazz in his own dapper, neo-conservative image. Thanks to Mr. Marsalis's talent, ambition and marketability, jazz became very hospitable to dexterous young black men who looked great in Armani suits. So who could have predicted that a leading voice on tenor saxophone among the under-50 set would belong to Joe Lovano, a heavyset 43-year-old Italian-American with a receding hairline and a goatee?
It may be considered an act of bad faith to divide the jazz world along racial lines, jazz being America's great monument to racial synthesis. But the simple fact is, Mr. Lovano sticks out. He will play the Village Vanguard for six nights beginning on Tuesday, and if past gigs are any indication, he will sell out the club for virtually every show. 
 Not since Stan Getz has a white tenor sax player been taken seriously as a prime exponent of the instrument. But Getz enjoyed his peak popularity in the 50's and early 60's, when the top white players profited financially from the racial chauvinism of white audiences willing and able to ignore the black giants of jazz. Today the jazz audience as a whole is even whiter, but the racial preference has been turned upside down. In marketing terms, young black or mixed-race horn players like Roy Hargrove and Joshua Redman, as well a rediscovered elder like Joe Henderson, have a near lock on the middle-of-the-road jazz market, while white players find more visibility at the extremes of the esthetic spectrum, in the pop-fusion of Kenny G. or the arty downtown jazz typified by John Zorn.
Mr. Lovano may have the distinction of being a white man who has made it in a black man's world, but race itself does not make much of a case for musical importance. His recordings attest to that. Whether as a sideman in the drummer Paul Motion's trio or the guitarist John Scofield's quartet or as a leader of his own groups, Mr. Lovano has made his way onto a startling number of exceptional albums over the past two decades. On the tenor, his voice is readily identifiable, affecting without being especially pretty. Often he'll move back and forth between an earthy, barrelhouse tone in the lower register and a drier, querulous one in the upper, the sound of raw cotton rubbing against metal. "He plays modern ideas," the pianist John Hicks says of his sometime collaborator, "but his sound encompasses the history of the tenor sax."
It is the very richness of that history that has conditioned jazz fans to seek out that saxophonist who will usher in the next glorious age. But no younger sax player dominates the current scene in the manner of a Charlie Parker or a John Coltrane. Instead of giants, there are question marks. Mr. Redman, whom Mr. Lovano featured on his most recent album, "Tenor Legacy," is selling CD's by the gross, but is he too young and too glib? Will Branford Marsalis ever end his agonized dance with popular culture?
Clearly the cognoscenti who flock to Mr. Lovano's engagements at the Vanguard want to believe that his free-jazz inflections suggest an alternative to the prevailing orthodox hard-bop. But the Vanguard is a small church and Mr. Lovano's four well-reviewed, modest-selling albums on Blue Note haven't reached much beyond it. His next two releases, "Rush Hour," an orchestral collaboration with the celebrated composer and scholar Gunther Schuller, due out on Feb. 7, and "Live at the Vanguard," which will come out this summer, may well determine whether Mr. Lovano will ever gain a purchase on the popular imagination.
IN PERSON, THERE IS AN ursine solidity about Joe Lovano that would be intimidating if he were not famous in the jazz community for being the gentlest of men. Others may be obsessed with matters like race or commerce; he would rather talk about the joys of communal art that he discovered in 1978 when he moved into his funky-elegant Chelsea loft. "I had my friends, I had musical concepts I wanted to work on," he says. "My loft became one of those scenes."
Two years later, his musical circle expanded to include Judi Silverman, who was trained in classical voice and modern dance. Before long, they and their friends were putting on regular performances at the Washington Square Church in Greenwich Village. "I would sing a piece in leotards and then the dancers and I would do a piece I had choreographed," recalls Judi Silvano, who changed her name after she and Mr. Lovano married in 1984. Mr. Lovano adds, "We played some beautiful things." Where cynics might see a Jules Feiffer cartoon, Mr. Lovano finds a sustaining bohemian idealism. His 1993 album, "Universal Language," features Ms. Silvano's soprano voice pitched at weird angles against his horn -- interesting but, unapologetically, not for everybody.
These days, Mr. Lovano is the General Motors of jazz. He has his two avant-gardish groups, the Universal Language Ensemble and Symbiosis, as well as a quartet and a quintet that hew more closely to the ideal of hard-blowing modern jazz. But the 75-year-old gongs from Wuhan, China, that dominate the entrance to the Lovano loft suggest that nothing that produces tones is truly foreign to him.
This past April, Mr. Lovano was closeted in the recording studio with an assemblage of 23 string, brass and woodwind players and Mr. Schuller, the 1994 Pulitzer Prize winner in music composition. Two years ago, Mr. Lovano had heard one of Mr. Schuller's classical chamber pieces and had conceived the idea of returning with the maestro to his early-60's experiments in Third Stream music, folding improvisation into longer, composed pieces.
Owing to the straitened economies of jazz record labels, the entire process of rehearsing and recording had to be telescoped into two days. Mr. Schuller occupied center stage grandly, if wildly, furiously copying out parts during lunch breaks. Mr. Lovano was partitioned in a glass booth, given the barely conceivable job of sight reading the parts, following Mr. Schuller's baton and improvising with and against the sound of the ensemble being fed to him via headphones. Somehow, he served all masters. He blew through the manic-depressive mood swings and the jostling polyphony of Mr. Schuller's compositions and his arrangements of pieces by classic jazz composers like Duke Ellington and Thelonious Monk. "Joe just picks up everything," Mr. Schuller says.
BLUE NOTE IS NOT unaware that Mr. Lovano's brainstorm is its marketing opportunity to take him out of the commercial ghetto of hard-core jazz and show him off in a tonier crossover neighborhood. "Does this mean that Lovano is going to be the big success in white jazz?" asks Bob Belden, a tenor saxophonist and arranger for Blue Note. "Probably not. His roots are in his family tradition and in the working-class communities of the Rust Belt, white and black."
While "Rush Hour" might be seen as an elaboration of the white jazz tradition that emphasized harmony and the melodic line, Mr. Belden is right that no one is going to mistake Mr. Lovano for the tenor saxophone's answer to the trumpeter Chet Baker. Mr. Lovano's roots are in complex, aggressive rhythm. Before his stint as a 23-year-old soloist with the Woody Herman big band, he had played rhythm-and-blues-inflected jazz with the organists Lonnie Smith and Jack MacDuff. He was in the distinct minority of white players on the so-called chitlin circuit of black jazz joints. "That was a trip," he recalls, "but I was accepted because I was in the band."
His most important teacher, however, was his father, Tony (Big T) Lovano, a Cleveland barber and an accomplished club tenor player. "My father had a beautiful, big sound that was coming from the Illinois Jacquet school," he says, "but it also had Lester Young elements when he played a ballad. I had stuff to reach for right there in the room with me. Not just from a record." In his early teens, he sat in for his father on wedding gigs and spent evenings drinking Cokes in the Smiling Dog Saloon, his father's favorite jazz club, absorbing some of the more adventurous jazz that still informs his playing.
In contrast to peers like Branford Marsalis who, for better or worse, have to wrestle with earlier allegiances to rock and funk, nothing but jazz ever registered with Mr. Lovano. The purity, and the severity, of that conception is perhaps most striking on the forthcoming "Live at the Vanguard." Listening to passages where he is playing a keening tenor with one hand and accompanying himself on the gongs with the other, one gets the feeling that Mr. Lovano is moving forward by reaching back to the early 60's, the free jazz of Ornette Coleman. "For a long time, my practicing was more a technical thing," Mr. Lovano says, "and then at a certain point it turned into a meditation." At that level of artistic engagement, issues of race and class, however instructive, dissolve, and what is left is the hard-won, deeply felt music.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 33; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 859 words

HEADLINE: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;
Gleaming Baubles That Could Make A King Envious

BYLINE: By RITA REIF 

 BODY:
NOT SINCE THE BLOCKBUSTER auction of King Farouk's paperweights in Cairo in 1954 has a collection as celebrated come on the market. Now, the New-York Historical Society is selling 500 glass paperweights from a collection that while slightly smaller in size, is more comprehensive than that of the Egyptian monarch.
The sale will be held on Wednesday at Sotheby's in Manhattan and is expected to bring about $1 million. Proceeds from the auction will go to the society's endowment for maintaining its vast collection of books, paintings and furnishings. While approved by the State Attorney General, the society's decision to sell art and objects from its collection has been widely criticized. 
 Praised for decades as one of the finest in public hands, the paperweight collection consists of items made between 1845 and 1960 in France, the United States, England and China. Virtually every known 19th- and 20th-century maker and type is represented. The insect and floral fantasies, prancing horses and glorious pinwheels of color include some outsize ones, up to four inches in diameter and a variety of shapes: ovals, hexagonals, doorknobs, pitchers and bottles.
Most of the paperweights in the collection, like glazed plums, rock candy and petits fours under glass, look good enough to eat. Even those depicting miniature gardens and starry skies seem squeezed from tubes of cake frosting. And those topped by relief portraits in white clay of Napoleon, Queen Victoria, Benjamin Franklin and Washington appear to be carved of sugar.
The oldest paperweight is an egg-shaped hand cooler, which was made at St. Louis, a factory in the French province of Lorraine, and is signed and dated "S.L. 1845," the year glass paperweights were first produced. It is expected to command a hefty $9,000. "The date, its oval shape and the use of glass canes that do not appear in later weights explain the high price," said Lauren K. Tarshis, Sotheby's paperweight specialist.
Miss Tarshis said she chose in this catalogue to describe the condition of any altered or damaged piece as an aid to bidders who cannot view the paperweights in person or to speak with Sotheby's representatives. Paperweights that are refaceted, reground or repolished with chips or bruises are expected to bring one-tenth to one-half the prices of unflawed pieces. But the rarest ones may still fetch four- and five-figure prices.
An unusual American piece, for example, a peach-colored dahlia paperweight by the Mt. Washington Glass Works of Boston, while cracked inside, may sell for $20,000, half what it might bring if perfect. And two rare but flawed French paperweights -- a blue trumpet-shaped flower on a lattice ground and a multiwindowed glass ball with a nosegay in the center -- are expected to bring less than $10,000 each.
The paperweights up for bidding are expected to range in price from a low of $100 for a group of five paperweights, including one from China depicting yellow birds on a red tree, to a high of $25,000 for a large clear glass paperweight centered by a bouquet of velvety violets and tinier wild flowers.
And just in case other New York museums wish to buy at this sale, the Attorney General has approved what is called preemptive bidding, which allows museums to override the winning bids and purchase the works at discounts below the hammer price.
Paperweights, which were sold in the mid-19th century for pennies, or at most $12, have been auctioned for much higher prices than Sotheby's estimates for anything offered in this sale. The record for a paperweight is $258,500, a figure paid in 1990 at Sotheby's in New York for a rare basket-shaped work from Clichy, a Paris producer.
Not all of the museum's paperweights are being sold, said Philip Zimmerman, the society's acting curator of decorative arts. About 35 are being retained by the society as a record of the type of objects New Yorkers collected. Many of these -- and the majority of those in the sale -- were acquired in the 1920's and 1930's by Jennie H. Sinclair of Manhattan, the widow of Francis McDonald Sinclair, a producer of printing inks. She bought them on trips abroad and in New England and left more than 400 to the society at her death in 1965.
Whatever she paid, the sums would seem small today. The Farouk sale of predominantly French paperweights was organized by Sotheby's in Cairo two years after the king was overthrown and brought what were then considered record prices of up to $850 each. All 600 were sold, glutting the market and creating a 10-year recession in paperweight sales as prices plummeted. By 1970, a new generation of buyers was happily paying 30 times the figures realized at the Farouk sale.
Will this sale spark another downturn in the paperweight market?
"Probably not," said Homer Perkins, president of the Paperweights Collectors Association, an international organization based in East Hampton, Mass. There are many more collectors actively buying today, he said. Since 1980, the association's membership has doubled, to 1,600. And there are buyers out there who are so competitive they never join any organization.

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
On-Line Property Listings

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS 

 BODY:
LUCILLE BOCCHICCHIO, a management consultant who has developed a reputation as a computer whiz, was recently asked by a friend if there was a way to list his East 59th Street co-op apartment on an electronic bulletin board.
The result was the "for sale" announcement (co-op, East 59th Street, 2 beds, 2 baths, asking $215,000) that appeared on CompuServe's residential listings all last week. Costing just $1 per line per week, it certainly started the phones ringing. 
 Similarly, Iris Engelson, a general manager at a computer software company in Millburn, N.J., bypassed the usual sources such as brokers and newspaper ads when she recently became interested in comparing mortgage rates for the 2-bedroom apartment she is seeking on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.
"I didn't want to rely only on brokers," she said. "And I certainly didn't have the time to start calling around to all the banks." So she sat down at her computer and during a routine cruise of the Internet for mortgage-related information she stumbled upon the mortgage advisory services of HSH Associates in nearby Butler, N.J.
Using the HSH toll-free number, along with her own credit card number, Ms. Engelson was then able to order an instant E-mail copy of HSH's latest weekly comparative listing of mortgages in the area where she was making her purchase. Time spent was only 30 minutes. The cost of the print-out was $10. And there were no access charges since she has log-on privileges through her business (otherwise expect to pay about $4 or so per hour).
Anyone interested in buying, renting, financing or selling a property might also do well to think seriously about cruising cyberspace for the sort of information that once required endless legwork, phone calls and the purchase of many magazines or newspapers.
Although on-line services connected with residential real estate are still in their infancy -- and may therefore occasionally produce irritating solicitations from anxious vendors rather than actual facts or customers -- there is now enough good stuff on the electronic byways to make an on-line trek well worthwhile.
For example, some on-line services offer access to discussions with specialists who are not subject to the sorts of potential conflicts of interest faced by someone who will directly benefit from a specific deal. "People like to exchange information with someone who's not part of the selling process," said Peter Miller of Silver Spring, Md., a former real estate broker and author of numerous books on mortgages and home buying. He answers questions on America OnLine.
Other experts include such people as Julian Block, a highly respected tax attorney in Larchmont, N.Y., who regularly writes consumer-oriented books on taxes and real estate. He can be reached on Prodigy.
But limitations should be anticipated. For example, America OnLine (AOL), CompuServe and Prodigy all promote the fact that they offer "classified" listings of homes for sale. But as yet there are just a scant few to choose from -- which could be good for the seller but awful for a buyer.
Last week on AOL, for example, only 153 entries were posted for the entire state of New York, with just 29 for all of Connecticut. CompuServe similarly offered only 72 in its combined New York/New Jersey category and just 4 in Connecticut (which it lumps with most other states on the Eastern seaboard). Prodigy, with 1,618 properties listed in New York State and a total of 32,000 listed nationally, may currently have the most.
It may also not be clear whether the contact person is an agent or the seller (for-sale-by-owner), although the distinction is supposed to be noted. For example, a contemporary home ostensibly listed by a Charles Bull of East Hampton, L.I., on CompuServe last week turned out to have been the contact phone number of the local Coldwell Banker real estate office.
The office, which confirmed that it carried the listing, later apologized for the mix-up. It was not intended to deceive, it insisted, but rather due to its inexperience with the medium.
Ms. Bocchicchio, the management consultant, also felt she had been drawn into an electronic blind alley when many of her return calls started coming from services, such as movers and brokers, rather than from potential buyers. She said she had thus learned the importance of adding "interested parties only -- no vendors or brokers."
But reaching brokers or vendors may not be all that bad. Pollock & Williams, a real estate agency in Darien, Conn., ran into similar problems even though it was itself an agency. But it is planning to regularly list properties anyway.
David Epprecht, a broker with the firm, maintains there are indeed customers out there in electronic land. But, he said, "I haven't yet had calls from anyone except other brokers." Still, he argued, it draws attention to the properties. And the potential customer base is enlarging daily as these services expand at a rapid clip. America OnLine already says it has 1.2 million members.
Probably the most useful part of the current on-line real estate services are the data banks offering relocation information such as the demographics of a particular community or neighborhood.
CompuServe is especially strong in this area. It can provide Bureau of the Census data based on ZIP codes that can identify average household income and age of the local population, among other facts. Prodigy allows a subscriber to post a notice asking for another subscriber living in a community to discuss its pros and cons.
Browsers can also order "school match" information that can provide statistical information and standardized scores for the community's public and private schools. Most of the on-line services also offer access to local newspapers, which may further provide a window into a particular community.
And they also provide a mortgage calculator option that allows someone to figure out monthly costs instantly based on a number of variables, such as the size of the loan, the interest rate and term.
Further, virtually all of them have become more user-friendly, providing easy access to the various categories of information through the simple use of point-and-click graphic icons, the entering of key words or making selections from main menus.
Useful key words at CompuServe include: "homefinders," "demographics," "classified," "newspapers" and "mortgages." At America OnLine its easiest to start with the key words "real estate" and then choose more specific topics from its general menu of real estate topics. At Prodigy click on "jump" and type "real estate center."
Other on-line services with real estate components include Delphi (800-544-4005; GEnie (800-638-9636); Whole Earth 'Lectronic Link (WELL) (415-332-4335). America OnLine can be reached at (800) 827-6364; CompuServe at (800) 848-8199 and Prodigy at (800) 822-6922.

HEADLINE: Converting Brownstone Homes Into Office Space

BYLINE: By DAVID J. WALLACE 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
A SOFT real estate market and a spate of vacancies have created opportunities for small companies and bargain-seeking investors to convert private brownstone homes to other uses, real-estate agents say.
Such conversions, from homes to offices or stores, and even back again, have altered the landscape of Center City's narrow streets for more than 300 years, since William Penn began his Colonial real estate development. But the steady pace of conversions in recent years, real-estate professionals say, has created a buyer's market. 
 One reason for the vacancies, said Larry Isard, president of the Isard-Greenberg Company, which specializes in downtown properties, is that many businesses have moved to the suburbs to escape the city's nearly 5 percent wage tax and the inconveniences of traffic or parking.
Another reason, Mr. Isard said, is the changing fortunes of the small companies that occupy the brownstones. They can grow or shrink unexpectedly, require bigger quarters or even go out of business.
And the demand for these properties may be cooling, brokers say, as some companies compare the cost of taxes and maintenance with the flexibility of renting. But there are still other concerns that prefer the long-term advantages of owning their own building and of controlling their own space.
For companies wanting to locate in town, Mr. Isard said, prices for private buildings can range between $60 and $100 a square foot, depending on size and amenities.
Most of the conversions are separated from the central business district by a three-block buffer zone designated by the Philadelphia City Planning Commission. The buffer zone, between the high-rise office towers on Market Street, the city's main east-west thoroughfare, and the residential areas as close as four blocks away, includes Chestnut, Walnut and Locust Streets. Most brownstone buildings are at the edges of the roughly three-square-mile downtown area; many are on Locust, Spruce and Pine Streets, including some in the buffer zone. Commercial activity is permitted in the zone, but there are limits on building size and the shape of offices.
BUILDINGS usually are not demolished to make way for commercial use, but renovated to open up office spaces and hallways that were not part of the original design. At the edges of the city's center, some buildings have apartments above storefronts or street-level offices, while others are used entirely as corporate addresses for architects, lawyers, consultants and other business professionals.
Such shifts keep the city vital and help it to maintain its small-town scale, said Otto Sperr, a restoration architect who lives and works near Rittenhouse Square.
"It's an interesting mix of people and users," Mr. Sperr said. "The commercial uses go quiet at night. But its an ongoing renewal and redevelopment in a neighborhood that's had its ups and downs."
One law firm that recently opted for a brownstone address is Bowser, Weaver & Cousounis. It moved from rental space in a high-rise office tower to a brownstone five blocks away, the former headquarters of the Republican Women of Pennsylvania, in a four-story building at 16th and Latimer Streets, just south of the buffer zone. The building's neighbors on the block, within walking distance of City Hall and the major downtown office towers, include a jewelry boutique, a doctor's office and a restaurant.
Charles W. Bowser, a partner in the firm, bought the building and paid for the needed renovations. Mr. Bowser said he paid $350,000 for the building -- down from an initial listing price of more than $1 million -- and that he has put more than the purchase price into the renovations.
The firm now occupies about two-thirds of the 10,000 square feet available and will save the balance for expansion or possible rental. For comparable space at his previous address, the annual rent was $92,000, including maintenance and other charges, he said.
"We can amortize the purchase price in 10 years or less -- and we plan to be in business that long -- but we'll also get the depreciation, the direct tax benefits and any appreciation of the property's value," he said.
What made the move possible, he said, was the age of the computer -- an age that has provided the technological ability to work from home offices or in smaller quarters. "I can do as much work with seven lawyers and a computer as I did with 15 lawyers at a large firm," he said.
In years past, law books and client files filled much of a law office's space, Mr. Bowser said, but storage of files on computer disk and access by modem to law libraries or databases reduces the need for large libraries and conference rooms.
Mr. Bowser said that a building's layout could be an obstacle to creating offices. Many homes are designed to move people from one room into another without hallways, but most offices require doors that close onto connecting halls.
HE knew it would be difficult to work with the distractions of people passing by constantly, he said, so he sought a property large enough to construct private spaces. His building, though, has retained some of the original architectural features, such as large leaded-glass windows. An airy, bright front parlor has been converted to a conference room.
There can, however, be unexpected problems in corporate homesteading, Mr. Isard said. A building's owners may after time outgrow the space, or dissolve the business, and find no buyers for the property. The companies, he said, may end up stuck with a onetime corporate asset that has become a liability, that is declining in value rather than gaining.
"There are several small law firms that bought buildings in the 1980's and are now trying to get out of them," he said. "At this point, they've removed kitchens and showers or put in drop ceilings, and to make them into a home again will cost somebody a lot of money. So they're trying to market them as offices and there's not a lot of buyers."
In addition, said Barbara L. Greenfield, who represents several commercial properties for Albert M. Greenfield and Company, office buyers -- like home buyers -- tend to "overcustomize" with flourishes and renovations that can boost the price for the next potential buyer. A higher price, of course, can make a sale more difficult.
Ms. Greenberg represents a 6,000-square-foot brownstone office building at 21st and Pine Streets where only half the space is being used because of turnover at a small law firm. The law firm is trying to sell, has found no takers, and the price has dropped by half, to $440,000.
Also, conversions from one business to another may be difficult because zoning variances granted for one owner do not transfer with the building's title. An office use approved by local officials and nearby residents may not be permitted for a new owner, said J. Ward Larkin of the Larkin Group, a real-estate advisory service. That can scare off prospective buyers or torpedo deals that take too long to get necessary approvals, Mr. Larkin said.
For example, one building on Locust Street was zoned for a single floor of office use and three apartments. The 90 days required to get community support for an additional floor of office use caused one bidder to withdraw, he said.
"You really need an entrepreneurial spirit to undertake the purchase of a property," Mr. Larkin said, "because there are lots of trapdoors and alligators in buying a brownstone building."

HEADLINE: Solar Power Unit At Work in Valhalla

BYLINE: By TOM CALLAHAN 

 BODY:
THE sun is now powering the lights and equipment of the Westchester County Public Health Building in Valhalla as part of a demonstration project run by the New York Power Authority.
The 36-kilowatt power system on the roof of the building consists of 180 solar panels. Each panel measures 26 square feet and faces south at a 19-degree angle. The system produces 36,000 watts of power. 
 The Power Authority installed the $360,000 system at no expense to the county for "demonstration and advertising," said S. David Freeman, the authority's president. The county will save about $6,000 a year in electrical costs at the Public Health Building, which is part of the county's Lab and Research Department.
"This system is so simple, it's brilliant," said William Pisani, deputy commissioner of the Westchester Department of Public Works. "The sun's rays are converted directly to electricity with no chemical process, no nuclear reaction and no smoke. It's good for N.Y.P.A., the county government, taxpayers, science and the environment."
The authority has joined with 64 other utilities across the United States in a consortium, with each utility agreeing to buy and test solar systems. The cost of the Westchester project is being divided equally among the power authority, the New York State Energy Research and Development Authority and the Empire State Electric Energy Research Corporation, which consists of the New York Power Authority and six private utilities. The utilities hope that their combined purchasing power will drive down the cost of solar systems and encourage others to use the technology. "If we take 1 percent of the solar energy that hits the earth and harness it at an efficiency rate of 1 percent, we will get more energy than we use now from coal, gas, nuclear and all the rest," Mr. Freeman said.
The Public Health Building project is the second solar system that the Power Authority has installed in Westchester. In June 1993, the authority put a small 4-kilowatt, 12-panel system on the roof of White Plains High School. The authority plans to install eight solar projects in the state next year, with a total capacity of 300 kilowatts.
"We are picking some prominent spots to do these projects," Mr. Freeman said. "Each project is a small demonstration that we can take the sun's energy free of charge and, with modern technology, convert it to electricity. If it works on one roof, it can work on a lot of roofs."
The unit on the Public Health Building, called Solarex, has no moving parts. Photovoltaic cells convert the sun's rays into 480 volts of direct current, which are then turned into the more efficient alternate current. The system will power the lights, motors and air-conditioning fans of the building. But the building will not rely solely on solar power.
"We have two electrical feeds into the building: the normal and the Solarex," Mr. Pisani said. "When the sun is shining, we use the Solarex. When it becomes dark and cloudy, we automatically switch back to the regular electrical system. The system can sense a drop in voltage and switch over without even causing the lights to flicker." The Power Authority will maintain the system for two years, after which it will become the property of the county.
The solar power system at White Plains High School has "made no difference" in electrical costs so far, said Michael J. Lynch, director of facilities and operations for the White Plains city school district. That is because of the small size of the unit, which Mr. Lynch described as "making even less electricity than is produced in your kitchen, perhaps enough to run a coffee maker." Mr. Lynch said that "somewhere down the road, solar power will work" and added, "We are happy to help the Power Authority in this project."
While solar energy has been available for years, county and Power Authority officials say they believe that recent advances in technology -- like advanced metals that make the panels absorb sunlight better -- have made these systems more efficient and affordable.
"The cost has gone down by a factor of five," Mr. Freeman said. "Ten years ago, a solar system comparable in size to the Valhalla unit would have cost $2 million or $3 million. We think that by the turn of the century, the price of solar power will be highly competitive. This will be a major source of power for the planet over the next century."

HEADLINE: The Need to Preserve Indian Sites

 BODY:
Concerning the West New Brighton, S.I., Journal of Dec. 18:
Native Americans came, some from out of state, to speak about two Native American sites, Lot 33 and the Last Green Hill, which are in imminent danger. This land is next to and part of a Lenape burial ground and dwelling site. 
 We were surprised to see that Native Americans were not even mentioned in this article. A great many Native American people were here 15,000 years before there were European settlers. Native Americans were treated as if they were invisible.
The message of the American Indian is most needed now at a time when pollution has almost made this a place where people cannot live, and values seem to be lost. The Native Americans knew how to treat and love the land, water and air and respect the balance of nature.
These sites must be saved -- all that remains of the last green spaces and Native American sites along Richmond Terrace facing the Kill van Kull. Interestingly, this also means economic restoration of this historic area near the New York ferry and the Snug Harbor Cultural Center. This historic place should be a Richmondtown on the waterfront.
Native American sites must not be desecrated. The New York City Parks Department wants these sites. A choice must be made now. We trust that New York City will see that Lot 33 and the Last Green Hill go to the Parks Department. We hope that the New York City government makes the choice for the people, our heritage, and our environment and true economic growth.
JOSEPH BRAVE FIRE MATHIS
Staten Island

HEADLINE: We've Come Far Since the Victorians . . .

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Gertrude Himmelfarb suggests in "The Victorians Get a Bad Rap" (Op-Ed, Jan. 9) that a return to the values of Victorian Britain might help solve America's social problems. Her article only illustrates, however, how bad history makes for bad politics. 
 For example, to support her case for the replacement of public provision by private charity, she asserts that in Victorian Britain such charity was taken seriously not only by the upper classes: in 1890, a survey showed half of the "respectable" working classes making regular charitable contributions. This is tendentious.
It is, anyway, implausible to suggest that half the members of this class, themselves only saved from degrading poverty or destitution by constant effort and good luck, were in the habit of giving a part of their overstretched income to help those even less well off.
What the historical evidence shows is that a substantial number of members of this class were contributing to organizations such as friendly and provident societies. This was not charity, but insurance for themselves and their families.
It is less defensible still for Ms. Himmelfarb to urge a return to the principles of the New Poor Law of 1834, one of the most thoroughly reviled and detested pieces of legislation passed in the 19th century. Is she seriously urging that the most powerful and affluent society in the world should now reinvent the early-19th-century workhouse and set the unemployed to do 10 hours' labor a day breaking stones?
Should the United States try to model itself on an early-19th-century society that was still overwhelmingly agricultural, aristocratic and Anglican? If reflecting on the history of the Victorian period were to yield any useful guidance for the present, it would surely be by considering the kinds of measures that enabled our predecessors to address some of the problems of an increasingly urbanized and industrialized society.
Regulation of working hours and conditions, legal protection of trade union activity, collective provision of essential services, publicly financed schools, libraries and museums, taxes on higher incomes, and death duties on inherited wealth -- these too were Victorian achievements.
Modern versions of these measures may or may not be appropriate to today's America. But recognizing their place in the historical picture may at least help prevent "Victorian" from becoming a code word for a particularly unlovely blend of myopic individualism and coercive moralism.
 
STEFAN COLLINI
Princeton, N.J., Jan. 10, 1995
 
The writer is professor of English and history at Cambridge University.

HEADLINE: PASSING THE BUCK;
War. Peace. Aid. All Issues Are Trade Issues

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
JUST hours after the Senate confirmed Robert E. Rubin as Secretary of the Treasury last week, he received an immediate full-immersion lesson in what life is like these days sitting under the giant portrait of Alexander Hamilton. Rather than arm-wrestle with Newt Gingrich over the Administration's forthcoming budget, or shoot his signature over to the Bureau of Engraving for inclusion on every new dollar bill, he spent endless hours on the telephone to capitals around the world, trying to keep the United States' biggest neighbor, Mexico, from going down the tubes.
Mr. Rubin's task was to out-psych currency speculators and nervous investors the way American policy-makers once tried to out-psych the Soviet military: Make elaborate and very public plans for coming to an ally's defense in hopes of deterring all attacks. In this case, the plans were for loan guarantees for Mexico, stitched together Thursday night at the White House by Mr. Rubin, President Clinton, Mr. Gingrich and other Republican leaders, and the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan. 
 It is still unclear whether they accomplished enough to keep Mexico's currency crisis from turning into a nightmare: wild inflation and political instability on America's southern border, an influx of more illegal immigrants, and rattled markets in other booming but developing economies from Brazil to Indonesia. But whether the plan works or not, Mr. Rubin, a former co-chairman of Goldman Sachs & Company, was already engaged in a new age of American foreign policy, in which Treasury, Commerce and the United States Trade Representative take the lead in managing many of America's most strategic relationships and the State Department focuses on the Middle East and the current hot spot (maybe Port-au-Prince, maybe Grozny).
"Everyone's been saying for a long time that foreign policy is becoming economic, but like everything it's taken a while for the message to sink in around here," the former Treasury Secretary, Lloyd Bentsen, said just before he left town last month. "It just shows you how important the economic issues are internationally, and that's a situation Secretaries of State don't work at very much."
The job of Treasury Secretary has permanently changed, Mr. Bentsen argues, and the result is that it has virtually merged with the job of Secretary of State. In a number of recent interviews, he told about turning Boris Yeltsin around on issues of Russian aid, pressing top Japanese officials to change their tax policies in an effort to spur more imports, cajoling Latin American leaders to speed the pace of reform.
Mr. Rubin may not be quite as tightly focused on his mission abroad; during his largely pro forma Senate confirmation hearing, he talked a good deal about job retraining, capital gains taxes and budgetary prudence. But the fact is that domestic fiscal policy is virtually dead; there is not enough discretionary money left in the budget to spur growth internally through government spending or big industrial policy programs. There is widespread acceptance of the notion that if the American economy is going to expand, it will do so through exports of goods, services and information. Even Warren Christopher says so. But his response has been to hand away countries to his colleagues, one by one.
He started with Japan, concluding that America's problems with its greatest ally in the Pacific were largely economic, and thus out of his bailiwick. China came next: Ever since last spring, when Mr. Bentsen won the day in one of the Administration's biggest policy arguments and persuaded Mr. Clinton that the linkage of human rights to trade relations with China was a recipe for America's commercial ruin, China policy has been dominated by the likes of Commerce Secretary Ron Brown and the United State Trade Representative, Mickey Kantor.
Their talk of "commercial engagement" hasn't eased tension with China -- by many measures things are worse -- but now officials in Washington and Beijing do not argue over China's continued imprisonment of dissidents. Instead, they issue threats of a trade war, prompted by the Administration's insistence that China shut the factories that churn out 70 million pirated compact and video disks a year.
And as the Latin American summit in Miami last month proved, the Western Hemisphere is going the way of the economic gurus as well; the secret airstrips where the C.I.A. once flew arms to the contras now look like promising distribution channels for the new "Free Trade Area of the Americas." That is, unless the Mexican crisis sinks Mr. Clinton's plan for creating millions of jobs in the United States by building export markets throughout the the hemisphere.
"The question isn't whether Warren Christopher will stay in his job," one State Department official active in economic issues said the other day. "The question is why he has given so much of it away."
The answer is that he had little choice. Mr. Christopher has few levers to pull when it comes to helping direct international capital flows around the world -- and access to capital is the leading subject of discussion these days. The State Department has a large economics section, of course, but it plays little role in coordinating economic foreign policy.
 
Money's the High Card
 The rise of the Age of the Finance Minister, of course, is not entirely new: James A. Baker 3d carved out a lot of the territory when he served as Ronald Reagan's Treasury Secretary. But in the Reagan and Bush years, as throughout the cold war, keeping the anti-Soviet alliance together always trumped commercial concerns. Two years into the Clinton Administration, things have changed. To tell the difference, just peek inside the situation room -- not the one at the State Department, but the new one, over at Commerce.
Technically, it is the "Advocacy Center," a sleek computer room staffed by specialists who track, minute by minute, the status of thousands of giant projects around the world that American firms are vying to win. "The idea is to bring the whole force of the Government together to press the case for American business -- ambassadors, commercial officers, investment bankers, the Ex-Im Bank or OPIC," he said, naming the two government agencies that have taken a major role in financing big deals abroad. Competitors are also tracked.
On Thursday, 24 hours before Commerce Secretary Ron Brown's departure with an entourage of officials and industry executives to India, the screens were flickering with data about big electric power and telecommunications projects still up for grabs. "I for one was tired of seeing President Mitterrand and President Kohl travel the world representing their country's industry while we stood back and did nothing," Mr. Brown said last week. "Our attitude was, 'Good luck, let us know how it turned out.' "
But a series of deals does not constitute a foreign policy. The risk, of course, is that relentless pressure to buy, buy, buy American undercuts alliances and breeds resentments. Just ask the Australians, who are among America's most critical strategic allies and are outraged by the Agriculture Department's plan to help American dairy farmers export to Australia's markets. At the height of the cold war, when exports meant little to Americans and defending against Soviet attack meant a lot, the decision would have been easy. Now it may take up most of Mr. Rubin's day.

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
A City Asks For a Return On Its Dollar

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS 

 BODY:
MAYOR RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI'S new urban agenda is a political alchemist's ingenious formula for coping with diminishing returns from Albany and Washington: He argues that New York, like many other American cities, is a well-capitalized national economic resource that would be largely self-sufficient if only the state and Federal governments got out of its way.
The logical, if unlikely, extension of that agenda is another political retread that dreamers recycle periodically: statehood. 
 "From an intellectual analysis, if New York were a 51st state, New York would not have a budget deficit," Mr. Giuliani suggested last week after outlining the agenda in his State of the City speech. "Its budget deficit, to a very large extent, is a factor of the mandates placed upon it by the state and the treatment that it gets from the Federal Government because it isn't a state."
For well over a century, secessionists as disparate as Mayor Fernando Wood, William Randolph Hearst, Norman Mailer and Bella Abzug have been galvanized by the same frustration Mr. Giuliani now faces in arguing that Albany and Washington are dragging the city down, not the other way around. Washington and Puerto Rico have at different times agitated for statehood, but this month both got a taste of bitter medicine when the new Republican majority revoked even their symbolic votes. Congress as a whole always seems unwilling to grant anyone statehood.
But Mr. Giuliani is not advocating statehood. Who needs statehood when one has the vows of Congress and the Governor to cut budgets and taxes, and promises to free local officials from costly regulation?
Over the decades, cities were transformed from self-sustaining creatures of increasingly anachronistic states to supplicants pleading for Federal grants.
"We have developed a habit in New York of thinking of these grants as free goods, and they're not," said Senator Daniel P. Moynihan of New York. "You pay for every one of them and you get back 80 cents on the dollar."
Mr. Giuliani said the metropolitan area sends $3.3 billion more to Albany than it gets back. And New York State sends $14 billion more to Washington than it receives in return.
Those figures are gross calculations, of course. The costs of secession, or merely of fairness, would be tougher to compute. Still, Leon E. Panetta, a former executive assistant to Mayor John V. Lindsay and now Chief of Staff to President Clinton, wrote two decades ago that analyzing the issue would be worthwhile because "then, in the very least, the issues that will have been debated and studied will help the citizens of this city better understand the discouraging prospect of having to bargain annually with Albany for its life."
Or, as Norman Mailer, the author whose 1965 mayoral campaign platform championed a 51st state, mused recently: "Governor Giuliani, at this moment, sounds better than Governor Pataki."
