SECTION: Section 13; Page 1; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 3400 words

HEADLINE: The Life of a Small Landlord

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
OSCAR PEREZ, landlord to the poor, compares his precarious calling to that of a family farmer. So much is out of his control. The other day, a seemingly respectable tenant was arrested on child abuse charges, and another apartment was empty. The week before, he thought he finally had a fifth-floor walk-up rented until the prospective tenant climbed the endless stairs one last time.
So the owner of four small South Bronx buildings with 38 units now has six empty apartments, and feels like a farmer gazing at a hail-ravaged field. 
 He is not cheered by the fact that he had eight empty apartments in 1993, a year when he evicted two tenants for years of not paying rent.
Part of his problem is that the city and nonprofit housing organizations have in recent years renovated much housing in the South Bronx. This is sometimes cheaper than what Mr. Perez offers, and some of his tenants, usually ones who are scrupulous about paying rent on time, snap it up.
But the tale of Oscar Perez is no sob story. For all the hard work and unpredictability, the value of his investment may have tripled in 15 years, and he could walk away with a profit of more than $200,000, providing the right buyer materialized. But taking care of old buildings is all Mr. Perez has ever known, and buyers eager to dish out large money for real estate are still rare in the South Bronx.
His experience illustrates a way of life and livelihood with a long tradition here, as generations of cabdrivers and schoolteachers, many of them immigrants, have scraped and scrimped to buy a piece of America, often a single tenement. For those interested in rolling these particular dice today -- or for those who are only curious about people who choose to be landlords -- Mr. Perez's situation is instructive.
There are easier ways to make a living. Last year his rental income after expenses was $31,000. Though he does most of the maintenance himself, he pays himself no salary for his 60-hour weeks.
Life as a landlord has never been easy for this 34-year-old Puerto Rican son of a floor polisher and zipper factory worker. He was effectively given his first and biggest building in 1977 at age 18 when the ailing owner gave up on it after a bloody shootout in a corridor. For the young man who had dropped out of high school to learn building maintenance skills, the initial challenge was filling 11 suddenly empty apartments in the 20-unit building, which is at 1162 Hoe Avenue in the West Farms section.
The pressures never diminished, though they are not particularly uncommon. Indeed, Mr. Perez's current problems -- which, he says, vary from sharply higher costs to tenants who don't pay rent to bureaucratic obstacles to redlining by insurance companies -- are emblematic of those facing tens of thousands of small property owners. Some say more buildings are in trouble than at any time since the great wave of abandonments in the 1970's, and government and industry experts are warning that the stakes are the homes of the city's poorest residents.
"These landlords are holding neighborhoods together," said Deborah C. Wright, Commissioner of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development. "So many can't make ends meet. We fundamentally have to find a way for them to be successful."
The Citizens Housing and Planning Council, a group that raises much of its money from property owners, estimates that there are more than 350,000 privately owned apartments in the 20 poorest community board districts. It says 50,000 of these are in immediate danger of being seized by the city for tax arrears or simply abandoned.
The problem is severe enough that even tenant advocates acknowledge it. "I'm not unsympathetic to the problems small, hard-working, decent landlords have," said Michael McKee, director of development for the New York State Tenant and Neighborhood Coalition.
Mr. McKee specified that his compassion does not extend to the bigger landlords who his studies indicate dominate New York rental housing, even as landlords like Mr. Perez provide most of the housing in the poorest neighborhoods. His worry is that all forms of low-income housing are facing harder times. "Without some kind of subsidy -- which is unlikely in today's climate -- it is going to be very, very difficult," he said.
The numbers are chilling. A study by the Rent Guidelines Board in 1992 showed that 10 to 14 percent of the city's housing was in serious trouble -- about 100,000 units, virtually all in low-income areas.
"In this group, the cost of running the apartments almost equals what the landlords are receiving in rent," said Aston Glaves, the board's former chairman, who presided over the study. "In many cases, costs exceed rent."
Another indication of mounting difficulties is an increase in buildings behind in taxes, 18,003 in 1993 compared with 13,737 in 1989. What has historically happened is that owners in arrears negotiate a payment plan with the city Finance Department. But according to the rent board's study, the percentage who have done that plunged from 90.8 percent in 1989 to 29.4 percent in 1992, meaning that more tend to just walk away.
Worse, these late payment agreements are not being kept. A Finance Department official recently said that of 12,000 pacts in effect, 10,000 are in default, a sharp increase.
 
NO POPULARITY CONTEST
 And if the money is sparser, it hardly seems plausible that landlords remain in business for the popularity. From the Russian proverb suggesting the only good landlord is a dead one to Jackie Gleason's ranting about his on "The Honeymooners," building owners have seemed the easiest of targets, not least because a small but steady proportion have richly deserved it.
Indeed, a handbook published by the city Human Rights Commission in 1992 warned that a landlord is "likely to try to get his money through lying, promises, intimidation, harassment."
At least one property owner who failed in an effort to provide low-income housing in East Harlem is bitter about these prevalent attitudes. "There's kind of a knee-jerk prejudice against property owners; we're all supposed to be rich," said Harley Brooke-Hitching, who was forced by banks to sell her own co-op apartment as well as give up her 11 tenement buildings when she could no longer keep up with payments.
"It gets you angrier and angrier and sicker and sicker," she said.
The one glimmer of perpetual hope, the same hope that sustains cash-squeezed farmers, is that a property's value is going up. Mr. Perez, who acquired his buildings when the Bronx seemed to be sinking like a stone, said his $128,000 in real-estate purchases may have tripled in value, though assessments have only about doubled. But profiting from the price increase hinges on finding someone willing to pay that much. He has received only one offer for a building, his smallest, for $95,000, compared with a purchase price of $28,000. He turned it down, and has neither sought nor received offers for other buildings.
'I don't think anybody outside the neighborhood would buy them," he said. "And not many people here have the money."
But there is no question that he has done better with investments than most high school dropouts; he left Alfred E. Smith Vocational High School as a junior. And he is scrambling to make sure all his empty units have window guards, smoke detectors and new appliances so he can fill them as soon as somebody signs the dotted line. His ambition this year is a reprise of 1990, when he made more than $40,000.
But he also fears his fragile economics may force him to hang up his landlord hat, and perhaps go to work managing other people's buildings. "If I have to walk away, I'll walk away," Mr. Perez said.
The landlord grew up in the building at 1162 Hoe Avenue in West Farms, the Bronx, near the Morrisania section. His father, who polished floors in Manhattan office buildings, moonlighted as building superintendent there. The boy, who had four brothers and sisters, was kept inside to shield him from the gangs.
Samuel Barmherzig, a concentration camp survivor who invented gadgets and owned several buildings, took an interest in the youth's development and encouraged him to learn how to repair things. Mr. Perez remembers repairing a marble step with him at age 10. Then, he moved on to faucets and toilets, the first of which he broke.
Mr. Barmherzig would schedule plumber's visits so the boy could watch the work. "He would tell me to be there to make sure he doesn't mess up the pipes," Mr. Perez said. "But why would a plumber hurt the pipes? He wanted me to learn what this man was doing."
Then Mr. Perez's mentor was stricken with stomach cancer. In October 1977, he said: "I can't no more. You're going to have to take this building and make it work."
So on Jan. 16, 1978, Mr. Perez, at age 18, found himself the landlord of a building that had just experienced a shootout in a hallway, a nightmare that scared more than half the tenants away. "It was tough," he said. "It took awhile to realize the amounts of responsibility laid on me."
 
A LONG TRADITION
 Mr. Perez was representative of a breed. "This was the classic way buildings were saved from abandonment in those years," said Kathryn Wylde, president of the New York City Housing Partnership. "As the previous owners aged, many simply handed the keys over to a new generation, often immigrants. Through their hard work, some of these buildings have survived."
It is part of a long tradition of mom-and-pop building ownership here, the sort of thing to which a cabdriver might aspire. "These guys feed their families off their buildings," said Michael D. Lappin, president of the Community Preservation Corporation, a bank consortium that has lent $1.25 billion to finance 38,000 housing units. "It's different than just an investment."
Not that Mr. Perez got the building for nothing. He paid $25,000 in $300 monthly installments over 10 years. The building is now assessed at $95,000, an increase in value that is partly the result of today's spiffier South Bronx. A decade ago, all the buildings on this block were abandoned. Now, just the house across the street is.
Slowly, Mr. Perez began to build his small empire. In 1983, a friend of the old man who had first befriended the boy gave Mr. Perez a chance to buy an eight-unit building at 1245 Woodycrest Avenue near Yankee Stadium for $1,000 down and $263 a month over eight years.
The total monthly rent from that building was then $1,100, barely enough to pay for heat and other monthly expenses. That meant Mr. Perez had to begin a campaign of capital improvements to legally justify raising rents to profit-making levels. He accomplished that, but is proud that four of the original eight tenants have stayed on, even with the higher rents. Because the building is a better moneymaker as well as because of a general increase in values in the neighborhood, Mr. Perez says he thinks the property may now be worth as much as $150,000.
He next bought a three-unit building at 804 Freeman Street for $28,000 in 1986. That was the building for which he was offered $95,000.
His last building, at 936 East 169th Street, was bought with a partner, the owner of a local hardware store, in 1991. Each man put up $50,000 for the seven-unit building. Mr. Perez says it may now be worth $150,000.
These numbers suggest his net worth has tripled. He also has very little debt, just five more payments of $217 on the last building. (He also makes monthly payments of $1,040 on a two-and-a-half-bedroom house in the Bronx's Soundview section with his wife, Jannette, and their two children.)
What Mr. Perez represents is a property owner whose income is eroding, in the face of some stiff new challenges. Moreover, his cash flow is inherently unpredictable, dependent as it is on poor people paying him regularly and keeping apartments occupied.
And he is quick to say that he differs from farmers in that his product is not supported by government subsidies, as are corn and peanuts, but instead is kept cheap by the rent stabilization system.
As an example, he points to two identical six-room apartments at 1245 Woodycrest. For one, he gets $660 and for the other he gets $397. The lower price is not enough for proper maintenance, he says. "It destroys the desire you have to try to make everything nice," he said.
But rent regulation is not as big a problem as landlord complaints would suggest, he acknowledges. At the same address, he gets $502 from a tenant who pays rent regularly and is tidy. "Let's face it; we're not on Park Avenue," Mr. Perez said. "I prefer to take a little less and keep a good tenant."
Frank P. Braconi, executive director of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council, said that in poor areas, property owners' returns are limited more by people's low incomes than by rent ceilings. "In many cases the landlord can't get the regulated rent," he said.
But then there is the problem of tenants who do not like to pay rent at all. Mr. Perez says he has one tenant who pays $388.48 for a six-room apartment on Hoe Avenue. Each year, he says he takes her to Housing Court for back rent. She then agrees to pay a lump sum of $2,000 or so, and to pay the rest of the debt at $50 a month. She does this for a while; then the whole cycle starts again.
"This could drive you to kill a person," Mr. Perez said.
His lawyer says that despite Mr. Perez's frustration, it is exceedingly hard to persuade him. "I have to play the role of bad guy and push him to evict," he said.
Indeed, Mr. Perez goes fishing and on picnics with some of his tenants. Many send him Christmas cards, and he is often invited to parties in tenants' apartments.
"Sometimes I don't pay exactly on time, but he never gets angry," said Maria Rodriguez, who has lived in his Freeman Street building for five years. "He says O.K."
Cassandra Vernon, a spokeswoman for the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, said there are a relatively small number of violations in Mr. Perez's buildings, all minor. One, at Hoe Avenue, for example, is for failure to mark floors with painted numbers.
 
THE BIGGEST PROBLEM
 Such small landlords' biggest problem over time is that they cannot afford the major renovations needed to keep buildings running. "These buildings are on the edge at best," said Mark Willis, president of the Chase Community Development Corporation, a unit of Chase Manhattan Bank. "This guy can't hold that building together forever by continually patching it."
In particular, Mr. Perez has postponed getting a new boiler for the Hoe Avenue building, both of which were built in 1905. He says even the boiler salesman will not guarantee that the $22,000 expense will save energy. So he keeps patching cracks in the old steel, doing the welding himself. "It's a big decision to make," he said.
Other spending is a result of rough treatment by tenants themselves. For example, Mr. Perez said, one tenant has broken his apartment lock three times. "If the tenant breaks it 20 times, I still have to take care of it," Mr. Perez said. He said if he took this tenant to court, it would cost him $800 and he might lose. A new lock costs $50.
The bigger expenses have all shot up too, Mr. Perez said. Real-estate taxes exceed $10,000 at Hoe Avenue, compared with $1,600 in 1978. Repairs for all the buildings are no less than $10,000. Heat runs about $17,000. Sanitation tickets, almost always caused by neighborhood youths' overturning garbage cans, reach $3,000 a year. Fire and other insurance would be unavailable had not small property owners banded together and bought as an association: it runs $6,000 for all four buildings.
Another huge expense comes from the city's requirement that apartment owners pay higher water and sewer bills. At Hoe Avenue, these bills now approach $12,000, compared with $700 in 1978. The increase will be even greater after meters must be installed everywhere; so far, Mr. Perez has avoided meters by paying higher estimated costs.
Dan Margulies, executive director of the Community Housing Improvement Program, an organization of medium-sized landlords, said water and sewer costs are expected to increase by 5 percent a year over the next decade. "That is a real killer for small buildings in poor neighborhoods," he said.
And an even larger financial threat is looming: the cost of lead paint abatement. If the city, which is now planning tougher rules, requires all lead paint to be removed to protect children from brain damage, it could cost about $12,000 an apartment in old buildings like Mr. Perez's.
The landlord does not dispute the need. "I'm not a piece of meat with eyes," he said. "I have two kids of my own."
But he does hope the eventual requirement is either less costly than full removal, or in some way compensates property owners for their abatement expense. In terms of the economic threat to low-income housing, "this is like a ticking time bomb," said Mr. McKee, the tenant advocate.
In part, Mr. Perez survives because he has learned a trick or two over the years. One is to cultivate such necessary people as emergency plumbers by paying their bills first. Another is to go through the trash of a tenant who absconds without paying rent; he found one such woman's work address and succeeded in having her paycheck garnisheed. Still another is to ask about the "off the books" income of a prospective tenant who at first appears unable to pay the monthly rent.
But a startling amount of Mr. Perez's success has come from being a nice guy, tenants say, the last thing most people would expect from a landlord. Nersa Quinones tells of living in the Hoe Avenue building, then in 1977 moving to a larger apartment on the third-floor of a detached house. The rent went up faster than her husband Ralph's income as a body-and-fender repairman. They called Mr. Perez. "No problem," he said, and moved them into a $357.97 two-bedroom apartment.
"It's good to be back," Mrs. Quinones said. "My kids grew up here, you know."
 
From the Other Side: The Rights of New York Tenants
Here is a listing of some of the major rights of tenants living in New York City, according to Michael McKee, director of development and public relations for the New York State Tenant and Neighborhood Coalition, a state-wide organization that lobbies for tenant's rights:

BUILDING CONDITION Landlords must provide heat and hot water for tenants. Heat should be turned on on October 1 and remain active until the end of May. The landlord also has an obligation to make repairs and guarantee that the apartment does not pose any threat to life or safety. This guarantee includes two types of locks on the door, a latch lock and a bolt lock, as well as protective bars on the windows if children under 11 are living there and a self locking front building entrance. Apartments are also generally required to get a new coat of paint every three years and have two-way intercoms.

ACCESS Tenants must grant access to the landlord only under a few specific conditions: for repairs, to check for violations, or to show to prospective purchaser. In all cases, the landlord must give the tenant reasonable advance notice and show up at a decent hour. Except, of course, in case of emergencies like ruptured pipes or flaming stoves. Tenants are also required to give the landlord a key, especially if they decide to change the locks.

OCCUPANCY In any regulated housing, including rent-stabilized and rent-controlled apartments as well as Mitchell-Lama housing and public housing, tenants have a right to tenure, i.e. they can stay in the apartment indefinitely until they choose to vacate or in the worse case, are evicted. Regulated status remains when a new tenant moves in. New tenants should check with previous renters or neighbors to make sure the rent hasn't been inflated beyond allowable limits. In unregulated housing, generally including small buildings with fewer than six units, your lease can be terminated without reason.

GENERAL RIGHTS Tenants can organize tenant groups and meet in public areas of the building, like lobbies and hallways and are free to distribute literature throughout the building. Tenants can keep pets if the landlord doesn't object within the first three months of you and your pet's occupancy.

HEADLINE: Building Up From Ground Zero

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: MOTT, N.D.

 BODY:
HERE in southwest North Dakota, the population peaked decades ago and signs of economic decline are as commonplace as winter blizzards. Farmers abandoned vast reaches of marginal cropland during the 1980's in return for Federal conservation payments, the latest in a long line of blows to farm equipment dealers, hardware stores, fuel supply companies and other local businesses. Most high school graduates move away to find work.
In towns like Mott, which has 950 or so residents, commercial districts are pocked with empty storefronts and the surviving merchants cobble together diverse enterprises to make ends meet. The laundromat here is also the television repair shop. The florist rents tuxedos to bridegrooms and high school graduates. 
 "This is Ground Zero for Buffalo Commons," says David Crane, a local lawyer, referring to a theory popularized in the 1980's by Frank Popper, a Rutgers University land specialist who suggested that large portions of the Western Plains be returned to the buffalo. "Mott is where NBC brought him to film a newscast on it."
But Mr. Crane and Thomas Secrest, a lawyer 40 miles away in the town of Hettinger, have a brighter future in mind. It is based on what legal scholars say is an ingenious plan that could save Mott and many similar rural communities from the slow death that looms before them. The two lawyers have been hunting in bankruptcy courts around the nation for small manufacturing companies that could benefit from moving some or all of their operations to an area like this, where land, labor and tax costs are low. The men's strategy: arrange for investors from several of the area's towns to settle the debts, buy control of the companies and then move them.
"We are not interested in starting up companies," says Mr. Secrest. "These little communities don't have time for that and starting up takes more money."
The Dakota Management Corporation, the two lawyers' year-old enterprise, originally set out seeking a 20 percent equity stake in each imported company, plus a management fee, with at least 31 percent of the remaining equity in the hands of the townspeople. Ideally, the transplanted companies would be in related industries, and the corporation would, for a fee, enable them to share accounting, marketing, distribution and other operating costs.
"It sounds fabulous," says Elizabeth Warren, a bankruptcy and commercial law professor at the University of Pennsylvania Law School. "Small business bankruptcy is an overlooked segment of the U.S. economy."
"It's a very creative idea," agrees Mark E. MacDonald, a Dallas lawyer who is chairman of the Chapter 11 subcommittee of an American Bar Association group of lawyers specializing in bankruptcy. (Chapter 11 is the section of the Federal Bankruptcy Code that allows companies to stay in business with court protection from creditors while they try to settle their debts.)
But, Mr. MacDonald warns, Chapter 11 is a world rife with shady entrepreneurs. In addition, there is so little information available on small companies in Chapter 11 that finding attractive candidates could be an insurmountable challenge.
So far, Mr. MacDonald's concerns seem right on the mark. Efforts to bring three companies here have flopped. For their labors, Messrs. Crane and Secrest have more than $45,000 in legal bills and administrative debt, a pending lawsuit filed against them seeking damages of up to $1 million and scores of disappointed neighbors. And they have an albatross of a business partner: William J. Vaughan 3d, a 33-year-old high-school dropout from California whose attempts to build a career reorganizing underperforming businesses have been accompanied by an unnerving number of legal irregularities and financial problems.
Companies looking for a respite from the difficulties and costs of urban America have been moving to North Dakota's biggest towns, like Bismarck and Fargo. But despite economic incentives offered by the state, luring businesses to the 175 or so communities five miles or more from the handful of communities with more than 10,000 residents has proved much harder.
With the help of advanced telecommunications systems, small companies and individual entrepreneurs in some of the nation's rural communities can now compete on a more even footing with urban and suburban rivals based closer to customers and suppliers. But the new technologies also allow traditional employers like utility companies and the Agriculture Department to close local offices and serve customers from regional centers, driving many small towns further toward oblivion.
"Geography matters, despite the fanfare that the information-age economy is no respecter of places," says Tim R. Smith, a senior economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, Mo. Mr. Smith has studied the 25 percent of rural counties that have grown faster than the nation's metropolitan areas and how they differ from the majority that are losing ground.
A high proportion of the winners are near urban centers. Those prospering in remote areas tend to be especially scenic, like counties in the Rocky Mountains or the Ozarks, or crisscrossed by interstate highways and rail lines. That reality explains why relocating established but bankrupt businesses might look promising to less fortunate regions, especially if several towns can coordinate efforts.
Since 1990, about 20,000 companies a year have filed Chapter 11 petitions, more than 99 percent of them small, privately held concerns. The most widely accepted estimate, based on a 1989 study by the Administrative Office of the United States Courts in Washington, is that less than 20 percent manage to come up with a court-approved plan to satisfy creditors and stay in business. Of that group, about half have so little financial muscle they fail to live up to their plans and soon fold. That probably leaves a pool of scores of basically healthy manufacturing ventures with up to 50 employees and as much as a few million dollars in sales. If successfully transplanted, they could spell the difference between life and slow death for remote towns like Mott.
But while vulture capitalists actively serve investors interested in gaining control and reorganizing companies with $30 million or more in sales, most investors do not bother with shaky companies smaller than that. Those attracted to small companies, says Mr. McDonald, the Dallas lawyer, include "a lot of sharks" looking for quick fees in return for promises to find investors. And many smaller companies show up in Chapter 11 with what Mr. MacDonald calls "shoe-box accounting" -- records so disorganized it is hard to tell if the company has insoluble operating problems or if it can be saved with debt restructuring.
 
Hatching the Plan
 Mr. Secrest came up with the plan for Dakota Management after helping a safe-manufacturing company in Chapter 11 move from Boulder, Colo., to Edmund, S.D. A native of Texas who moved to the region in 1949 after marrying a North Dakotan, Mr. Secrest, 67, has been an assistant attorney general for the state, a county prosecutor, a county judge and head of the state Republican Party. He attacked each job with an aggressive, albeit folksy, style that left him well known but not universally loved.
Nor has Mr. Secrest been averse to taking business risks. He has bred race horses and sunk money into a packing plant that expanded so rapidly it went bankrupt during the 1970's. And he is unfazed by controversy. He has advocated that the region make a bid to become a nuclear waste storage site. Until last year, he regularly debated issues of the day with Tony Bender, then editor of the local newspaper, on a radio show called "B.S. in the A.M."
Mr. Secrest's Dakota Management partner could hardly be more different. A soft-spoken, intensely religious man with little taste for confrontation, Mr. Crane, 41, is head of Mott's Chamber of Commerce and has a law practice built by his grandfather and father, a longtime professional acquaintance of Mr. Secrest.
The two partners were unable to locate suitable buyout candidates through informal contacts with bankruptcy lawyers around the nation or through an advertisement in The Wall Street Journal. Then in the fall of 1993, Mr. Crane saw a classified ad placed by Mr. Vaughan in National Review magazine, identifying himself as a "chief financial officer" with Chapter 11 reorganization experience.
When Mr. Vaughan was reached by phone, Mr. Crane recalls, "he deluged me with ideas." A package of material about Mott and environs was sent off to California and Mr. Vaughan quickly responded with more development ideas.
"I was impressed with how thorough he had been," says Mr. Crane. "He had researched our transportation and telecommunications capabilities."
The first face-to-face encounter was last January, when Mr. Vaughan visited the region. "Vaughan wowed everyone," Mr. Crane says, recounting a meeting with potential investors. One target Mr. Vaughan suggested, Vitamin Research Products, looked perfect. The premium-priced vitamin supplements it manufactured and sold through mail and telephone orders had a good reputation. Its nationwide customer base could be easily served from North Dakota. It had 23 employees, a reasonable number for Mott to absorb; assuming a few moved with the company, the rest of the jobs could be filled locally. It had begun to make healthy profits while in Chapter 11.
And although the company had cut costs by moving from San Jose, Calif., to Carson City, Nev., it had expenses in its new home that could be slashed further by moving to Mott. For example, instead of paying $72,000 a year in rent, says Mr. Vaughan, it could buy an entire building for $8,500.
Mr. Vaughan also introduced Dakota Management to Jeffrey Chauncey, a Los Angeles-based entrepreneur whose futon assembly and retail company, Chauncey Enterprises, had recently emerged from Chapter 11 and was looking for capital to expand. Through Mr. Chauncey, Dakota also met Bill Warne, whose Warne Fiber Company, in Littlefield, Tex., was Mr. Chauncey's main supplier of mattresses. Mr. Vaughan proposed bringing Vitamin Research to Mott, a branch of Chauncey's company to Hettinger, and part of Mr. Warne's business to Elgin (a town 30 miles east of Mott), painting an alluring picture of how management and administrative costs could be shared among them.
The strategy might have had a better chance if Mr. Vaughan's knowledge of Vitamin Research had not come from his own troubled past with the company. Hired in 1991 to help reorganize it, he had been promoted to chief financial officer and president before being fired by Robert Watson Jr., the owner and chief executive, in February 1993.
The company sued Mr. Vaughan, charging in the complaint that, among other things, he had lied about his credentials and background in order to get hired in 1991, had wired company funds into personal accounts and had put on company expenses trips with other employees to Nevada brothels.
Mr. Vaughan has filed a countersuit, denying the charges and claiming he had been fired because Mr. Watson was trying to back out of an agreement to give Mr. Vaughan half-ownership of the company.
 
Signs of Trouble
 Mr. Vaughan had warned the North Dakotan lawyers about the dispute early on, but he had not been pressed for details. He had more disturbing news for them last January, shortly before his trip to North Dakota, when he was arrested and charged with fraudulently using another William J. Vaughan's Social Security number to get a $28,000 loan to buy a used Cadillac Seville. After the charges were reduced to a misdemeanor in February, Mr. Vaughan accepted a guilty finding, paid $600 in fines and administrative expenses, and began serving a year's probation.
Mr. Vaughan's would-be partners accepted his explanation that the Social Security Administration had issued him the second number by mistake after he reported his card lost. And he was able to point out that no payments were missed and the car was returned in good condition to the dealership once it told him the financing had been blocked.
There was more bad news in March, when Vitamin Research won a partial summary judgment in its case against Mr. Vaughan for $17,604.38. Mr. Vaughan filed a personal bankruptcy petition, later withdrawn. Among his creditors is the Internal Revenue Service, which wants nearly $43,000 in taxes it said he failed to pay from 1989 to 1992.
These and other red flags raised by Mr. Watson and his lawyer were not enough to send Mr. Crane and Mr. Secrest running the other way. Mr. Crane did check criminal records and talk to Nevada law enforcement officials. But he did not contact the people on Mr. Vaughan's resume or any Vitamin Research employee. "I wasn't anxious to look for reasons to discredit the guy," Mr. Crane acknowledges.
"The thing that mattered to me was who controlled the money," says Mr. Secrest. "And we never let ourselves get into a position where he did."
Most importantly, perhaps, everything Mr. Vaughan said about the soundness of Vitamin Research checked out when a Hettinger accountant was sent out on two separate auditing trips.
"We were tickled to find someone who appeared to be knowledgeable and Vitamin Research looked so promising that it overrode the negative stuff," says Mr. Crane.
 
Plunging Ahead
 Burying any misgivings, the two lawyers took the Californian on as a partner, giving him a 50 percent stake in Dakota Management rather than paying him upfront for his work. They also made him president of the West River Nutrition Corporation, a company set up to buy Vitamin Research, thus ending whatever chance there might have been for working out a friendly deal with the company. Two other companies were also formed: one to bring Mr. Chauncey's futon group to Hettinger; the other, Mr. Warne's to Elgin. By last summer, Dakota Management was ready to begin selling stock in the three ventures. Both Mr. Vaughan and Mr. Chauncey made trips to the region in advance of the offerings and, in October, Mr. Vaughan moved his wife and two young children to Hettinger.
That same month, The Adams County Record, Hettinger's weekly newspaper, discovered court records of the dispute between Mr. Vaughan and Vitamin Research. That led The Record to contact Mr. Watson, who arranged for it to receive a flood of negative information. The accusations it could confirm were published this past fall, raising public doubts about Mr. Vaughan's character and business record. Those doubts grew when Mr. Vaughan, needing money, abruptly moved back to California to seek consulting work.
In late November, with the stock offerings dead in the water, Dakota Management decided to return the more than $50,000 it had collected. The partners also decided they would focus on winning an auction the bankruptcy court overseeing Vitamin Research had set up to determine who could offer the most to the company's creditors. Dakota Management quickly won approval from the state to issue promisory notes, allowing it to borrow up to $450,000 from local investors.
Mott residents, some annoyed by the negative coverage in the Hettinger paper that many viewed as motivated by rivalry between the two towns, put their faith in Mr. Crane's continued support and Mr. Vaughan's explanations of his problems. Many were also impressed that Mr. Vaughan had worked on the project without being paid.
"Vaughan's never asked us for one cent," said Claude Heidt, a shoe store owner. Mr. Heidt and others also felt that Mott needed to move faster than Hettinger, which sits on a Burlington Northern rail line, is home to a regional medical clinic with 12 doctors, and has a healthier range of businesses as well as 700 more residents than Mott.
"If I don't invest this money now," Mr. Heidt maintained, "I'd have to invest it in five years to move." He lent $100,000, the compensation his young daughter received for a car accident that has left her an invalid. With support from several other residents and the Commercial Bank of Mott, Dakota raised $450,000.
On Dec. 19, Mr. Watson and his backers, who could have anticipated how much Dakota raised by reading the public prospectus, won the auction by bidding just over $455,000.
 
The Aftermath
 Two weeks before the auction, Mr. Crane described himself as "mentally, spiritually, psychologically and physically at the end of my reserves." Today, he still believes in Dakota's original strategy but is not ready to go after another company.
"I need to straighten my business out and spend some time with my wife and kids," says Mr. Crane. Dakota Management's first goal, he says, should be returning the money raised for Vitamin Research and paying debts. He is hoping Mr. Watson will drop the lawsuit filed against Dakota and its partners for allegedly interfering in its efforts to raise money for the December auction.
The less flappable Mr. Secrest has written off the past year's experience as a "shakedown cruise." He says he is now leery of working with Mr. Vaughan, who blames him for not bringing more money to the auction.
"I don't think Vaughan is a con man," Mr. Secrest says. "If he was out to con us, he never would have pursued Vitamin Research so hard. He knew that he had enemies there who would do everything conceivable to blow him out of the saddle. My problem with him is that he is a control freak."
Mr. Vaughan is looking forward to Sept. 11, the date set for the trial of his claims against Vitamin Research. Meanwhile, he acknowledges he wants more control over Dakota's acquisition tactics. He continues to talk about investment opportunities, including some arrangement with Mr. Chauncey.
Mr. Chauncey, though, describes negotiations as "pretty well stalled." The flaw in the North Dakotans' efforts to date, he says, is that they were unable to raise equity investment funds for inventories, provide tax and rent relief, or offer moving subsidies that would make a setting up in North Dakota worthwhile. "You can't relocate on borrowed money," he says. "That just adds to debt."
Everyone agrees the stakes are too high to give up easily on Dakota Management's original vision. "Everything that happened was something I didn't expect," says Mr. Crane. "If nothing ever comes of it, it will be truly devastating."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 594 words

HEADLINE: Tax Deductions for College

 BODY:
President Clinton decided shortly after election to cast aside his campaign pledge to cut taxes on middle-class families for the more pressing purpose of controlling the deficit. He has paid dearly for that act of fiscal prudence. The Republicans seized the political low ground by promising all but the richest 1 percent of families a $500-per-child tax cut. The promise energized their campaign -- even though the spending cuts required to offset the tax cuts would punish the poor and most middle-class families as well.
The President had little choice but to respond in kind. To his credit, he struggled to make the best of a bad idea. His tax cut encourages something the economy desperately needs: a better-educated work force. Mr. Clinton proposes a tax deduction for most families of up to $10,000 per year to cover the cost of post-secondary education. The idea is to stimulate the type of investment that lies at the core of his economic platform. It is easy to poke holes in the plan. But at least the President put a constructive goal before the public. 
 Mr. Clinton's tax-cut plan was driven by the need to rebuild his political popularity. His advisers would not otherwise propose tax deductions to encourage college enrollment. Deductions are poorly targeted -- providing twice as much savings to a family earning $100,000 a year (tax bracket above 30 percent) as to one earning $30,000 a year (tax bracket of 15 percent). The lion's share of the tax cut will go to relatively well-off families that would gladly pay tuition for their children whether Washington stepped in or not. There is also the threat that colleges will find ways to exploit Congress's generosity and raise tuition by offsetting amounts.
A better way to boost college enrollment would be to direct aid to needy families. Congress already pays for grants and subsidized loans that go primarily to families earning less than $25,000 a year. But a fiscally strapped Congress has let the value of the Pell grants slide by about 15 percent since 1980 while college tuitions were rising by about 50 percent. Sadly, if Congress passes the President's tax-cut plan, let alone the larger tax cut proposed by House Speaker Newt Gingrich, it will almost surely cut back spending on Pell grants and other targeted financial aid.
For all its flaws, Mr. Clinton's plan would still do some good. Prof. Thomas Kane of Harvard estimates that the tax deduction could raise post-secondary enrollment by between 120,000 and 360,000 students. That would not be a huge boost to the 12 million already enrolled, but it would mean that many fewer Americans were facing bleak futures. Studies show that each additional year of post-secondary education adds between 6 and 12 percent to average annual income. But many families cannot afford, nor even borrow, the money needed to pay for higher education or vocational training. The nation faces far larger costs if these individuals fall into lives of poverty or criminality.
The President's plan is not the most effective way to boost enrollment of needy students. Mr. Kane estimates that the money the Treasury would lose from the tax deduction could be used to double the money spent on Pell grants. Such a policy would concentrate Federal aid on families that truly need help.
That is economically sensible, but, alas, politically difficult. The game between the White House and Capitol Hill requires each to wave benefits before the maximum number of voters -- no matter how much the waste, no matter how complete the illusion.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Throw a Bit? Hit a Little? Majors Want You

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
On the one hand, the fellow showed ingenuity; on the other, he showed how desperate major league clubs are to find replacement players for their replacement season.
The fellow was the Philadelphia Phillies' employee that Andy McGaffigan had called to invite to play in his golf tournament in Lakeland, Fla., a tournament that would benefit the baseball team at his alma mater, Florida Southern College. 
 "He said, 'Can you throw?' I said, 'Yeah, I can throw,' " McGaffigan said, recounting the telephone conversation. "I didn't know what he meant at first. He said again, 'Can you throw?' Then I understood. I said, 'Yes, but I'm not going to.' He said, 'We're looking for guys, guys who have had time in the big leagues, guys on the bubble the last few years. We're looking to fill rosters.' "
And did McGaffigan, a former major league pitcher, enroll for the cause?
"I said I just couldn't do it," he related. "I said my coming in as a player would only prolong the process, hurt the Players Association and in the long run hurt my reputation among my peers. Any short-term gain I would receive monetarily, I'd have a tough time looking my teammates and opponents in the eye. I'm just not that kind of guy."
Dan Gladden and Von Hayes told clubs they aren't that kind of guy either. The two outfielders and McGaffigan are typical of the players that clubs are seeking in their determination to show striking players they can play without them and make the strikers nervous enough that they'll be lured back to work, at least when the season starts or shortly thereafter.
Gladden, Hayes and McGaffigan all rejected the propositioning. Others have, too. Some probably have accepted or will accept, but they will most likely remain quiet about their plans. Gladden, Hayes and McGaffigan didn't exactly advertise their experiences, but word spread from people they did tell.
McGaffigan, 38 years old, last pitched in 1991, appearing in four games for the Kansas City Royals. Hayes, 36, last played in 1992, his career effectively ending when the California Angels released him that August. He was in the Milwaukee Brewers' minor league camp last spring but went home voluntarily. Gladden, 37, has not retired. He played in Japan last year after spending two seasons in Detroit.
"Those guys haven't played," Gladden said, speaking of Hayes and McGaffigan but not belittling them, just the clubs' recruitment efforts. "They've been out of the game. At least I played last year. If a guy's not good enough to play in the big leagues but he's going to be playing in the big leagues, that's fraud. You can't pull that on the fans."
With a need for 32 players for each of the 28 clubs, or a total of 896, clubs are scouring the lists of retired and released players and six-year minor league free agents. Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, said the clubs "are committed to playing the 1995 season and will do so with the best players willing to play."
That's not exactly the way George Steinbrenner did it in the 1970's and early 1980's when he put together "the best team money can buy." Instead of having Steinbrenner woo Reggie Jackson with dinner at "21," the owners are sending their general managers after players they think can be bought with a cup of coffee at a diner.
The general managers hate the idea of finding and using replacement players just as they hate the implemented salary cap, but they also hate the strike.
The ones who called Gladden are the ones he contacted upon his return from Japan, seeking a way back to the major leagues. That is, he wanted to return to the majors but not this way.
"I didn't feel I was a replacement-type-caliber player," Gladden said. "I thought I was better than that. I thought I was a major league player. If you're not going to put major league players back on the field, don't call me. I feel I'm good enough to play on your major league team. If you don't think so, don't call me."
Gladden recalled the National Football League's use of replacement players during a players' strike in 1987 and the schism that strategy caused within the union. He related it to the baseball owners' current efforts.
"They think it'll be like the football players: get a couple of big- name guys crossing the line and everybody else will scamper," he said. "If anybody knows about the history of baseball, we're a different athlete. We're more of a tight-knit fraternity than the football players. We're completely different than that."
Hayes said the Royals called him and asked if he wanted to be a replacement player. He reminded them that he had retired because he had tendinitis in his right wrist, but he added that he wouldn't become a strikebreaker even if he had a healthy wrist.
"I was a strong backer of the union when I was playing and I have no intention of going against their cause now that I'm retired," he said. "They said, 'Well, we appreciate your honesty, thank you very much and good luck.' "
But when Hayes was playing in McGaffigan's golf tournament last Friday, he encountered the manager of another club.
"As soon as I saw Jim Fregosi," Hayes related, "he said, 'Here comes my center fielder.' "
Hayes no more will be in center field for the Philadelphia Phillies April 3 than McGaffigan will be on the pitching mound for them.
"It seems like an incredibly bad idea, especially from a former player's standpoint," McGaffigan said of the notion of being a replacement player. "Look at the position he would be in. This strike will be settled. When it is, the chances of that individual who walked across the line sticking with the club will be incredibly small. The ill will that will be developed because of that action for a short-term monetary gain is just not worth it."
Last week, McGaffigan took his story to the players' meeting the union held in Tampa as one of a series of eight regional meetings.
"All the striking players know they're not striking for themselves," he said. "They're striking for everyone who played this game and will play it. I shared exactly that thought at the meeting. I said I have to let you know that if I were to take that $115,000, that would fit real nicely into my budget, but it's not worth it to me. I know what happened in 1976, '72, '81. Guys went to the mat for me so I could earn what I earned. Maybe this is my turn."
The Phillies' employee who extended a replacement invitation when McGaffigan called with a golf invitation did not disagree with his old friend.
"I probably wouldn't do it either," the former pitcher quoted him as saying.
 
 
Orioles May Sit It Out
 In reacting to the executive council's approval of guidelines for the recruitment and use of replacement players, Peter Angelos has adopted a mild stance. "I've just glanced at them," the Baltimore Orioles' owner said yesterday. "I've got a couple guys reviewing it. We're in the process of formulating a position."
But people familiar with Angelos's thinking said he has no intention of changing his stated position against the use of replacement players. In other words, short of a legal move by Major League Baseball to force the faux Orioles onto the field at Camden Yards, there will be no Baltimore team in the standings come April.
Angelos, those people said, believes that use of a replacement team would present Orioles fans with an inferior product, cause long-term damage to their confidence in the team and jeopardize their economic support of the Orioles.
It's not very likely that baseball officials, beginning with Selig, would quietly let Angelos stick to his position. That introduces the possibility of a lawsuit among b owners that would rival the labor, legal and Congressional skirmishes between the owners and the players.
Angelos was one of three owners who voted against implementation at the owners' meeting in Chicago Dec. 15. What hasn't surfaced, though, is his position on a vote to extend for five years the agreement that permits Selig to serve in the role of acting commissioner.
According to a person who attended the meeting, the renewal was the first order of business at the meeting. The renewal was necessary because the agreement was due to expire Jan. 5. The vote figured to be a mere formality, but Angelos tossed a few nails onto the road when he called for a roll call.
Selig, the person said, asked Angelos what he wanted to say. Angelos replied that he didn't want to say anything. "My vote will say it all," he was quoted as saying. The vote was 27-1 for the renewal. Angelos was apparently opposed to it because he believes that Selig's presence in the role creates a conflict of interest. Selig owns a team, the Milwaukee Brewers, and as a result, Angelos thinks that Selig's interests, especially in the labor dispute, are contrary to the interest of the Orioles and other high-revenue clubs.
 
 
New Decade for Minoso?
 The replacement-player idea is perfect for the Chicago White Sox. Under two different commissioners, Fay Vincent and Bud Selig, the White Sox failed to gain permission for Minnie Minoso to play a game in the 1990's so he could extend his streak to having played in the major leagues in six successive decades. He began his career with nine games in 1949, and after he retired in 1964 the White Sox brought him back for three games in 1976 and two in 1980.
Considering some of the other players that clubs have pursued, Selig couldn't very well object to the use of the 72-year-old Minoso.
 
Another Loss for the Owners
 In his newly announced decision on damages for jobs lost as the result of the owners' collusion against free agents in the 1980's, Thomas Roberts, the arbitrator, thought the clubs treated Rod Carew so badly he granted the seven-time American League batting champion even more money than the Players Association recommended.
Roberts awarded Carew $575,000 for 1986 instead of the recommended $525,000. He also gave Carew credit for a year of major league service.
Citing a total disinterest shown in Carew by clubs after the 1985 season, Roberts noted that Carew never played baseball again and wrote, "The Players Association has identified Carew as a target victim of the collusion scheme so enthusiastically embraced by the California Angels. The greater shame attached to that contractually prohibited conduct as it impacted Carew and his career was the denial of an opportunity to properly exit baseball."
 
Some Miscast Votes
 Maybe Mike Krukow, Chris Speier and Jim Sundberg each had a particularly close friend among the baseball writers who vote for the Hall of Fame, but that is no rationale for anyone writing their names on the ballot. Each received one vote in the election that sent Mike Schmidt into the hall.
But if their careers warranted even one vote, the careers of Thurman Munson, Ron Guidry and Graig Nettles, responsible for much of the Yankees' success in the early Steinbrenner years, should have gained greater Hall-of-Fame sanction than 30, 25 and 28 votes, respectively.
In a strict, conscientious vote, Munson and Guidry would be found to have glittered too briefly and Nettles would be guilty of having undermined his 390 home runs and 1,314 runs batted in with a .248 batting average. But they had legitimately outstanding careers worthy of note.
Perhaps the most grievous vote, though, was that given Jim Rice -- 137 out of 460 for a man who never understood what Reggie Jackson tried to teach him about off-the-field courtesy to reporters trying to do their jobs but who was an on-the-field Hall-of-Famer.
